HEADLINE: A. H. Raskin, 82, Times Reporter and Editor, Dies

BYLINE: By RICHARD SEVERO

 BODY:
A. H. Raskin, an authority on labor whose articles and editorials ran in The New York Times for more than four decades, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.
The cause of death was cancer, said his wife, Marge. 
 Mr. Raskin served The Times as a reporter, editorial writer and as assistant editor of the editorial page.
Informative but never strident or accusatory, Mr. Raskin was noted both for the thoroughness of his research and for the clarity with which he presented his findings, even when they concerned complex economic issues that many readers might find arcane. Some said they believed he was especially searching when writing about inflation.
 
A Remembered Lesson
 On one occasion, Mr. Raskin explained why. In 1924, he said, while his family was living in Seattle, his father, Henry Raskin, a fur trader, decided to spend some time in Russia so that he could buy Siberian furs. Thus, the Raskin family temporarily relocated in Berlin to await visas. When they reached that city, an American dollar was worth 1,000 German marks. A few months later, with postwar Germany suffering under runaway inflation and badgered by its World War I enemies to pay reparations, the Raskins found that a dollar could fetch 4.2 trillion marks. The family never forgot it.
"Never in my later career as a labor writer and analyst," he said, "could I accept with equanimity the notion that 'a little inflation can be a good thing.' "
Mr. Raskin covered, among other things, the travails of desperate people who sought work during the Great Depression and, after World War II, the emergence of labor unions and leaders who had the strength and sophistication to make the American labor movement a formidable force.
He also described some of labor's darkest problems. In 1952 his articles about wrongdoers encouraged the American Federation of Labor to set up a special antiracketeering committee. For his work in this period he won the George Polk Memorial Award, a Page One Award from the Newspaper Guild and an award from the Society of Silurians, a group of professional journalists.
 
A Quip From Hoffa
 But not everyone was always pleased by what he wrote. James R. Hoffa, the head of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, told him, "Abe, you're going to scratch yourself on your typewriter one day and die of blood poisoning."
John B. Oakes, editor of The Times's editorial page from 1961 through 1976, recalled that in his editorial writing Mr. Raskin dealt with everything affecting labor in the broadest sense, as well as with a wide range of international and domestic affairs. Mr. Raskin, he said, was the first person he had asked to join his staff as his deputy. He was, Mr. Oakes said yesterday, not only The Times's expert but also a nationally recognized voice in the field of labor and industrial relations.
Mr. Raskin's ability as a reporter to coax stories out of his sources was legend. Stanley Levey, a colleague who also wrote about labor for The Times, called Mr. Raskin "one of the most amazing telephone manipulators since Alexander Graham Bell."
 
Born in Canada
 Abraham Henry Raskin was born on April 26, 1911, in Edmonton, Alberta. After the Berlin adventure, he settled with his family in New York, where he received his secondary-school education at Townsend Harris Hall. In 1927 he entered City College and majored in education and government. He became interested in journalism and edited the student newspaper, yearbook and literary magazine. He was elected president of his senior class and was graduated, Phi Beta Kappa, in the class of 1931.
He remained at City College for a time doing graduate work, mostly because he was unconvinced that any jobs were available, at least jobs that he might want. He furthered his interest in journalism by working as a campus correspondent for The New York Times.
In March of 1934 he joined The Times as a reporter. He was assigned to cover unemployment and the work-relief agencies set up by the Government to see the nation through the Depression. His editors took note of his aggressiveness, and his first byline did not come easily. But almost from the start copy editors noted that Mr. Raskin was usually very accurate, seldom made the same mistake twice and produced copy that required almost no editing. A rarity among reporters of his generation, he even typed well.
In 1940 he filed an exclusive account of David Dubinsky's being assaulted by Joseph S. Fay at a convention of the American Federation of Labor in New Orleans. Mr. Raskin did not see the assault, but his sources within the labor movement were such that he received an accurate account of it. At the time, Mr. Dubinsky was head of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union; Mr. Fay ran the Union of Operating Engineers. Mr. Dubinsky had said some things about labor racketeers that Mr. Fay thought uncharitable. Mr. Raskin's article made page 1 of The Times. In 1977 he wrote with Mr. Dubinsky a memoir called "David Dubinsky: A Life With Labor."
In World War II, Mr. Raskin served as chief of the industrial services division of the Pentagon, a job in which there was one memorable episode.
In April 1944 President Franklin D. Roosevelt was vexed with Sewell Avery, who was president and chairman of Montgomery Ward, the retail merchandising corporation. Mr. Roosevelt wanted Mr. Avery to make peace with a union, as ordered by the War Labor Board.
When Mr. Avery proved intractible, two soldiers under Mr. Raskin's command appeared at his Chicago office and picked him up, still in his chair, and removed him. The Government seized all of Montgomery Ward's offices, held them briefly, then returned them to the company.
In 1946 Mr. Raskin was discharged from the Army with the rank of lieutenant colonel.
After returning to The Times he also acted as a consultant to President Harry S. Truman on universal training, a program the President proposed that would have organized a citizen reserve to reinforce professional armed forces. The plan, which called not for drafting young men but for training them as civilians, was never adopted by Congress. In those same postwar years, Mr. Raskin also helped organize the Defense Department's Division of Industrial Relations.
 
Assessing a Newspaper Strike
 In 1961 he joined the editorial board of The Times and three years later became assistant editor of the editorial page. One of his most notable performances in the 1960's was his lengthy account of the 114-day New York newspaper strike of 1962-63, which appeared in the news pages of The Times in its first issue after the strike ended.
The effort was a journalistic tour de force that provided New Yorkers with a candid appraisal of what the strike had been all about. And although it was critical, in some respects, of some Times executives, it was printed without editorial deletions of sensitive material.
Soon after it was printed, the chief negotiator for The Times resigned. The article was hailed by, among others, James A. Wechsler, who wrote in The New York Post:
"It was a remarkable exercise in many ways -- but perhaps most remarkable because it suggested that not all virtue was on one side in the long struggle and that, in the view of men who had lived through the long days and nights," The Times's management negotiator "had not been a flawless figure."
Mr. Raskin retired from The Times in 1977 but continued to write. For a time, he served as editor of The Journal of International Labor Affairs, published by the Department of Labor. In the autumn of 1990 he had a stroke.
 
A Change in Vocation
 He endured the disabilites that followed with a determination to overcome them, but speech remained difficult if not impossible. In September 1992 the Op-Ed page of The Times carried excerpts from a piece he had written for Martha's Vineyard magazine.
He wrote: "I now realize that my vocation in life has changed. Now I represent the one million Americans who cannot speak for themselves. My plight and theirs are one: to inform the public that those of us who have lost the ability to invent fluent phrases or sentences have not lost the ability to think. We retain the skill to communicate our thoughts and feelings, whether through writing, picture boards, pantomine or facial expression. We can still speak! We hope that you will listen with your ears, with your eyes and always with your heart."
In addition to his wife, Marge, Mr. Raskin is survived by two children from his earlier marriage to Rose Samrock, who died in 1989. They are a son, Donald, and a daughter, Jane Brown. He is also survived by a brother, Bernard Raskin; three stepchildren, Mary Lou Frankel, Jill Isaacs and Geoffrey Campe; three grandchildren, David Raskin, Carolyn Raskin and Sarah Verneuille, and two great-grandchildren.
A service will be held at 11:30 tomorrow morning at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 81st Street and Madison Avenue in Manhattan.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 24, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about A. H. Raskin, an authority on labor whose articles and editorials ran in The New York Times for more than four decades, misstated his source of information about an assault by Joseph S. Fay on the garment union leader David Dubinsky at a 1940 convention in New Orleans. Mr. Raskin was present and witnessed the attack.

HEADLINE: A Mystery on Every Plate

BYLINE: By Betty Fussell; Betty Fussell is author, most recently, of "The Story of Corn."

 BODY:
"If we are what we eat," as some wit has asked, "what the hell are we?" And how do we find out?
How hard both questions are to answer is dramatized by the Government's recent confession that its bible of food composition, the Department of Agriculture's Handbook 8, is "flawed and unreliable." 
 For a century, the department has been in charge of national nutrition, as it was defined by the science of chemistry in the 1890's. To ask why it should head all our food information, education and assistance programs, from school lunches to food stamps, explains why nutrition, in the midst of a national food and health crisis, remains the Government's orphaned child.
The word nutrition comes from the Latin "to suckle," and for centuries the nourishing and nurturing of families in sickness and in health was woman's work. But a century and a half ago, when America industrialized its food chain, it turned farms into factories, food into commodities, nurturers into "domestic scientists" or "home economists" and babies who were suckled into bottle-fed ones.
At the turn of the century, government, science, industry and technology changed not only what we ate but also how we thought about it. Food was reduced to those physical properties that could be analyzed and synthesized chemically. Chemistry turned corn, our national staff of life, into an industrial raw material equivalent to petroleum. It dictated how we grew our crops, what we fed our animals and how we processed, preserved and distributed all our foods.
America led the world in creating a new chain of nutritionally equivalent synthetic foods. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration first met an astronaut's nutritional needs by assembling in a plastic bag the chemical equivalent of an entree, two side dishes, a dessert and a beverage, which the astronaut was to knead for three minutes and squeeze into his mouth.
With a century of continual change at each link in the food chain and with so many vested interests at stake, it's small wonder that nutritive information continues to be assembled by a hodgepodge of conflicting interests, who then dissemble. As bureaucracies have multiplied, accountability has diminished.
The lack of coordination among the department agencies involved in nutrition is ludicrous. More than 60 million lives each year are affected by Government food programs, including 25 million schoolchildren and 27 million people on food stamps. Yet 13 years after the Agriculture Department issued dietary guidelines on fat, sodium and sugar, virtually no schools conform to them and few welfare recipients follow them.
The medical establishment, focusing on pathology and chemical treatment by drugs, has long equated diet with what's put on hospital trays. Even today, when five of America's major health problems -- heart, liver, cancer, diabetes and cerebrovascular diseases -- have been proved to be related to diet, just 23 percent of American medical schools require a course in nutrition, and many offer none.
We need new collaborations like the one devised by Dr. Steven Zeisel at the University of North Carolina, where he has linked the School of Medicine with the School of Public Health to form a shared nutrition department, the country's first, and to develop a pilot program, "Nutrition in Medicine," for medical schools.
Medicine needs to move with speed toward the goal of prevention. In the debate over health reform, watchdog agencies like the Center for Science in the Public Interest point out that surgery is far costlier than proper diet and that Americans spend $17 billion a year on bypass operations alone.
Mike Espy is the first Agriculture Secretary in memory to call for reform and make nutrition "a priority mission." In recruiting Ellen Haas, formerly head of Public Voice for Food and Health Policy, to be Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for Food and Consumer Services, and in proposing to elevate that position to Under Secretary of Food, Nutrition and Consumer Services, he has put his money where his mouth is. As Ms. Haas says, Espy has "a bold new plan to reinvent a bureaucracy which has remained largely unchanged since it was founded by Abraham Lincoln."
The Government should finance long-term nutrition research and education. While the Agriculture Department's budget for analyzing the 5,000 foods in Handbook 8 is $200,000 a year, Kellogg spends $28 million a year to promote a single product, Pop Tarts.
We have to acknowledge that what anyone puts in the ground, on a plant, in an animal or in a processed food -- pesticide, radiation, hormone or excessive additive -- eventually affects communal health.
The food industry must take responsibility for the consequences of the blitz of TV ads it aims at children, recognize that a junk food diet affects health adversely and promote a healthy diet for kids. Health, like the environment, is everybody's business.
In the professional food community, the split between hard-core hedonists and puritanic healthies, which began in the gastronomic revolution of the 1960's, is at last being bridged. Spearheaded by Julia Child, the American Institute of Wine and Food's national program "Taste and Health" is promoting culinary and nutritional education at all levels. The International Association of Cooking Professionals is focusing on ways to enhance nutrition in restaurant food. Most recently, Assistant Secretary Ellen Haas has enlisted celebrity chefs to help teach kids about good food while feeding them good-tasting lunches.
Ironically, national attention is finally being paid to chemical information about food at the very moment biotechnology is rendering much of that information irrelevant by restructuring food at its DNA source. Now more than ever, food safety and wholesomeness is everyone's concern and should not be left simply to the already overburdened and underfunded Food and Drug Administration.
Everyone who wants to know what we are needs hard, clear, objective information about what we put in our mouths.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Deficit Cuts: Success Gets Little Notice

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
There was a time not long ago when the capital was consumed by the budget deficit, by the fear that it would exceed $300 billion and by intense partisan attacks as each party blamed the other and said the other guy's solutions were no better than snake oil.
Honest, there was. But was that the same city where Leon E. Panetta, the budget director, announced this week that the Clinton Administration's first real budget would put the deficit at about $190 billion instead of the $302 billion projected by President George Bush, and hardly anybody noticed? 
 Nobody was issuing press releases of praise, or assailing dubious bookkeeping the way they usually do.
 
A Much-Doubted Promise
 Does that mean that nobody in Washington gets excited, or even interested, except by political bloodshed or impending disaster? President Clinton is hardly the first President to complain that no one here notices success, even something that looks like a big first step toward meeting a much-doubted and now rarely mentioned campaign promise to cut the deficit in half by the end of what he hopes will be called his first term.
By some definitions, of course, Mr. Panetta's pronouncement was not very big news. The steep reduction from the Bush figure came from last summer's tax increases. And this week's $190 billion figure was not much below his last guess of about $200 billion, with the difference coming not from a new degree of sacrifice in spending but from somewhat better economic projections.
At one level, the announcement meant no more than that the Government was keeping its word and abiding by the budget law passed last summer -- though this is no small matter, since the law barred any overall increase in discretionary spending, not even an inflation allowance. As one phlegmatic Republican aide said: "I don't see anything special. They did what they said they would."
Wait a second! Ever since deficits first topped $100 billon in 1982, Congress and Presidents have been enacting laws that they said would cut the deficit. They were wrong. But if Mr. Panetta's projections hold up, the budget deficit will have been reduced for three years in a row. The last time the Government's balance sheet improved for even two consecutive years was 1947 and 1948.
 
Worries for Democrats
 Of course, the budget for the fiscal year beginning next Oct. 1 has not been formally proposed yet, and when it is it will not be easy to pass. But because the White House and Congress are both in Democratic hands, the proposal will be treated more seriously on Capitol Hill than most Reagan and Bush budgets were. Indeed, that is what worries some Democrats, like those who fear cuts in mass transit operating subsidies will have more credibility if they are proposed by a Democrat rather than a Republican.
It was not easy to follow the law and hold the spending level. Mr. Panetta spoke of "very tough decisions." Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, put it less gently, saying, "There was blood all over the floor as they said, 'No, you can't do this; you can't do that.' "
There are lots of reasons this accomplishment caused only faint ripples. Representative David R. Obey, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, said the press was at fault. He said that when he told people last week that the deficit for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30 was $254.9 billion instead of the $327.3 billion projected by Mr. Bush, his constituents flat out did not believe him.
"They haven't seen it in the newspapers, and they haven't seen it on television," he said. "The news media in general have decided that what they will do is peddle information that maintains audience rather than what conveys information." As a result, he says, "the public will believe no good news about government."
 
The 'Sinking In' Factor
 Senator Moynihan offers another explanation, though he does believe the new budget will be evidence that "some progress has been made," both because the budget vote "sent the right signal" and because the Federal Reserve Board has held interest rates down.
But, he said, "It took five years, if not 10 years, for it to sink in that the U.S. Government was running regular, huge and growing deficits. Then it sank in." Now, he said, "If we in fact get ourselves into a reverse mode, it's going to take some time for people to say it's getting better."
Not without reason. When Republicans charged that only the tax increases in Mr. Clinton's bill would be real and that Congress would use them for more spending, it struck a ready chord with the public. In August, a Gallup Poll for the Cable News Network and USA Today showed that only 38 percent of Americans said the bill would cut the deficit. Fifty-five percent said it would not.
Even so, when the Government begins to keep its word on the budget, perhaps it is something to remark on.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Steady Against Yen But Dips in Other Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar steadied against the Japanese yen yesterday and drifted lower against other leading currencies in slow trading. Markets closed early for the Christmas weekend.
Currency markets in the United States and in many other nations will be closed today. 
 A fresh batch of upbeat economic reports did not have much influence on the United States currency yesterday, which stayed within tight ranges relative to its foreign counterparts.
The Commerce Department said new orders for durable goods rose 2 percent in November, a slightly higher rate than expected. It also said that personal income rose six-tenths of a percent in November while spending rose four-tenths of a percent.
Gold prices were mostly lower. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for delivery in February, the most actively traded contract, closed at $387 an ounce, down 20 cents from Wednesday.
Earl Johnson, a vice president of Harris Trust and Savings Bank, said trading was uneventful despite reports confirming that the nation's economic expansion gained momentum as the year drew toward a close.
"There was no incentive to trade in this market," Mr. Johnson said. "I think the sentiment is still bullish for the dollar, but it will be the new year before people start acting on it."
Traders typically hold back from staking out new positions during holiday periods when light trading can skew movements in the markets.
Dollar trading was also abbreviated yesterday because markets were closed in Japan for the Emperor's birthday, a national holiday.
The dollar was quoted at 110.60 yen in London and moved to 110.68 yen in New York, up from 110.40 yen late Wednesday. It appeared to be steadying after a wild week in which it was buffeted by speculation about whether the United States would support the yen with purchases of it.
The British pound rose to $1.5034 late in London from $1.4946 Wednesday. A pound traded at $1.5015 late in New York, compared with $1.4968 a day earlier.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's quotes, included: 1.6960 German marks, down from 1.7025; 1.4360 Swiss francs, down from 1.4380; 5.7760 French francs, down from 5.8005, and 1,659.00 Italian lire, down from 1,662.00.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Fresh evidence of an improving economy was reported by the Government. New orders for durable goods surged 2 percent in November, marking the longest streak of gains since 1987. The Commerce Department also reported that personal incomes rose 0.6 percent and personal spending grew 0.4 percent. [Page D1.]
Sales of domestically built vehicles rose 31 percent in mid-December. Nearly every company that builds vehicles in North America sold more of them. [D1.] 
 The I.R.S. proposed unusually simple regulations to begin taxing lobbying expenses. But it postponed until next year the matter of defining what lobbying is. [D1.]
Back-seat ambulance drivers can use SimHealth, a $29.95 computer game, to design a health care system from scratch and to observe the consequences. [A16.]
 Hardly anyone noticed when the Administration said its first budget would put the deficit at $190 billion, instead of the $302 billion projected by President Bush. Washington Talk. [A1.]
 
Companies
Stephen M. Wolf's reserve may work against him if shareholders and members of the machinists' and pilots' unions approve an employee buyout of United Airlines, of which he is chairman. [D1.] Details of the union proposal emerged, but analysts say they will have to wait weeks before they have enough data to evaluate it. [D2.]
Monsanto seems destined to lead the battle to convince consumers that the benefits of products produced with biotechnology outweigh their risks. [D1.]
Shares of Broderbund Software plunged $6 each after the company offered a cautious view of its growth prospects. Broderbund's earnings met or exceeded analysts' estimates. [D3.]
 Baxter International's onetime heir apparent is leaving. James R. Tobin had won praise on Wall Street for overseeing a two-year program to cut costs. [D3.]
The Fed allowed First Union to give discounts on stock brokerage commissions to certain bank customers. [D3.]
Chiron hired a Du Pont Merck Pharmaceutical executive to head its global therapeutics business. [D3.]
Metallgesellschaft's new management carried on talks with its two main German banks on how to cover oil futures losses. [D4.]
The F.A.A. ordered air-traffic controllers to warn aircraft flying behind Boeing 757's of the potential for turbulence. [A14.]
An outpouring of friend of the court briefs followed the Supreme Court's decision to review Turner Broadcasting's challenge of the 1992 cable law. [A22.]
 
International
There is no consensus on the best method for privatization in Eastern Europe, but economists estimate that 60 percent of the Czech Republic's large companies are now in private hands. [A8.]
 Six of 11 workers who said they were dismissed by G.E. in Mexico for union organizing will be rehired, union leaders say. [A8.]
 
Markets
Most stock market averages rose slightly in a quiet session, with only the Dow industrials edging lower, by 4.47 points. Key indexes in London, Paris, Frankfurt and Mexico City all set closing highs. Most of the world's markets will be closed today. [D4.]
Prices of Treasury bonds ended mostly higher. [D12.]
Cocoa futures prices rebounded strongly from steep losses early in the week. [D11.] The dollar steadied against the yen and drifted lower against other leading currencies. [D11.]
 
Today's Column
 It may sound like a skit from a Madison Avenue satire, but a commercial featuring homeless people singing "New York, New York" has become a remarkable example of public service advertising. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D14.]

HEADLINE: Castro's Daughter Pleads for Her Own

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ga., Dec. 23

 BODY:
Fidel Castro's estranged daughter, who defected to the United States on Tuesday after what she described as a cloak-and-dagger escape from Cuba, surfaced here today to tweak her father for his misrule and to plead with him to let his granddaughter join her in freedom.
Appearing haggard and tense at a news conference, Alina Fernandez Revuelta told how she had secretly obtained a Spanish passport, gained weight, donned a wig and applied layers of makeup so that her appearance would match that of the woman whose identity she had assumed. On Sunday, she said, her chance came and she seized it, boarding a flight to Madrid and then heading to the United States after her request for political asylum was quickly granted. 
 "You have to realize the desperation it takes to turn a person's core to iron to withstand the hardship of escape and the possibility you may have no hope of ever seeing your child again," she said, referring to the 16-year-old daughter she left behind. She urged her fellow Cubans to "have faith in God" and said she would do "everything possible to be deserving" of the refuge granted her by the United States.
 
Strained Relations
 Ms. Fernandez Revuelta's relations with her father have been strained for at least a decade. Mr. Castro has never publicly acknowledged that she is his daughter, though their relationship is widely known to the Havana elite. She made clear the extent of their estrangement when asked if she wished to send a message to her father, who next week will celebrate the 35th anniversary of his seizure of power.
"I've never spoken of Mr. Castro as my father," she responded, her tone a mix of irony and asperity. "Please."
Ms. Fernandez Revuelta, 37, was born out of wedlock to Natalia (Nati) Revuelta, a wealthy Havana socialite and early revolutionary sympathizer and protector of Mr. Castro. Ms. Revuelta was married to a prominent cardiologist, Orlando Fernandez, when the child was born. Ms. Fernandez Revuelta's mother continues to live in Havana, but Dr. Fernandez and other members of the family eventually left for the United States.
 
Repeated Efforts to Leave
 Since the mid-1980's, Ms. Fernandez Revuelta, a former model, repeatedly sought permission to leave Cuba to join her husband, a Mexican. But her requests for an exit visa were repeatedly turned down by Government officials aware of her identity and fearful of the diplomatic embarrassment that her departure and criticisms abroad of her father's rule might cause.
Earlier today, Ms. Fernandez Revuelta said, she spoke by telephone with her mother, grandmother and daughter and was told that no reprisals had yet been taken. "I'm worried about these three people, but nobody has come to the house" from state security, she said.
Ms. Fernandez Revuelta urged Mr. Castro to allow her only child, who is also named Alina, to leave Cuba. But she acknowledged that the Cuban government might be smarting from her defection and she said her daughter might have to be smuggled out. "I want the Cuban Government to respect the right of mother and daughter to live and grow together," she said. "This is an obvious case of human rights."
 
Hope for a Foundation
 Ms. Fernandez Revuelta would not say where she plans to live, but said she hoped to establish a foundation to deal with health issues relating to refugees and Cuba after Communism falls.
Ms. Fernandez Revuelta spoke to reporters in the penthouse quarters of Elena Amos, a Cuban-American whom Ms. Fernandez Revuelta described as "the soul" of the operation to spirit her from Cuba. Mrs. Amos, the widow of an insurance magnate whose company has its headquarters here, has helped other defectors and their relatives leave Cuba, most notably a former Cuban Air Force pilot, Orestes Lorenzo.
One year ago this week, Mr. Lorenzo, who had flown to the United States in a MIG jet fighter, returned to Cuba clandestinely in a small plane for his wife and children, who were waiting on a remote stretch of highway east of Havana. Mrs. Amos financed that daring rescue, which made her and Mr. Lorenzo heroes to Cuban exiles.
 
No Discussion of Accomplices
 Ms. Fernandez Revuelta declined to talk in any detail about who else had helped her leave Havana, saying their lives could be endangered. But she said it had been relatively easy to get past security and immigration officials at Havana's airport, describing how she had packed a suitcase as a tourist might and tried to act casually. There is "a lot of Spanish tourism" in Cuba, these days, she said, so it was easy to pass herself off as a visitor.
For the most part, Ms. Fernandez was reluctant to be drawn into discussing Cuban politics. When asked about the political and economic situation on the island and how it had influenced her decision to leave, she replied, "Draw your own conclusions."
In recent years, Ms. Fernandez Revuelta has given interviews in Havana to Spanish and American journalists in which she described Mr. Castro as "a tyrant" and the Communist regime he installed as "a dead-end street." In his book "Castro's Final Hour," Andres Oppenheimer quoted Ms. Fernandez Revuelta as saying she associated Mr. Castro's rule primarily "with economic collapse, with food shortages" and political and cultural repression.
"I don't have the slightest idea whether his days are numbered or not, because his days don't matter to me," she said today when asked if her father's dictatorship seemed to be nearing its end. "What is important to me are the days remaining until I can see my daughter."
 
A 10-Mile Bike Ride to School
 But Ms. Fernandez Revuelta later indicated that conditions in Cuba are so bad that even the governing elite is suffering privations. She said her daughter attended the National School of the Arts, considered the best in Cuba, but that the institution had not functioned normally for at least two years.
"The situation has degraded," she said. "She has to ride her bicycle 10 miles to school, through a dangerous route" because the bus system no longer works and fuel for private and state vehicles is scarce. And when the girl gets to school, "the teachers are absent because they have the same transport problems," she said.
Ms. Fernandez Revuelta mocked news reports in which Cuban Foreign Minister Roberto Robaina was quoted as saying that she, like all other Cubans, had the right to leave the country. "If I could leave like any ordinary Cuban, I would have left before at various junctures," she scoffed. "If I could leave like any ordinary Cuban, I would not be standing here today."

HEADLINE: In Big Cases, Lots of Briefs And 'Friends'

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Hard cases may or may not make bad law, but for the select circle of lawyers who practice regularly before the United States Supreme Court, big cases certainly make work.
A grant of review by the Court in a case with important economic or social implications typically sets off a frenzy of brief-writing, not only by the parties but also by many organizations seeking to appear as "friends of the Court." The opportunity to speak to the Justices on an issue that matters is one that few with a stake in the outcome care to pass up, particularly when the actual parties cannot be expected to address the distinct concerns of all who might be affected. 
 One big case in the current Supreme Court term is Turner Broadcasting v. Federal Communications Commission, which is scheduled for argument on Jan. 12. At stake is the constitutional future of cable television -- or, if some of the more vigorously written briefs are to be believed, the future of all telecommunications. The case is a First Amendment challenge by the cable industry to the provisions of a 1992 law requiring cable systems to carry the signals of local broadcast stations.
 
126 Lawyers' Signatures
 If the Justices had any doubt that the stakes were high, they have only to glance through the 22 briefs that have been filed since the Court accepted the case on Sept. 28.
Actually, they have only to scan the covers of the briefs to see a virtual Who's Who of the Supreme Court bar. No less than 126 lawyers, representing 49 companies, organizations and governmental bodies, have signed the briefs that constitute the six-inch stack.
Thirteen lawyers signed a brief for Turner Broadcasting and nine other cable programmers. It was one of five main briefs filed by the cable industry in its challenge to the law. On the other side, five main briefs were filed by the Federal Government, the broadcast industry and others defending the law, which was upheld by a lower Federal court.
The total filings in this case come nowhere near the 78 "friend of the Court" briefs the Court received in a 1989 abortion case, Webster v. Reproductive Health Services. And neither is Turner Broadcasting anywhere near unique among the many Supreme Court cases that put an important issue in play and prompt the great American legal machine to respond.


GRAPHIC: Here are the briefs filed with the Supreme Court in Turner Broadcasting System v. Federal Communications Commission. An asterisk identifies each brief's counsel of record, the lead lawyer in the group. The appellants -- essentially, the cable industry -- are asking the Court to declare unconstitutional the 1992 law that requires cable systems to carry the signals of local broadcast stations. The appellees -- the Federal Government and the broadcasters -- are asking the Justices to affirm a lower court opinion that found the law constitutional.

HEADLINE: Pac-Man It's Not. The Future of a Presidency and U.S. Health Care, Maybe.

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
November 1995. National health care has been law for a year, and universal coverage is almost a fact. But costs are already running above projections, and Bob Dole is making wisecracks about voodoo Democrat economics. A value-added tax or Oregon-style rationing would solve the budget problem, but would be suicide to introduce before the elections . . .
A page from Hillary Rodham Clinton's future? Perhaps. But with a little help from Silicon Valley, the future is now, and open to anyone with access to a zippy I.B.M.-compatible personal computer. SimHealth, a $29.95 computer game produced by Maxis Business Simulations with a grant from the Markle Foundation, gives back-seat ambulance drivers the chance to design their own health care system from scratch and to observe the consequences, including the possibility of being voted out of office. 
 With its slick graphics and randomly introduced news bulletins, the game may prove as entertaining as Maxis's popular simulations of genetic mutation (SimLife), urban planning (SimCity) and insect colonies (SimAnt).
 
Budget Policy May Follow
 But this time, the idea is to sugarcoat a maximum-strength civics lesson. Lloyd Morrisett, the president of the Markle Foundation, hopes SimHealth will be the model for making complex public policy understandable to a generation that is used to absorbing the news in video bites. "If people think the game is fun and interesting, we will try it elsewhere," he said, "perhaps with budget policy, welfare reform or the environment."
The White House has already installed a preview version of SimHealth in a dozen of its computers. And Jeff Eller, a spokesman for the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform, thinks simulation games could serve policy professionals as well as amateurs by forcing those with different views to examine their assumptions. "You can't dismiss this as another Pac-Man or Tetris," he allows.
Computer simulation has been a standard industrial design technique for two decades, allowing engineers to test the stability of a new aircraft wing or the adequacy of a factory's quality-control system without investing a penny in the real thing. By the same token, scientists have used simulations to solve problems that resist straightforward mathematical solutions. Forecasts of global warming, for example, depend heavily on the technique.
Simulations that are both timely and worth the effort have generally had the drawback of requiring immense number-crunching power: Multimillion-dollar supercomputers are still the tools of choice for simulating the explosion of nuclear weapons and tracks of hurricanes.
 
Faster Personal Computers
 Indeed, John Hiles, the general manager of Maxis Business Simulations, notes that only in the last few years have personal computers become fast enough and cheap enough to serve as vehicles for mass-market simulation games.
But even the most realistic simulations of jet-fighter duels and sports leagues have obvious limitations, being no better than the fixed assumptions that drive them. In SimCity, Maxis's urban planning game, Mr. Hiles points out that the "the nuclear power plant always melts down."
The Markle Foundation, which is always hunting for ways to bridge the communications gap between complicated issues and a public that has neither the time nor the inclination to spend hours absorbing the often-dreary stuff of policy, had something very different in mind.
Since the whole point of SimHealth is to create a relatively painless way of exploring the practical problems of providing health care, players are always free to alter either the priorities of the plan or the assumptions about how the moving parts interact.
"I think SimHealth is an intriguing alternative," Mr. Eller, the Presidential panel's spokesman, said.
 
Playing the Game
 To start the game, a player must make explicit what he or she values most about health care reform. The two broad dimensions of choice, what SimHealth labels "liberty versus equality" and "community versus efficiency," are applied to a variety of core issues.
On cost control, for example, the player is asked whether competition should take precedence over regulation, whether individuals should take primary responsibility for preventive care and whether standardization of treatment protocols is an acceptable interference in the doctor-patient relationship.
From then on, the player is free to mix and match policies on the understanding that failure to sustain consistent priorities will cost political support and perhaps end the game with an election.
One might, for example, choose a Canadian-style single payer system with rationing of individual procedures, paying for it with an income tax and a 10 percent patient co-payment. Or one might opt for managed competition, underwritten by employer-paid insurance and buttressed by caps on the growth of hospital outlays.
Every policy sets off a stream of consequences for businesses, individuals, hospitals, doctors and government budgets. And a player can always monitor the effects; for example, asking what percentage of household income is going to health care, or how large the budget deficit is. Policy changes require the expenditure of "political chips" that translate into lost votes at election time.
Most ingenious, perhaps, every policy is linked to a set of relatively optimistic "default" assumptions and a "counter" set of pessimistic assumptions, designed with the help of a panel of health care experts assembled by the Markle Foundation. The game even permits players to custom-design the working parts.
 
A 'Neutral' Forum
 For example, the decision to increase by 10 percent the number of acute care procedures covered by insurance would ordinarily increase the demand for hospital beds by 2 percent. But under the pessimistic counter-assumptions, a 10 percent increase in coverage generates a 5 percent increase in hospital care demand. "It's about as neutral a forum as you can get," Mr. Eller said.
Alternatively, a player might experiment with a half-dozen different numbers to see how they would affect hospital crowding or Federal deficits -- or even the profitability of businesses in paying insurance premiums over a period of months or years.
That flexibility excites Dan Beauchamp, a former Deputy Commissioner of Health in New York State who now teaches public policy at the State University in Albany. "Even very smart policy makers have trouble thinking about several variables rocketing around at once," Mr. Beauchamp said.
Whether or how SimHealth will influence the national health debate is unclear. The Markle Foundation has distributed a preview version of the game to Congressional staff members and senior Administration officials. But the foundation's major concern at the moment is getting it into the hands of a wider range of opinion leaders, everyone from business executives to doctors to economics professors.
While he at first considered giving away the game, Mr. Morrisett decided that doing so would make it impossible to distribute it through commercial channels like software vendors, mail-order houses and college bookstores. Instead, the foundation will subsidize promotion and hold the retail price below $40. "No one is going to make money on SimHealth," Mr. Hiles predicted.
That, of course, is not the primary goal.

HEADLINE: A 1-in-55-Million Chance Brings an Early Christmas

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Percy Ray Pridgen, a retired bricklayer with 17 children and 29 grandchildren, trembled and burst into tears today when he was asked how he would spend $45 million he won in a lottery jackpot.
Mr. Pridgen, 69, will split a $90 million payoff from the Powerball lottery with Chuck Gill of Richmond, a 35-year-old former barber and government worker who is now unemployed. 
 Both men, who had the only winning tickets, will receive payments amounting to $6,000 a day for the next 20 years.
Mr. Pridgen said he planned to buy a country home for his wife. But beyond that, he said, "Somebody's going to have to tell me" how to spend the rest. He then buried his head in his hands and wept.
Mr. Gill, said he wanted to move to a place "with a lot of palm trees and a lot of umbrellas." But first, he said, he, his wife and their 4-year-old daughter, Tiana, would travel immediately to Paris.
"It's going to be an early Christmas," he said. "I'm going to try to give something back to my neighborhood, because my brothers out there."
Mr. Pridgen and Mr. Gill will receive their first checks in about 10 or 15 days, said Beverly Hunt, a spokeswoman for the D.C. Lottery. The owners of the Washington liquor stores that sold the grand prize tickets will each receive $25,000.
The Powerball game, played in 14 states and the District of Columbia, had not yielded a winning ticket in 16 previous drawings over the last eight weeks.
The winning numbers drawn on Wednesday were: 1, 3, 13, 15 and 29. The powerball was 12.
The odds of a ticket being the big winner were 1 in 55 million. Fifty-four ticket holders matched every number but the powerball and won $100,000 each,

HEADLINE: Stocks Close Mixed in Quiet Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Most stock market averages rose slightly yesterday in a quiet session ahead of the Christmas holiday. Only the Dow Jones industrial average edged lower, falling near the close after trading higher most of the day.
The market will be closed today. Analysts said the Dow's strong performance in early trading yesterday prompted selling in anticipation of the three-day break. 
 Prices were supported by continued low interest rates and solid gains earlier in overseas markets. Major stock indexes on the London, Paris and Frankfurt exchanges set new closing highs. And the Mexican Bolsa, lifted by continuing demand for Telefonos de Mexico stock, soared to its second consecutive record high.
The Dow industrials, however, lost 4.47 points, closing at 3,757.72. For the week, the Dow gained 6.15 points.
 
 
Intraday High for Dow
 At one point, the Dow surged through its Dec. 13 closing high of 3,764.43, posting an intraday high of 3,774.21.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange fell to 227.2 million shares, from 272.4 million on Wednesday. But gainers outnumbered losers, 1,257 to 835.
Eugene E. Peroni Jr., director of technical research for Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia, said that while no trends were apparent in the trading, he saw some strengths in the underlying market.
"We saw some pretty good positioning by investors as they set up for a year-end rally," he said.
"The market's behavior in the last few weeks has been toward building a base, or platform, that will carry it into February 1994."
Some analysts said support for stock prices was coming from the continued release of positive economic data and the absence of significant inflation. With more such reports issued by the Government yesterday, Treasury bond prices ended mostly higher and interest rates held steady.
 
 
Gains in Computers and Drugs
 Traders said renewed strength in computer and medical stocks helped pull the Nasdaq composite index higher to 758.70, up 2.63 points.
The Standard & Poor's composite rose 0.06 point, to 467.38, and the Big Board composite index rose 0.34 point, to 258.49.
The stock of Broderbund Software tumbled 6, to 34 1/2, losing 14.8 percent of its value, after reporting first-quarter earnings that were below analysts' estimates. While Broderbund's earnings rose 28 percent, the company's revenues were only marginally higher. In response, analysts did what they usually do when earnings disappoint them: they lowered their ratings on the company's stock.
Another software stock, Cisco Systems, rose 1 3/8, to 62 1/8, on the news that it would be added to the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks on Thursday, replacing Travelers, which plans to merge with Primerica. Shares of Travelers rose 1/4, to 31 7/8.
Shares of UAL, the parent of United Airlines, which rallied on Wednesday in anticipation of the board's approval of a union-led buyout, gave back some gains. The stock fell 1 7/8, to 146 5/8.
High-technology stocks rose, led by Intel, up 3/8, to 62 1/8; General Electric, up 3/4, to 106 1/8, and Motorola up 1 1/4, to 90 1/4.
Drug stocks gained. Johnson & Johnson rose 5/8, to 43 1/2, and Pfizer advanced 1/2, to 67 1/8. Pfizer said it had filed for Food and Drug Administration approval to market Tenidap for the treatment of arthritis.
Amdahl fell 5/8, to 6 1/8. The company said it expected a loss of more than 35 cents share for the third quarter. The company said that pricing pressures had hurt profits.
Georgia-Pacific dropped 1, to 68. The shares were down as much as 2 3/4 before Smith Barney Shearson raised its rating on the stock, saying that the weakness in price was a buying opportunity. The paper company said it expected a loss of between $30 million and $50 million for the fourth quarter because of weak pulp and paper prices and a $21 million charge for compensation programs.

HEADLINE: Lewis R. Koller, 98; Was Physicist for G.E.

 BODY:
Dr. Lewis R. Koller, a retired physicist who developed supersensitive photoelectric devices and equipment for the General Electric Company, died yesterday at the Josephine M. Lilly Care Center in Falmouth, Mass. He was 98 and lived in Falmouth and Cambridge, Mass.
Dr. Koller was a native of New York City. He graduated from Cornell University in 1917 and then earned a Ph.D. in physics there in 1921. After postgraduate studies in Cambridge, England, he joined General Electric's Edison Lamp Works in Harrison, N.J. 
 In 1925 he transferred to the General Electric Research Laboratory in Schenectady, N.Y., where he held the title of research associate until his retirement in 1960.
Among his early inventions were a giant, highly sensitive photoelectric cell that recorded the amount of daylight over any desired period; a photoelectric cell that acted as a traffic checker, registering passing automobiles for traffic planners 24 hours a day, and a germ-killing lamp.
After his retirement, he moved to Cambridge and worked as a research associate at the National Research Corporation.
Dr. Koller's wife of 59 years, Noreen Mathews Koller, died in 1985. He is survived by three daughters, Felicity K. Putnam of Falmouth, A. Noreen Koller of Cambridge and Sylvia K. Gerhard of Canton, Mass.; a sister, Hortense K. Becker of Highland Park, Ill.; three grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Some Details Emerge on United Deal

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Details emerged yesterday about the proposal by unions at United Airlines to gain control of the carrier, but industry analysts said they would have to wait several weeks before they had enough data to evaluate the offer.
For example, according to information provided by the company and the unions, the employee stock ownership plan that will hold 53 percent of the stock of United's parent, the UAL Corporation, if the deal is consummated, will result in new accounting methods for UAL. That change makes estimating future earnings difficult. 
 "It is such a complex transaction," said Tom Longman, an airline analyst at Bear, Stearns. "We're sitting here with nothing other than newspaper articles to guide us."
Other details that will likely sway investors' decisions include who will manage United along with Gerald Greenwald, a former vice chairman of Chrysler, who has been chosen by the unions to replace Stephen M. Wolf as chairman of United. Union leaders have not said how many current top managers they intend to replace.
Some of the uncertainty may have been reflected in investors' actions yesterday. UAL's stock lost $1.875 to close at $146.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Profitability Is Seen
 Still, the stock has gained back a few dollars since the highlights of the buyout proposal were first publicized in mid-December. Many industry analysts and institutional shareholders have criticized the deal as too low, and some have predicted that UAL's stock will trade around $200 a year from now.
Proponents of the offer say that union concessions will help make UAL more profitable in the long run. Those concessions include work rule changes that will enable United to create a separate lower-cost division to take over flights of less than 750 miles. The unions have committed to operate that division, with lower costs from decreased wages and increased productivity, for 12 years.
The agreement includes a no-strike clause as well as job protection provisions for a period of slightly less than six years, during which the unions will provide wage and work-rule concessions.
United's unions have said their members will vote on the transaction no later than Jan. 31. All the details of the offer will then be available to shareholders and their advisers by March 15.
The broad terms of the offer call for the unions to exchange roughly $5 billion in wage and work-rule concessions for 53 percent of the company. Current shareholders will receive $88 a share in cash, preferred stock and notes. The dividend on the preferred stock and the interest rate on the notes will be set several months from now.
Because of the varying size of their wage concessions, employees of each labor group will receive a different share of the 53 percent of the company represented in the employee stock ownership plan, or ESOP. The pilots' union will have 46 percent, machinists will own 37 percent and nonunion employees will own 17 percent.
The flight attendants' union left the buyout effort this fall after a dispute with United executives, but they have been invited by the other unions to rejoin the effort. They are expected to make that decision next month.

HEADLINE: Durables Orders Post Sharp Gain

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Fresh evidence of a rejuvenated economy appeared today, with factories posting the longest streak of gains in big-ticket orders since 1987 and consumers enhancing their ability to keep on spending.
New orders for durable goods, items ranging from radios to steamrollers that are expected to last three years or more, surged 2 percent in November, the Commerce Department reported. The advance, the fourth consecutive, showed that factories were clearly participating in the economy's pickup this fall. 
 The department also reported today that both personal incomes and personal spending grew at healthy rates in November and that incomes were a bit higher than previously thought for each of the preceding three months.
 
 
'A Reasonably Robust Pace'
 "The numbers we've seen today suggest the economy has the wherewithal to grow at a reasonably robust pace" into the new year, Daniel Laufenberg, economist at IDS Financial Services in Minneapolis, said. The savings rate, he added, has climbed back, somewhat surprisingly, to 4 percent.
In another report, the Labor Department found today that first-time claims for unemployment benefits edged up 4,000 last week, to 332,000, a negligible change. On a four-week average, claims continued to improve, to 332,750.
Mainly because of the rise in orders for durable goods, several analysts raised their sights for the economy's performance early next year. Growth, as measured by the gross domestic product, has been expected to slow sharply from a rate of 4 percent or more in the final quarter of this year.
One was Ben K. Han, the economist for the Corestates Financial Corporation in Philadelphia. Today's results "tend to support the thesis that the first quarter next year will be quite a bit stronger than some people expected," he said, raising his own January-March forecast to a 3 percent pace. He now expects that noticeable slowing will not occur until the second quarter, when he sees national output slipping to 2 percent as consumer spending tapers off and taxes rise.
Although about two-thirds of the rise in durable goods orders was accounted for by the volatile aircraft and motor vehicle industries, the gain was nonetheless widespread. Over all, there were jumps of 5.7 percent for transportation equipment, 4.5 percent for industrial machinery and equipment and 2.1 percent for primary metals, all exceeding or matching October's gains.
 
 
Decline in Electronics
 The only major sector to decline was electronic and other electrical equipment, down 7.6 percent, which roughly wiped out gains in September and October.
The gain in orders for durable goods would have been even higher, 2.2 percent, had it not been for the continuing erosion of military business. November's 1.7 percent decline, however, was far less than the 17.3 percent dive in October.
The last time there were as many as four consecutive monthly gains in durable orders was from February through July 1987.
One of the most widely followed subcategories, orders for capital goods other than aircraft and military equipment, posted another solid gain of 2.6 percent, up 24.9 percent from a year earlier. In comparison, durable goods orders as a whole rose 8.8 percent in the last 12 months.
 
 
Investing in Machinery
 Capital spending, running last month at a $139.4 billion annual rate, was a main factor in the economy's growth this year as cost-conscious manufacturers sought to substitute computers and other machinery for workers.
Shipments of durable goods also posted their fourth consecutive monthly gain, rising an impressive 2.7 percent. But unfilled orders slipped six-tenths of a percent, continuing a decline that has persisted for 28 of the last 33 months.
Although shrinking backlogs have traditionally been a caution signal for the economy, analysts now regard this trend mainly as evidence of the adoption of increasingly sophisticated techniques for managing inventories.
The Commere Department's other report released today found that personal incomes rose six-tenths of a percent last month, a fourth consecutive advance. The gain for October has now been put at seven-tenths of a percent.
Spending rose four-tenths of a percent in November, the eighth consecutive increase, as holiday shopping got under way.
 
 
Incomes Outpace Spending
 Incomes grew faster than spending in November, allowing consumers to rebuild savings at a time when installment debt and other figures suggested that they were spending beyond their means.
Savings rose to an annual rate of $200.4 billion in November after being basically unchanged in October and falling $8.4 billion, to $189.3 billion, in September.
Wages and salaries rose at a rate of $11.7 billion last month, the report showed, a gain about two-thirds as great as in October. Personal interest income continued to forge ahead, rising $2.5 billion, to $702.8 billion on an annualized basis.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Wilkens Tackles Wilkins

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON

 BODY:
DOMINIQUE WILKINS was annoyed. That was obvious to Lenny Wilkens, and everyone else in Boston Garden, from the start.
He had been in a bad shooting slump. He had a sore ankle and began a game against the Celtics Wednesday night bothered by the flu and the fact that on Atlanta's opening possessions, he couldn't get his itchy fingers on the ball. 
 Mookie Blaylock was dribbling out near the key. Wilkins ran toward him with his hands out. Blaylock dribbled the other way and hoisted a jumper that missed. Wilkins turned, facing the Hawks' bench, and cursed. He didn't exactly sprint back on defense. Soon, without fuming or fuss, Lenny Wilkens called him to the bench.
The tranquil-looking coach knew it was going to be a stomach-churning night with the 33-year-old no-conscience scorer. Wilkins is in the last year of his $3.5 million contract. That will exacerbate any game-night situation when Wilkins isn't in the flow.
When Wilkins isn't in the game, the Hawks' ball movement is noticeably improved. But he is still their marquee player. Their chance to challenge in the East is linked to him. Thus the coach's dilemma in Boston was to figure out how to get Wilkins through the night, extract something positive from his game, without letting him drag the Hawks down.
For years, the Hawks have been Dominique's team. Their recent reputation has been a reflection of Dominique's, an exciting highlight film with no defensive core. When Wilkens's career alarm started ringing last spring in Cleveland, where he helped make a contender out of what was a horrendous team, people wondered why this scholarly basketball teacher would choose Atlanta and this seemingly incorrigible class.
The season began. The Hawks were suddenly playing defense, trapping, hustling, as they hadn't since Mike Fratello and a young Doc Rivers were on their side. Their ball-hawking guards, Blaylock and Stacey Augmon, were reminiscent of Dennis Johnson and Gus Williams from Wilkens's Seattle championship coaching days. The Hawks won a team-record 14 straight, 17 of 18. Before they left Boston, before they ran out of steam in the fourth quarter and lost to the Knicks, 84-75, last night at Madison Square Garden, the Celtics honcho Dave Gavitt bumped into Wilkens in the hall.
Gavitt told him, "Thirty-three years I've known you and it took me until this year to realize you're a genius."
Who would've told him? Who would've blown Wilkens's horn, or smoke? Sometime next year, this scholarly 56-year-old native of Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant will pass Red Auerbach's 938 career victories and become pro basketball's top-winning coach. He covets that record. His name in the book would be all the recognition he would need.
Had the Hawks landed their first choice, Rick Pitino, there would have been much glorious hype about Pitino's system, how his mere presence, like Pat Riley's in New York, would surely tame the Hawks. In London, after the Hawks put on an embarrassing exhibition display in October, Wilkens knew what everyone was saying about him. "Poor Lenny," he said.
His entire career, as coach and Hall of Fame player, has been spent in low-octane haunts like St. Louis, Portland, Seattle and Cleveland. He never sought attention. He demanded time for family, for reading, for mountain hikes. He didn't care to lecture the corporate lunch crowd. He was an economics major at Providence who originally hoped to teach. Basketball was never his whole life.
Americans prefer obsessive workers in sports. Coaches who watch film all night are somehow better. When Wilkens was the point guard for Bill Fitch, Captain Video, he was asked to sit through thousands of pick-and-roll screenings. "I'd fall asleep," he said.
When Wilkens became a player-coach 22 years ago in Portland, he said he actually screamed his head off. "No one heard me," he said.
Not much was getting through to Dominique in Boston the other night either. He shot 6 for 21. He briefly cost the Hawks a fourth-quarter lead with a handful of terrible shots. At that point, Wilkens called time. His voice about as loud as it gets, he said: "We take control of this game right here!" With total command of his huddle, he diagrammed a play for Kevin Willis on the low post. Willis hit a jump hook. The Hawks kept going back to Willis, again and again. He scored 32 points. The night was won.
Never the model of consistency, Willis shot 4 for 19 last night against the Knicks. Dominique's woeful shooting continued. The Hawks still played tough defense. They rallied from 15 points behind. Dominique may still have the ball, but this is no longer his team.

HEADLINE: A Rush to Judgment on City Taxes

 BODY:
With reckless disregard for the public, and with very little discussion, the New York City Council this week rammed through a tax abatement bill that may be good for developers but could well be bad for the city. Though the bill was introduced at Mayor David Dinkins's initiative, he should veto it, forcing the Council to give the measure the careful deliberation it requires.
The bill in question would broaden an existing real estate tax abatement program to cover a swath of midtown and lower Manhattan; the program now covers the rest of Manhattan and other parts of the city. It would freeze real estate taxes on residential buildings for 10 years at rates set before the building was constructed. The rates would rise gradually for another 10 years until they reach their normal level. 
 The property would have to be vacant or "underused" -- a small building, for instance -- and developers would have to reserve one in five apartments in the new structure for low-income families for the life of the abatement.
The idea is to encourage development, boost the city economy and build some low-income housing. Without a tax break, proponents say, developers in this economy will not build.
There are sites, even in midtown Manhattan, where incentives might make sense. But that argues for a carefully drafted bill with limited application, instead of a piece of global legislation that could have unintended, and detrimental, consequences. For example, the bill might give unnecessary breaks to developers who would have built anyway; it could also temporarily cost the city tax revenues as it confronts another huge budget gap.
The Council gave little thought to these and other possible consequences as it raced through its final, agenda-packed meeting of the year. Council members and the public had hardly any notice that the legislation was even coming. There was no environmental or economic analysis. The bill is so ambiguously written that Manhattan Borough President Ruth Messinger and a Council member, Ronnie Eldridge of Manhattan, both leading opponents, can't even determine what sites it would cover.
The Dinkins administration says the Mayor warned during his re-election campaign that he would seek this legislation. It also says that the Housing Preservation Department has been working on the bill for months. But the last-minute legislative rush job fuels suspicions that City Hall hurried the bill along to help one developer, William Zeckendorf, who is said to be planning a residential project at 56th Street and Broadway that would be covered by the bill.
Making a law, especially a law that could have wide economic impact, is a serious matter. The Council should be forced to go back to the drawing board. If Mr. Dinkins refuses to issue a veto, then it will be up to Council Speaker Peter Vallone to redraft legislation he never should have allowed to pass in the first place.

HEADLINE: Free Trade at the Movies Puts U.S. in New Role;
Since Adam Smith

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"How Free Trade Prompts Growth: A Primer" (front page, Dec. 15) asserts that the "nearly universal conviction that open trade drives global prosperity rests more on observation than on well-developed theory." Not so. 
 The economic theories supporting free trade have been well developed for centuries, beginning with Adam Smith more than 200 years ago. The idea is very simple: The more specialized the division of labor in the world, the more productive world economic activity becomes. If each human being had to provide for all of his or her necessities, there would not be enough hours in the day for each of us to build houses, make shoes, grow and gather food. So we specialize.
Those who put roofs on buildings, perform open-heart surgery or adjudicate disputes are efficient enough at their own specialties to be able to purchase the fruits of other specialized skills with money.
Free and open international trade merely extends this theory of labor specialization. If ready access to the world's best rubber trees makes Malaysia the most efficient producer of condoms (it does), it is more efficient for American computer manufacturers (something we are particularly good at) to buy their condoms from Malaysia and for Malaysians to get their computers here.
Everybody benefits from such specialization.
 
PHILIP D. HARVEY
Washington, Dec. 15, 1993

HEADLINE: Free Trade at the Movies Puts U.S. in New Role

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "High Noon at Uruguay Gulch" (Editorial Notebook, Dec. 13), Karl E. Meyer defends French foot-dragging on the demands in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade concerning United States access to Europe's audiovisual market and France's insistence on a cultural exception. The question has, at any rate, now been deferred (front page, Dec. 15). 
 Mr. Meyer is right that France is "not alone in fearing for the survival of its national culture." Even the United States does not leave culture entirely to markets. At year end, the rich remember tax writeoffs for gifts to museums. The real question is: How do we best protect national culture? The answer appears to be: Subsidize your movies, but permit free access (without quotas) to ours.
But the French-American dispute has other ironies that only economists will recognize. Jack Valenti, head of the motion picture association, and Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, have claimed that, since 57 percent of the movies shown in French theaters are American, the 11 percent surcharge levied on all movies (and spent on subsidizing French film production) must be shared with Hollywood.
I suggest that this remarkable new principle of taxation be adopted symmetrically by the United States. Our toll receipts (often earmarked for our highway spending) should be shared with Japan pro rata to the number of Japanese cars that pay road and bridge tolls in this country.
For those who have tracked and fought the Clinton Administration's shift to a tough, managed-trade, "results-oriented" trade policy toward Japan, based mainly on industry complaints that our shares in Japan's markets are low while Japan's shares in our markets are high, the irony is that the French are accusing us in the same way on movies.
Since Hollywood takes 80 percent of the European market, while European films take only 2 percent of ours, France accuses us of invisible protectionism, of structural impediments, much like those of which our industries accuse Japan!
Perhaps this role reversal might help to restore sanity to a Japan-fixated Administration that has allowed itself to become a handmaiden of Japan-bashers and special interests.
 
JAGDISH BHAGWATI
New York, Dec. 15, 1993
The writer, professor of economics at Columbia University, was an adviser to the director general of GATT.

HEADLINE: Free Trade at the Movies Puts U.S. in New Role;
The Mexican Case

 BODY:
To the Editor:
William Safire, in "Hold That GATT" (column, Dec. 9) opposes France's attempts to limit Hollywood penetration of its market, stating, "the French public prefers the American product." This is questionable. 
 From my research on the interaction of Hollywood and United States foreign policy with the Mexican film industry since the 1930's, I conclude that moderate protection is necessary for other countries to preserve national culture. This goes beyond greater demand for Hollywood films.
The problem is competing economically with Hollywood. Demand for domestic movies in other countries is high, but it is impossible to fulfill when confronted with Hollywood's international economies of scale (in large part derived from its enormous domestic market), as well as the economic and diplomatic power of the United States.
It is true that there is great foreign demand for United States movies, and moderate protection and subsidization cannot erase it. What it can do is create the necessary space for other national film industries to exist -- allowing for cultural sovereignty in other countries and a more diverse world culture system.
Today Mexico issued postage stamps honoring several stars of its golden age of cinema (from the mid-1930's to the late 40's), including Maria Felix and Jorge Infante -- to go along with a recent one commemorating Cantinflas. The demand for films by such stars extended beyond Mexico to all of Latin America in the 40's. And the films of the era remain popular throughout the region.
It was the inability of Mexico -- weaker and more dependent on the United States than France is -- to protect its film industry after World War II from the coercive policies of Washington and Hollywood that has left Mexico with nostalgic stamps but a crippled movie industry.
For other countries, faced with Hollywood's insistence on free trade at all costs in an industry where Hollywood has all the advantages, regulating movies is in the national interest as a matter of cultural sovereignty.
Further, as South American states jump on the North American Free Trade Agreement bandwagon, Latin Americans should perhaps look to France, and to Mexican history, in demanding that their governments negotiate trade deals that defend cultural sovereignty.
 
SETH FEIN
Mexico City, Dec. 14, 1993
The writer, a doctoral candidate at the University of Texas at Austin, is a visiting scholar at the Instituto Mora.
