HEADLINE: In Battling for Biotech, Monsanto Is the Leader

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS

 BODY:
As the range of products produced by biotechnology grows, so do the stakes in the battle to convince consumers that there are greater benefits than risks in tampering with nature. For the next few months, at least, the Monsanto Company is destined to lead the battle.
Monsanto, the diversified chemical company that makes Ortho lawn and garden products and Nutrasweet, finds itself at the biotech front line because it won the race against companies like Eli Lilly, Upjohn and American Cyanamid to alter bacteria genetically into mini-factories producing a cow hormone called bovine somatotropin, or BST, that stimulates milk production. Monsanto received Food and Drug Administration clearance for its Posilac brand of BST last month and can begin selling it to American farmers on Feb. 3. 
 Based on a leafy campus outside this city, Monsanto has financed its drive into biotechnology with a bulging portfolio of existing products. Monsanto's current jewel is Roundup herbicide, a 19-year-old product that industry analysts say generates more than $1.4 billion annually in revenues.
Roundup still has strong growth potential because it is environmentally safer than its major competitors and an aid to the spreading practice of "no till" agriculture in which farmers reduce soil erosion by killing weeds with chemicals.
In addition to other herbicides and its Ortho line of products, Monsanto also makes high-quality polyesters, specialty plastics used widely in the automotive, appliance and medical products industries, Nutrasweet sweeteners, and, through its G. D.Searle subsidiary, a range of drugs. It earned $436 million on sales of $6.02 billion in the first nine months of this year.
Analysts said they believed the eventual worldwide demand for BST products could be $1 billion a year. But prying the new market open will be tough because biotechnology opponents are intent on stopping it.
"BST's the flagship product of agricultural biotechnology, but it has no socially redeeming value," said Andrew Kimbrell, staff counsel for the Foundation on Economic Trends, a Washington-based group that has opposed most biotechnology commercialization efforts. He said that his group planned to file lawsuits in January aimed at blocking Monsanto from beginning sales of Posilac.
Unlike most other products of gene-splicing that have reached the market, BST is not a medicine intended to improve human or animal health. Nor is it a substitute for an established product that would otherwise be extracted from animals at a much higher cost and risk of impurity, like the renin used in cheese making. The F.D.A. in 1990 approved an application by Pfizer Inc. to make that enzyme in genetically altered bacteria instead of recovering it from the stomachs of calves.
What BST injections can do is increase the output from the average herd by about 10 percent. Output for individual cows could rise as much as 20 percent. That should benefit the most efficient farmers, but in a segment of farming already swamped by surpluses, many agricultural experts believe it will hasten the long-term decline in the number of dairy farms. And no one expects consumers to see any lower dairy product prices.
 
$1 Billion Investment
 Monsanto's moment in the biotech spotlight is hardly a surprise. It has been one of the heaviest investors in the field, having spent more than $1 billion on BST since 1982 and hundreds of millions more on other biotech research, including drug-related research at Searle. Close behind BST in Monsanto's pipeline are a pork hormone that could produce leaner pigs and a variety of genetically altered plants with improved herbicide tolerance and insect resistance.
Still, the outcome of the BST battle may have more impact on the stock prices of small biotech companies than on Monsanto's shares. Even a smashing success for BST would not gain Monsanto as much attention from investors as a healthy upswing in worldwide demand for its core chemical businesses. At the moment, many analysts are focused on gauging the strength of the rebound in profits at troubled Searle, which has four new drugs in the market, including the hot-selling sleep aid, Ambien, and Daypro, a treatment for arthritis.
Analysts are also watching Nutra sweet more closely than BST. Nutra sweet has had no significant return yet on its efforts to develop fat substitutes and its biggest product, aspartame, came off patent a year ago. While the subsidiary has actually increased net income this year through rigorous cost cutting and expanding markets, analysts do not see a major upside potential.
 
'BST Is a Wild Card'
 "BST is a wild card in their earnings," said Robert S. Reitzes, who follows the company for C. J.Lawrence. Most analysts conservatively assume it will be a bust, he said.
It would not be the company's first high-profile flop. A light heavyweight in the chemical business behind giants like Dow and Du Pont for much of its existence, Monsanto has spent years methodically renovating and reshaping itself in search of better profit margins and faster-growing, less cyclical businesses. It developed Astro-Turf, the artificial grass carpet, for indoor arenas like the Houston Astrodome but failed to make much money on it.
The most recent major disappointment has been Searle, which Monsanto acquired in 1985. Searle's poorly managed drug pipeline left it saddled with about $100 million in costs for introducing new drugs at the same time it was trying to deal with the end of patent protection for Calan, the hypertension treatment that was its best seller. Company officials now agree that Searle cannot keep up with bigger competitors on its own, particularly at a time that the industry's profit margins are under pressure, but two years of seeking a suitable alliance have failed.
 
Simple Pleasures' Simple Flop
 The company has also suffered through Nutrasweet's efforts to develop markets for its Simplesse fat substitute, including an ill-fated venture to make Simple Pleasures ice cream that was quietly killed early this year.
"Every time we have tried to be in the distribution business, we have had our lunch, breakfast, dinner and midnight snack handed to us," said Robert Flynn, the blunt Canadian dispatched from headquarters in 1990 to overhaul Nutrasweet, which is based outside Chicago.
But Monsanto clearly has a respectable overall batting average. In its nine years under Richard J. Mahoney, its detail-oriented chairman and chief executive, management has kept its eye fixed on a goal of remaking itself into an enterprise capable of achieving a steady 20 percent return on equity and 10 percent annual growth in sales by the mid-1990's. Although it is still well short of its goal, Wall Street seems confident it is on the right track. More than half the 22 analysts who follow it rate the company a buy and no one recommends selling shares, according to Zacks Investment Research.
"I think the world is beginning to believe we are going to do it," said Mr. Mahoney, who calculates that the company has more than 60 percent of its assets deployed in businesses that meet the target, up from less than 25 percent in the early 1980's.
 
Shed Astro-Turf
 Monsanto in the last decade has purchased businesses with more than $3 billion in sales and shed others that generated $4 billion annually. Among those dropped are the Astro-Turf operations, oil and gas production, industrial control equipment, animal feed operations and Searle's consumer product businesses including products like Dramamine and Metamucil and Pearle Vision Centers.
During that same period, Monsanto has slashed costs and improved quality at many of its manufacturing operations, in part by becoming a leader in the use of industrial work teams that empower employees to make more operating decisions.
"Your opportunities to get prices up are very limited," said Robert G. Potter, president of Monsanto's chemical group, when asked about near-term prospects. "You really only have one tool at your disposal: control of your own costs."
In the long run, though, Monsanto cannot meet its financial targets without plenty of successful new products both inside and outside the biotech field, Mr. Mahoney said. That gives it all the incentive it needs to go all out to win the BST battle.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 5, 1994, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Dec. 24, about the Monsanto Company's biotechnology business, misidentified the company's main fiber product. It is nylon, not polyester. The article also misstated the company's goal for growth, and its spending on biotechnology. Monsanto is seeking a 10 percent annual increase in earnings, not sales. It has spent more than $1 billion on biotechnology in general, not just on a cow hormone known as bovine somatotropin, or BST.

HEADLINE: Medical Costs Slower to Rise In New York

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Changes in the way doctors and hospitals are paid -- how much and by whom -- have begun to curb the steady rise of health care costs in the New York region. Costs are still going up faster than overall inflation, but the annual rate of increase is the lowest in 21 years.
Economists said this trend was especially noteworthy in view of the New York region's long-standing identification with high-cost health care. In fact, in recent months, medical-care inflation in the rest of the country has outpaced increases here. 
 Health care prices in the region rose 4.1 percent in the 12 months ending Nov. 30, down sharply from 6.3 percent a year ago and 10.9 percent in 1990, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics said. It was the smallest 12-month increase since 1972.
"We have led the inflation parade," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the bureau's New York Commissioner. "This is a rarity, whether you are talking about medical care or anything else in this region."
What is particularly important is that the gap is narrowing between the medical portion of inflation and the rest of the price index. Health care prices across the country are still rising at 5.5 percent, almost double the 2.7 general inflation rate. But the increase nationwide had been as much as 9 percent three years ago.
Health care experts said the moderating trend was propelled by growing competition among doctors, hospitals and medical insurers, as well as a rise in public acceptance of managed health care programs that offer incentives to restrain costs.
They said the long-running economic slowdown and persistent unemployment also played a role by placing a damper on increases in wages, which are a big item in hospital budgets.
Changes in the system have accelerated as hospitals, physicians and insurers scramble to anticipate or deflect President Clinton's health care proposals. The President's effort is intended in part to help the country regain control of health care costs, something that may be beginning to happen even before any national plan is enacted.
The changes show up in a variety of ways.
 
Changing Coverage
 Many employers in the region, including General Electric, Martin Marietta, Allied-Signal and a growing number of retail stores and law firms, have been aggressively moving their people out of traditional coverage that pays separately for each service, with little or no supervision.
And both New Jersey and New York have loosened hospital rate regulations, freeing hospitals to compete for business as never before.
A brochure from New York University Medical Center itemizes the center's state-approved rates for selected procedures and higher charges at five other large Manhattan hospitals. It says, for example, that its price for gall bladder surgery is $5,810.24 while prices elsewhere range from $6,527.43 to $8,251.73.
Health maintenance organizations, such as U.S. Healthcare, provide incentives for obstetricians, for example, to follow professional rules that foster natural childbirth instead of expensive Caesarean section deliveries.
Egged on by cost-conscious employers, some patients are asking doctors to disclose the charges before agreeing to a test or procedure. And managed care companies often telephone to press doctors for reduced fees.
"The New York hospital market is seeing the dawning of competition," said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association.
 
Doctors Taking Action
 "It's been a revolution in the past year or so," added Joseph E. Davis, president of the 3,600-member New York County Medical Society. Exemplifying the changing medical culture, Dr. Davis, a urologist, has signed on with 10 managed care networks -- a step that thousands of doctors in New York and New Jersey are taking after decades of resistance.
He said physicians at several New York hospitals, including Cabrini Medical Center, where he practices, New York University Medical Center, and Lenox Hill, are also organizing their own networks to bid directly for group business, bypassing the H.M.O.'s and insurance companies.
"Physicians are anticipating change and really beginning to change their practices," said Kenneth J. Reifert, a vice president for corporate benefits planning at Merrill Lynch & Company. "They are more willing to negotiate than in the past."
Helping to drive costs down, a growing number of H.M.O.'s, including U.S. Healthcare, Cigna, Sanus and Prudential, are paying family doctors, pediatricians and internists a pre-set monthly amount for each health plan member, replacing the traditional fee for each visit, test or procedure. As a result, these primary care physicians are careful to avoid unnecessary services.
Hospitals also receive a fee for each illness, or a flat rate per day from many managed care plans, instead of reimbursing item by item for lengthy bills.
Cigna, which says it has H.M.O. contracts with 200,000 people in the tri-state area, pays $600 to $1,000 a day for medical and surgical patients, according to Tracy Bahl, executive director for Cigna in New York, a deep discount from the rate people on their own are charged.
Besides the new hospital-based physician groups, a number of hospitals are following the example of New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, which has forged a network of hospitals to bid for the business of insurers and self-insured employers.
 
Labor Costs Are a Factor
 The sluggishness in the regional economy is holding down labor costs in hospitals, economists said. And as business declines under managed care, some hospitals are combining departments and reducing staffs.
Mr. Raske said 1,000 hospital jobs were eliminated in New York this year. New York University Medical Center, for example, has cut 325 jobs overall, even while it added 150 employees at a new women's center and a research institute.
Adding yet another possible explanation for the changes, some economists believe the insurance business may be at a low point in a cost cycle as insurers lower prices to attract new customers. If they discover they are losing money, their prices might soar in the next year or two, the economists said.
But some experts doubt that this pattern will hold. "Is this just another cycle, or a fundamental shift?" asked Bob Braddick, a principal with the Foster Higgins consulting firm. The answer may not be clear until next year at the earliest.
Although New York still lags far behind such hotbeds of managed care as California and Minnesota, health maintenance organizations here have recruited about 15 percent of the region's 19 million people, compared with only 11 percent in 1989.
Advertising heavily to increase their share of the market, U.S. Healthcare, Prudential, and Empire Blue Cross, among others, expect to raise monthly charges for H.M.O. members by 5 percent or less next year, compared with projected statewide increases averaging 5.7 percent in New York and 5.6 percent nationally.
With spending moderating for hospitals and physicians, insurance company requests for rate increases are getting a skeptical reception from state regulators.
 
Rate Increase Is Denied
 Noting that profits of U.S. Healthcare, the largest investor-owned H.M.O. in the region, were "significantly higher" than projected, the New York Insurance Commissioner, Salvatore Curiale, denied the company's request for a 6.2 percent average rate increase for next year.
Instead, he ordered U.S. Healthcare to cut premiums by 14.6 percent for individuals and 4.9 percent for employers with more than 50 workers. He approved a 1.6 percent increase for groups with 3 to 50 workers.
U.S. Healthcare, which has 350,000 members in 11 downstate New York counties, has appealed the ruling in New York Supreme Court.
New Jersey recently approved a 2 percent increase for U.S. Healthcare for the 12 months ending next June 30.
Trying to stay competitive, Healthnet, a H.M.O. owned by Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, is not seeking a 1994 rate increase in New York, Ramesh Punwani, Empire's chief financial officer said.
The nonprofit Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the state's largest health insurer, also canceled a previously approved general increase for non-H.M.O. members scheduled for next month.

HEADLINE: U.N. Leader Has Talks With North Korea

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PANMUNJOM, Korea, Dec. 24

 BODY:
The United Nations Secretary General crossed the border between South and North Korea today for talks with North Korean leaders on their suspected development of nuclear weapons.
The trip coincided with reports that North Korean and United States officials have made considerable progress in talks to allow international inspections of the North's nuclear plants. 
 Before traveling to the border from Seoul, the Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, said, "I believe a crisis exists that requires the attention of the international community."
He was met by Col. Kim Ryun Ki, secretary of North Korea's delegation to the Korean Armistice Commission, a watchdog of the 1953 cease-fire that ended the three-year Korean War.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali later met for two hours with Kim Young Nam, Vice Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, to offer the United Nations' help in defusing the situation, a U.N. official traveling with the secretary-general said. Mr. Kim told Mr. Boutros-Ghali that North was consulting directly with the United States and that no mediation was needed, the official said.
North Korea has refused to discuss inspections with anyone other than United States, apparently because it wants better relations with Washington as well as help with its economy.

The Economy
For millions of regular users of computer networks, holiday traditions are being updated and adapted to the infinite, conceptual realm called cyberspace, including the giving of electronic gifts, sending electronic Christmas cards and, yes, last-minute shopping at the electronic mall. [Page 1.] Cyberspace Santa Clauses have been receiving and answering requests for toys, peace on earth, and advice on relationships. [48.] 
 Medical inflation in the New York region fell to a 21-year low in the past year, reflecting sweeping changes in the way doctors and hospitals are paid. Economists said the moderating trend was especially noteworthy in view of New York's longstanding identification with high-cost medicine. [1.]
It is a ritual nearly as traditional as drinking eggnog: searching for batteries on Christmas Day. For battery manufacturers, the scramble ends the most profitable time of year, with industry leaders making nearly 40 percent of their sales in the fourth quarter, much of that in December. [47.]
With 170 Indian casinos opening in the past five years and more being planned, tribes are devising safeguards against both corrupt management and the assaults of gambling predators. [6.]

HEADLINE: Indian Tribes Close Ranks to Protect Casinos From Cheats and Rivals

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE

 BODY:
The con artist was tracked by the Indians across a half dozen reservations, their ceiling TV cameras zooming in on her hands as she played at blackjack tables and coolly cheated tribal casinos out of $3,000 a sitting.
"In the old days, the tribes never got together on anything this way," said Roger Miller, a Mohican who is security director for the Potawatomi tribe's bingo and casino hall here and the founder of Wisconsin's new Indian Gaming Intelligence Association, which covers 11 tribes and 17 casinos. "It was divide and conquer. But with gaming, we're experiencing the same growing pains and lack of expertise, and so we help each other out now." 
 These are, indeed, new days of casino fortune for American Indians, and the tribal TV tapes finally exposed the blackjack player's scheme. It was a closed-TV system spying from her purse through a tiny, unobtrusive lens. It was tied into a van parked out in the casino lot in which her conspirators counted the cards being dealt out and instantly radioed back discreet betting instructions. The con artist was arrested, and a security bulletin was dispatched to all the tribes.
"It sounds crazy to go to all that trouble, but there's an awful lot of money out here now," Mr. Miller said, summarizing the attraction and risk in the booming new world of Indian casino gambling that is prompting a parallel revolution in tribal cooperation and safeguards.
 
Competitors Are Watching
 As Donald J. Trump and other envious competitors predict that the tribes will encounter corruption because of their inexperience, the leadership of Indian gaming is taking a variety of steps to defend the tribes' economic windfall. With 170 casinos opening in the past five years, by a Federal count, and many more being planned, tribes are building safeguards against both corrupt management and the ever ingenious assaults of the same predators who work the tables and slot machines in Nevada and Atlantic City.
A range of wariness can be found in the reservation casinos, from the latest electronic sophistication to the sort of fledgling naivete in management that marks any business rush. But the huge success of Indian casinos like Foxwoods in Ledyard, Conn., a veritable revenue machine that has become the most lucrative gambling hall in the nation in less than two years, is the reigning inspiration for the tribes.
There, Richard (Skip) Hayward, the Mashantucket Pequot chief regarded now as a casino genius, took care to hire as his chief executive and integrity expert G. Michael Brown, the former director of New Jersey's Division of Gaming Enforcement. Mr. Brown, a former prosecutor who built a reputation in forcing Atlantic City casinos to cut their underworld ties, has eased back from the absolute sovereignty so dear to other tribes and instead invited full on-site cooperation with state and Federal law-enforcement experts in gambling.
In setting an example for other tribes, Foxwoods, like most other big casinos, does not hesitate to arrest a gambler or employee openly, on the casino floor, once documented evidence is in hand. The showy arrest is valued as an assurance to the public and a warning to the staff that tribal standards are tight. More important, Mr. Brown, who also exchanges the latest gaming intelligence with Las Vegas and Atlantic City operators, says he urges other tribes to duplicate a key Connecticut requirement in the tribal gaming compact for thorough criminal and professional background checks of each employee and sizable outside contractor.
"The tribes have the same concerns and worries as other legitimate casinos: high-level security, strict internal controls of the movement of money and experienced management," said Mr. Brown, who also runs a Foxwoods consulting service for tribes starting up in the casino business.
"We've found a predictable mix," he said of two recent studies of other Indian casinos. "One was excellently run, the other was so lax in controls that it could easily fall victim to illicit dealings."
Mr. Brown estimated that the main threat to Indian gaming was not underworld infiltration as much as "bad business deals in a risky area, just as with junk bonds."
The Wisconsin tribal association has now extended its information exchange to a similar group of a dozen Indian casinos in Minnesota. It is an interstate model for a larger nationwide pooling of reservation intelligence that is being planned by the National Indian Gaming Association, the tribes' main industry and lobbying group.
The better casinos' emphasis on integrity is clear in a visit down to the security room at the Mystic Lake casino, an impressive gambling palace blending Las Vegas and wigwam themes that is run by the Minnesota Shakopee Sioux outside Minneapolis. A wall of television screens faces a control desk of 24-hour monitors who operate a custom-designed "eye in the sky" system of surveillance that can zoom in on fingertip-tight close-ups from three angles of each employee and produce instant snapshots of any suspicious characters on the floor. It was designed by Atlantic City experts hired by tribal leaders wanting industry savvy over simple blood ties.
Beyond warning about corrupt employees and players and threats from the underworld, the Wisconsin tribal network has been comparing overhead costs and urging tribes to maintain their own slot machines at a tenth of the cost of some outside experts. A recent Bureau of Indian Affairs report emphasized inflated management contracts as a greater threat to tribal profits than elaborate mob infiltration.
 
Value of Clean Games
 The Wisconsin Attorney General, James E. Doyle, who has a new gaming branch in the state's Criminal Investigation Division that works with the tribes, believes that action is needed on the Federal level to create and share a national repository of gambling intelligence and to help train enforcement agents. "The tribes recognize their long-range well-being rests on having clean games," Mr. Doyle said.
While Wisconsin's approach is a considered a model for tribes and states, Mr. Doyle, an expert on Indian gaming for the National Association of Attorneys General, warns that state laws present a crazy quilt in which oversight, accounting procedures and other necessities are often vague. In the rush to open tribal casinos, state authorities are understaffed and the risk is that background checks will be skimpy, Mr. Doyle stresses. "We're not having big problems with organized crime, but there are always the illegal dealers and player rip-offs that go with the territory," he said.
Federal law is rooted in Indian sovereignty and defers to state-tribal compacts for regulatory procedures. But Washington does require professional accounting standards and allows tribes to pay outside managers no more than 30 percent of overall profits. Exceptions up to 40 percent were widely allowed as tribes dealt with outsiders for start-up capital, but the National Indian Gaming Commission, the new Federal oversight agency, intends to reign that back in to guard against sweetheart deals that might siphon tribal revenues, said Tony Hope, the executive director.
"There are weaknesses in some of the compacts," Mr. Hope said, "'but the tribes are doing remarkably well. Because they are extended families, they are the ones who have taken action first in the three instances I know of in which figures from organized crime have attempted infiltration and been thrown out."
More pesky are the endless attempts at theft by fast-fingered employees and the array of new cheating devices from players. These include using a slot machine coin with a tiny tether so it is never actually deposited, using doctored credit cards to fool the banking cash machines now all over casinos and wearing minute electronic blackjack computers, taped onto an ankle, perhaps, to receive impulses signaled from a spying conspirator.
Justice Department reports have thus far discounted charges of significant underworld influence on reservations. But the money is ever inviting, and Mr. Hope is worried about the rapid casino proliferation and the shortage of Federal manpower, particularly to check that the compacts provide for first-rate accounting that he feels is the key to alerting the tribes to money skimming and other abuses, whether within the tribe or without. Here at the Potawatomi casino, each slot machine is connected to a central computer for instant accounting to tribal leaders down to each nickel bet.
 
Supreme Court Help
 The key to the tribal casino boom has been the Supreme Court's modern decisions bolstering the sovereignty and business prerogatives of Indians. Pressure is growing in Congress to curtail this billion-dollar tribal power, and while the Indians now have more lobbying withal of their own, they are aware that any serious reservation scandal would be seized upon as typical by critics like Mr. Trump. He angers some tribal leaders and amuses others with his complaint, as a casino manager threatened by Indian competition, that more and more tribes are coming forward led by gambling proponents who "don't look like Indians to me."
Mr. Miller takes this not as implicit racism but as a measure that Indians look more and more like established entrepreneurs who are mastering the gaming industry with growing sophistication. "The really incredible story in all this is how it's finally bringing the tribes together," said the Mohican guarding the Potawatomis' gambling coffers.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Roger Miller, a Mohican and security director for the Potawatomi tribe's bingo and casino hall in Milwaukee, looking at monitors in the surveillance room of the casino last week. (Morry Gash for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 2 Japanese Companies Set Merger

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Two of Japan's leading chemical manufacturers said today that they would merge, creating one of the 10 largest chemical companies in the world and speeding the restructuring of one of this nation's least competitive industries.
Mitsubishi Kasei, one of Japan's largest general chemical manufacturers, will combine with Mitsubishi Petrochemical, the country's biggest petrochemical company, in a stock transaction. The new entity, tentatively called the Mitsubishi Chemical Company, would have consolidated sales of more than $14 billion. 
 Under the terms of the agreement announced today, each share of Mitsubishi Petrochemical stock would be exchanged for 1.3 shares of Kasei stock. Kasei would issue 641.3 million new shares in a transaction valued at about $2.5 billion.
 
A Need to Cut Costs
 Executives said the move had been driven partly by the need to cut costs because a severe economic slump was causing both companies to lose money in this fiscal year. But a bigger motivation, they said, was to become bigger and more competitive in the next century.
"We have to compete with the big global companies," Masahiko Furukawa, the president of Mitsubishi Kasei, said at a news conference.
Unlike automobiles, electronics and steel, Japan's chemical industry has barely been a player on the world stage. Not only does it lag well behind the world leaders in the United States and Europe, it also faces stiff competition from South Korea and Taiwan, which have lower costs and have been expanding their capacity.
Part of Japan's problem is that the country lacks petroleum and energy resources needed for the industry. But another factor is that Japan's industry is fragmented into small companies that lack economies of scale.
 
12 Companies Split a Market
 In Japan, for instance, 12 companies split an ethylene market of six million metric tons a year, while in the West, a million tons is regarded as the minimum sales needed for a company's survival, according to Nicholas D. Smith, an analyst with Jardine Fleming Securities in Tokyo.
When the two 1970's oil crises shook out the petrochemical industries in the West, Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry organized Japan's industry into cartels and spread production cuts around, rather than letting smaller or less efficient companies fail.
"Allowing natural selection to keep industries in shape was unfortunately not regarded as the Japanese way," Mr. Smith wrote in a recent report.
Now, he said, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry is encouraging joint ventures and alliances and there have been rumors of other mergers.
Mitsubishi Kasei ranked 13th on Fortune magazine's list of the world's largest chemical companies in 1992, with revenues of $9.55 billion. The merged company would rank ninth on that list with sales of $13.7 billion, still well behind the industry leader, Du Pont, at $37.4 billion.
The merger partners are both part of the Mitsubishi Group, a family of companies, known as a keiretsu, in which members often hold small stakes in one another.
 
Helped by Shell
 Mitsubishi Kasei and other companies in the Mitsubishi Group formed Mitsubishi Petrochemical in 1956 with help from Shell. Mitsubishi Kasei owns 4.7 percent of the petrochemical company, while various Shell affiliates own a combined 22 percent.
Kasei shares closed today at 433 yen, about $3.90, down 10 yen on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, while shares of the petrochemical company finished at 611 yen, about $5.50, down 19 yen. Trading in the two stocks was suspended when the news broke.
Akira Miura, the president of the petrochemical company, is to become the president of the new company while Mr. Furukawa, the president of Kasei, is to become chairman. The merger is expected to be completed in October.
How quickly its benefits will be realized is open to question. Since Mitsubishi Kasei has its own petrochemical division, there is some overlap. In fact, the two have petrochemical plants next door to each other in central Japan.
 
No Plans for Layoffs
 But a spokesman for Mitsubishi Kasei said the companies had no plans for layoffs or plant closings after the merger, although the two adjacent plants will be combined for greater efficiency. He said the companies did not expect the merger to raise antitrust problems.
Mitsubishi Kasei also makes carbon products such as coke, electronic materials such as for data storage disks, and pharmaceuticals. In the fiscal year that ended last March, it reported consolidated sales of 1.18 trillion yen, equivalent to $10.6 billion at today's exchange rate. Net profit was 6 billion yen, or about $54 million.
Mitsubishi Petrochemical had consolidated sales of 508 billion yen, about $4.6 billion, in the year ended in March. Net profits were 6.7 billion yen, about $60 million.

HEADLINE: Stocks Reach Record Levels In London and Paris Trading

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed at a record high for the second consecutive day today, prompted by continued hopes of lower interest rates and higher corporate earnings.
The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index rose 15.8 points, or almost a half percent, to 3,412.3. It was the first time that the index had closed above 3,400. 
 The London markets closed early for the Christmas holiday, but in Paris, where trading continued for a full session, the bourse ended at its second successive record close. The Paris CAC-40 share index gained 8.46 points, to 2,251.48; it gained 55.04 points for the week.
Many other exchanges in Europe had limited trading, while all stock, bond and commodity markets in the United States and Germany were closed.
The American markets and most in Europe will resume trading on Monday, but London will remain closed until Wednesday.
 
Positive Sentiment
 London traders said that while trading was slow today in the shortened session, the market sentiment was positive and they expected the rally to continue next week and into the new year.
In Tokyo, stocks closed lower in thin trading today as investors worried about the Government's slow response to calls for substantial steps to lift the economy, brokers said.
Investors said they feared that Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa would not announce any concrete steps at a news conference later in the day.
The Nikkei average lost 304.63 points, or 1.75 percent, closing at 17,141.11. The Tokyo markets were closed on Thursday for a national holiday.
At the news conference, Prime Minister Hosokawa outlined a six-point economic proposal that did not include new Government spending or tax cuts to stimulate the economy. He also apologized for not having achieved political reform by his self-imposed deadline of the end of the year.
The market has been held back by the Government's procrastination on economic stimulus. "Ministers are holding repeated meetings, but it is still unclear what they are going to do for the economy," Kenichi Nagasu, a trader for Cosmo Securities, said.
In Hong Kong, prices closed sharply higher before the Christmas break, with the main index breaking through the 11,000 level for the first time. Brokers said the rise was fueled by continued demand from overseas for blue-chip property counters.
The Hang Seng Index ended the half-day session up 158.64 points, or 1.46 percent, at a record 11,039.84. Trading ended at midday for the Christmas holiday. Light profit taking brought the index off an intraday high of 11,044.65.
The Australian market ended 20 points higher in a reasonably busy half-day of trading before the four-day Christmas break, brokers said.
At the close, the all ordinaries index was up 20.4 points, or about 1 percent, to 2,089.2, its high for the day.
In Mexico, stocks gained for the third consecutive day as investors bought shares in hopes that companies' earnings would rise in 1994, analysts said.
The Bolsa index, which has gained 45.9 percent so far this year, gained 5.23 points, or two-tenths of a percent, today to finish at another record high of 2,567.07.

GIULIANI ADDS A JOB TO SUBTRACT OTHERS

Bedford-Stuyvesant had to confront a crime that was ghastly by any measure, even the Brooklyn neighborhood's own. The victims were a 4-year-old boy and a 6-year-old girl who were found strangled with electric cord inside an apartment in the Sumner Houses. The girl's body was hanging on a closet door, investigators said. A woman was found with several stab wounds, but still alive. Detectives said her boyfriend was not a suspect. Page 35.
 
 REGION
 
COST OF CARE SLOWS DOWN
Changes in the way doctors and hospitals are paid -- how much and by whom -- have begun to curb the steady rise of health care costs in the New York region. Costs are still going up faster than overall inflation, but the annual rate of increase is the lowest in 21 years. Economists said this trend was especially noteworthy in view of the New York region's long-standing identification with high-cost health care. Page 1.

HEADLINE: For Haiti, Sanctions That Bite

 BODY:
Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, has been subjected to unrelenting pressure in recent weeks to try to resolve his country's political crisis. The junta that runs Haiti has refused to step aside, as its members had agreed to do, and allow Father Aristide to govern. This week the Haitian military declined to meet with a delegation from the "Four Friends" group of countries: the U.S., Venezuela, Canada and France.
In response, the international community finally is beginning to apply pressure where it is due: on Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras and his cronies. The United States has an obligation to make sure that the pressure continues. 
 After General Cedras refused to step aside, as he agreed to do at the U.S.-sponsored Governors Island conference in October, the international community imposed half-hearted sanctions that have mostly hurt Haiti's poor while doing very little to put pressure on the people who count. While many Haitians go hungry, the members of the elite still shuttle to Miami for supplies.
Until Wednesday, Washington and other friendly governments were urging Father Aristide to agree to an international conference in Port-au-Prince -- suggested by acting Prime Minister Robert Malval -- to try to break the stalemate.
Father Aristide refused, with good reason. His allies had been assassinated and the Parliament has been unable to function for fear of political terrorism. Given that atmosphere, Father Aristide feared his supporters would not feel free to participate. He was also upset at suggestions in a French newspaper interview with Mr. Malval that participants in the conference include some well-known members of the former Duvalier dictatorship.
Father Aristide's backers have proposed an alternative conference in Miami -- a much safer venue. They have not invited the military, on the grounds that there is only one subject to discuss with the junta leaders: their date of departure.
In principle, that's correct. Politically, however, it was probably unwise. Given General Cedras's refusal to meet with the Four Friends group and his general intransigence, he would be unlikely to accept such an invitation from Father Aristide and his backers. But that would leave Father Aristide on much firmer footing to ask for tougher sanctions.
The international community has at last begun to consider sanctions that could actually hurt the country's elite. The State Department has threatened to limit private flights to and from Haiti; France has indicated that it may freeze the assets of Haiti's military rulers and their backers. It's regrettable that such steps were not considered earlier; still, they represent a welcome change. The United Nations should endorse the sanctions, including limits on commercial air traffic, and oblige compliance from all member states.
The junta has held on partly because its members were confident that the world would eventually tire of the problems of a small, poor country. Now the Haitian elite must be made to feel the pain. Washington could help immeasurably by taking the lead in tightening the sanctions and helping to make the proposed Miami conference a success.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Elderly Paid Dues, But Get the Brushoff

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I'm one of those middle-class elderly people who, after working 50 years, is getting Social Security. I get the feeling that it's becoming ever more acceptable to discuss getting rid of the elderly as soon as possible. We are even being convinced that we should die or commit suicide so as not to bother anyone, particularly poor struggling youth. 
 Why don't young people look upon us as role models who have lived up to the best of the American dream? We too worked our way through college, struggled for jobs, paid for our children's college and graduate educations. We paid top-level taxes to help support poor children, the unemployed, welfare recipients, the drug addicts, mentally ill and criminals.
Our group has donated enormous amounts of volunteer time to multiple causes, and we have given billions to charities. We are still giving. We are the ones who passed the entitlement legislation in the first place. And our young ones have and will continue to benefit from it.
Should not our young also believe that if they work hard and well they too can expect the reward of a well-off old age? Or would they rather the Government told them how much income is "enough" for them? Would they rather suffer the broad hints that they should get out of the way and stop being a burden?
What do young people think we do with our money now that we've finished supporting them for their first 20 years or so? We don't burn it or hide it in a shoe box. Every cent we spend is income for someone else. The money we bank provides capital for the jobs young people take.
May today's youth respect and admire their affluent parents and grandparents! May they work hard to figure out how to make the economy work better for all of us.
And may they never forget that if they decide to buy into the trend of bashing their forebears, their own young will almost certainly do the same to them.
 
RACHEL M. LAUER
New York, Dec. 15, 1993
 
The writer is founding director of the Barbara & Robert K. Straus Thinking & Learning Center, Pace University.

HEADLINE: The British Novelist Who Turned A Class System Upside Down

BYLINE: By SUZANNE CASSIDY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
When Sue Townsend's novel "The Queen and I" was published in Britain last year, she sat back and braced herself for what she was sure would be a deluge of hate mail.
After all, the novel, which was published in the United States in September by Soho Press, imagines nothing less than the overthrow of the British monarchy and the banishment of the royal family to a rough-and-tumble public housing project. Queen Elizabeth II is forced to eke out a mingy existence on state benefits. Prince Charles grows a ponytail and gets into trouble with the law. Princess Diana and Princess Anne take up with men of dubious character. Prince Philip descends into a state of filth and madness. Worst of all, the beloved Queen Mother dies. 
 As Ms. Townsend expected, one hostile letter arrived, followed by a few more. Then, nothing. Nothing, that is, except bags and bags of cheerful, appreciative, nice letters, most of which began, "I used to be a royalist, but . . ."
"I was staggered," Ms. Townsend said in mock disgust. "I thought, you know, I was going to be the darling of the anti-establishment."
 
Signs of Changing Attitudes
 "The Queen and I" spent four months at the top of The Sunday Times of London's best-seller list for hard-cover fiction, and it remains on the paperback fiction list. Read by Miriam Margolyes, it has been turned into a BBC radio series, and now it is being adapted into a play to be staged in May at the Royal Court Theater in London. This remarkable success is a measure of just how much attitudes toward the once-sacrosanct royal family have changed here.
Still, the book's British publishers, Methuen, were nervous enough about the Queen Mother's death scene to insist that the book end with a twist (which will not be revealed here).
Even today, the Queen Mother is to many Britons "like God, Jesus and Mother Teresa rolled into one," Ms. Townsend explained in an interview at her colorfully decorated Edwardian house in Leicester, the city in the East Midlands where the Queen's family is relocated in "The Queen and I."
A Buckingham Palace spokesman said it was not palace policy "to comment on works of fiction." There never was any question of legal action, he said.
A down-to-earth 47-year-old with a dry wit, Ms. Townsend is best known in Britain as the creator of Adrian Mole, an achingly pretentious but fundamentally good-hearted working-class lad who fancies himself a poet. According to Bookwatch, the market research company that compiles the best-seller lists for The Sunday Times, "The Secret Diary of Adrian Mole Aged 13 3/4," the first of a series of Mole books, was Britain's best-selling fiction book of the 1980's. "The Growing Pains of Adrian Mole" was the decade's best-selling hard cover in fiction.
 
A Biography Turns Into Fiction
 Ms. Townsend began writing "The Queen and I" in 1990, well before a spate of royal scandals turned the House of Windsor into a tragicomic soap opera. "It's the oldest cliche: Life will always outstrip art," she said.
Her agent, Giles Gordon, who has also been Prince Charles's literary agent, had been asked by an American publisher if Ms. Townsend would be interested in writing a biography of the Queen from a feminist perspective. Instead, she proposed writing about the monarch's "major life events" -- her marriage, the birth of her first child -- and contrasting them with her own such experiences as someone who, until she found fame as a writer, was solidly working-class. She found, however, that she couldn't do it. "I could write about her," Ms. Townsend said. "I couldn't write about me."
One evening it came to her: she would fictionalize the Queen's story. In a flash, she decided to take the monarch "away from everything she'd ever known" and see how she might fare at the other end of the social and economic spectrum.
It was a decision totally in keeping with the upbringing and political instincts of Ms. Townsend, an avowed socialist and republican.
 
Fears About the Crown
 She remembers throwing herself into the festivities surrounding the Queen's coronation on June 2, 1953. Her neighborhood held a street party and a "fancy-dress competition," to which Ms. Townsend, then age 7, went as a Gypsy, wearing a crown and veil fashioned from curtain rings and a bandana. She remembers her neighbors crowding into her family's house, the only one on the street with a television set, to watch the ceremony, and she remembers being numb with fear for the young Queen.
"The whole of the buildup to the ceremony was about the crown, which weighed five and a half pounds," she recalled. "I was really, really afraid that the crown would fall off her head."
Her parents, though socialists, believed, as almost everyone else did then, that the royals were above politics, that "they were what kept this country together."
Ms. Townsend's Gypsy costume had not long been abandoned when she decided otherwise. She simply concluded, she said, that the royals "were not gods" and therefore did not merit adulation.
 
A Worker's Fantasies
 Nothing in adulthood would change her mind. When her first husband left her to bring up three children on her own, she had to take three part-time jobs, including one as a waitress at a restaurant and bar where one of her tasks was to pick mouse droppings out of the cream pitcher. In her lowest moments, she would fantasize about being sent to prison, where, she imagined, she at least would have some peace and quiet to read books. Later she worked at a playground on the public housing project on which Hellebore Close, the royal family's new home in "The Queen and I," is based. Over the years, her conviction grew that the monarchy bore a good deal of responsibility for the class-bound nature of British society.
"Because they're at the top of the pyramid, then somebody has to be at the bottom," she explained. "When I'm in the presence of somebody who's from a higher class, I still feel very, well, inferior -- let's not mess about -- inferior. And they can be the biggest dimwit, you know, but still, you feel that."
She said she had nothing against most of the royals as people, however, and in "The Queen and I" she treated the Queen with particular gentleness.
"They are only human beings," she said. "You can't be vicious to them. That's the whole point."
 
A Last-Minute Deletion
 Of all the royal characters in "The Queen and I," the Queen's sister, Princess Margaret, and husband, Prince Philip, are the most harshly drawn. Princess Margaret is depicted as a whiner and a fearful snob. As for Prince Philip, Ms. Townsend said: "I was bored with him. I put him to bed, and I could not bear to get him out."
Somewhat to her relief, she had to delete the Duchess of York from the book at the last minute when the Duchess's separation from Prince Andrew was made public.
"I didn't find her that interesting, either," Ms. Townsend said. Even when the Duchess tries to be serious, the author noted, she comes across as "a very, very jolly hockey-sticks type of English girl." She added, "I mean, you don't see many of them in Leicester like that."
Just as you don't find many English writers who are willing to poke fun at the royal family.
To her, the royals are "just intrinsically funny" because "they have to pretend to be people that they're not." And that, the author said, "is always very funny."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 2; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1471 words

HEADLINE: What Would Happen If . . . ?

BYLINE: By Serge Schmemann; Serge Schmemann is the Moscow bureau chief of The New York Times.

 BODY:

RUSSIA 2010
And What It Means for the World.
By Daniel Yergin and Thane Gustafson.
300 pp. New York:
Random House. $23. 
 GUESSING Russia's future must rank among the more frustrating pursuits of businessmen, statesmen and reporters, Russian or Western. Few nations have cloaked themselves in quite as dense a cultural and political fog, and even fewer have followed a historical trail quite as erratic, careering from feudalism to Brave New World, total war, famine, global might and finally collapse, all in the span of one average lifetime. Take these last few months alone: who in early September suspected that President Boris N. Yeltsin would order tanks against the nettlesome Congress of People's Deputies, or that by year's end Russians would be voting on a new Parliament and constitution? And who today can anticipate what the results of that election might mean?
"There are two ways you can tell when a man is lying," Charles E. Bohlen, a lifelong student of Russia and United States Ambassador to Moscow from 1953 to 1957, used to say. "One is when he says he can drink champagne all night and not get drunk. The other is when he says he understands Russians."
Yet try we must to understand, if only because Russia's last incarnation, as an Evil Empire, posed the foremost challenge to our lives and well-being for so long, and its next one could shape our world for decades to come. The trouble is that too much latter-day prophesying is based on either wishful thinking ("They're a great people -- I just know the Russians will make it") or dubious myths ("They've always been expansionist -- sooner or later they'll try to rebuild their empire").
For all of us who dabble in trying to divine whither Russia, Daniel Yergin and Thane Gustafson have performed an invaluable service. No, they do not discover where Russia is headed. What they do in "Russia 2010" is to play out "what would happen if . . ." -- if Russia continues as is, if a nationalist government comes to power, if the military comes to power, if Chernobyl blows again, if President Yeltsin is assassinated -- and they do it in a way non-Kremlinologists will have no trouble following. Mr. Yergin is the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of "The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money, and Power," in which he demonstrated a talent for parlaying cold research into a snappy yarn. Mr. Gustafson is a professor of government at Georgetown University and the author of several books on the Soviet Union.
Essentially, the authors set up a methodology for intelligent prophesying -- sorting out the myths from the social, political and economic forces at play in Russia, then stacking those forces up in different ways and throwing in the odd surprise. The year 2010 was chosen, they explain, because that will mark the 25th anniversary of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's rise to power.
Mr. Yergin and Mr. Gustafson tell us that their book grew out of studies done by Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting firm of which they are, respectively, president and director. The work shows symptoms of haste, as if the authors hurried to expand one or more studies into a book and did not have time to smooth the transitions or order the concepts. Some chapters are scenarios, some are straightforward analysis, some are commentaries on how American policy should be shaped.
The work also has the obvious disadvantage of dealing with a moving target. It was written before Mr. Yeltsin scattered the Congress of People's Deputies, and it will be read after the results of the parliamentary elections are known.
But these weaknesses do not really detract from the usefulness or enjoyment of the book. Changing events, in fact, only make it more like a sophisticated board game, challenging the reader to deduce how the shifting factors might alter the various scenarios.
The scenarios account for only 56 pages of the book, but they are its real core, and what elevates it above the bloated body of available works on Russia. There are four of them, and each is written from the vantage point of the year 2010, tracing events that brought Russia either to collapse, civil war, a military regime or miraculous prosperity.
At one extreme is what the authors call the "Russian Bear" scenario: The date is May 17, 2010, and a military parade is being held in Red Square to mark the eighth anniversary of the army coup. Double-headed eagles glint from tanks and the Kremlin towers, and banners read "Hail to Our Supreme Commander and to the Glorious Russian Army."
At the other extreme is "Chudo," Russian for "miracle": May 17, 2010, in this scenario marks the inauguration of a state-of-the-art trading center for the Moscow Stock Exchange, at which the head of Russia's largest bank announces the acquisition of the seventh largest bank in the United States.
The scenarios in between range from the slow unwinding of the Russian state under political and economic paralysis to a Russia ruled by an authoritarian alliance of bureaucrats, defense industrialists, state industry managers, the army and the police.
Anyone who is at all familiar with Russia is certain to find points of argument, to disagree with the plausibility of a development, to question a conclusion. But that is very much part of the fun -- moving or changing the building blocks of a model and wondering what emerges.
That is also the usefulness of the study. Though Mr. Yergin and Mr. Gustafson map out scenarios ranging from civil war to prosperity, they identify several realities that will exist in 2010 no matter what road Russia takes.
One is heartening: "Under all scenarios, Russia is likely to keep up its gradual return to the world economy." Another is discouraging: "There will be no strong agricultural revival in Russia by 2010, even if farming becomes largely private. The countryside has been so systematically emptied of its best people that many areas are incapable of supporting modern agriculture."
Ultimately, both of these conclusions derive as much from analysis as from instinct and imagination. Having spent the better part of 13 years in Moscow, this reviewer found each of the scenarios intriguing and plausible, less for the facts and figures than for the appreciation of the many intangible factors that shape modern Russia.
The oft-invoked "Russian character" does play a big role in these models, but as a consequence of concrete factors, not as some hereditary handicap. The authors write: "The reasons why chaos has not broken out in Russia have little to do with 'Russian stolidity,' 'stoicism' or other supposed traits of Russian national character. Rather, enough of the old system still survives, and enough of a new one has emerged, to keep most people fed, clothed, housed -- and busy."
Above all, Mr. Yergin and Mr. Gustafson understand that Russia's future will be shaped by its own unique past and present, however frustrating this may appear from the sidelines: "Ultimately, of course, Russia will make its own history. . . . The evolution of Russian politics will be a Russian game, played mostly by Russian players, and largely over Russian issues."
But with their book as guide, we can at least follow that game.
 
 
 
AN IMPERIAL CONSCIOUSNESS
 Russia faces a fundamental challenge in the coming years. It is to find a new identity in an era when the rebirth of nationalism and ethnicity is the central and frequently destabilizing factor in all the former Communist countries. Russia dominated its neighbors for hundreds of years; its sense of national identity and national interests arose in conjunction with its imperial destiny, and was inseparable from it. Russia is a very significant military power and will remain so for the foreseeable future. It retains a vast nuclear arsenal and a large conventional force. . . .
But Russia has yet to fully accept that it has lost its empire -- indeed, many do not yet recognize the loss -- and it will take years to fully digest this fact. It will take more than diminished means to change Russia's self-perception as an imperial state. After all, one could argue that some in France retain an imperial consciousness, even though France gave up its empire in 1958. But for Russia, unlike France, the former empire lies just beyond its borders, remains economically part of it and contains 25 million of its own people.
To make matters still more difficult, Russia has not only lost its external and internal empire, it must now deal on an equal footing with former subject states whose own history of independence and statehood is somewhat ambiguous. Russia will only become a post-imperial state if the forces that propelled it to empire are no longer operative in the next century and it can coexist with its immediate neighbors. From "Russia 2010."

HEADLINE: What Was Eating Jim Beard?

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial; Frank J. Prial writes about wine for The New York Times.

 BODY:

JAMES BEARD
A Biography.
By Robert Clark.
357 pp. New York:
HarperCollins Publishers. $27.50. 
 IN an afterword to his painstaking and admirably unvarnished life of one of America's best-known food authorities, Robert Clark finally acknowledges that it's not easy to say just who or what James Beard really was.
"Words like chef, cooking teacher and food writer all came to mind," he writes in "James Beard: A Biography," "yet these were all labels that failed to capture entirely what he was, or what he did." What's more, Mr. Clark maintains, they were labels that "he himself often detested." Rather lamely, he concludes: "In the end, Beard's measure may now consist less of his achievements or occupations than of the things he came to symbolize."
In fact, neither James Beard's achievements nor his occupations were insignificant. He wrote 22 books. Half are still in print, and several remain classics of the food-writing genre. Throughout his long life, he fought for honesty and simplicity in the kitchen. He championed fresh native ingredients over watered-down industrial products, and although he loved France, he loved simple American cooking even more.
When he died in 1985 at the age of 81, Craig Claiborne, one of his proteges, praised him in The New York Times as "an innovator, an experimenter, a missionary in bringing the gospel of good cooking to the home table."
In 1946, he initiated America's first television program on food. His classes, in New York, in California, in his native Oregon and as far afield as the Gritti Palace in Venice, brought his skills and enthusiasm to three generations of cooks, both amateur and professional. He was generous with his time and knowledge -- a rare trait in the narrow world of food writing, a milieu notorious for its pettiness and infighting.
Few if any American cooks can say they have never been influenced by James Beard, whether it was through his books, his television and radio appearances, his newspaper columns or his cooking classes. But there was a darker side to the gentle culinary giant (6 feet 2 inches tall, well over 300 pounds). He was a frustrated singer and actor who never subdued his craving for center stage. Freelance food writing is not now, nor was it ever, particularly lucrative. So James Beard became a shill for the food industry, whose products he often loathed. In the years when an article for a food magazine might have earned him $500, a product endorsement, which involved no work, might bring in $10,000.
He became adept, Mr. Clark writes, "at reducing the actual cash costs of living by amassing trade-offs, favors and freebies." A plug for Air France in his book "Paris Cuisine" defrayed travel costs to Europe "for the next few years."
At one time or another, according to Mr. Clark, Jim Beard worked for or endorsed Adolph's Meat Tenderizer, Skotch Cooler picnic containers, Green Giant canned and frozen vegetables, French cognac, Old Crow whisky, Pillsbury, Restaurant Associates, Time-Life Books, Spice Islands, American Airlines, Planters Peanuts, Swift & Company, Du Pont, Shasta Beverages, Corning Glass, Jenn-Air kitchen ranges and Omaha Steaks International, among many other companies.
He had few illusions about this work. In revelatory moments he could refer to himself as "the world's greatest gastronomic whore." But in a speech he gave in the early 1960's, Beard said, and apparently with a straight face: "I think it is safe to say that in the majority of our homes food is appetizing, healthful and tasty. Without our food writers, backed by our great food industry, this would not be true."
James Beard was born in Portland, Ore., and never lost his love for the Pacific Northwest, its climate, its beaches and, above all, its food. In later life he would return there often to renew his energy and recapture a bit of his youth.
When he tired of the New York life, he would talk of opening a country restaurant or of doing the kind of literate food books that M. F. K. Fisher wrote. Nothing came of these reveries. Mr. Clark writes: "Even James's fantasies of a quiet and decent life of craftsmanship were, as he would be the first to recognize, tinged by a purplish undercurrent of grandiosity, greed and cynicism."
In Mr. Clark's hands, Beard is often sad, occasionally embarrassing but never dull. Nor for that matter are any of the supporting players in the story, from Poppy Cannon, whom he calls "America's first lady of the freezer," to Dione Lucas, "queen of the omelet," to Julia Child, "a droll six-footer with a Seven Sisters tone." (Beard was no slouch himself in the sharp-phrase department. His description of one female competitor: "Bitchery incarnate.")
Mr. Clark, a former editor of The Journal of Gastronomy, portrays James Beard against a backdrop of America's postwar infatuation with food. A conscientious researcher as well as a rattling good writer, he traces the social and economic forces that produced Betty Crocker and the Four Seasons, frozen peas and the Galloping Gourmet. He has given us a vivid portrait of a sometimes bizarre but ultimately fascinating man of our times. But his real achievement is having produced a valuable and thoroughly engrossing work of contemporary cultural history.

GRAPHIC: Photo: James Beard at his home in Manhattan in 1976. (ROBERT M. KLEIN)

HEADLINE: SUNDAY, December 26, 1993;
Dollars That Make Sense

 BODY:
It's no secret that America's monetary policy is a mess. Not the policy set by the Federal Reserve; the one made by the United States Mint. The problem is the penny and the dollar.
Pennies are so unpopular that something like 6 billion, give or take a billion or two, disappear each year (last year, 9 billion were produced). Presumably they run off to mate with lost socks. The dollar bill is also getting tiresome (for people lucky enough to have them in bulk). The Southern California Transit District sells crumpled dollars at 97 cents each to a subcontractor who unwrinkles them by hand. Anti-dollar bill advocates claim that a dollar coin could save the Government $395 million or more a year. The clean policy seems obvious: Ban the bill. Drop the penny. What's the problem? 
 Well, with money nothing is ever simple. Over time, pennies have lost much of their value to inflation but they are still a source of profit for the Mint. They cost less than a penny to make and distribute. And then there is the zinc lobby. Since 1982, pennies, only coated with copper, have been made almost entirely of zinc, which has helped pull the zinc industry through some rough times.
As to the dollar coin, which is once again under consideration by Congress, it is still in bad odor because of the Susan B. Anthony dollar, which felt too much like a quarter and thus became the Edsel of coins.
There is, however a way out of both of these problems. If the mint got rid of the dollar bill, people would have to use the dollar coin. If the dollar coin were different in size, feel and color from a quarter, it would not be a source of confusion. And if the dollar coins were made out of zinc, the loss of the penny market would be nullified. Then just about everybody should be happy.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN THE ARTS: Architecture/1993;
A Year More Remarkable For What (or Who) Was Destroyed Than for What Was Built

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp

 BODY:
New World Disorder -- From the World Trade Center to the Mostar Bridge, images of exploding buildings dominated 1993, each hinting more graphically than the year's new buildings at some larger story that began with the end of the cold war and is still unfolding.
 
Stone, Brick and Savagery -- In Washington, the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, designed by James Ingo Freed, rose to the excruciating challenge of making art out of the unspeakable. 

Coming and Going -- Urban decentralization and downtown renewal collided imaginatively in Ohio in Peter Eisenman's Greater Columbus Convention Center, a building whose serpentine roof snakes across the city's edge like an inner state freeway.
 
Yes, in My Back Yard -- In Phoenix, an ambitious program that joins art to infrastructure reached a high point with the opening of a recycling center, designed by the artists Linnea Glatt and Michael Singer to transform a landfill into a landmark.
 
Disfigured Landscape -- Despite protests from architects and scholars over an addition to the Salk Institute for Biological Sciences in La Jolla, Calif., bulldozers moved in to demolish a eucalyptus grove that formed the symbolic entrance to Louis Kahn's radiant fusion of architecture, land, sea and sky.
 
Book of the Year -- "Architecture Culture 1943-1968," Joan Ockman's documentary account of postwar modernism, revealed the creative ferment of a period often dismissed as sterile, and sketched an intellectual genealogy for today's emerging architects.
 
Hello to All That -- Frank Gehry remodeled his Santa Monica house, a building that inspired a generation of architects and will continue to invigorate those who value architecture as an art of living.
 
A Loss -- The death of Robert Wagner Jr., a veteran politician and urbanist who was expected to guide the city planning policies of New York Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, cast gloom over those who were counting on Mr. Wagner to revive New York's lapsed coalition between political leadership and urban design.

HEADLINE: What a Police Force Should Look Like

 BODY:
Re: "Nassau's New Police Officers Shape Up" [Dec. 12], it is important for us in Nassau and Suffolk Counties to recognize that employment discrimination is a source of tension in police-community relations. This is so primarily because it makes our police departments appear to be all-white, or predominantly white, institutions in the eyes of racial-minority communities.
The basis of support for policing our society must come from all citizens. Given this basic tenet, it follows that police agencies should be representative of the populations they serve. To be otherwise diminishes their ability to respond empathetically to many community concerns and reinforces the perception held by some segments of the minority public that law-enforcement agencies represent the force of the dominant society, to preserve the status quo. 
 The importance of minority police officers cannot be overemphasized. It is not only a question of equal access to an economically desirable government position, but it is also a question of effective policing. It is extremely difficult for members of an underrepresented group to view the police as being responsive to their needs, free of prejudice and interested in the cause of justice if they do not see members of their group on the force. The importance of ethnic identification makes it essential that the agents of justice reflect the characteristics of the community.
It's encouraging to see 38 blacks, Hispanics and females in the current 200-member Nassau County Police Department recruit class. This good feeling is jaded somewhat inasmuch as this fact necessitated a Federal lawsuit by the Nassau County Guardians in conjunction with the U.S. Justice Department alleging bias in the testing process. However, the end product is a positive one -- opening the door to a police agency truly representative of all Nassau's citizens.
 
JAMES J. GREEN
Farmingdale
 
The writer is an assistant professor of criminal justice at St. Thomas Aquinas College in Sparkill, N.Y.
