SECTION: Section 10; Page 5; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1289 words

HEADLINE: Seizing the Moment for a Shorter-Term Mortgage

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON

 BODY:
JOHN McCREADY says that he was born and brought up in the South Bronx and that "because of that fantastic education, you always know when you're being taken and when you're not."
So when mortgage rates began to plummet, he and his wife, Rita, who own a red and white aluminum-sided house in New Rochelle, N.Y., started reading the financial pages every day, watching the mortgage rates and examining the deals being offered by competing banks. 
 "It was driving me crazy," said the 42-year-old Mr. McCready. "I was paying $1,400 a month on a $150,000, 30-year mortgage and after four years I still owed $148,000. Even my bookie gives me better odds."
Like millions of other Americans, the McCreadys decided the time was ripe to refinance their house. And like about half of the homeowners who chose a fixed-rate mortgage, they took one for 15 years.
Donna Calejon, a senior vice president of the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae), which purchases home mortgages from primary lenders, said that 15- and 30-year refinancings were "running almost neck and neck" in popularity. Last week Fannie Mae officials estimated that while the number of refinancings by homeowners would decline in 1994, there is expected to be a 17 percent rise in new mortgages -- those obtained to finance a purchase.
In all this activity, the movement toward shorter-term mortgages is clear: In October 1990, 12,400 families signed up for a Fannie Mae-approved 15- or 20-year mortgage; in October, 106,997 families turned to these shorter-term mortgages. A spokesman last week reported a "steady increase" in 15-year fixed-rate purchase mortgages.
"It isn't spiking up like the 15-year refinances, but it's steady growth," he said. Overall, 62 percent of Fannie Mae's 1993 business has been refinancing; purchase mortgages made up the rest.
Mortgage brokers and real estate agents said that for the first-time younger buyer, the 30-year mortgage was still the mortgage of choice. And the young person with an entry-level job still may choose a variable-rate mortgage, with the lowest monthly payment of all. They said the buyer interested in a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage was usually financially secure, with a larger income but with less need for the longer-term tax breaks the 30-year mortgage allowed.
"We're seeing more and more buyers taking advantage of the 15-year option, but it's a sophisticated market," said Margie Wexler, an agent at Julia B. Fee, a Westchester brokerage. "We counsel them about what it takes to qualify; we may recommend a bank or a mortgage broker for them to talk with."
While customers shopping for year-end mortgage deals will not find the "free" appraisals available several years ago, there are nevertheless some deals around.
Mortgage brokers say that there are variations between banks and that even the most conservative keep an eye on their equally conservative competition. Many people don't know, said Ronnie Goldstein, a regional mortgage broker, that banks have sales quotas and may offer established customers slight savings to "make it worth their while" to close by a certain day.
MS. GOLDSTEIN worked with one couple seeking a sizable mortgage who didn't care whether they closed by the end of this year or the beginning of the next. But the bank did, and shaved an eighth of a point off their rate as an incentive.
Sol Waxman, a mortgage broker who serves Manhasset and Manhattan, said some banks offered the best-qualified buyers loans up to 100 percent of the current value of their home, rather than the conventional 80 percent. This lets someone whose house has decreased in value switch to keep the same mortgage amount at today's lower rates.
The McCreadys are an example of buyers who did their homework. With mortgage rates lower than they have been in decades, they found that they could cut in half the life of the existing mortgage and still have the same pre-tax-deduction monthly payment by switching the interest rate from 10.875 percent to 7.75 percent through refinancing.
Their loan balance is now declining far more rapidly -- by about $460 a month at present. By the time the McCreadys' son and daughter, now 5 and 3, go off to college, the mortgage will be almost paid off.
Over the 15 years of their new $150,000 loan, the McCreadys will pay a total of $254,145, including the extra charges for appraisals and processing. If they had kept their old 30-year mortgage at the higher rate, they would have paid a total of $509,162 -- almost twice as much. He estimated his savings, after tax deductions, at about $170,000 with the shorter-term mortgage.
Ira Drosnin, a 48-year-old Manhattan accountant, is an example of the sophisticated first-time buyer with the income to afford the higher payments of the 15-year fixed-rate mortgage. He and his wife, Roberta, a vice president at Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, just traded their large, but noisy, rent-stabilized one-bedroom apartment at 34th Street and Third Avenue for a house on Shore Acres Drive in the Rye Neck section of Mamaroneck, across the street from Long Island Sound.
"We just bought a Jeep," he said. "We're having culture shock and we haven't even moved in yet." Mr. Drosnin said he originally had told the mortgage broker he wanted a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage.
"BUT being an accountant, I naturally ran the numbers through a computer program, and the total payments are hundreds of thousands of dollars less," he said. "Sure, you get the tax write-off for 15 years longer, but nobody's in the 100 percent tax bracket . . . " He paused. "Yet."
In 15 years, Mr. Drosnin will turn 63, he said, "a nice time for the mortgage to be paid off and to live rent-free."
Susan Severance, who sells advertising for a magazine, thought she could manage the extra 6 percent a month for her 15-year mortgage. "It's not so different," she said. "It's half a car payment."
Ms. Severance, who is 40 and has short blond hair and a friendly, husky voice, explained that because of the poor real estate market, she and her husband, Steven Esformes, "took a bath" on selling their smaller house: they had paid $168,000 for it and sold it for $138,000.
But the market worked for them when they went to buy a bigger house in South Orange, N.J. The 5,000-square-foot, 7-bedroom 1921 colonial revival would have sold for close to $500,000 in the heyday of the 80's, she said, but they paid $300,000 -- and it is three times bigger than their other house.
"It's a cool house in a really cool area," Ms. Severance said. "We made out great. If we didn't have a 15-year mortgage I'd have to keep working forever. We wouldn't pay it off until I was dead. These are our peak earning years, and we want to make the whole thing as short and painless as possible."
Dr. Vito Guarnaccia, a consulting psychologist in White Plains, wants to make his repayment even shorter. He just closed on a large refinanced mortgage to cover both his house and a $250,000 home equity loan he took out a couple of years ago to invest in garden apartment condominiums -- and hopes to pay it back in "eight or nine years."
Dr. Guarnaccia said that with the $250,000 home equity loan, he could deduct only up to $100,000 on his income tax, but with the new refinanced loan at 6.875 percent, he can deduct the whole thing. Deductions are limited to $100,000 on home equity loans.
Obviously, his home's value was supported by the bank appraisal. Those whose houses are not worth as much as they are trying to borrow will be denied the new loan.
"Everyone is saying they are waiting for interest rates to hit rock bottom," Dr. Guarnaccia said. "But the day they reach bottom means the next day they start climbing."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PROFILE;
Officer Revisits His Old, New Neighborhood

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

 BODY:
Vincent Mansfield, who grew up in Flushing more than two decades ago, just landed a job in his old neighborhood. But things have changed since his youth, when the Gertz department store was Main Street's retail giant and the RKO Keith's movie theater packed in matinee crowds.
Many of the mom-and-pop stores are gone, replaced with gleaming Asian banks and restaurants. And scores of temples, mosques and churches, many of them serving new immigrants, have opened. 
 "The differences are very visible," Captain Mansfield said one morning last week, just days after he became commander of the 109th Precinct. "There's a real difference in the flavor of the neighborhood. It definitely makes me feel old."
Still, some things haven't changed. Drag racing continues along Francis Lewis Boulevard. And, he noted, "There are still the two pizza parlors that I went to as a teen-ager."
Captain Mansfield, who is 47 years old, assumed the new post after spending more than two years as commander of the 112th Precinct in Forest Hills, a less diverse and more middle-class area.
He says there are many challenges ahead of him as he charts the future for the 109th Precinct, which has more than 300 officers and clerical workers serving an area that is undergoing a dramatic cultural and economic transformation amid a tide of immigration.
Captain Mansfield says he plans to build upon the legacy of his predecessor, Deputy Inspector John Timony, who is credited with fostering better relations between the area's new Asian immigrants, many of them from Korea and China, and the precinct's officers.
Deputy Inspector Timony, for instance, hired more Asian-American officers and clerical workers to strengthen ties between the precinct and the neighborhood's newcomers.
"Without question, that will be a top priority," Captain Mansfield said.
He said the nature of police work is changing. He likened it to the changes in doctor-patient relationships, with physicians having to be less dictatorial and more receptive to patients' needs and desires.
Above all, though, he says he wants to focus on the problems that have always concerned people in Flushing, College Point, Whitestone and other neighborhoods within the 109th Precinct: burglary, graffiti, loitering, public drunkenness and car theft.
Under his command at the 112th Precinct, officers reduced car thefts by 613, or 16 percent, during his last year there, he said.
"These are the issues that affect the fabric of the city," he said.
Before Captain Mansfield makes any moves, though, he acknowledges that he has more immediate concerns within the 109th Precinct station house itself.
"I got to get to know who the cops are around here first," he said. RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

GRAPHIC: Photo: Capt. Vincent Mansfield is returning to Flushing as commander of the 109th Precinct. (Rebecca Cooney for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX;
Can a Mayor Make a Difference?

 BODY:
NEXT weekend, Rudolph W. Giuliani will be inaugurated as the 107th mayor of New York City. There will be hoopla and many bold words.
But can a mayor really make a difference? Fiscal monitors judge his every move. An ailing economy puts him in a box. Strong unions tie his hands. And AIDS, drugs and poverty are problems hardly unique to New York. Can a mayor really set a course for the city? 
 Some New Yorkers were asked to answer the question and predict what's ahead for the next four years.
 
THE REV. JOHN J. JENIK , the pastor of Our Lady of Refuge Roman Catholic Church in Fordham-Bedford Park, the Bronx, has organized boycotts of stores that were drug fronts.
 
THERE is no will to fight crime anymore. No municipal will. No community will. People are too frightened. It permeates the whole system. Our past mayors -- I don't know where their mind-sets were. Possibly they let it happen because they live in areas not affected by this. Where is the planning coming from? We need some Draconian measures -- property rights have to be weighed against the well-being of the community. Right now, if a man is selling drugs from a store, you can't shut it down -- they say he doesn't own the space, he just rents it.
The right mayor can be an advocate for the people suffering under laws that do not help them in crisis. People want to hear some assurances that they are safe on their own streets. A mayor can help make the institutional environment very hostile to anybody involved in drugs who is going to come before an agency.
An effort will be made to get some of the drug dealers off the street. But the energy will be dissipated. There's not enough money for guards. The courts will become overcrowded. It will just take too much energy. It's like building a power station without the lines to carry the power.
 
ANGELO FALCON , a political scientist, is president and founder of the institute for Puerto Rican Policy, a nonprofit, nonpartisan policy center based in New York City.
 
A MAYOR makes a tremendous difference. Whoever is mayor has to take to the stage of city government, much as does an actor, to creatively play out the daily drama and comedy of a city wrapped up so tightly that it is always in danger of being committed. A mayor can capture this collective imagination and energy to make more substantive changes possible.
As for more substantive changes, a mayor can make a difference if he or she does not mind being a one-termer -- the ultimate civic sacrifice, made necessary by the many strong constituencies on both sides of almost every issue. Ironically, this quixotic attitude may be rewarded by New Yorkers. Conditioned to expect high levels of cynicism, they may reward a more straightforward approach.
How Mayor Giuliani deals with the racial-ethnic divide will define whether he will make a difference. Unfortunately, his actions will be driven by his re-election and the fact of his razor-thin margin of victory this time around. This would mean the fiscal sleight of hand we have become accustomed to, the search for a more solid majority of the vote that could reach out to Latinos at the expense of blacks, and the continual caving in to the city's rich and powerful.
 
CAVERLY STRINGER , who says he "sleeps here and there," is the senior editor of Street News.
 
I DON'T want anything from a mayor. I don't see being on the street as the Great American Tragedy, but others are terrified. It's not something a mayor can solve. People are going on drugs in droves because they're spiritually empty. They just cop out.
You can't legislate humanity. Things now are very secular and very selfish -- it's them against us. We're all trying to draw in the wagons and protect our turf. That's doomed to fail. A mayor can create an environment that says, "No, it's not acceptable to say, 'This is my side of the street and leave me alone.' " But how is he going to get elected?
Mayors are like the change in weather to me. You have to gear yourself up for atmospheric changes, but you still have to get through the day-to-day. Sometimes mayors have an impact. They told people to stop giving to panhandlers in midtown, so the panhandlers followed the money uptown to the neighborhoods.
Giuliani is provoking more of a them-versus-us thing. You've got his police commissioner saying he'll take back the streets door to door. He may let an element of fascism in. The new commissioner says New Yorkers want discipline. But what's going on is that they want to homogenize, purify the society.
I witnessed something the other night. A gentleman was drinking a beer on Ninth Avenue. A cop jumped out of a car and said put it down. He smashed the beer. He said: "There's a new program here. We're gonna get rid of scum like you, then the crackheads and others like you."
There are people waiting for this to happen. But you can't be a leader and pander to that.
 
RICHARD GREEN is head of the Crown Heights Youth Collective.
 
THE mayor sets the tone, the temperament, the intensity. He sets the level of consciousness.
These young people are more politically astute than you think. Theymake determinations. They will look at the new City Hall to see if this is an improved product.
In the last four years, they saw beacon schools and they saw outreach. You walk into a youth services office now and young people are greeting you. They're involved. They see a commissioner walking the streets with them, a hot line to call. Now they can relate to what youth services is about. Is it going to change? If it gets better they're happy with it. We got 1,000 summer jobs in Crown Heights in 1992. It would not have happened unless Dinkins picked up the slack. Because of the Safe Street/Safe Cities program, cops and youth get along better.
With Giuliani, the first thing is we'll sit down and talk. I think he wants to figure out what's working. I pray this is what's going to happen. If you inherit the Philharmonic, you don't change the musicians. You've got to play into the character of the city. Basically, he'll stand pat.
 
MARY A. CUMMINS , a member of the District 24 school board in Queens, led the fight against Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez over a curriculum that included teaching respect for gay people.
 
I LOOK around the city and, I tell you, to try to clean it up would make cleaning out the Augean stables seem like a light dusting job. Can a mayor make a difference? In some things, yes. In others, no. He can show leadership. That's the main thing anyone can do as the head of a government. If you can show leadership, then I think you can get some things done. A lot depends on the people he appoints. That is the most powerful thing he can do. Frankly, with the city in the state that it is in, I don't know why anyone would want the job.
Giuliani remains to be seen. Of course, I voted for George Marlin, but I have an open mind. Dinkins was a farce. I had an open mind about him, but he fell short. Anybody could. We won't know for sure until he's been in there awhile.
 
MATT LEE is the executive director of Inner City Press/Community on the Move, an advocacy group for low-income housing.
 
THE mayor means very little. The basic relations of power stay the same. New York is so dependent on financial services and the global economy that mayors have to be supplicants to businesses. There is a fixation on financial services. But ghetto people are not getting those jobs.
The root problem is the lack of a long-term power base in low-income communities. Mayors, because of political pressures, do not understand this. Dinkins did boost money to community groups, but it was like staring into a mirror. His people only talked to the people who agreed with them.
A lot of big groups in the South Bronx get a fee by becoming the marketing agent for middle-income housing. If they stop being the sponsor, they lose power. Instead of saying, "This housing is not affordable to people who live here," they end up saying it's going to be thrown down anyway, so we might as well become the marketing agent. By building housing in a way that doesn't build indigenous power, there is no grass-roots political structure to constantly advocate what needs to be done.
Under Giuliani, community groups will be more willing to fight City Hall since they'll be less concerned about making the city's first African-American mayor look bad. Low-income groups were in Dinkins's back pocket. The idea was just to your piece of the action.
 
TONY HISS , a staff writer for The New Yorker, is the author of "The Experience of Place." (Vintage)
 
I'VE lived on Eighth Street in Greenwich Village almost all my life and watched it go from distinguished to so-so to chaotic. Next year, the city will let the Village Alliance start a privately financed Business Improvement District on Eighth Street, with its own security and sanitation crews. To announce this plan, the alliance has put up Christmas lights and holiday banners along Eighth Street and St. Marks Place, from Sixth Avenue to Second Avenue. The lights are looped to form giant snowflakes.
This tiny and very temporary change has been casting its own magic spell. Instead of hurrying by, people look up and smile, and then grin at each other; months before the new street cleaners go to work, there's already less trash underfoot. Somehow the lights have reconnected Eighth Street to itself, reminding people that this is the Main Street of a world-famous neighborhood.
New Yorkers are especially fed up right now. But it's at times like these that a new mayor can make a difference, if he connects to the people who are already trying to make a difference. I see neighborhoods all over the city taking tiny, first steps that will (with a mayor's help) bring on dramatic changes. I think Mayor Giuliani will find himself sponsoring street-smart ideas like putting up white street lights in place of these sickly yellow ones that make shadows darker. A truly safe street is a street you can take pride in.
 
REPRESENTATIVE SUSAN MOLINARI , a Republican, represents Staten Island and a part of Brooklyn.
 
THE mayor matters terrifically. It is one of the most important positions in the country, if not the world. New York's ability to rise and fall gives or deletes hope for other cities. If New York can survive, others can, too. New York should be setting urban priorities in America. We have got to be more of a national player. Also, the mayor can create a environment so that businesses will move to and stay in the city. The mayor can set priorities. If Rudy had been elected in 1989, perhaps we wouldn't be dealing with the budget problem today. We wouldn't be dealing with a demoralized police force.
I predict Rudy will make four years of terrifically unpopular decisions that will leave our city stronger and him a mayor for the history books. It is more important to him to restore the city than be popular. In Washington the city is seen as sloppy. There are so many instances of the misuse of money or the city's failing to access Federal money with the same resolve as other cities. On the Federal level, Rudy's resolve will engender good will.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF;
They Came, They Saw, They Built a City

 BODY:
NEW YORK is a city of immigrants, and the stories of its immigrants could fill a very large bookshelf. Here are some starters.Most of these books are at New York Bound Bookshop (50 Rockefeller Plaza, 212 245-8503); and many can be found in other stores.

CHINATOWN: A PORTRAIT OF A CLOSED SOCIETY by Gwen Kinkead (Harper Collins).
This book covers a wide range of Chinese experiences, from food to work to organized crime.
ADAPTING TO ABUNDANCE: JEWISH IMMIGRANTS, MASS CONSUMPTION AND THE SEARCH FOR AMERICAN IDENTITY by Andrew R. Heinze (Columbia University Press).
A deconstructive history of a group of immigrants who experienced wealth for the first time, and how consumerism and the immigrants' traditional values faced off.
CARIBBEAN NEW YORK: BLACK IMMIGRANTS AND THE POLITICS OF RACE by Philip Kasinitz (Cornell University Press).
An examination of American and Caribbean blacks, and a look into West Indian neighborhoods.
ELLIS ISLAND TO EBBETS FIELD: SPORT AND THE AMERICAN JEWISH EXPERIENCE by Peter Levine (Oxford University Press).
The stories of Jewish-American sports stars, from the days when Hank Greenberg and Sandy Koufax were baseball heroes.
THE ITALIANS OF GREENWICH VILLAGE by Donald Tricario (Center for Migration Studies).
A study of second-generation Italian-Americans and their adaptation to American life.
LITTLE GERMANY: ETHNICITY, RELIGION AND CLASS IN NEW YORK CITY by Stanley Nadel (University of Illinois Press).
A history of Kleindeutschland, the German enclave in the Lower East Side, home to 350,000 Germans at its height in the mid-19th century.
THE DEMOGRAPHICS OF IMMIGRATION by Nadia H. Youssef (Center for Migration Studies).
An analysis of the demographic, social and economic characteristics of immigrant groups in New York.
DOWN THESE MEAN STREETS by Piri Thomas (Vintage Press).
A true story of a Puerto Rican boy's struggle in East Harlem.
BROWNSVILLE by Alter F. Landesman (Bloch Press).
A study of Brownsville, Brooklyn, which was rural in the late 19th century, and by 1925 was the largest Jewish section of New York.
AROUND THE WORLD IN NEW YORK by Konrad Bercovici (out of print). The author shares what he learned about Syrian, Greek, Chinese, Hungarian and Czech New York.
NEW IMMIGRANTS IN NEW YORK edited by Nancy Foner (Columbia University Press).
Essays on the experience of immigrants from Asia, Latin America, the West Indies and Russia since 1965.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BEDFORD PARK;
Living Where Edison Filmed

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

 BODY:
Construction of a much-awaited apartment building for the low-income elderly was completed earlier this month at the very spot where Thomas A. Edison's studio made movies nearly a century ago.
At least 40 tenants are expected to start moving into the new building, called the Edison Arms, next month. The building has 69 studio and one-bedroom apartments, all of them being rented for $400 a month to individuals or couples. 
 The $6 million construction project at Oliver Place and Decatur Avenue is being sponsored by the Fordham Bedford Housing Corporation, a community group, and by Fordham University.
The project is being financed with loans from the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development.
The sponsors of the project are continuing to interview prospective tenants for the remaining 19 apartments -- a process that began this summer with a lottery and that has received more than three applicants for each apartment.
The project began more than a year ago at a cost of $6 million. It has resurrected a lot that was overrun with litter and other debris ever since 1977, when the city demolished the vacant building that housed Edison's movie studio.
For years, residents and civic leaders complained that the lot was a persistent blemish on the landscape of a neighborhood that had been struggling to overcome years of urban deterioration and neglect.
"It was unsightly and it didn't engender a lot of pride for the people in the community," said Joe Muriana, the director of the university's Office of Government Relations and Urban Affairs.
The sponsors have been involved in other similar restoration projects, among them the Rose Hill Houses, another apartment building for the low-income elderly that the university sponsored in the area several years ago.
The university and the Fordham Bedford Housing Corporation had been pressing for development of the vacant lot where the new building stands and bought the property from the city in September 1992.
"We're hopeful that this project will be something that will help stabilize that part of the community," Mr. Muriana said.
"It'll be another element in shoring up a neighborhood that's been under a good deal of stress lately," he added. R.H.

HEADLINE: The World;
A World Unhinged Gropes for New Rules

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

 BODY:
AT a time when past certainties -- the constraints of totalitarianism and the comforts of faith -- either have been swept away or are under assault, Dostoyevskian thoughts about the fragility of the barrier between civilization and chaos come easily to mind.
In both Western Europe and North America, what might be called an age of unbelief has sharply challenged and eroded traditional religious, moral and ethical codes, and both economic and social change have put tremendous pressure on traditional family structures. Together with problems like racism and poverty in inner cities, these changes have been accompanied by horrendous crime rates and rampant drug use. 
 In the formerly Communist world, Marxist-Leninist social and political standards have been completely discredited, but new ones have not yet taken their place. Demoralized populations groping for values to guide them through a painful political and economic transition have grasped at the too-simple answers offered by ultranationalism -- in the bloodied lands of the former Yugoslavia and elsewhere. Many did so two weeks ago in Dostoyevsky's land, where parliamentary elections catapulted a man who evokes the worst of Hitler and Stalin alarmingly into the international limelight.
Civilization has been through periods of simultaneous political and religious upheaval, like the Hundred Years' War, before. Yet modern communications, modern weapons and modern Angst make the current one seem even more bewildering.
After all, religion is not dead; religious revivalists thrive in many parts of the world where traditional values clash with modern secular and commercial ones. But the struggle is the more turbulent for not having been resolved. Militant Islam is one answer thrown up by a traditional society's bewilderment at the intrusion of alien modern ideas, but its repressive answers to them -- indeed, its seeming embrace of terrorism in Iran, Egypt, and many other places, including the World Trade Center -- only add to the general sense of anomie.
 
Value-less
 For as old, traditional moral, ethical and religious values have been swept away, they have often been replaced by a relativistic ethos that is easily construed to mean "anything goes." St. Paul pointed out the inadequacies of this 2,000 years ago: "Where no law is, there is no transgression," he wrote to the Romans.
And so in America, "Greed is good" -- Gordon Gecko's motto in "Wall Street" -- was also a prevailing theme of the real-life 1980's, and small wonder that petty criminals who couldn't get in on the corporate boom went for whatever they could get on the streets. Inhibitions on criminal behavior are weakest where institutions like the family that convey values from one generation to the next have been most severely ravaged.
In the old Communist world, the loss of ethical norms was long masked by the monolithic grayness of corrupt totalitarianism. In the Soviet Union since Stalin's time, the Communist Party and the state laid down the law, telling citizens what to do, where to live and how to think. In the ideology, capitalism and "biznes" were the embodiment of evil. By the late 1980's, Communism was collapsing. Freedom replaced its strictures, but many of its values remained in place. Raised to believe that "biznes" was amoral and that capitalists could treat people any way they liked, many of the new "biznesmyeni" began acting more like Mafiosi than respectable entrepreneurs.
 
Losing Ground
 The ethical underpinnings that make civilized commercial transactions possible in the Western world -- binding contracts, fair dealing and so on -- take time to grow. But many ordinary Russians have concluded that President Boris N. Yeltsin's transition to a market economy means that black marketeers and criminals can careen through the streets in fat Mercedes limousines while the rest are reduced to selling old clothes to earn enough money to survive. And many expressed their dissatisfaction by voting for Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, a radical nationalist who promised to restore the glory days when Russia was a superpower.
Traditional structures seem to be losing ground everywhere. Prosperous Western Europe is seeing its previously accepted values eroded as it tries to come to terms with the end of the cold war, with the flood of refugees from economic and political chaos to the east, and with rising unemployment caused by the inadequacies of its welfare states in an era of sharp new competition with the Far East and Eastern Europe.
Dr. Elisabeth Noelle-Neumann, a German poll taker, recently recalled that in 1967, fully 71 percent of young Germans believed that children should be raised to do work "properly and conscientiously." By 1972, only 52 percent of them did. The Ten Commandments fared little better, Dr. Noelle-Neumann found: "The precepts according to which one should not use force, not lie, not steal were slowly but steadily eroded in West Germany between 1981 and 1990," she observed.
In officially atheist East Germany, as long as it was strict and Communist, this was not the case, and traditional middle-class German values survived there right up to 1990. So what, many might argue. East Germany was hardly a model in other ways, and German history from 1933 to 1945 proved that traditional values were no guarantee against evil. But a moral collapse of some kind lies behind the recent years of rising violence, predominantly by young Germans, against foreign workers and asylum-seekers in a country that had tolerated millions of Turkish "guest workers" for decades.
Religious leaders in Britain, alarmed that less that 2 percent of the population bothers with the Church of England anymore on Sundays, anguished this fall over whether the collapse of religious life could somehow explain how two boys in Liverpool could abduct, torture and kill an infant and leave his body on a railroad track.
But even the "God is dead" argument does not explain why a lonely black man would deliberately start shooting passengers on a commuter train in Long Island in early December just because they were white.
Explanations that make society's failings responsible for rising crime rates everywhere do not satisfy Alexander Schuller, a sociologist in Berlin who believes that something more fundamental, the darker side of human nature, is at work. "I believe like all theoreticians, theologians and students of human behavior that we carry evil within us and can commit evil," he told Der Spiegel magazine recently. "Differentiation between good and evil is a uniquely human trait, but good seems worn out. There's no reward in it anymore."
Some blame the media or the movies for the degeneration. Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York doesn't quite do that, but he wrote in The Los Angeles Times recently that "civility and sensibleness and feeling of community" had been "eclipsed by the dark images coming from the television screens."
Did we really desire so much violence, so much disgusting behavior, as we see on the programs Hollywood and television offer us? St. Paul might have said yes: "For the good that I would do, I do not; but the evil which I would not, that I do."
The age of unbelief is still groping for substitutes for religion and other traditional ways of keeping destructive human impulses under control. It is not clear whether it will find them.

HEADLINE: 20/20 Foresight Is Its Own Reward

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
NINETEEN NINETY-THREE will long be remembered as the year we finally got rid of all the people without a vision thing, and replaced them with a fresh crop of forward thinkers. Fresh President; fresh Congress; fresh cast of poohbahs and icons, all brimming with fresh visions of the future. Don't stop thinking about tomorrow, don't stop, it'll soon be here, dah-dah-dah-dah and so on. How recent it all seems.
And now tomorrow is here, and by and large, the events of 1993 have vindicated that foresight. With one or two exceptions, but, then, who's counting?
 

There was Somalia:
"We will always provide the other side an opportunity to lay down their weapons. If they do not, they face dire consequences."
Maj. General Charles E. Wilhelm, in January.
"Others are fully able to take our place without any change in the effectiveness of the operations on the ground."
Robert W. Oakley, the special envoy to Somalia, in January as United Nations forces prepared to take over the bulk of relief operations from American troops.
"The military back of Aidid has been broken."
President Clinton, in June.
 
And Bosnia:
"This is an important moment for our nation's post-cold-war role in Europe and the world. . . . By acting now, we can demonstrate that not every crisis needs to become a choice between inaction and unilateral American intervention."
Secretary of State Warren Christopher, in February.
 
Of course, anyone is entitled to a change of heart:
"Frankly, we come into office and find a situation in Bosnia that has already deteriorated to a point where the solution is, is almost beyond the grasp of any human instrument."
Mr. Christopher, in April.
 
And Haiti:
"Mr. Chairman, I think the last few weeks have seen some significant progress in the situation in Haiti."
Mr. Christopher, in April.
 
And last month's parliamentary elections in Russia:
"I have every confidence in the outcome. Every time, the Russian people have chosen reform over retrenchment, hope over fear, the future over the past."
Mr. Christopher, in October.

 Well, look, it's impossible to predict what some foreigners will do next. Domestic issues, on the other hand, are genuine terra firma.
 
Presidential appointments, for example:
"The choice of Zoe Baird to be Attorney General is the most inspired stroke of Bill Clinton's Cabinet-making."
Anthony Lewis, the New York Times columnist, after Ms. Baird's selection was announced in late December.
"It's no big deal."
Senator Orrin Hatch in January, making light of Ms. Baird's failure to pay taxes on salaries paid her nanny and driver.
"It's not a significant problem."
Senator Edward M. Kennedy.
"The Senate ought to be able to put up with a little controversy in the cause of civil rights, and go on to confirmation."
Mr. Clinton, in May, arguing that Lani Guinier was a shoo-in to head the Justice Department's civil-rights office.
"I don't think there's a problem."
Secretary of Defense Les Aspin, on whether he was about to be eased out of the Pentagon, in December, three days before he was eased out of the Pentagon.
"I think the way Bill Clinton picked his Cabinet says a lot about how he will make decisions."
Stan Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's pollster, after the President-elect disclosed his Cabinet selections at Christmas 1992.
 
Federal spending?
"Of the $500 billion, two-thirds of that came out of spending, and one-third out of revenues. And I have to tell you that that's about the right formula if you want to put together a deficit reduction plan."
Budget Director Leon Panetta, eight months before Mr. Clinton claimed victory with passage of a one-to-one mix of tax hikes and spending cuts.
 
Forget Government, then. At least Hollywood still offered role models:
"Michael Jackson is the least weird man I've ever known. If he has any eccentricities, he's larger than life, and some people just cannot accept that."
Elizabeth Taylor, in January.
"Harry's like a bowl of good soup. . . . and he's particularly good on a dark, cold night when things don't look too good."
Democratic strategist James Carville, in January, on Harry Bloodworth-Thomason, the Hollywood producer and presidential friend.
"I am suspicious of Hollywood friendships, but I'm not suspicious of theirs."
Jay Kriegel, senior vice president of CBS, on Mr. Thomason and his wife. A few months later, Mr. Thomason lost his White House pass after being tied to an effort to steer Presidential press charters to a travel agency he held an interest in.
"I feel good about the movie's potential, really and truly good about its potential."
Sid Ganis, marketing president for Columbia Pictures, last summer before the box-office tallies came in on the year's most expensive dud, "Last Action Hero."
But some of us never went to the movies much anyway.
"The U.S. is ready for a downward correction. . . . At best, New York will go sideways for the remainder of the year."
Bob Boaz, chief economist at Deacon Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd., in February, when the Dow Jones was puttering along at about 3,200. This month showed record closing highs, like 3,764.
Actually, a lot of us spent most of our time watching CNN's "Larry King Live":
"Perot will kill Gore."
Ed Rollins, the Republican consultant, before Mr. Gore bested Mr. Perot in a broadcast debate last month.
"They are resurrecting Perot just when the air was running out of his balloon."
The Rev. Jesse Jackson, just before Mr. Perot's debate performance sent his standing in opinion polls plummeting.
"We have the votes now."
Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the trade agreement's chief opponent, telling reporters on Nov. 8 that Nafta was dead.
 
And we wondered whether a fresh cast of leaders meant that politics was no longer the last refuge of scoundrels.
"Florio will win substantially. Whitman's offer of a 30-percent tax cut, she lost all credibility. Last year's hustle doesn't work."
Eleanor Clift, the journalist, in October, writing off Christine Todd Whitman's bid to become Governor of New Jersey.
"I am going to fully cooperate with the ethics committee, period."
Senator Bob Packwood, just after the Senate Ethics Committee started asking for his cooperation in the last days of 1992.
"I have never participated in, condoned, encouraged -- nor did I have any knowledge of -- any wrongdoing in my 1990 campaign for governor."
Oklahoma Gov. David Walters in April.
"Guilty."
Mr. Walters, in October, copping a plea on eight felony counts of campaign-law violations, as reported in the Daily Oklahoman.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
It's Confounded Change Calling Again, Honey!

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT is rare when a legal case has a direct impact on almost everybody in the United States, and it is even more unusual when it unleashes a torrent of change that is still under way 10 years later.
On New Years' Day, Americans will mark the 10th anniversary of just such a moment: the breakup of Ma Bell's monolithic telephone system. At 12:01 A.M. on Jan. 1, 1984, the American Telephone & Telegraph Company fulfilled the terms of its antitrust settlement with the Justice Department and officially turned over its local telephone monopoly to seven new and independent "Baby Bell" companies. 
 Now, just when people have gotten used to one brave new world of competition, Congress and the Clinton Administration are gearing up to rewrite the rules of telecommunications once again. Paradoxically, one of the casualties of that effort would be the breakup decree itself -- not because it failed, but because it was overtaken by the very revolution it helped foster.
Last week, Vice President Al Gore outlined a broad plan that calls for eliminating the legal barriers that currently separate the telephone, cable TV and broadcasting industries into balkanized fiefs. In addition, Mr. Gore praised bills now pending in Congress that would relax key restrictions in the Ma Bell consent decree barring the seven Baby Bells from providing long-distance service or manufacturing equipment.
Why is government acting? Largely because in the new digital world, many boundaries erected to protect the public interest are now simply insulating companies from competition. Local telephone companies and cable TV companies, both monopolies created in part by regulators, are now racing toward a similar vision of the information superhighway. Both want to offer a huge selection of channels, movies on demand and two-way voice and data communications. Hence the frenzied mating attempt by phone companies to buy or invest in cable TV systems outside their territories. Yet a host of state and Federal regulations still limit the extent to which either side can raid the other's markets.
Meanwhile, competition is heating up on other fronts. A new generation of wireless phones could in time compete directly with ordinary phones. In a challenge to the Bells, A.T.&T. is planning to buy the nation's largest cellular company, McCaw Cellular Communications.
TV broadcasters, using new digital technology, could soon be able to transmit data as well as entertainment. Satellites beaming more than 100 TV channels directly to home antennas no bigger than a pizza will be competing against cable TV by this summer.
 
Big Deals
 Gargantuan corporate deals were the order of the year. Last week the bidding war for Paramount Communications (a war bankrolled in part by Baby Bells) seemed close to resolution when the board of the entertainment giant tentatively agreed to merge with the partner it had resisted for months, QVC Network Inc. In earlier megadeals, Bell Atlantic agreed to buy Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable TV operator, and British Telecom bought a 20 percent stake in MCI Communications, signaling a movement toward global alliances.
The accelerating free-for-all poses some of the same difficult issues that the A.T.&T. divestiture did. Under the Bell System, high long-distance prices subsidized inexpensive basic service. After the breakup, some of those costs had to be shifted back to local customers so A.T.&T. could compete in long distance. And so, life became more complicated for Americans, many of whom believed with some reason that they already had the best phone system in the world. Virtually overnight, customers found that they couldn't simply go to one company for phone service. They had to choose a long-distance company. They had to buy their own phone. If something went wrong, many ran into a maze figuring out who to get to fix the problem. Was it the line or the equipment?
But for all the headaches, the breakup fostered healthy change. Long-distance prices plunged as A.T.&T. lost ground to rivals like MCI and Sprint. Customers can now choose from many kinds of telephones, and businesses from many advanced communications systems.
The Bell breakup had even more far-reaching effects. It established an entirely new canon of communications policy: replacing regulation with competition to guard the public interest. The opening of the long-distance and telephone-equipment markets is now the model for thinking about every other line of business, from cable TV to cellular phones. In the decade since the breakup, the United States has moved rapidly toward a free-wheeling information economy linking independent networks that operate at blinding speed.
But while the future may bring wondrous technology, it could also prove leaner and meaner for some. Just as many Americans live in rundown areas neglected by banks and developers, a brash world of purely market-driven communications could leave many in technology ghettos where it seems unprofitable to run fiber optics or advanced switching.
Today, local phone companies use billions of dollars of internal subsidies to underwrite inexpensive service for millions of people, just as Ma Bell used high long-distance charges to keep local service cheap. Today's local companies admit that they charge highly inflated "access charges" to link long-distance carriers with their customers, thereby keeping prices of basic telephone service low. But new competitors are eager to enter this $25 billion market, and industry experts agree they can easily undercut current prices.
Policymakers are seeking ways to incorporate the public interest in telecommunications, but there are no easy answers. One idea is to broaden "universal service" -- the affordable minimum -- to include more than just phones. Under a House bill, companies competing in a local telephone market would contribute to a pool of money for universal service, and carriers serving customers at artificially low prices would be compensated from the fund.
How such complicated changes would work in practice is unclear, but it is safe to say that for some people, the second wave of competition could prove just as jarring as the original breakup. If customers are mystified over the difference between MCI's "Friends and Family" and Sprint's "Most" plans, imagine rival companies offering dueling packages of cable TV, wireless telephone and long-distance services. Would it be cheaper to get 40 channels of cable, long-distance service for 10 cents a minute and 10 free movies off the video server? Or would it make more sense to get 20 channel, 10 hours a month of wireless talk time and a high-speed data link to a national library? Choices like that could make people yearn anew for the boring simplicity of Ma Bell.

HEADLINE: Those People;
An Unfinished Portrait of the Poor

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE

 BODY:
"IT'S yellow," she explained to the blinking, uncomprehending man. "It's a yellow-looking substance that's coming out of his ear."
The subject was ear wax. The setting was parents' night. And the ear belonged to Chinedu Ezeriki, a fifth-grader in a parochial school uniform who could no longer hear his lessons. 
 His father, a cabdriver from Nigeria, could hear, but scarcely understand, the teacher's English.
"Wax?" he wondered.
He peered through his own broken eyeglasses, copied the address of a public clinic and vowed to unclog the boy's ears.
This evening of earnest, mundane exchanges is one of the most appealing memories of a decade spent writing about the lives of the poor.
It occurred this spring at a crumbling Catholic school, two miles from the White House, where housekeepers and janitors, nursing aides and vendors nervously filed forth to receive the teacher's judgments.
Most were immigrants. Few were Catholic. Some needed their children to translate. All had to strain for the $1,500 tuition. But they seemed to believe they were buying a piece of the American prosperity.
Here was the face of the American poor -- striving, decent and proud.
 
A Lot of Theories
 Poor people wear other, less flattering faces, of course, and there are many theories about dealing with them. They are oppressed (Jesse Jackson), lazy (Ronald Reagan) and seduced by the welfare state (Charles Murray). They have too many babies, and they have them too soon (Daniel Patrick Moynihan). They need tax relief (Jack Kemp). They need our help (Bill Clinton). They need to help themselves (Bill Clinton, again).
Who are the poor, these 36,734,000 souls scattered across the American landscape? The Government answers quite precisely: people with income amounting to less than $14,279 for a family of four.
But the numbers don't begin to tell the stories, and the theories rarely capture the complexity of the lives. What's striking is the infinite shades of gray, the strange combinations of bad luck, bad choices and bad places that sculpture individual lives.
The picture of poverty is really a succession of disjointed images. Poverty is the blend of Lysol and body odor at a homeless shelter in Detroit. It's the bent spine of an 80-year-old farm worker on the edge of a dusty grape field in Delano, Calif.
It's the blare of television soap operas in a Chicago high rise, drowning out the squalls of the badly diapered baby on a linoleum floor. It's the shrieks of Ricardo Terry's friends in a St. Louis funeral home as the teen-aged murder victim is mourned.
Some poor people suffer from a lack of jobs and some from a lack of fathers. Some suffer from the color of their skin and some from the constraints on their imagination.
Trying to coax a resident of a New Orleans housing project into an interview, I once offered to take her to whichever of the city's fabled restaurants she desired. "Shoneys?" she exclaimed.
In Washington, a sullen young woman named Margaret Williams was dragging her toddler into a medical van. He was more than a year behind on his vaccination shots.
She had no job. She had no husband. She explained in disgust that she had had no time to hassle with the social workers and the Medicaid forms that would have given her son free care.
"They want you to run around, and do this or that for nothing," she said. In the meantime, her son had got rickets.
The talk of "American apartheid" had always seemed wildy hyperbolic, an annoying snippet of lefty cant, until I took a drive down South State Street in Chicago and disappeared into the desolate high-rises, a civilization of menace.
Downtown faded to memory and mirage, glass wonderboxes and a blue-green lake. Here, 35 blocks away, lives lay abandoned as far as the eye could see.
Since it's hard to imagine creating a world worse than Stateway Gardens, even if we tried, the mind takes a conspiratorial turn: maybe someone did try; perhaps this is what the power structure plotted.
Linda Baldwin lived there. She had four children and no husband, and she used to be on welfare. Now she was hustling off to work at 7:30 each morning.
It was an unremarkable activity, except for the math. Her $6-an-hour clerical job left her with $169 less each month than the welfare system would have provided. That meant she fell $7.75 behind for every day she worked. Why bother?
"I feel better about myself," she said. Then she added, "but I'm still living here."
A month before, the Chicago River had broken through a freight tunnel and flooded downtown basements with muck. The city recruited welfare mothers from public housing projects, at $10 an hour, to help shovel the slime. Ten dollars an hour! They donned yellow gloves and smiles and they walked home in the afternoon as if they'd won the lottery. They wanted all the muck they could get.
About a week later I was at a white beach club in Jacksonville, Fla., on the Fourth of July. A friend's relative tossed out a joke about black people and watermelons. It was banal and bizarre and prompted by absolutely nothing. Maybe someone with a quicker mind or a better heart would have shattered the peace with protest, embarrassed a friend, laid down a line. I squirmed, kept silent, colluded.
A few old friends were there, people who had seemed of average talent and ambition 15 years earlier when we were classmates at the city's prep school, people no more or less decent than the rest.
Just as the residents of Stateway Gardens inherit gangs and welfare checks, they had inherited bank vice presidencies and sprawling lawns. But they would not use the word "inherit." They, we, prefer the word "earn."
Intellectuals sometimes yearn for the moment when people stop making moral judgments about the poor. The issue is poverty, they argue, not morality. Few people cluck about the morality of the rich.
A fair observation, but the judgments seem here to stay. Most people say it, if only to themselves: Get a job! Go to school! Stop having babies!
 
Strikes Against Her
 The social workers in Indianola, Miss., say it aloud when they go to visit Betty Briggs. ("She's ignorant," her caseworker said.)
She had five children, a sixth-grade education, no job, few teeth, a crossed eye, and a boyfriend named T. L. Truitt who boasts of his opposition to birth control. Her five-month-old son, C. L., had just died.
The boyfriend said it was her own fault, for smoking and fighting while pregnant. "This girl can't think," he said.
Betty Briggs smiled passively through two visits, said little, shouldered the blame. Then shared her secret treasure: five dim Polaroids of her son's crib-sized coffin. "I feel like dying myself," she said.
Sometimes, Government anti-poverty programs seem so futile they make the stomach flutter. Riverside, Calif., runs the country's most acclaimed welfare training program.
Last spring, a dozen poor people filed into a conference room to hear a social worker fret. "Hopefully we can get you employed as soon as possible," she said. "I shouldn't say hopefully. I keep losing my train of thought."
Some of the women wore bored looks that suggested they had seen it before. A woman from Ethiopia wore a big turban on her head and understood no English.
A woman with a Spanish accent sobbed and protested that she was a "survivor" -- not a refugee, but a victim of domestic beatings, terrified that the welfare system would return her to her husband.
A woman in stretch pants raised a fleshy arm and voiced doubts about her own employability. "I went to a factory," she said. "They saw how fat I was and they said no."
 
'Reform' in Action
 Policies seldom play out the way politicians envision. Last year, Michigan decided it could strengthen the work ethic if it ended a welfare program for single adults it considers able-bodied.
It worked for Glenn Williams -- sort of. He started wandering through church basements, collecting free clothes and selling them to his neighbors in a seedy Detroit hotel -- $3 for a shirt, $5 for a pair of pants.
His whisper was barely audible beneath the blare of Christian radio. "From the blessings of God," he said, "everything come out beautiful."
Some Government programs work. Paramedics in Anchorage do an admirable job of keeping street alcoholics from freezing to death. One afternoon last year they found an unconscious man in an alley, face-down in the dirt, foaming at the mouth. He was flanked by an empty bottle and a pornographic magazine. They knew him by name.
"C'mon Frank, wake up," the medic said. "Party time's over."
Sometimes poor people disdain poor people. Jose Palacio, the night janitor at Penn Station in New York, does not like the homeless who live there.
They do not like him either. They mock his earnest, broom-pushing ways. He holds his nose and wipes the wastes they leave on the bathroom floor. "Those people live like animals," he said one night. "You can't help them."
Sometimes poverty twists the affluent. Robert Mangum was a landlord at Sugar Ditch, the notorious Tunica, Miss., slum. The shacks he owned had leaky roofs and perforated walls and emptied their waste into a canal a few yards away. He seemed angrier at his tenants than they were at him.
He noted they were "colored." He said "bugs have to do with personal hygiene." He said some of the tenants were on welfare, and people who "are 21 and healthy, I have no cares what they get."
I pictured him living in a big house with white columns. He knew it and he defiantly drove me home, to a big house with white columns. The halls were filled with medals from the Special Olympics. His son has Down syndrome. The anger and suspicion never left his voice, but the words changed: he lectured me on the special love a disabled child brings to a family.
When times get tough, as many as a million Americans a year go bankrupt. But others, like Bob and Amy Davis, aren't so lucky.
They were too poor to go bankrupt. They couldn't afford to pay the lawyer to file the papers to protect them from their creditors.
In a world of hard-luck stories, the one they told from a trailer park in Morganton, N. C., went beyond the bounds. They have three children. The children each have a rare genetic disease. The parents bought them bicycles for Christmas. The bicycles got repossessed -- probably by someone like their father.
Bob, an unemployed mechanic, needed work. He signed on as a repo man.
It was the holiday season. I offered each of the children a $5 bill. They turned it down. "Mister," said the 8-year-old ringleader, "you might need it for gas."
Bob foraged in his drawer and insistently offered a coupon from Kentucky Fried Chicken. He said the family couldn't afford to use it.
It offered about 99 cents off the three-piece dinner. I did the only decent thing I could think of. I put the coupon in my wallet, drove back toward the Interstate, and ate.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Will Success Spoil Kwanzaa?

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
Today is the first day of Kwanzaa, a 27-year-old African-inspired harvest celebration in which many American blacks give thanks over a period of seven days. Each day a candle is lit and families share intimate feasts. Each day, families dedicate themselves to a different guiding principle.
One of these principles is ujaama, a Swahili word meaning cooperative economics. At last week's Kwanzaa Holiday Expo in New York City, ujaama was flourishing. Some 300 exhibitors paid $900 each to set up shop at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center to sell African sculpture, Kwanzaa cards and wrapping paper, teddy bears in African garb and Kente pattern tablecloths. 
 But the event also revealed the increasing participation of major corporations, including Anheuser-Busch, Pepsi-Cola, Revlon, Hallmark, Chemical Bank, A.T.& T., Time-Life Books, Woolworth's and JCPenney.
With millions of blacks expected to observe Kwanzaa, the Expo's organizers calculate the national market for Kwanzaa products is as high as $100 million.
Does all this mean that Kwanzaa, with its goals of grace and intimacy, is being co-opted by larger economic forces and becoming as commercialized as Christmas?
Maulana Karenga, chairman of the black studies department at California State University at Long Beach, who developed the concept for the holiday in 1965, says American society is a culture eager to make the tenderest of sentiments ring bells at the cash register. "This is a capitalistic society where they rent wombs and sell bodies," Dr. Karenga said. "One can expect they will try to commodicize. The challenge for the African people is to avoid the problems of commercialization that they've learned from other holidays like Christmas."
 
Whose Gain?
 Dr. Karenga and others say the important thing is how Kwanzaa is used commercially and who profits. "There is no problem with commercializing it, but who will be the benefactors of the commercialization?" said Cedric McClester, who has developed an alternative to Santa Claus, an African storyteller named Nia Umoja whose gift-giving role is considerably smaller. "It should be people of African descent, not just corporate America."
"Black people need not be embarrassed about making money," said Bobbi Humphrey, a flutist who had a booth to sell her compact disks and a poster of one of her photographs. "That is what pays the rent and that is what makes America tick."
But the worry remains that consumers might be whipped into yet another consumerist frenzy. "I have friends who go kind of berserk," said Lagrane Brooks, who lives in East New York and strives to keep things simple for her family. "Some people are out there really, really crazy running up debts." DOUGLAS MARTIN

HEADLINE: The World;
The Social Safety Net Most Russians Need is Cold Cash

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
AS the United States and the West scramble for responses to the electoral success of Russian extremists, building Russia "a social safety net" has become the cliche of the day.
If only Russians were better protected from the pain of economic reform, the argument goes, they wouldn't vote for neo-fascists and neo-Communists. So Russia should slow down reform and focus on social benefits now that there is no longer a Soviet-style guarantee of employment. This argument has found favor so far among figures as far-flung as Russia's President, Boris N. Yeltsin; Vice President Al Gore, and the deputy director of the International Monetary Fund, Ernesto Hernandez-Cata. 
 Never mind that this argument misreads the vote this month, which had to do with many other matters besides Government economic policy, including: instability, crime, corruption, social inequality, and the October shelling of the Russian parliament; splits among the reformers; unity among the extremists, and the reformers' miserable campaign. Nearly half of Russia's inexperienced voters were so alienated they didn't bother to vote.
And never mind that no Western nation has volunteered to grant an extra dollar for any new, improved social safety net, on the perfectly sound political theory that you cannot get away with paying for Russia's unemployed when you have so many of your own at home.
The real problem with the argument is that actual structural change of the Russian economy and its huge, ancient and distorted industrial sector -- which really will produce high unemployment -- has only barely begun, let alone cut down the work force with too sharp a sickle. The best estimates suggest that 5 million Russians are unemployed (officially, only 770,000 are), which represents about 5 or perhaps 6 percent of the work force -- good figures in European terms.
Most of the pain, anger and confusion felt by Russians (and by no means all of them) stems not from unemployment but from the steady impoverishment produced by high monthly inflation -- and this, most economists agree, has roots in too incoherent a policy and too little reform, not too much.
The biggest pain Russians feel stems from the low levels of their state-mandated salaries and pensions, which do not keep up with inflation and for weeks at a time are not paid at all. As state subsidies on items like bread and energy disappear, because the Government can no longer afford them, and as inflation rages because the Government is divided and the Central Bank seems incompetent, many Russians have become poorer than before. But it is not a "safety net" they crave; most of the angriest Russians are neither jobless nor pensioners.
 
Getting Ready Now
 If there is a reason to desire a stronger social safety net now, it is to prepare for what may happen if significant economic reform ever does happen in Russia. Such reform could indeed produce large numbers of the openly unemployed. That is, if the current Government, led by the industrialist Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, can be persuaded to stop subsidizing inefficient and essentially bankrupt enterprises. If it does that, it will have to help retrain workers, feed them for a time and provide new investment funds to enterprises willing to restructure.
That's not to say there aren't big problems with Russia's existing "social safety net," and the World Bank has already devoted much time to advising the Government how to improve it. Some officials of multilateral agencies say Russia's reformers have not been very interested in this problem, in part because unemployment has stayed low and in part because it would cost a lot when they are trying to cut spending.
One World Bank official said carefully: "For an aid program you need an interested partner, capable of developing and implementing projects." For instance, he said, a $70-million World Bank loan for the Russian Federal Employment Service, approved over a year ago, has still not been signed by Russia, so it could not be dispersed. Some Russian officials admit the charge is partly true, but they also say that year-old requests to multilateral agencies for funds to start small-business investment funds have yielded study groups, not money.
 
A Benefit Program
 Officially, Russians who have worked for 12 consecutive weeks and lose their jobs receive 75 percent of their average pay for the previous two months for 12 weeks; then 60 percent for the next four months; then 45 percent for the next year. Another 10 percent is provided for each dependent. Other Russians are entitled to the monthly minimum pay (currently $11.70) for a year. This program is funded in each region by a 2 percent payroll tax.
The problem is that inflation of some 20 percent a month reduces those benefits to minimum levels very quickly. World Bank officials say the 2 percent tax is much too low, and 90 percent of it is kept in each region. So the program is underfunded, and if one region has higher than average unemployment, its money will run out.
The World Bank has also pushed for a national program of social protection, so that anyone in real need can go somewhere for help -- an ultimate safety net, European-style. But the Russian Government has been leery of such a funding commitment. The Bank has helped Russia more clearly define its poverty line, and has pushed with success for fewer across-the-board subsidies, as on milk and bread, in order to use the money for the truly poor.
Pensions, given the inflation, remain a large source of pain. They are generally so low that pensioners keep working. This double-dipping makes the pension system much more expensive and ties up jobs. In another small but important reform, the Government has decided to compensate for inflation by increasing pensions by an absolute amount across the board, rather than through a percentage increase. This raises the lowest pensions the most.
Loans can help Russia lessen the pain. But for these loans to have real value, they have to be in the context of an economic stabilization program that really does cut inflation. "We can't just finance Russia's budget deficit," one official said. "The tendency is to say that stabilization has too high a price. But unless they stabilize, you can't have reform. Then what's the alternative?"

HEADLINE: The World;
Chile's Engine Revs Up With Free Trade's Fuel

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

DATELINE: CURICO, Chile

 BODY:
UNTIL recently this quaint farming community beside the Andean foothills was the picture of prosperity. Vast apple orchards lined its roads and teams of workers pruned, sprayed and irrigated the trees. Curico was a product of the economic miracle that had made Chile the Latin American tiger, a free-market, export-based economy often symbolized by its sales of fresh fruit to Europe and the United States during the Northern Hemisphere's winter.
But there is a disturbing new look to many orchards this year -- tall weeds among the trees, fences in ill-repair, irrigation ditches dry -- signs that apple production, like much of Chile's export sector, has hit hard times. 
 For the first time in more than a decade, Chile's exports have fallen in the past year because recession abroad has pushed down prices while a wave of consumerism at home has driven up production costs. In an earlier time, such world market gyrations would have set off calls for this or any other Latin American country to stem the exploitation of its natural resources by foreigners, to close its economy, and to develop small industries to make the nation more self-sufficient.
But now a different strategy is heard.
"Our trade problems only mean that we need to open the world economy even more," said Gonzalo Espinosa, a large producer of Chilean apples. "We need more free trade and more elimination of trade barriers."
Finance Minister Alejandro Foxley added: "The fruit producers are used to very high margins, making a lot of money, and those days are over. They've had problems with the quality of their products, their timing of getting the produce to market. And they have to fix those problems themselves."
Almost 40 years after the emergence of the so-called Dependency School in Latin America -- the theorists who argued that developing countries need to protect their resources from being ravaged by multinational corporations, the argument has been turned around. Now, having seen Mexico secure a place in the North American Free Trade Agreement, hopes are being pinned on the prospect of interdependence with the United States and other advanced industrial nations, through diversified and efficient economies that can compete in free trade.
In recent decades, the Latin nations found that they not only lacked human and financial capital to develop a multitude of local industries, but that their internal markets did not have enough demand to justify, for example, a home-grown automobile industry. Eventually, by the late 1980's, every attempt to gain independence from so-called industrialized neighbors had failed.
So the thinking began to turn toward increasing interdependence -- a notion that had its earliest manifestations in the privatizations of many Government-owned industries in countries like Argentina and Chile. Though foreign investors eagerly came in to buy large shares of these enterprises, they also sought out local partners and industrial groups for joint ventures.
Already, such joint ventures have brought a wealth of modern management strategies and technologies into Latin America.
 
Assurances Needed
 But a big hurdle remained -- guaranteeing broad access to markets in industrialized countries. Having opened its own markets to the industrialized world, Latin America needed assurance that the industrialized world would not shut out Latin products.
Enter the recently completed talks on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, and the passage of Nafta. These were major steps in assuring a continued open market, and the relief that was felt throughout Latin America was reflected in the relatively self-confident reaction to the drop in apple production here.
Chile is, after all, thought to be the South American country most likely to next join Nafta. And Chilean fruit producers say the GATT agreement will lower European tariff barriers to their products, one main reason for their weak sales this year.
Indeed, GATT and Nafta also now permit each country in Latin America to develop the industries in which they have a competitive advantage in labor costs, access to natural resources, or proximity to markets. This is only encouraging businessmen to think they can finally go beyond the exploitation of natural resources and apply more manufacturing processes to their products, such as persuading a foreign copper company mining ore to refine the ore in Chile itself, rather than export it for refining abroad.
"We now need to add value to our exports," said Roberto Fantuzzi, general manager of his family-owned aluminum fabricating business. "If I export an aluminum cooking pot, its value is three times the value of the metal. But if I export a piece of machinery, its value can be a thousand times the value of the metal. That means more higher-paying jobs in this country."
 
New Challenges
 Nevertheless, the process of creating higher-paying jobs is slow. Today, Chile's work force looks less attractive to foreign investors than, for example, Argentina's, because the level of education there is higher. So the Government will be challenged to invest more in schools -- as it also will have to invest in new or improved roads, bridges and ports, areas where there has been little real investment for more than a decade. In this, Chile may also fall behind Argentina, where the Government has privatized highway maintenance, railroad operation and port operation.
"For years we were far ahead of our Latin neighbors but they are now catching up on us," said Jose Pinera, a Harvard-trained economist, former Finance Minister under the military Government and a presidential candidate in the country's recent elections.
For now, and especially for fruit farmers, the focus is on cost-cutting and efficiency. Fernando Del Valle, an apple farmer, says he must constantly plant higher-yield trees of varieties tailored to market tastes. "To make money now," said Alessandro Bozzolo, general manager of the Copefrut fruit packing plant, "you have to produce more per acre and a lot more than before."
