HEADLINE: Conversations: Milovan Djilas;
He Sees Ideologies Come and Go But the Balkans Remain the Same

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER

DATELINE: BELGRADE

 BODY:
THE living room is dominated by a huge painting of Faust, brooding at his desk as he ponders in Goethe's drama whether to be a man of action or remain a contemplative scholar.
The image is appropriate to the tempestuous life of its owner, Milovan Djilas, the rebellious Montenegrin who made a Faustian bargain with the Devil of Leninist ideology, trading a budding career as a writer for one as a Communist campaigner in 1930's Yugoslavia, emerging as a leader of Tito's wartime partisans, then, after victory, assailing the new tyranny he had helped create. 
 Mr. Djilas paid repeatedly for his nonconformism with 12 years behind bars -- first as a prisoner of the royal dictatorship, second and third as a prisoner of Marshal Tito's Communist dictatorship. In the early 1950's he had begun publishing articles attacking the new Communist bureaucracy, prompting his ouster from party and government posts. He soon became Communist Yugoslavia's most prominent dissident, prompting Tito to jail him again and again for works like "The New Class" and "Conversations With Stalin." His son Aleksa, who now lives next door in their apartment building near Parliament, has followed his father's dissident footsteps on his way to becoming a respected historian.
At 82, Mr. Djilas's contemplative phase, part of it in the confines of a cell, has lasted half his life.
Facing his Faust, he reflected on how imprisonment affects politically minded inmates. "It often hardens their will to power," he said, and cited some examples. "Stalin was sent to prison five times, Hitler for five years." He went on to Yugoslav leaders who had spent time in prison: Tito; Franjo Tudjman, the President of Croatia; Alija Izetbegovic, the President of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and others. "They wanted power," said Mr. Djilas. "I didn't want power. But prison transformed me, too. It transformed me from an ideologist into a humanist."
Reflecting on the 30 months of warfare that have torn apart the former Yugoslavia, Mr. Djilas said softly, "I see no way out."
With a touch of the fatalism endemic to the Balkans, Mr. Djilas spoke of the feckless efforts by the United States and other Western powers to persuade the warring ethnic leaders to make peace. "You didn't understand the Balkan mentality, to have power at any cost," he said. "They are fascists in the sense of nationalist racism, not of a fascist ideology as such."
 
'The War Will Last'
 "Balkan leaders," he said, "they know how to make a compromise, and then break it. The war will last more years."
The room on the second floor of the apartment house at No. 8 Palmoticeva Street was cold, like most others in Belgrade in a premature winter in which the international sanctions imposed upon Serbia have sharply reduced supplies of gas, oil and other fuels. An electric heater warmed his thin frame. He wore thick, red-and-black-checked woolen trousers and a windbreaker. Usually abstemious, he was sipping lozovac, a clear brandy, against the cold. "It is homemade," he said, grinning, "from Montenegro."
He is proud of his origins in the Black Mountains and has probably written more about his homeland than anyone since Njegos, the 19th century prince-archbishop, an outstanding epic poet of whom Mr. Djilas wrote a tender biography. Yet he cheerfully acknowledges that for all their colorful traditions "Montenegrins are basically Serbs."
Ideology has been a dominant theme of his life. Now, his youthful embrace of Communism long abandoned, he views ideologies with a mixture of pity and revulsion: "Khrushchev, Gorbachev, others, they all thought they could reform Communism. But that was always impossible. You cannot reform an ideology."
Noting that nationalism has replaced Communism as the main ideological currency in the Balkans, Mr. Djilas said he believed that the Slavic Muslims running the besieged government of Bosnia and Herzegovina in Sarajevo also fall into this category.
"You," he said, meaning Americans and other Westerners, "don't understand that Islam is a state ideology, to dominate in the name of a religion. It is very strong. Now the Bosnian Muslims are very determined in this." This was said without rancor.
Reminded that under President Clinton, the United States seemed to be shifting attention away from the West and toward the East, Mr. Djilas said: "The U.S.A. is right to turn to Asia. There the economy is growing. We in Europe are old and corrupt."
But he agreed to a suggestion about the origins of the American nation: "Yes, you are a European culture. You are the westernmost European people, while Russia is also a European culture, but eastern."
Mr. Djilas, who used to enjoy tramping the mountains and valleys of Montenegro and angling for trout, has been weakened by age and heart trouble. "When the elevator doesn't work I have difficulty getting up the stairs," he said. He has lost sight in his left eye and his hearing has diminished. "Intellectually I am all right," he said. "I'm still writing, a 500-page book with some new things, a collection, with other things American readers haven't yet seen."
 
'These Djilases'
 But he has been deeply affected by the loss of Stefica, his wife of 41 years, who died last summer of cancer. "I don't know if I can survive without her," he said, his eyes misting. "She was braver than I." As a young partisan fighter, Stefica Baric had distinguished herself in battle against the Wehrmacht.
Their son, Aleksa, 43, entered the living room, his wife of one month, Olgica, a university instructor in dentistry, on his arm. The author, in 1991, of the acclaimed study "The Contested Country: Yugoslav Unity and Communist Revolution, 1919-1953" has returned from the United States to be beside his father and to shoot an occasional flaming arrow into the murk of Serbian politics.
"I gave an interview in Borba," the son said, referring to the former Communist Party newspaper, "and a reader sent a letter saying he had had enough of these Djilases, that we should have salt poured on our tails." This drew a chuckle from his father, who had whole sacks of salt poured on him in his day.
"This is not the most glorious time for the Serbs," Aleksa said and, after assaying the various opponents of President Slobodan Milosevic, added: "Milosevic is the most skillful of them all. He cannot anticipate events, but he can read people."
The day was Nov. 29, still a holiday in truncated and no longer Communist Yugoslavia. It is sheepishly called Day of the Republic. But until 1990, when the ruling Communist Party collapsed, it was the Yugoslav National Day commemorating the Anti-Fascist Council of National Liberation of Yugoslavia, which in 1943, in defiance of the Nazi occupation, declared the creation of the new Yugoslavia of six federated republics.
Mr. Djilas noted that exactly 50 years ago, he and the rest of the Communist leaders had convened in the liberated Bosnian town of Jajce to proclaim a federal government and name Josip Broz Tito field marshal. The slogan then and until the collapse of Yugoslavia in 1991 was "Brotherhood and Unity."
"Not a bad slogan," said the elder Djilas.
The other slogan in 1943 was "Death to Fascism! Freedom to the People!"
"A very relevant slogan now," said the younger Djilas.

HEADLINE: Germans Find Unity May Mean Long-Term Change and Sacrifice

SERIES: Tarnished Dream: Germany After Unification -- First of two articles.

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DUISBURG, Germany

 BODY:
More than three years after the initial euphoria over reunification, Germans are beginning to discover that they have to build a new country not only in the formerly Communist east, but also in the industrial west, requiring new ways of thinking and more sacrifice than they ever imagined.
Those in the west learned quickly that absorbing East Germany entailed more than enlarging and enriching the old Federal Republic of Germany. The new, united Germany is finding that the post-cold-war world is a more harshly competitive place than it was before. For many western Germans, the biggest shock is the discovery that the forces that made their country the richest welfare state in Europe and made its economy the Continent's most powerful can no longer guarantee the annual raises and increases in leisure time and the social security that they took for granted for decades.
 
Ruhr Steel in Crisis
 Nowhere is the shock more dramatic than here in the Ruhr, where recession and inexpensive imports have thrown the steel industry, long the core of the region's prosperity, into crisis. 
 In the Ruhr, whose sinews of coal and steel used to power the German industrial economy, some of the economic and social problems might have struck, as they did in the American "Rust Belt" a decade earlier, even if the Berlin wall had not fallen. Like other countries, Germany is affected by competition in high-quality manufacturing and technology from East Asia, but since 1989 it has suddenly had a highly trained, low-wage work force just across its own border, in Eastern Europe.
Just a few months ago, many workers at the giant Thyssen steel works in this port and manufacturing city in the west were sullen and resentful over the prospect of sacrificing living standards so their less fortunate counterparts in eastern Germany could improve theirs.
 
Refugees and Attacks Decline
 They worried about the influx of foreign asylum-seekers and a wave of rightist violence against foreigners. Last summer the rules for admitting foreign refugees were tightened, and their numbers have dropped, as have those of right-wing attacks.
Today, with more than 3.5 million Germans out of work and no sign that unemployment will decrease even when the recession ends, many workers here seem more worried about losing their jobs to global economic forces too complex for them to understand.
The anger is directed not so much against outsiders as against Chancellor Helmut Kohl. When hard times fell after the post-unification boom, he told voters that he was wrong in 1990 when he promised that no one would be worse off after the country came together. Now he has been telling Germans to tighten their belts and get used to lower wages and fewer welfare benefits if they want to keep jobs in Germany instead of losing them to more competitive countries.
"My advice to Kohl is to start slimming down himself before he starts asking the rest of us to," said Willi Geskes, 45, an electrician at the Thyssen plant. "The politicians should set an example of how to cut waste, instead of putting the whole burden on our shoulders."
 
Kohl Suffers in Polls
 After 11 years in power in Bonn, Mr. Kohl and his Christian Democrats have sunk to their lowest point in national public opinion polls since unification. With a string of local, state and regional elections set for next year and a national election coming in October, the Chancellor's position seems vulnerable as euphoria is replaced by harsh disillusionment.
In an interview with the daily Die Welt before Christmas, former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt said he credited Mr. Kohl with "seizing the opportunity instinctively." "But," Mr. Kohl's predecessor said, "I also believe that the way unification was then carried out was to some extent catastrophically wrong."
The brief boom was followed by a recession that was only partly a result of the worldwide economic slowdown that began in the United States much earlier.
In eastern Germany, unification did not mean the instant prosperity that many expected. In fact, it appears that it will take at least a decade to make living standards in the east equal to those in the west.
 
Deficits Are Blamed
 Mr. Schmidt and others blame the severity of the loss of economic confidence in Germany on the fact that state, local and federal governments financed the reconstruction of the east's dilapidated infrastructure with budget deficits totaling between 7 and 7.5 percent of the gross national product this year, a postwar record, according to the Bundesbank. The independent central bank had to slam the brakes on money-supply growth by raising interest rates, and business growth plummeted.
Nationwide, unemployment has now risen to about 10 percent of the labor force. It is hard to tell precisely, because even three years after unification the Government keeps separate statistics for east and west.
German labor costs make it difficult to create jobs as fast as they are being lost. Many German companies have moved assembly lines to the Czech Republic because hourly wages and fringe benefits there are a 10th of what they are here.
For years, German industrial workers have been among the best paid in the Western world, with hourly wages nearly double those of American workers.
Workers in France and in Belgium have waged bitter strikes and angry demonstrations in fierce resistance to the notion that their living standards may have to suffer in the short run to assure them of jobs over the longer term. German workers do not like it either, but for the first time since World War II, they accepted pay cuts this year to save jobs.
 
Lost Jobs
Layoffs Increase While Wages Fall
 Here in the Ruhr, the traditional Christmas markets dispensed mulled wine, cookies and tree ornaments in the pedestrian zones of Duisburg and most other cities, but the stores filled with luxury goods began cutting prices in late November.
The Thyssen plant here plans to lay off 10,000 workers over the next year, on top of tens of thousands more it has let go since 1989. Rolf Bulck, 57, said his colleagues would probably be prepared to accept a wage settlement this year that might leave them with a net loss of income after 3.5 to 4 percent inflation. That, he said, was better than no jobs at all.
His union, the Metalworkers, began the bargaining by asking companies staggering under the impact of recession and cheap imports from Eastern Europe and other low-wage areas for wage increases over the next year of 5.5 percent, plus unspecified "job security measures." Few, including Mr. Bulck, expect to get it.
"What you see in the faces of young workers and trainees nowadays is fear," said Thomas Kennel, a union official. "People are afraid of losing jobs."
In the Ruhr, workers are feeling many of the same economic pressures that shattered the Communist industrial economy in the east.
There, the sudden transition from a planned economy to a free market based on the German mark made many overstaffed enterprises and factories bankrupt overnight. Here, the advent of increased competition has suddenly made generous German fringe benefits, wage levels and vacation entitlements uncompetitive.
"Because of the processes that led to reunification and the fall of the iron curtain, steel has been coming into Germany from eastern Europe, where labor costs producers only a 10th of what it costs steel companies here," said Friedrich Noth, deputy chief of the labor consultative council at the Thyssen plant.
Coal from the Ruhr has also been in decline for decades, because mining it deep underground is uncompetitive against cheaper coal from open pits in Poland or the United States, a fact that does not prevent the German Government from sinking more than $3 billion in subsidies into it every year to insure supplies to electricity plants and protect the few jobs that are left. The money, the equivalent of about a quarter of all German Government expenditure on research and technology, is raised by a special 7.5 percent tax on electricity bills that will rise to 8.5 percent next year.
Even so, coal-mining jobs are steadily disappearing. Ten years ago, there were more than 130,000 coal miners in the Ruhr, more than there are in all of western Germany now. Today fewer than 90,000 still earn their living underground.
Earlier, coal mines and labor unions made the reductions as painless as possible, reducing employment by about 5,000 people a year by attrition and early retirement. But now, miners face the possibility of joblessness for the first time in Germany's postwar history.
To avoid it, the Mining and Energy Union and mine owners agreed on a four-day week for the coming year that would reduce miners' take-home pay by about 10 percent. Workers and management at the giant Volkswagen plant in Wolfsburg accepted a similar agreement in November to prevent the loss of 30,000 jobs.
But few officials see the shorter work week as anything but a temporary solution to a long-term problem. Coal mining will never be profitable here without Government subsidies, but the Government parties in Bonn are thinking of cutting them back after the year 2000, a step that would mean layoffs for thousands.
"We believe national security alone justifies keeping the bargain, which is a Government promise anyway," said Christoph Meer, a spokesman for the coal miners' union in Bochum. "How do we know the Russians will keep delivering gas reliably forever?"
 
Cutbacks
Subsidies in East, Sacrifices in West
 For the next 10 years, the Government estimates, west Germans will have to pay about $100 billion a year to subsidize the rebuilding of roads, railroads, communications networks and real property in the east. Starting in 1995, some of this will be financed by a 5 percent income tax surcharge in the western part of the country.
A Government report on economic conditions issued this autumn concluded that national priorities need to be reordered. "In essence, Germans have been living beyond their means for some years, because demands have risen faster than economic productivity," it said. "It would be wrong to blame errors that have developed over the long term -- in part, over decades -- on German unity."
But many taxpayers at the lower end of the scale feel that they are being asked to sacrifice more heavily than the rich. To reduce the deficit, for instance, the federal Government will cut unemployment payments by between 1 and 3 percent, to 53 percent of the last net monthly paycheck for childless workers, as of Jan. 1. Over the next two years, welfare payments will increase by only 2 percent, less than the rate of inflation.
A parliamentary majority also approved a plan to eliminate payments to construction workers to replace wages lost when the weather is bad, a move that brought tens of thousands to the streets of Bonn in protest in October. Legislators later agreed to delay the end of this subsidy until 1995.
In all, Bonn slashed $12.4 billion from the federal budget with steps like these, which the opposition says hit the poor harder than the rich.
[Mr. Kohl said a few days before Christmas that more deep cuts would have to be made next year, apparently on the same order of magnitude.]
In Duisburg, where officials say unemployment exceeds 14 percent, Government spending cuts will mean additional welfare costs of $23.5 million, Norbert Giersch, the city manager, said. It also means that Duisburg will have to close two indoor swimming pools and four branch libraries, and save $58.8 million.
"In principle," he said, "we accept the need for the cuts, because it's better to help people to stay where they are than cause a mass migration out of the east."
But with the Government still spending millions of dollars to construct buildings for official offices in Bonn, even though the capital will move to Berlin by the end of the decade, many taxpayers are growing restive.
"I am not bothered by paying a 'solidarity surcharge,' " said Mr. Geskes at the steelworks. "What bothers me is all the waste."
The Government says the contracts had been settled before unification and would be too expensive to cancel, and it hopes to find some other use for the buildings.
 
Resentment
Some Are Getting 'Nothing at All'
 Among younger workers, some resentment of eastern Germans continues to simmer. Many in the area come from families that have lived here for generations, with few of the emotional or family ties to people in the east that made many Germans grateful for an end to the artificial divisions that kept them apart for 28 years. Others are "guest workers" who came to West Germany in earlier prosperous years and feel no emotional sympathy for the east.
"I wish we could have the same promises made to us that Kohl has given to the people in the east, but we get nothing at all," said Ismail Gurel, 26, a German steelworker born in Turkey who represents younger plant workers on the Thyssen labor-management board.
The company has a spanking-clean professional training plant here, the kind of place that President Clinton has spoken of as a model for the United States. It used to be a model for German companies as well, with its modern equipment and computer data processing training for every apprentice. But next year, because of the steel crisis, Thyssen will take on only 32 apprentices, compared with 260 a few years ago. Like other companies here, it is unable to offer most apprentices jobs after they finish their training.
"I'll finish my training next September," said Achim Forster, 18, who started learning the trade of machine-tool mechanic two years ago. "There were plenty of jobs then," he said, "but now after I finish, they'll probably hire me for three months and then I'll have to look for work at the employment office. Maybe I'll go into the army. I'll have to see what happens."
But some young people are more forceful in their frustration. In November, demonstrators bricked in the front door to the Duisburg office of Mr. Kohl's Christian Democratic Union party. "Block our future and we'll block you in," said the slogan they left behind.
NEXT: The new world of one east German village.

HEADLINE: INTELLIGENCE STUDY SAYS NORTH KOREA HAS NUCLEAR BOMB

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG with MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25

 BODY:
The Central Intelligence Agency has told President Clinton that North Korea probably has developed one or two nuclear bombs, according to Administration officials.
The classified assessment -- supported by virtually all intelligence agencies but disputed by the State Department's analysts -- deepens the Administration's dilemma as it tries to fulfill Mr. Clinton's pledge that "North Korea cannot be allowed to develop a nuclear bomb." 
 If confirmed, North Korea's nuclear status would have significant implications for Asian stability. Many American officials fear that it would touch off an arms race in the region and push Japan to develop atomic weapons.
 
A 'Worst Case' Scenario?
 Some officials contend that the Administration is playing down the recently completed intelligence study because it calls into question the effectiveness of its diplomatic efforts to persuade North Korea to abandon its nuclear program.
But other senior Clinton Administration policy makers question the assertions, arguing they represent a "worst case" analysis that is based not on conclusive proof but on estimates about the amount of plutonium the North Koreans could have produced and assessments on the pace of their program.
"What the intelligence community is saying is that the horse is already out of the barn," one official said. "It's too late."
Asked about the new assessment, Clinton Administration officials said they were still determined to pursue diplomacy to prevent North Korea from producing more plutonium for nuclear weapons, or, if the study proves correct, to force the country to relinquish its bombs.
 
Not an Attractive Option
 Pentagon officials have said the option of a preemptive strike against North Korea's nuclear installations is not an attractive one, because it would risk a war and American intelligence does not know where Pyongyang has hidden its plutonium or bombs.
The comprehensive review of Pyongyang's nuclear program represents the collective judgment of American intelligence agencies and was presented to Mr. Clinton and senior White House officials in recent weeks. Defense Secretary Les Aspin and Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who chairs the Senate Armed Services Committee, have alluded to the report's conclusions but have couched their remarks with more ambiguity than those of the document itself.
The document, called a National Intelligence Estimate, says there is a "better than even" chance that North Korea already has a nuclear bomb and holds out little hope that the Clinton Administration can derail the reclusive North Korean Government's nuclear program. It argues that diplomatic efforts or economic sanctions, a next step contemplated by some officials, are unlikely to succeed. The study said sanctions could even prompt an attack by the North Koreans against the South.
Most of the intelligence analysts agree that North Korea is investing significant amounts of its scarce cash in a program to obtain plutonium, develop the high-explosive trigger needed for a nuclear detonation and build a medium-range missile that can reach Japan.
The study estimates that North Korean could have extracted as much as 12 kilograms of plutonium, about 26 pounds, which would be enough under optimum conditions for two bombs.
 
No Satellite Picture For Confirmation
 American officials also said they have detected craters near North Korea's nuclear site at Yongbyon that are consistent with experiments with conventional munitions needed to detonate a nuclear bomb.
Still, American intelligence does not have a specific satellite picture, electronic intercept or agent's report that confirms deployment of a weapon.
The judgment that North Korea probably has a nuclear bomb is supported by almost every intelligence agency, including the C.I.A., the Defense Intelligence Agency, the National Security Agency and also the Energy Department. Only the State Department's intelligence arm, the Bureau of Intelligence and Research, disputes the conclusion, arguing that the data are not persuasive.
Several officials said the disagreement over North Korea's nuclear abilities turns not only on an analysis of its scientific prowess but also on a fundamental dispute over the intentions of the Government. C.I.A. analysts tend to see Pyongyang's leaders as despots who have turned to nuclear weapons to insure their hold on power. Analysts at the State Department assert there are splits within North Korea's ruling elite, and they say moderates should be encouraged through a combination of incentives and punishments.
The new intelligence assessment has important implications for efforts by the Clinton Administration to persuade North Korea to open its nuclear sites to international inspectors and abandon its nuclear program.
Those negotiations have recently showed signs of progress.
Administration officials have said, for example, that there has been progress in persuading the North Koreans to open all seven of its officially disclosed nuclear sites to international monitors. But they caution that important details need to be worked out, and there is no agreement on the separate question of whether inspectors can visit two waste dumps to see how much plutonium the North Koreans might have produced.
 
Problems Created For South Koreans
 American officials said that if President Clinton accepts the intelligence report as true, the diplomacy aimed at trading broader diplomatic and economic ties for nuclear concessions would be considerably complicated. If Mr. Clinton concurs, the United States would be seeking not only to end North Korea's nuclear program but to force it to relinquish bombs it has already completed and hidden away.
"Ultimately, the President will have to make a decision on the basis of the evidence," said a senior Administration official. The study's findings raise problems for South Korea, which has been urging a negotiated solution. "Having one or two bombs would create a very serious issue for us," said a senior South Korean diplomat in Seoul.
Present and former intelligence officials say that monitoring North Korea's nuclear program has always been one of their most vexing problems. North Korea builds much of its military-industrial base underground, and engages in extensive efforts to deceive the prying eyes and ears of American satellites. North Korea's fearsome security apparatus also makes it difficult to gather even routine information about the Government's and intentions.
Nonetheless, Western intelligence officials have grown increasingly concerned about North Korea's progress toward a bomb in recent years. Robert M. Gates, the Bush Administration's Director of Central Intelligence, told Congress in February 1992 that North Korea could have a bomb from within a few months to a couple of years. The main focus of concern is the nuclear site at Yongbyon, about 60 miles North of the capital, Pyongyang. It includes a reactor fueled by uranium mined from North Korea. The reactor is similar in design to those used in the 1950's by the Soviet Union and United States to produce plutonium for nuclear bombs. Nearby is a building in which the North Koreans separate plutonium from fuel rods removed from the reactor.
 
Plutonium Amount Is Crucial Question
 After operating the reactor for several years, the North Koreans in 1989 shut it down for about 100 days. During this time, the fuel rods were removed and plutonium extracted. North Korea acknowledges that it refined some plutonium, but insists the amounts were trivial.
North Korea signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty in 1985, but it declined until last year to permit inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency to look at the nuclear sites it has officially disclosed to the agency. When the agency analyzed samples of North Korea's plutonium, it concluded that Pyongyang scientists had engaged in more extensive reprocessing than they had acknowledged.
The question became: How much more?
In the recent intelligence study, most of the analysts assume that the North Koreans were able to reprocess enough plutonium for one to two bombs. One Administration expert said a relatively inexperienced nuclear nation would need at least about 12 pounds for a bomb.
The State Department challenged this estimate, arguing that North Korea's poor equipment for extracting fuel rods was likely to limit the amount of plutonium that could be produced to less than the amount needed for a single bomb.
Previous intelligence failures by all parties are casting a shadow over the debate. Some State Department and Pentagon officials believe intelligence analysts have put forward "worst case" conclusions so they cannot be accused of failing, as they did in the case of Iraq, to sound sufficient warning about a nuclear program.
"In the face of a very high level of ignorance, nobody wants to repeat the experience of Iraq," said one Administration official.
 
Agency Misjudged Ability of the North
 On the other hand, intelligence experts assert that the State Department has consistently underestimated North Korea's abilities. Analysts in the Department, for example, for years disputed the notion that North Korea had a reprocessing plant for plutonium, accepting North Korea's assertion that the giant building at Yongbyon was a textile factory.
Even as the United States tries to head off the program centered around the Yongbyon reactor, American officials are worried by the possibility that the North Koreans could expand their production of plutonium. Shutting down the reactor a second time, which Pyongyang said earlier this year it wanted to do and which may happen in the next several months, would enable the North Koreans to reprocess as much as 12 additional kilograms of plutonium, enough for perhaps two bombs.
Officials are also raising questions about a second, significantly larger North Korean reactor scheduled to be completed in 1995. An Administration official said that each load of spent fuel from a reactor of this size could produce 10 times as much plutonium as the Yongbyon reactor -- about 265 pounds.
If the North Koreans chose to, they could use this reactor to produce bombs that could be traded for oil to a country like Iran. American officials say that North Korea has for years been exporting its short-range Scud missiles or components to the Middle East, including to Syria and Iran.
North Korea is also developing the Rodong 1, a surface-to-surface missile with an estimated range of 620 miles. It is unclear to American analysts whether the North Koreans could develop a nuclear weapon small enough to fit on a missile. American analysts note that a crude bomb can be delivered by airplane, but the circumference of the Rodong is relatively small, requiring fairly considerable technical sophistication on the part of the weapons designers.
"We don't know everything about this program," one Administration said. "We only know what we can see, and those parts are disturbing enough."

Korea Sees 'Positive Signs'
 TOKYO, Dec. 25 (Reuters) -- The President of North Korea, Kim Il Sung, said today that there had been "positive signs" in his country's talks with the United States over inspections at suspected nuclear-related facilities.
But he told the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, who is visiting Pyongyang to help defuse the crisis, that there was no need for United Nations involvement.

HEADLINE: Columbus Divides Ohio's Capital City

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 22

 BODY:
The winter wind is blowing hard and mean, the Ku Klux Klan wants a permit to demonstrate downtown and the city's beloved Ohio State Buckeyes are headed for one of those second-tier bowl games that no one really cares about.
So, maybe it is a good thing that the people of Columbus have something else to fuss over these days: should a 500-ton statue of Christopher Columbus that is 6 feet taller than the Statue of Liberty be put near the banks of the Scioto River, not far from the full-size replica of the Santa Maria and the other monuments already dedicated to the man and the myth? 
 The 311-foot statue, nicknamed Chris Kong, was built by a prominent sculptor in Moscow, Zurab K. Tsereteli, as a token of friendship between Russia and the United States. But, he says, he has not yet managed to give it away to the people of America. Several cities and citizen's groups in Florida turned him down even after a Dade County businessman spent $500,000 trying to persuade his neighbors that the monument would be good for pride and profit.
Now, a group of citizens here wants to bring the bronze statue to this heartland city, the largest in the country named after Christopher Columbus. If it ever arrives, it will close a chapter in an international episode of unrequited love, politics, art and money with a cast that includes two fallen world leaders, fasting demonstrators and a blind masseuse with a vision.
 
No One Willing to Spend
 The Mayor, Greg Lashutka, says his city has other pressing needs and will not spend a penny on the project. Mr. Tsereteli says he does not want any payment for his work -- only the merchandising and licensing rights. But shipping and assembling the statue in Columbus would cost close to $25 million. The Governor of Ohio, George V. Voinovich, likes the statue but also says no state money is available. That leaves the citizens' group, including a winery owner, Christopher Columbus buffs, an investment banker and the civic-minded masseuse, Karen Hadley, to try to raise the money for the statue.
Ms. Hadley heard about the statue last winter and told everyone she knew what a great tourist attraction it would be with, maybe, a restaurant and gift shop to go along.
"Karen has more vision than most people with 20/20 eyesight," said Jane Butler, the president of the citizens' group, the New World Monument Foundation. "She was able to see into the future."
 
Help for Skyline
 For the group, the statue is a chance to put the city and its skyline on the map. The statue would be only three stories shorter than the city's tallest building, the 34-story state office tower, and, group members insist, it would rival Seattle's Space Needle, the Arch in St. Louis, the Eiffel Tower and, of course, the Statue of Liberty.
"A statue like this comes along once every 100 years," said Ralph Frasca, a member of the group. "Now, we're going to be known for football and the statue. If we ever win the Rose Bowl, we'll put a big Buckeye T-shirt on it."
But for others here, the idea of Chris Kong looming over the city is a disgrace, a blow to American Indians and a sure bet to put Columbus near the top of Jay Leno's monologue for the next 365 nights.
Mark Welsh of the Native American Indian Center in Columbus said he was circulating a petition to stop the statue. In October, during the city's Christopher Columbus Day celebrations, American Indians, along with others, fasted and protested for more than a week.
 
A Laughing Matter
 "To the Native American people, Christopher Columbus represents 500 years of genocide," Mr. Welsh said. "Plus, the statue is ugly and the whole country will be laughing at us if we put that thing up. It's a very insensitive idea."
Max Goldberg, the former president of the group that tried to bring the monument to south Florida and who is now advising the group in central Ohio, said Mr. Tsereteli had no idea when building the statue what a disputed figure Christopher Columbus had become in the United States.
To Mr. Tsereteli, Christopher Columbus was still the heroic adventurer of old grade-school history books that barely mention the slaughter and the sorrow of American Indians, Mr. Goldberg said. All the artist wanted to do was symbolize and support the newly discovered friendship between his country and the United States. And maybe make a few bucks.
"The name of the statue in Russian is New World," Mr. Goldberg said. "He had no idea that Christopher Columbus was politically incorrect by today's standards."
 
Likes Big Art
 So, Mr. Tsereteli began to build and build. He likes to make big art and the monument is his biggest piece yet. One of his works, "Good Defeats Evil," a statue of St. George slaying dragons made from defanged missiles, soars 40 feet in the air at the United Nations in New York.
While building the Columbus monument in the late 1980's, the artist had the support of several Republics and the Mayor of Moscow because his foundries, which once turned out bigger-than-life statues of Lenin and Pushkin, kept people working. Mr. Tsereteli is a member of the presidium of the Russian Academy of Arts.
"The governments made materials and manpower available to him," Mr. Goldberg said. "The Mayor of Moscow is the chairman of the Columbus Committee of Russia."
The statue has been completed and its 14-foot-tall head is in a warehouse in Florida. It was shipped there in the unsuccessful effort to find American money and support for the project. Another 1,500 pieces are in storage in St. Petersburg, waiting for a home.
 
High-Level Agreement
 In the last days of the cold war, it looked like the wait would not be long.
One day in Moscow in 1991, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of Russia and President George Bush quietly reached an agreement. It had nothing to do with nuclear weapons or troop reductions or economic assistance.
During a tour of Mr. Tsereteli's studio, the two world leaders were asked which of two versions of the statue they preferred. The two men, each of whom would soon be thrown out of office, agreed that they liked the model showing Columbus at the wheel of his ship, with three flags snapping in the wind behind him. The base of the ship turns into a map of the New World and Columbus has his hand raised above his head, in a greeting or, according to some, a signal that the conquest and destruction of the Indians was about to begin.
Wilma Roberts, a 51-year-old Navajo, was signing people in for free Christmas lunches and toys from the Native American Indian Center here when she stopped to talk about the statue.
 
'I'll Protest. I'll Picket'
 "It looks to me like they're trying to make Christopher Columbus into a God," she said. "He was a thief, a rapist and a murderer. I guess the people of Russia don't have the slightest idea what happened to us. I'll protest. I'll picket. If they dig a hole, I'll jump in it. I'll do whatever it takes to stop it."
To offset such hard feelings, the statue supporters say they also plan to build a cultural center to display the contributions and triumphs of all the people of the New World.
"I don't look at it as a monument to Christopher Columbus," Mrs. Butler said. "It is a symbol of discovery and exploration."
The statue supporters say more than 300,000 people will visit the monument every year, bringing their wallets and pocketbooks with them.
Others disagree. "I think it's going to be pretty abominable," said Wes Blizzard, a high school art teacher in Columbus. "No one is going to pay money to see it. You can see the thing from miles away. And we've already got a Christopher Columbus statue. We don't need another one."
That statue stands under the sky and the pigeons in front of the Columbus City Hall, not far from where the Klan hopes to demonstrate.
It was a gift nearly 40 years ago from Genoa, Italy, as a testimonial of the values and virtues Christopher Columbus "entrusted to the human conscience."
The Columbus Mayor at the time, M. E. Sensenbrenner, said, "We shall ever cherish and be guided by its meaning."
It was dedicated, according to a plaque, on Oct. 12, 1955, "before 100,000 grateful Americans."

HEADLINE: AMTRAK PRESSING FOR CAPITAL FUNDS

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25

 BODY:
Although Amtrak is approaching self-sufficiency in its operating budget, the Government-owned railroad needs a substantial infusion of Federal money to replace dilapidated equipment and property, Federal and Amtrak officials say.
Fares paid 80 percent of the railroad's operating costs in 1993, continuing a steady increase from the 48 percent they contributed in 1981. The officials say the railroad could be self-sufficient in the next decade. 
 But they also say the railroad needs nearly $4 billion in Federal money to repair and replace its aging trains, dilapidated stations and inadequate maintenance yards. Without this money, experts say, Amtrak will have to curtail routes and service.
 
Declining Subsidies
 The Government's current $351 million operating subsidy to Amtrak augments passenger revenues of nearly $1 billion. The subsidy has fallen over the years from $720 million in 1981 as more passengers have traveled farther and as costs have been reduced through increased efficiency.
The Clinton Administration's current budget provides another $200 million for Amtrak's capital improvements, and railroad officials expect about the same amount next year.
But Amtrak's manager of capital investment, Bijay Pandit, said the railroad would need $3.9 billion for capital improvements in the next five years, including $2 billion for new cars -- more than half of its cars are more than 40 years old and some are 45 -- $917 million for maintenance, and about $1 billion for new maintenance yards, stations and reservation and information systems.
 
Invest or Perish
 Thomas M. Downs, who took office as Amtrak's president this month, said in an interview that the railroad's future depended on modernization. "You have to invest in the capital plant, or this railroad will simply die as we know it," he said. "We've delivered a more cost-effective railroad in the short term by not funding our capital plant."
Competition from the airlines also provided a strong incentive for modernization, he said. "Airlines can provide transportation cheaper that we can in a lot of corridors," Mr. Downs said. "So it can't be pricing that gets us out of this. It's got to be productivity, and a substantial portion of that comes from better capital investment."
Although the Clinton Administration is expected to continue to provide operating subsidies, the availability of capital funds is unclear. Morton Downey, Deputy Secretary of Transportation, acknowledged in an interview that "the present level of capital investment is not enough to keep the railroad going."
 
Difficult Choices
 Congress will consider Amtrak's financial needs next year and has asked the General Accounting Office, the research arm of Congress, to make a comprehensive study of the railroad. Kenneth M. Mead, the G.A.O.'s director of transportation, said, "If Amtrak's financial situation doesn't improve, they're going to have to cut back either routes or frequency of service outside the northeast corridor."
Amtrak has gradually wooed two million more passengers since 1981, for a total of 21 million this year, and reported an increase in longer, more profitable trips. It has also cut operating costs, largely by negotiating new labor agreements that gave managers more flexibility in assigning workers.
William L. Gallagher, Amtrak's senior director of route planning and strategy, said, "As the economy improves and new equipment is delivered, we expect that passenger revenues will increase substantially and allow us to continue our increase in the revenue-cost ratio."
Amtrak has ordered 195 regular coaches and 50 sleepers. "If you take away the antiquated equipment, some long hauls can be pushed into profitability," Mr. Gallagher said.
Only two routes have shown a clear profit: the Auto Train between Lorton, Va., near Washington, and Sanford, Fla., near Orlando, which made $5 million last year, and trains between Boston and Newport News, Va., which made $1.4 million. Amtrak leases the tracks to Newport News, which reduces overhead costs.
 
A Costly Success
 The northeast corridor, between Washington and Boston, turned a $128 million profit on its day-to-day operations last year, but lost money overall because of overhead costs, though Amtrak officials still consider it a success. The corridor had 10 million passengers last year, nearly half Amtrak's total, and provided $347 million in passenger revenues, about 35 percent of the total.
Long-distance runs, like the Sunset Limited between Los Angeles and Miami, accounted for 28 percent of Amtrak's passengers and $481 million in passenger revenue, nearly half the railroad's total. But these routes of more than 600 miles, including Chicago-Seattle and New York-Florida, lost a total of $152.5 million in 1992.
The remaining 20 percent of Amtrak's passengers were divided between short-distance services, which collected $63 million in passenger fares but lost $23 million in 1992, and state-supported services, which lost $10.6 million. Short-distance services are routes of less than 600 miles, like New York-Albany and Chicago-St. Louis. State-supported services are trains that Amtrak only runs at the request of state governments, like the route between Chicago and Springfield, Ill.
"Amtrak has been a shoestring operation," Mr. Mead said. "If Amtrak is going to keep operating all the routes it's been operating, it's going to need capital."

HEADLINE: U.S. Denies Request for $3 Million to Fight TB

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25

 BODY:
The United States cannot provide new funds requested by the World Health Organization to fight tuberculosis, says an official with the United States Agency for International Development.
The organization, which is part of the United Nations, had asked Washington to finance a third of a $9 million program to fight the deadly lung disease in developing countries and to thwart the mutation of the TB bacterium into drug-resistant strains. 
 "In the budget environment that we're looking at, it is a lot of money," the official, Dr. Ann Van Dusen, the United States agency's global health chief, said on Thursday. "It's funding we just don't have."
Urging that the United States agency approve $3 million for the United Nations program, Senator Frank Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, warned in a letter last week that "apathy courts a public health disaster."
But Dr. Van Dusen said her agency's health funds had already been committed to AIDS, child health and family planning programs. Moreover, the United States agency has cut other programs, including tropical disease and malaria vaccine research.
The United Nations organization contends that spending to fight tuberculosis, which kills three million people a year, more than all other infectious diseases combined, should be a high priority. The organization says $13 is enough to cure a tuberculosis patient in many countries.
"It is a logical, simple, cheap thing for America to do to bring a halt to what otherwise will be an incurable plague in the 21st century," said Richard Bumgarner, deputy director of the organization's tuberculosis program.
About one-third of the world's population is infected with tuberculosis, and eight million people get sick every year. Doctors hoped to eradicate TB in the United States by 2010, but cases instead have jumped 20 percent since 1985. And drug-resistant strains are rising rapidly.
The World Health Organization asserted last month that the United States and other countries were failing to fight TB. The world gave $16 million in tuberculosis aid to developing countries in 1990, when the disease killed 1.9 million people, but found $77 million for leprosy, which killed 2,000.
Mr. Bumgarner said the organization's project would provide developing countries with new drugs and training in TB treatments that work in half the time of the old yearlong therapy. Shorter therapy means patients have less time to spread TB.
Without American aid, "there's really no hope to do what we need to do," he Mr. Bumgarner said. He said he would reapply.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Moves on 'Privatization' Pledge

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Even before he becomes Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani has started to lay the groundwork for turning over some New York City agencies and their functions to private companies, indicating that he will move quickly on his pledges to improve services and shrink government through "privatization."
Mr. Giuliani and his aides announced last week that they had already begun drafting a proposal to shift control of as many as three of the city's 11 municipal hospitals -- probably those most ailing -- to private, nonprofit corporations. 
 Mr. Giuliani also met this week with executives of the New York Racing Association and asked them, in effect, to make an offer for the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation, which Mr. Giuliani has repeatedly derided as "the only bookie in New York City who loses money."
And the committees reviewing policy for the Mayor-elect are considering whether a variety of services now provided by the city might be done more efficiently by private groups. One committee, for example, has recommended privatization as an option for the city's Emergency Medical Service.
Though he offered few details during the campaign, Mr. Giuliani has praised the idea of selling off agencies or contracting out services as a way to create a leaner, more efficient government. The early proposals have made it clear that he intends to make a broad push for privatization soon after taking office, exempting few services from consideration, his aides said.
 
Praising the Profit Motive
 "We have to ask ourselves," said John S. Dyson, who is to serve as Mr. Giuliani's deputy mayor for economic issues, "can the government ever run government as effectively as somebody in the private sector with the profit motive?"
But it remains to be seen whether privatization will prove to be the panacea of municipal reform or whether it will merely serve as a hammer that Mr. Giuliani can use to extract concessions from municipal unions.
Under Mayor David N. Dinkins, New York City has already taken small, tentative steps toward having some services performed by contractors -- from managing centers for the elderly to inspecting boilers in commercial buildings. But it has lagged behind efforts in other cities, including Chicago, Philadelphia and Phoenix.
Earlier this year the New York City Partnership and the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry estimated that the city could increase revenue by $16 billion over the next decade if it privatized bus service, garbage collection and the water supply and treatment systems.
Mr. Giuliani's plans are certain to encounter the greatest resistance from those unions, and their supporters in the City Council, who fear that putting services in private hands will ultimately cost city workers their jobs.
In fact, the unions mounted an intense effort in the City Council to push through legislation that would slow efforts to privatize agencies by requiring detailed studies and extensive public hearings -- an effort ultimately blocked by Mr. Dinkins on Monday.
 
OTB Is a Target
 Few of Mr. Giuliani's proposals have been fully developed, and his aides declined to identify all of the agencies or services that might be considered candidates for privatization, though during the campaign Mr. Giuliani mentioned such services as hospitals, garbage collection and the operation of Kennedy International Airport.
Another prime candidate has become the Offtrack Betting Corporation, the city's beleaguered parimutuel betting agency. Formed in 1970, the agency was once a source of huge profits, generating $40 million for the city at its peak in 1977, only to struggle to break even in recent years.
Mr. Giuliani and his top aides, including Mr. Dyson and Peter J. Powers, met this week with officials of the New York Racing Association, which operates the state's race tracks, to discuss ways to privatize OTB.
Mr. Dyson said the new administration might first try to hire a manager to improve its operation but would seek a buyer soon. He added that the racing association was an obvious choice since it had expressed interest before, but that the administration would consider any bids, as well as the possibility of keeping the agency if it proved profitable again.
The Dinkins administration has already set a timetable for selling the agency after commissioning a study by Morgan Stanley & Company that estimated its sale could reap at least $55 million.
But that study recommended postponing a sale until the agency became more attractive to potential buyers. Under its current president, Hazel N. Dukes, the agency has streamlined service and reduced its administrative staff. Last month the Dinkins administration projected its sale by the end of 1994.
Mr. Giuliani also indicated his interest in privatization of the city's hospital system this week as he announced his selections to run the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, including Dr. Bruce Siegel, the New Jersey Health Commissioner, who has praised privatization.
Under a proposal now being drafted by Mr. Giuliani's aides, private, nonprofit boards would take control of as many as three of the city's municipal hospitals.
A senior policy adviser, Richard W. Schwartz, said the changes, while intended to shake up the city's health-care bureaucracy, would be put into effect without reducing the level of care or prompting layoffs of city workers, as many opponents of privatization fear.
Mr. Powers, who is to serve as Mr. Giuliani's top deputy mayor, said the new administration's broad goal was to introduce the concept of competition to city services.
 
Following Phoenix's Lead
 He cited the example of Phoenix, which has put out contracts each year for garbage collection, allowing private companies as well as the city's Sanitation Department to bid for contracts in districts. While the private companies won most of the bids, the city's department has become more efficient and now regularly underbids them. Earlier this year, the city estimated that it had saved $23.9 million since 1980 under the program.
"Competition is the key word," Mr. Powers said. "That's how you get lower costs and more efficiency."
Mr. Powers said the Giuliani administration would look at virtually every service that the city offers to consider whether such an approach could produce savings.
He added that the administration would try to reassure the city's unions, possibly by requiring that private companies hire displaced workers, and that it would also work to persuade a public often wary of turning over control of services traditionally performed by the government.
"This is something we're going to look at from Day 1, but we're not going to rush to privatize all of New York City," Mr. Powers said. "We want to move carefully. If you move too fast, the potential for making mistakes is much greater."

HEADLINE: Oldest Dairy Farm Is Put to Last Pasture

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNION VALE, N.Y.

 BODY:
After 199 years of raising animals and growing crops to feed them, the oldest farm in Dutchess County is going out of business.
The 200-acre Ken-Ray Farm here, founded in 1794, auctioned off its herd of 160 cows last month and plans a spring sale of tractors, balers, manure wagons and plows. The land itself is on the market, too, at a price of $1.5 million. 
 "It's not because I wanted to retire, but dairy farming is no longer profitable," said Raymond Vail, 66. Ever since he was old enough to walk to the barn, he has been working on the farm, which is named after him and his brother, Kenneth, who died in 1975.
He said that low prices for milk, the sluggish economy and high property taxes were chiefly responsible for the decision to go out of business.
 
A Continuing Decline
 The demise of the Ken-Ray Farm has become another statistic in the continuing decline of dairy farms in Dutchess County and the United States. The Federal Department of Agriculture reported 171,560 dairy farms in the nation in 1992, down from 181,270 in 1991.
In New York, the third-leading dairy state in the nation behind California and Wisconsin, the number of dairy farms dropped from 15,371 in 1982 to 10,625 in 1992, according to the State Department of Agriculture and Markets. But milk volume has remained high, largely because of increased production per cow on large farms.
Over all, the remaining dairy farms in the state are in healthy shape, with $1.53 billion of milk and milk products sold in 1992, up from $1.4 billion the year before. Geographically, though, the picture is spotty, with upstate farms doing well and downstate farms poorly, mainly because of taxes.
"One of the problem areas is in the Hudson Valley corridor between New York City and Albany," said Richard T. McGuire, the state Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets. "The real property tax is double there compared to what they are paying in the rest of the state."
 
Only 52 Left
 Today, there are only 52 dairy farms in Dutchess County, down from 105 in 1987 and from 275 in 1972, said David Tetor, the dairy agent for Cornell University's Cooperative Extension Service.
He said he expected three or four more farms in the county to go out of business before the end of the winter, in part because of drought that forces farmers to choose between selling their herd or buying feed to support them, in part because of longer-term economic pressures on farms here on the northern fringe of the New York City metropolitan region.
"If you ask farmers here what their major problem is, they will reply taxes," he said. "And what drives taxes up is people moving into the area."
The impact of a growing population is evident around the Ken-Ray Farm, particularly new houses and housing developments on Route 55 between the Taconic State Parkway and Pawling.
For Mr. Vail, the result of increased services required for the rising population has been a property tax of $24,000 a year, double what it was 10 years ago.
 
Stayed Too Long
 "Five years ago we considered selling out, but we wanted to farm as long as possible and we probably continued too long," he said. "This year was probably the worst crop year since the 1950's because of the drought. To stay in business we would have to buy feed, and we didn't have the money."
An added reason for selling this year was to settle the estate of his brother and co-owner, he said.
Mr. Vail, who has six children and 12 grandchildren, worked the farm with a son-in-law, Victor Holmes, and an assistant, Peter Deforest. Mr. Holmes now works for an excavating company and Mr. Deforest has been elected highway superintendent of Union Vale.
But Mr. Vail is still on the farm, uncertain about the future. Standing in an empty barn where he once milked up to 100 cows twice a day, Mr. Vail looked out a window at the empty farm fields and mused about his changed way of life.
 
The Natural Life
 "What I think I am going to miss the most, is looking out and seeing the cows out there," he said. "I liked coming into the barn at 4:30 in the morning to see the sun come up and hear the birds sing."
For the time being, he goes into the barn at 6 A.M. to milk two cows that he retained -- Millie, a Jersey, and Jamie, a Holstein -- and to care for nine calves that he has kept for his grandchildren.
He and his wife, Eleanor, a nurse who works at Sharon Hospital in nearby Connecticut, live in a house on the border of the farm, and plan to stay there after the land is sold.
"I'm a little on edge," Mrs. Vail said. "I was getting ready to retire, but now I'll have to wait and see what's going to happen on the farm."

HEADLINE: The State of the Game: In Extra Innings, No Score

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH

 BODY:
For the better part of half an hour, Bud Selig, the titular head of baseball, recently tried to sum up the state of the game. He talked about the restructuring and filling of the commissioner's office, which has been vacated for 16 months after the forced resignation of Fay Vincent, and he addressed the many pending policy matters that often seem to be in indeterminable states of being.
"When all is said and done, and our industry is looked at in the retrospect of history, people will understand exactly what we were trying to do," said Selig, baseball's acting commissioner since September 1992. 
 But, when asked if even he understands the situation all the time, Selig laughed. "No, not all the time," he said. "Some days, the understanding is quite muddled, to be perfectly blunt about it."
 
Congress Is Watching
 So it is for almost everyone connected with baseball.
How could it not be? After all, baseball moves into year two of life without a commissioner, and with a watchful Congress waiting to see if a new person to preside over baseball is appointed next month, as promised.
Meanwhile, of the two men charged with making the wheels of baseball turn in the interim, one of them, Peter N. T. Widdrington, chairman of the Toronto Blue Jays, left the position earlier this month, partly out of frustration. And retirement seems imminent for the other person, Dick Wagner, a former baseball club executive.
Widdrington temporarily signed on as chief administrator for what he thought would be three or four months only to find himself stationed in New York for nine months. Now he has departed. "I guess I'm just not quite used to the way things happen in baseball," he said. "My goal has always been to be effective and not let people down. To do that, I have to have a little bit of running room."
But running room is exactly what those in the central office lack these days because of the expected transition to a new commissioner and a restructuring that could change the nature of the way everything in baseball -- from marketing to revenue-sharing -- is conducted.
"It's fair to the new person that we not make a lot of new policy decisions," said one baseball executive, looking ahead to the naming of a new commissioner. "If you and I were coming to a new job, you and I wouldn't like to pick up a lot of stuff that had been done in the last 30 days."
And, insisted Selig, "The fact is that there will be a new commissioner one day."
Meanwhile, other changes and important decisions are being discussed.
Both the National and American Leagues are soon expected to bid adieu to their presidents. Employees in baseball's New York office sweat out rumors that there will be layoffs and that the headquarters will be moved to Chicago.
On the labor front, the basic agreement with the players union expires this week, and contract discussions have yet to ensue. And the much-ballyhooed three-division, multi-tiered playoff system is stalled in negotiations between management and the Players Association.
Baseball is also about to enter year one of its brave new world in which its major national television contract comes with no guaranteed revenue.
Still, in the midst of the seeming muddle, Selig insists that the world be patient.
"As we move along, we have to get three divisions done and we have to do a lot of other things, but at least we've addressed our problems, restructuring and otherwise," Selig said. "And remember, a year ago there was hysteria -- 'we don't have a commissioner, we don't have this, we don't have that.' But now there is no acrimony. It's really been an absolutely remarkable year."
So it is that Selig, a self-described optimist, prefers to believe that it will all work out. That revenue-sharing will save small-market teams such as his own. That the television deal with be a boon, not a boondoggle.
He prefers to point out that the angst in the central office in New York, as well as rumors of moves to Chicago, are decades old. As for actual layoffs, Selig, a realist, merely points out that no decisions have been made, but that baseball is an industry facing hard times within a national economy doing the same.
 
Listen to the Ticking
 Moves. Changes. Restructuring. Again, it's a myriad of decisions yet to be made, or at least made public. And when Selig says a lot of things have yet to be done, what is left unsaid is that they have to be done against a background in which some very loud clocks are ticking down.
The final bell on the great revenue sharing debate should sound Jan. 6. That's when the big-market owners and small-market owners will meet in Chicago. It is their high noon, when they should decide, at last, whether or not they will find a new, more economically equitable way of sharing the 28 varying pools of local revenue.
The biggest pools the owners want in on still belong solely to the Yankees' George Steinbrenner and the Mets' Fred Wilpon and Nelson Doubleday. The general belief remains that as Steinbrenner and the other richer teams on the East Coast go, so should revenue sharing.
Then comes Jan. 18-19, when the owners are scheduled to meet again and basically try to settle everything else, including the decision on the nominee for commissioner. Or so Selig hopes. To this day, Selig, the owner of the Milwaukee Brewers, insists that he is the man who would not be commissioner, despite feverish draft efforts by some of his fellow owners.
 
The Candidates
 Since Selig refuses to waver, other considerations must be made. And, indeed, other names continue to seep out. Such as Paul Kirk, the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee; Harvey Schiller, the executive director of the United States Olympic Committee; Dick Thornburgh, the former United States Attorney General, and Senator George Mitchell, the Democrats' majority leader from Maine.
While the great mystery continues, so does a correlating mystery of what the commissioner's office will look like once it has a warm body.
Selig insists the commissioner's role will be stronger. The restructuring, he says, will clarify a lot of the gray areas, ambiguities that he believes led to so much animosity in the past.
Until baseball owners start to unveil some answers, to reach some decisions, it will always seem a muddle on some days, as Selig said. He must now find ways to reduce those days in number, if only to assure history will treat this current era as kindly as he hopes.

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Patience Is More Than a Virtue for McIlvaine; It's a Strategy

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Joe McIlvaine, the man with the mandate to restore the Mets to respectability, then to greater heights, has spent the past couple of months looking for a couple of teams to twist his arm and wrest Bret Saberhagen and Bobby Bonilla away from him in exchange for a shortstop, perhaps a starting pitcher and an assortment of promising young players.
Trading high-priced stars for low-paid young players. If the idea rings a bell from a previous McIlvaine job, bang the gong loudly. As general manager of the San Diego Padres, McIlvaine was directed by the Gang of 15 -- the owners -- to divest the club of its high-priced stars instantly, if not yesterday. 
 But McIlvaine found that chore distasteful -- is this any way to run a ball club? -- and opted to forgo the remaining half of his contract, two and a half years worth. Still, in talking to other clubs about Saberhagen and Bonilla, is McIlvaine not engaging in the same kind of activity he shunned in San Diego? If not, what's the difference?
"That's easy," McIlvaine said, responding to the questions without needing time to form an answer. "In San Diego, we had a contending team and all of a sudden we were ordered to dismantle it because they didn't want to contend anymore. Here, I came into a situation where we're in last place, it's a rebuilding effort and you have to divest yourself of some of your high-priced talent and get younger players.
"If I was in San Diego in last place, I'd do the same thing. I'd move some of the high-priced guys to get multiples. I was guarding against that in San Diego because I thought with the addition of a pitcher or two, we could win. We were a pitcher or two away from winning in '92. Ed Whitson went down and didn't pitch all year. We never really found a replacement for him."
With 35 games remaining in 1992, on Aug. 28, the Padres were in third place, only six games from the top. That was as close as they would come to first place that late in the season most likely for years. The dismantling process already had begun. About three months earlier, the Padres' owners had begun telling McIlvaine to begin shedding the high-priced players.
The Mets' owners haven't told McIlvaine whom to trade and whom to keep. Nor, they have said, have they placed economic restrictions on him. They brought McIlvaine back because they had confidence that he could pull the Mets out of the quagmire in which they have drowned the past two seasons.
In attacking his chore, McIlvaine has passed up the quick-fix method -- signing proven but expensive free agents. McIlvaine sees expense in two ways -- money and lost draft choices as compensation for free agents.
He won't pursue Walt Weiss to plug the shortstop hole because the signing would cost the Mets their second-round pick in next June's amateur draft. He wouldn't pursue Rafael Palmeiro because he felt paying him about $6 million a year wouldn't be worth it considering the club won't be contending for any division championships the next couple of seasons.
Yet Palmeiro would have helped restore respectability, something the fans will have to see before they begin returning to Shea Stadium. Shrunken attendance resulting from their putrid performance cost the Mets $25 million or more in gate receipts the past two seasons. Mets fans have a history of letting the proprietors know (see 1979) when they don't like their product.
But McIlvaine remains undaunted by the failure to add a proven player who could convince the fans the club is serious about giving them an improved product.
"It's December," he said. "Time is not up yet on that front. We're going to be competitive this year. There are enough irons in the fire that some type of veteran will come to us. The off season runs from October to April. You don't get all your business done in October and you don't get all your business done in April. The time to look is April, when the season is ready to begin, and see what has happened."
Anyway, McIlvaine said, his best time for trading is spring training. Even more specifically, it's March 27. On that date in 1987, the Mets acquired David Cone from Kansas City, and on that date in 1992, the Padres obtained Gary Sheffield from Milwaukee.
"You just seem to be able to do something at that time," McIlvaine said. "Or one you've been working on all winter comes to fruition.
"In a normal year, you have to do less," he added. "But this year we have to do more. We're getting there. We're just about on schedule."
 
 
Looking for His Star
 Based on his performance in 1992, his second full season in the major leagues, Ray Lankford, the St. Louis Cardinals' center fielder, appeared ready to work his way into the corps of outstanding young players who have begun to dominate the majors. Lankford, though, fell from the threshold with a thud last season.
His batting average plummeted 55 points, from .293 to .238, his slugging percentage 134 points, from .480 to .346; his home-run output plunged from 20 to 7, he drove in 45 runs instead of 86 and he had 14 stolen bases in 28 attempts after having 42 in 66 tries the year before.
"We went down to the instructional league and he was a very good student down there," Cardinals Manager Joe Torre said of Lankford's recent activity. "The disappointment I had in Ray Lankford doesn't even approach the disappointment he had in himself. He was down there working on things, working on swinging the bat. His enthusiasm leads me to believe last year was a fluke. It was probably a lot of things piling up on him that he had trouble overcoming."
 
 
Dykstra at the Top of the Order
 Eat your heart out, Rickey.
The four-year extension Mark Fleisher has negotiated for Lenny Dykstra with the Philadelphia Phillies is the sort of deal Rickey Henderson thought he should get when he became a free agent last month. But Henderson fell far short as the two leadoff batters gained distinctly disparate contracts that were in direct proportion to their World Series performances.
Henderson's team, the Toronto Blue Jays, won, but Henderson played so poorly and Dykstra so spectacularly he put Henderson firmly in his shadow as the leadoff man of the moment. As it was, Henderson, 35 years old yesterday, received more from Oakland than many baseball people expected, $8.6 million for two years. Dykstra, soon to be 31, will get $24.9 million for four years beginning in 1995.
Even though Henderson's previous contract made him one of the two highest-paid players at $3 million a year, he never was happy with it. He would be even less happy if he knew that in the four years between that contract and this one, 141 players signed contracts worth more than $3 million a year.
