HEADLINE: BACKTALK;
N.F.L.'s Remote Control

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
Fox is Football and Football is Fox, and has been for at least two years; when "In Living Color" counterprogrammed the 1992 Super Bowl halftime show it became clear that the adolescent sensibility of the fourth network was a perfect fit with crunch time. The halftime show is a window into the soul of football; need we be reminded that Michael Jackson starred in the last one?
At first, football may not be as popular on Fox as it has been on the traditional networks because football as cartoon entertainment is fading. Real cartoon heroes like Bart Simpson make more sense than human cartoon heroes like steroidian linemen. Real cartoon heroes require less maintenance, fewer drugs, no money and can be erased. 
 But it won't matter because Rupert Murdoch, who can envision the future because he can create it, has sensed football's enormous potential as that ultimate video game for adults, the interactive gambling show.
Let's back up a bit. All of this happened because power always shifts. Ike was President when CBS began broadcasting National Football League games in 1956, Mickey Mantle was being booed and the hot books were "Peyton Place" and "The Organization Man." In the era of togetherness and crabgrass, men needed a socially acceptable way of tuning out women on Sunday afternoons. What better way than watching better men cream one another?
The N.F.L. was then dominated by clans like the Maras of New York and the Rooneys of Pittsburgh, Irishmen struggling to establish themselves in an English-oriented country, pioneers of the game, former legal bookmakers, men who ran their clubs despotically, benevolently and, whether or not you were on the same page with them, by their own moral standards. The Giants even had a Catholic chaplain who had the run of the cluhouse. The sons and nephews of the Clan and its allies grew up as ballboys and press-box runners and went into TV and advertising.
As the new princes of Manhattan, they carried the Clan's sensibilities on the invisible tramway that moved from the Polo Grounds to Toots Shor's, later P. J. Clarke's (they were called "watering holes" then) to Brooks Brothers to Black Rock. It was basically New York Giant football players and advertising executives and CBS sports producers, young and smart and energetic, who created this multibillion dollar industry from hot air waves. Their beau ideal was Frank Gifford, Giant star, Mara darling, nighthawk, eventually a CBS sportscaster.
The real dominance of CBS lasted only into the late 60's. The American Football League, led by Jewish newcomers like Al Davis of the Oakland Raiders and Sonny Werblin of the New York Jets, fronted by the son of Hungarian immigrants, Joe Namath of the white shoes and the truth (sex and whisky go with football), forced a merger and the shuffling of loyalties and power. Roone Arledge of the American Broadcasting Company may not have invented television sports but he shaped it into a mass entertainment. He also raided CBS (as CBS once raided NBC) for top production and on-air talent and made Monday night the logical extension of Sunday afternoon.
The wheel turns. The kind of loyalty the Maras and CBS enjoyed had to do with lack of options. Do we need to repeat that Notre Dame was the Gipper's third or fifth or eighth college? Or that Jumpin' Joe Dugan, the Ruth Era Yankee, got his name from his propensity to switch leagues? Remember Robert Irsay, who moved the Colts from Baltimore to Indianapolis in the middle of the night? Even Gifford jumped ship for ABC.
And now Murdoch, another newcomer pushing his way into mainstream power and confirming that power. Murdoch verified the old established league's social and economic importance. But he did more than that as far as the current group of owners were concerned. He insured the league's future in America and the world.
Murdoch is a main toll collector on the information highway, perhaps the world's most wired man. He has the hardware and the organization to send those football games, those halftime shows, those Coke commercials into every corner of the known universe. Football is not baseball, which you need to understand to enjoy. Football is Nintendo for big boys.
And the next major step in the evolution of sports, the inevitable step being slowed by state legislatures lobbied by major sports organizations, is universal sports betting on American games. It may even come to foreign countries before it is fully legalized here. And Fox will not only carry the games, but it will air the interactive shows that will make it possible for millions of Chinese to someday sit in their homes and bet on games, on quarters, on over and unders, on whether or not a pass will be completed.
That's what happened last week when Fox and Football, the future, got together. Let's enjoy it and not whine about loyalty and hostile takeover and the end of Western civilization. John Madden and Terry Bradshaw personally presided over the end of Western civilization while at CBS, and if sports TV history is a guideline, you can bet on them to jump to Fox and into sports' New Age.

HEADLINE: The Honor Roll, of Sorts, for 1993

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
IT WAS a wonderful year in the stock market, but not for all companies. Some suffered for treating their customers badly, some for being too nice to them. Some executives found opportunity in adversity, some made their own opportunity and some showed fortuitous timing. And any year in which a football player becomes a Wall Street star clearly deserves note. There will, unfortunately, be no presentation ceremony for the following, richly deserved, awards.
 
 
Fire the Messenger Award
 To Prudential Securities, for dumping its ad agency as bad publicity grew. The new agency is to find a slogan to replace "the most important thing we earn is your trust," which became embarrassing after Prudential agreed to pay $371 million to customers for abusing that trust when it sold highly dubious limited partnerships in the 1980's. Our suggested slogan: "Let buygones be bygones."
 
Employment Security Award
To the top executives of General Motors, who gave themselves employment contracts in the wake of the departure to Volkswagen of Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, the first (and so far only) G.M. executive to prove to have marketable skills.
 
Brilliant Management Award
To Maytag, the appliance giant, whose British executives cleverly calculated that they could bolster sales by offering two free trans-Atlantic plane tickets to anyone who bought at least $375 worth of appliances. They were stunned when 200,000 people in Britain and Ireland tried to take them up on it.
 
Fool Me Once . . . Award
To Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn, the large New York law firm. Proskauer signed on to represent Towers Financial, the collapsing empire of the erstwhile publisher of The New York Post, Steven Hoffenberg, in suits alleging Towers had welched on fees it owed to other law firms. Having failed to get payment up front, Proskauer wound up suing Mr. Hoffenberg and Towers for -- surprise -- unpaid legal fees.
 
Watch What I Do . . . Award
To Michael Dell, chairman of Dell Computer. On March 9, he proclaimed that Dell was clearly in "the winner's circle" and said that "the power of our direct marketing approach continues to be underestimated." Within the next three weeks, he took in $11.3 million selling Dell stock, at an average price of $38 a share. By summer, as profits turned to losses, the shares were fetching less than $15.
 
Best Self-Deal Award
To John Malone, the president and chief executive of Tele-Communications Inc. In 1991, he spun off Liberty Media from the parent company, on terms that discouraged public holders from taking Liberty while allowing him to buy a lot of its shares without putting up much cash. Now T.C.I. is repurchasing Liberty -- on vastly more friendly terms -- as a prelude to its own acquisition by Bell Atlantic. But for the earlier transactions, the Bell Atlantic takeover might have been worth less than $100 million to Mr. Malone. Now, his stake will be worth about $1 billion.
 
Due Diligence Award: Lawyer Division
To the New York firm of Squadron, Ellenoff, Plesent, Sheinfeld & Sorkin. The firm helped to take public a company whose chief financial officer turned out to be a disbarred lawyer who had served time after being convicted of stealing money from clients. Asked if the firm knew about the criminal record, which was not disclosed to investors, a partner shrugged off the query. "That is not the responsibility of the law firm," explained Howard Squadron.
 
Due Diligence Award: Executive Division
To John Sculley, who left Apple Computer to take over Spectrum Information Technologies. He expressed surprise when asked about a variety of Spectrum's past brushes with regulatory authorities. "It sounds like you know more about it than I do at this point," he told a reporter.
 
All Bluster, No Bite Award
To Robert Crandall of American Airlines, for his repeated threats to replace flight attendants if they struck, without having any effective plan to deal with a walkout. When it happened just before Thanksgiving, there was chaos, red ink and a quick surrender by American.
 
 
Labor Leader Of the Year Award
To Denise Hedges, head of the flight attendants union at American, for calling Mr. Crandall's bluff and providing organized labor with one of its few prominent victories in recent years.
 
Stock Promoter Of the Year Award
To Lawrence Taylor, the linebacker for the New York Giants and part-time president of All-Pro Products, a company with virtually no operations whose stock almost tripled in its first seven days of trading. After that move, Mr. Taylor forecast it would double again, leaving him with stock worth $20 million, for which he had paid $5,750. So far, the market value is holding at about $10 million.
 
I.P.O. Reversal Award: Winning Division
To Motor Coach Industries, the bus manufacturer sold to the public by the Dial Corporation, at $13 a share in August. The price cracked within minutes of the beginning of trading, and went as low as $11 in the next few weeks. But in November, the company agreed to be acquired by a Mexican firm -- for stock worth $16.72 a share.
 
I.P.O. Reversal Award: Losing Division
To Mathsoft, a software company that went public in February at $13, with insiders selling 1.25 million shares. The shares traded for $23 the first day. But they fell when the company posted disappointing profits in April, and again in July when it said it was losing money. By September the share price was below $5 -- and is only a bit higher now.
 
Bad P.R. Award
To CS First Boston. In a year in which Wall Street compensation rose into the stratosphere, it was the only firm that came in for heavy media criticism -- not for paying too much but for paying too little. Some investment bankers -- insulted by annual bonuses of less than $1 million -- drew sympathy as they fled to other, less parsimonious, firms.
 
Clouded Crystal Ball Award
To Bennett LeBow, for his forecast that Skybox International would be trading above $14 a share by early 1994. Brooke Group, Mr. LeBow's troubled conglomerate, had valued Skybox at that price in distributing shares as part of a plan to evade making good on a previous guarantee about Brooke's stock price. The current value of Skybox is under $7.
 
Career Timing Award
To Louis V. Gerstner Jr., for abandoning tobacco by resigning as chief executive of RJR Nabisco a few days before Philip Morris devastated industry profits by slashing cigarette prices. Mr. Gerstner took over I.B.M., where the bad news was already known to everyone.
 
Money Can't Buy Harmony Award
To the members of the Haft family, who built a retail empire consisting of the Dart Drug, Trak Auto and Crown Book chains and in the process came to thoroughly despise each other. Herbert, the dad, fired one son. Another son lined up with Dad, but Mom and Sis stood with the fired son. Everybody has sued everybody else, repeatedly.
 
Public Service Award
To Carlos Alves dos Santos, former budget director of Brazil, who was found to have $1.7 million stuffed in his mattress, plus $300,000 and 212 pounds of gold (value, about $1 million) in safety deposit boxes.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Holiday Cheer for the Toronto Market

BYLINE: By Clyde H. Farnsworth

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
CANADA'S stock markets must know something the people don't. In contrast to a general year-end mood of sullenness and pessimism, reflecting high joblessness, taxes and debt, the markets have never been more buoyant.
The Toronto Stock Exchange, which does 78 percent of all the trading in the land, has risen 25 percent this year, as measured by its leading index, outperforming Wall Street and many other markets abroad. Volume has never been stronger. 
 The story was roughly similar for Montreal, with 17 percent of the activity; Vancouver, with 3 percent, and the Alberta and Winnipeg exchanges, which do the rest of the business.
"We're sort of firing on all cylinders," said Tony Massie, portfolio manager of the Global Strategy of Canada Growth Fund, who manages $275 million of assets from Vancouver.
It's been a long time since Canadian markets have generated such enthusiasm. The recession has been far deeper and longer here than in the United States. Companies struggling in a freer trade environment have laid off tens of thousands of workers and made heavy use of labor-saving technology. The unemployment rate is nearly twice as high as in the United States.
But now the tide seems to be turning. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, which keeps tabs on the developed world, says Canada's economic growth will outpace that of every industrial country except Turkey in the next two years.
Bay Street, Canada's equivalent to Wall Street, is encouraged not only by growth prospects but the country's improved competitiveness.
The Canadian dollar, at around 75 cents, is near a six-year low. Inflation, at under 2 percent, is below that in the United States. Corporate restructuring has brought pain but also the productivity gains that translate into a higher percentage of revenues falling to the bottom line as profits.
Fred Ketchen, senior vice president and director of equity trading at ScotiaMcLeod Inc., a Toronto brokerage house, said he anticipated another 20 percent rise in the Toronto Stock Exchange 300 Index in 1994, fueled by "substantial increases in corporate income."
In August, the Toronto Stock Exchange 300 Index finally eclipsed its old high set back in 1987. Since August that index has set 14 new highs. The most recent high was 4,307.67 on Dec. 8. The close last Thursday was 4,246.39. (The market was closed Friday and will be closed tomorrow.)
Bullishness has been accompanied by ever increasing volume. Toronto's daily average of 60 million shares is almost twice last year's figure but still only a third to a quarter of the daily trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
The pure economic function of stock markets -- the raising of new capital for entrepreneurs -- was also well served. Investors bought $20 billion Canadian of new equity in 1993, nearly twice the $11 billion of 1992, the previous record year.
Further encouraging Bay Street's bulls has been a pickup in global economic activity, led by the United States, which means greater demand for the resource-based commodities in which Canada specializes. Gold, base metals, forest products and other such raw materials make up a quarter of the value of Toronto's listed stocks.
"Canada's day is coming," said George Domolky, who manages $1 billion of Canadian assets in two mutual funds of the Fidelity Group in Boston. "People want to live better in the world, and this means demand for things Canada produces, such as lumber, nickel and gold."
While Canada is just another international market to American investors, Mr. Domolky noted, "it has the advantage of having the same accounting methods, the same management style, and people speak the same language." Fidelity, the world's largest collection of mutual funds, altogether holds about $5 billion in Canadian stocks.
Toronto's gold index has doubled in 1993; oil stocks are up about a third and forest products 50 percent.
Yet there were a number of other high fliers. The robustness of the North American auto industry has meant especially big gains for Canadian steel and auto-parts companies. Magna International, one of the stars in auto parts, went from $35 to more than $60 this year and had been as low as $2.50 in 1991. Stelco, the biggest steel company, soared from $1 to around $8 this year.
Some high technology companies have also done well. Newbridge Networks, which discovered ways to punch more data through a line, has tripled this year to around $70 and was as low as $4 the year before. Delrina, which worked out a way to fax material from a personal computer, has jumped sixfold to around $25.
While many Bay Streeters remain optimistic, they also note hazards ahead. Quebec appears ready to elect a new separatist government in 1994, which once again will raise questions about national unity. Canada's fiscal problems are even more severe than those of the United States and may require draconian spending cuts.
Noted James Muir, director of RG Capital Management, asset management arm of Richardson Greenshields of Canada Ltd., a Toronto investment firm, "the markets could still get a little jittery."

INDUSTRY: NAICS523210 SECURITIES & COMMODITY EXCHANGES (85%); SIC6231 SECURITIES & COMMODITY EXCHANGES (85%); SIC6712 OFFICES OF BANK HOLDING COMPANIES (64%);

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
A Toy Indicator May Indicate A Bearish 1994

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
IT was the Christmas of hope on Wall Street.
Ever since 1990, the financial community has entered the holiday season with profound doubts about the ability, or the willingness, of Americans to spend enough to make Christmas merry for retailers. 
 But this year was different. There was optimism, about both the economy and the Christmas season. As it turns out, Christmas expectations may have been a bit excessive. If so, this will have been a quite decent season, but one that was still a bit disappointing for many storekeepers.
And in that fact may lie a bearish indicator for the stock market in 1994. When Wall Street Christmas expectations prove optimistic, the next year tends to have some unpleasant surprises for stockholders.
The final Christmas sales figures are not in yet, of course, but share buyers appear to be suspicious. Sears, by all accounts, is doing quite well this season. But its stock is off 5 percent since Thanksgiving and still doing better than the Standard & Poor's index of general retailers, of which it is a part. That index is down 10 percent, while the specialty retailer index is off 2 percent. And that has come as most stocks have advanced. Americans may not be buying as many toys, of either the child or adult variety, as the seers had expected.
The course of retail stocks in this most important of seasons has generally been up in recent years. The last time the index of general retailers dropped was in 1986. The specialty retailer index has fallen only two other times in recent years, in 1986 and 1989. One does not have to be a stock-market historian to recall that both 1987 and 1990 produced a lot of negative volatility. Or, to put it in the upbeat tone that is more appropriate for the season of hope, buying opportunities were created.
As Robert Barbera, the chief economist at Lehman Brothers, points out, the causes of the market setbacks of 1987 and 1990 did not have much in common. In 1987, the economy was so strong that the Fed felt a need to tighten credit. In the midst of a speculative frenzy, the stock market ignored higher interest rates for months, but then crashed in what proved to be a massive overreaction brought on by a combination of panic and a foolish institutional investment strategy called portfolio insurance. In 1990, the problem was a weak economy aggravated by worries over higher oil prices brought on by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
Last week's report that personal income rose nicely in November helped to confirm that the economy is gaining strength, but the big question for share buyers is how much of that is already in prices. "I think the economy will do fine, rates will go up, and we will have a correction," said Mr. Barbera, noting that economically sensitive stocks did very well the last two years.
The slightly disappointing Christmas season is no guarantee that 1994 will bring stock market problems like those of 1987 or 1990. But it is a reminder that it can be easier to exceed low expectations than it is to meet high ones.

HEADLINE: At Newsstands, Black Is Plentiful

BYLINE: By MICHAEL E. ROSS

 BODY:
AT a boisterous prepublication open house recently, Sheryl E. Huggins, the publisher of Shade, weaved through a crowd of black artists, writers, photographers and others, music from A Tribe Called Quest booming from the stereo.
There in one room at the magazine's Manhattan office, wearing everything from business suits to dreadlocks, was a microcosm of the diverse readership Ms. Huggins hopes to attract when Shade makes its debut in March -- a microcosm, too, of a black diversity that has fostered a flurry of new magazines. 
 For years the world of black publishing could largely be defined in two words: Ebony and Jet. Ebony was founded in 1945 and Jet in 1951, both by the Johnson Publishing Company, in Chicago, and with a combined circulation of two million, they have paced the field. Since then, black magazines have appeared infrequently, in fits and starts, with the most notable being Black Enterprise, about business matters, in 1970, and Essence, for black women, in 1971.
In recent years, though, black publishing has exploded. When Shade appears, it will join a crowded, raucous field of fledgling publications devoted to various aspects of black culture, from health to entertainment, hair care to politics.
Here's a sampling: Vibe (Time Warner's new magazine, begun in June), The Source (May 1991) and YSB (September 1991) focus on music, life styles and culture. Emerge (October 1989) and Upscale (February 1990) concentrate on news and social issues. Black Elegance (June 1986) examines fashion, while Heart & Soul, started by Rodale Press in June, addresses health issues. And African Voices, started in April by a Brooklyn-based journalist, seeks a literary audience.
This burst of activity is rooted in recognition of a lucrative market. As a sense of black identity widens, publishers and advertisers have discovered that black America is not a monolith of attitudes and opinions, but a rich mixture lending itself to numerous expressions in print -- and numerous opportunities for advertising.
"The 'black audience' is very diverse," said James Bernard, editor of The Source, a monthly whose circulation has topped 100,000. "People realize there's more than one type of black person, and more than one type of young black person."
It was perhaps inevitable that black diversity and niche marketing would come together to create a variety of black magazines for a national audience. Now, it is equally inevitable that those magazines will be subject to publishing's law of natural selection: only the well-financed, well-advertised and well-positioned survive.
In the constant battle for newsstand supremacy, with newsstands groaning from the weight of specialty publications, the biggest challenge facing any newcomer is distinguishing itself from the crowd, making its mission clear.
And new black magazines can expect an especially difficult time attracting and holding new advertisers, which often cannot justify new expenses when many mainstream publications already reach black readers.
"If you have a magazine that reaches an audience no one else is reaching or reaches them in a unique way, regardless of its niche, the magazine can do very well," said Roberta Garfinkel, director of print media for the ad agency McCann-Erickson. "The pie is the available dollars there are to spend, and it doesn't grow. The more choices advertisers have, the more carefully they have to spend money."
Edward J. Atorino, an analyst with Dillon, Read, said: "It's easy to launch magazines. The test will come in the next economic downturn."
The battle for survival has led to creative strategies for getting a magazine in the public eye, and keeping it there. One of the more unusual approaches has cashed in on the perception that black magazines are a lot alike.
In February 1992, six magazines embarked on a marketing strategy starkly different from the usual winner-take-all approach. The six -- Emerge, Ebony, Essence, Black Enterprise, YSB and Black Elegance -- linked themselves in displays in 2,700 stores nationwide. The joint promotion, tied to Black History Month, yielded significant sales increases for all the magazines in 1992 and again in 1993, said Yvonne Pearson, a sales director for Essence and a manager of the cooperative project.
Five of the six will do it again next February. YSB dropped out, but Jet and Heart & Soul have signed on. Ms. Pearson said the 1994 promotion "will have 6,000 displays in stores, and we're looking to do more connecting with other venues -- radio, TV and the newspapers." While the promotion goes against the grain, it showed that established voices and relative unknowns could pool their efforts to dramatic effect.
THE genesis and development of two other magazines offer a clue on how some black magazines would weather a shakeout. YSB and Emerge are properties of Black Entertainment Television (BET), whose programming -- syndicated series, music videos and special-event coverage -- reaches about 36 million homes.
YSB (for Young Sisters and Brothers) began publication in September 1991, with a mission of attracting younger black readers. Debra L. Lee, YSB's president and publisher, said it was started mainly to reach teen-agers. "We saw there was nothing out there for teen-agers, who are facing guns in the schools, drugs, AIDS and other issues," she said. "We found a need."
The network began YSB after selling it with a three-part strategy: a splashy test issue mailed to prospective subscribers; a telephone offer to attract charter subscribers, at $14.95 for 10 months; and ads placed on BET. "We made YSB a household word quickly, through our reach into homes via cable," Ms. Lee said. YSB claims a paid circulation of 100,000.
Emerge, which addresses current affairs, politics and life styles for readers 25 to 54, was started in 1989 by Wilmer C. Ames Jr., a former reporter at Time magazine, with money from BET, Time Warner and private investors. The network acquired a controlling interest in December 1991, after buying Time Warner's 19.5 percent stake. The magazine, recently redesigned, puts its circulation at 150,000 -- "not exactly a ton of people," said Martin Walker, of Walker Communications, a New York consulting firm. "The fact that they're still around is a testament to their role in the marketplace."
Vibe, which calls itself a multicultural magazine, has a role in the marketplace that seems to work to the advantage of Time Warner, its owner.
"Time Warner has been looking for a way into the youth market," Mr. Walker said. "Vibe's good for that. It's a natural tie-in with the Warner side -- the movies and music, the synergy they want."
Ms. Lee sees room for even more black-oriented magazines, to a point.
"The marketplace is diverse enough, and there are enough untapped segments of that marketplace, that for readers it's wide open," she said. But as for advertising, "there may not be enough to go around."
While some new magazines begin with promising budgets -- Ms. Huggins said the cost for Shade was "definitely in the six-figure range" -- others began on a relative shoestring. African Voices was started in April on a modest $10,000, said Carolyn A. Butts, the editor and co-founder.
"We're interested in highlighting serious writers and artists," said Ms. Butts, a former reporter for The New York Post. "With the success of Toni Morrison, Maya Angelou and others, there's definitely an audience for black writers and artists, and a need for a magazine that highlights up-and-coming writers, the ones who'll take the reins for the next generation. We want to be The New Yorker of the black literary world."
While Vibe, The Source, Shade and African Voices are products of New York City, the growth of black magazine publishing is not just a New York phenomenon. YSB and Emerge are published in Washington. Upscale, based in Atlanta, boasts a paid circulation of 250,000, as well as full-color ads from national advertisers like Ford, Procter & Gamble and Philip Morris.
HEART & SOUL, which will begin quarterly publication in 1994, is based in Emmaus, Pa. And Image, which will focus on black men, with a print run estimated at 50,000 to 100,000, is set to begin in April from its base in Studio City, Calif., near Los Angeles.
The economy, of course, is always a factor in publishing. So does the sudden birth of so many magazines suggest that it has turned a corner? Not necessarily. Florestine Purnell, Emerge's managing editor, conceded that for much of 1993 "our ad pages have been down, though that's reflective of the industry as a whole."
And Ms. Garfinkel expressed the uncertainty that figures in all magazines' plans. "I'm not sure the economy's getting better," she said, "so much as I think it's not getting any worse."

LENGTH: 691 words

HEADLINE: Mr. Giuliani's Mixed Start

 BODY:
Rudolph Giuliani says he wants to do things differently. Fine: that's why he was elected. But in building an administration, different does not have to mean inexperienced. So far, inexperience is the unfortunate distinction shared by Mr. Giuliani's designated deputies.
No fair New Yorker would ask Mr. Giuliani to staff his administration with veterans who represent the old ways of doing things. There are, however, professional, nonideological men and women whose knowledge could help guide a new government through the municipal morass. Former mayors were not shy about borrowing talent from previous administrations, and the city benefited. 
 Surely the Mayor-elect could have found some deputy mayors with more knowledge about New York City's complex government than the four he has chosen. Surely, too, he could have shown greater fidelity to his pledge to create a City Hall staff representing the city's diversity by including an African-American among his deputies.
His failure to do so sends a damaging message to a black community still shaken by David Dinkins's defeat. It is true that Mr. Giuliani has appointed a number of black commissioners, and several Latinos, but agency heads are not as influential as members of a mayor's inner circle.
Some of Mr. Giuliani's agency appointments are impressive. Paul Crotty, who will be his Corporation Counsel, was a commissioner under former Mayor Ed Koch; Mr. Crotty's calm temperament and knowledge about city government should be a great help to the new Mayor. The incoming Police Commissioner, William Bratton, and head of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, Dr. Bruce Siegel, have solid reputations. So does Luis Miranda Jr., who will chair the corporation's board of directors.
The budget director, Abraham Lackman, is an experienced number cruncher. The new head of the Human Resources Administration, Marva Hammons, is known for innovative ideas.
However admirable those appointees, none will serve on Mr. Giuliani's City Hall staff, and that's where the power is. Though he merits praise for his plans to trim staff at City Hall, reducing the number of deputy mayors from six to four, Mr. Giuliani would do himself and his city a favor by adding one more deputy -- a strong administrator with detailed knowledge of the city.
The Mayor-elect's top deputy, Peter Powers, is a bright and amiable lawyer and lifelong friend who ran Mr. Giuliani's campaigns. Like chief executives everywhere, Mr. Giuliani has every right to a trusted confidant. But Mr. Powers, who will run city agencies on a daily basis as the Deputy Mayor for operations, hasn't held a public job since he was a Parks Department intern more than 30 years ago. That means he'll be starting from scratch.
The three other deputy mayors are no more reassuring. Mr. Giuliani has put Ninfa Segarra, a Board of Education member, in charge of health, education and human services. Ms. Segarra has held other city jobs but her record was undistinguished, and none of her positions touched on health and social policy. Perhaps Mr. Giuliani's creation of new positions -- directors of social services, education and health policy -- is meant to address Ms. Segarra's shortcomings.
Still it does not bode well that as a school board member, the volatile Ms. Segarra has put highly emotional and political matters like AIDS education ahead of the broader educational needs of children.
Fran Reiter, the Deputy Mayor for planning and community relations, is a television marketing consultant who was named because she's chairwoman of the Liberal Party, which endorsed Mr. Giuliani's candidacy. John Dyson, Mr. Giuliani's choice for Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, is a former chairman of the State Power Authority and a wealthy investor. But he, like the others, comes with minimal experience in municipal government.
Mr. Giuliani says he doesn't need a powerful deputy because he'll be a hands-on mayor. Good, the city needs an aggressive leader. But no mayor can bury himself in details. Mr. Giuliani would be wise to bring in a seasoned coach to help his team through the early going.

HEADLINE: Salvaging Military Technology

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Wall St.'s Role in Military Conversion" (Viewpoints, Dec. 12), Jon B. Kutler says too little Federal money -- a mere half billion dollars -- has been earmarked to develop civilian products by military contractors. 
 Private capital hasn't been eager to finance these efforts not primarily because of a gap in markets but rather because of military prime contractors' poor record in bringing civilian technologies to market at reasonable prices. The principal reason for this failure lies in the organization of military companies.
Rather than give matching grants to help military contractors diversify and restructure, a more efficient method would be to finance mass transport, environmental and other public authorities to buy technological services and prototypes on a competitive basis.
 
MARTIN C. SPECHLER
Indianapolis, Dec. 13
 
The writer is an economics professor at Indiana University in Indianapolis.

HEADLINE: A More Accurate Historical Model

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I take issue with Albert Sindlinger's likening the current economy to that of the late 1920's in "Kill-Joy at the Recovery Ball" (Profile, Dec. 12). The debacle after the 1920's was the result of poor distribution of income, a jerry-built system of holding companies, investment trusts and banks and prolonged abdication of political leadership. 
 A more appropriate parallel would be the early stages of the Gilded Age, during which the pace of change in the technology, organization and methodology of economic effort accelerated significantly. From 1866-1897, when the United States achieved economic primacy, the wholesale price index declined 59 percent, industrial wage cuts of as much as 25 percent were common, eight cyclical contractions occurred, labor strife was persistent and deadly and per-capita income distribution became much less equitable.
While the Gilded Age II may not be upon us, we face a future fraught with accelerated change in the economic structure. Displacement and strife will result in proportion to the nature of change and the response of society to its victims.
 
THEODORE R. SNYDER
Ogunquit, Me., Dec. 13
 
The writer is a former economics professor at the University of New England in Biddeford, Me.

HEADLINE: HERS;
The Bottom Line

BYLINE: By Erica Abeel; Erica Abeel is the author of "Women Like Us," a novel
forthcoming in February.

 BODY:
Delia has an incredibly active social life. And" -- weighted pause -- "she doesn't even go out with married men." Knowing laughter.
 We had gathered for the monthly meeting of my women's group, a spinoff of the old consciousness-raising groups but harboring no agenda beyond friendship, solidarity and gorging on Chinese takeout. We were laughing at a shared -- and largely unvoiced -- presumption: that single women of middle years who enjoy an active romance frequently enjoy it with someone else's husband. 
Our laughter had a nervous edge. In this room we'd heard no shortage of acid comments on life with a borrowed husband -- accompanied by the inevitable cracks about getting weekends and holidays off. Glancing around the table, I suspected that few of us had eluded the toils of this uniquely tortuous tie, its mix of poisoned pleasures and inequities inevitably leading to the question: How do I get out?
 If my group in any way mirrors the larger world, then affairs with married men must be a flourishing, if sub rosa, concern. My ear has lately picked up the grousing of New York's "weekend widows," the female population deserted from Friday evening to Sunday, when their purloined partners disappear into the bosom of family.
 Affairs with married men are thriving, I suspect, due to a confluence of two groups in need. In today's wobbly economy, most husbands simply can't afford divorce; serial monogamy has become a luxury reserved for billionaires. Yet these same husbands -- for the record, we're talking middle-aged, long married and reasonably well-fixed (partly because they're long married) -- yearn to revive a moribund erotic life. Perhaps they see their last chance to act on the itch for sexual variety, which, says the anthropologist Helen E. Fisher in "Anatomy of Love: The Natural History of Monogamy, Adultery and Divorce," is built into the human male.
 Now consider the army of unattached women of middle years in search of a partner and often overlooked by their male counterparts, who are dipping into a younger pool. Say one of these women connects with a seasoned fellow who wants . . . who wants -- if only he could tell you. Maybe he could tell you over lunch? You then learn, often later than sooner, that he's connected to a wife -- though the link is fraying. Which may explain why you met him at the Yale Club's All Ivy Mixer. Dinners follow; imperceptibly, a divide is crossed. Now you're in over your head.
 Of course, philandering is as old as Zeus chasing nymphs. Yet each period stamps the enterprise with its own tone. The 90's-style affair might be dubbed post-romantic. As life in recession-battered New York grows ever more arduous, relationships not essential to survival are jettisoned in a downsizing of the personal sphere. Friendships wither, especially now that many women, traditionally the social glue, are emulating male workaholism. So the affair, surely a luxury item, is reduced to a tawdry flyby. In the 50's, the straying spouse played a high-stakes, potentially life-altering game; though divorce bore a stigma hard to imagine today, the secretary he was romancing might reasonably expect him to remake his life with her.
 Despite a few notorious exceptions known coast to coast, today's graying philanderer stays married -- an impression supported by a world divorce rate that, according to Helen Fisher, continues to decline after age 30. And he does so without apology: Divorce is not even an issue on the table; fidelity to his marriage, if not his spouse, is a given. Nor is today's wandering husband riddled with guilt. After all, he played it straight and narrow through the sexual revolution; he has Done Well. Isn't he entitled? A paramour is one more perk, along with the company BMW; a jewel in his crown, like his collection of Abstract Expressionists. (One detail consistently overlooked in the Sol Wachtler/Joy Silverman saga was his unwillingness to divorce his wife. The leap from there to his posture of rejected swain cuts the breath.)
 Sometimes the lure of a major life change is dangled. Terry McMillan's novel "Waiting to Exhale" is one long-running joke on the ploys of married men, as when a husband tells his girlfriend, "I just want to see if we could spend some time together, to see if what we have is something we might want to pursue on a more permanent basis." That otherwise discerning women swallow the bait is less amusing.
 Deconstruct the affair from the husband's perspective and his behavior makes a certain sense. A liaison serves him -- if not his lover -- on a variety of fronts. The fellow of conservative bent need not be rousted from 30 years' worth of habits to which he's become welded in middle age. And he preserves what a member of my women's group calls "the corporation": marriage as an association embracing money, real estate, family and social rituals -- what, at the end of the day, has substance and weight. In one's waning years, the upheaval unleashed by changing partners hardly seems worth the aggravation. How a grand passion shrivels when pitted against the house in Santa Fe.
 As a final bonus, in a kind of unwitting synergy between mistress and wife, the affair actually conserves, perhaps even enhances, his marriage. Marital ennui and friction become far easier to tolerate if he knows what pleasures he can access from the nearest car phone. All that's lacking is a proper forum for wives to express their appreciation.
 I suspect that what we're seeing in the 90's-style liaison is nothing less than the death of romantic love. Since its beginnings in the 12th century, romantic love has had a good, long run; now, to judge by my sample affairs, the second millennium may usher it out. I doubt that we will see a new Duke of Windsor anytime soon, because love is no longer at issue. In a culture that venerates money and power, Eros, too, has been eclipsed by commerce. What's pursued is the occasional frisson, a facsimile of passion -- best of all, love without responsibility.
 Recently a friend semi facetiously proposed a Mistress's Bill of Rights guaranteeing the Other Woman a fair share of weekends, holidays and the like. The model might be Victor Hugo, who, like the bon bourgeois he was, equitably parceled himself out between his wife and Juliette Drouet. But that was France. On these shores, women might pull a modern-day Lysistrata and bar the door to all married suitors, on the theory that it's better to do without than deal into piggishness enthroned.
 For my women's group, however, these measures may be superfluous. I suspect that most of us sitting around this table attacking the moo shu pork have already cut our borrowed husbands loose and wished them Godspeed. Or will do so one of these days, according to some mysterious lunar timetable -- soon, soon, any moment now.

HEADLINE: The Value of Music as an Avocation

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
DOES music have "charms to soothe a savage breast"? Robert A. Berman, who has been running a weekly jazz session at his home in Amawalk for the last two years, says the answer is yes.
"In tough economic times like these, people need other outlets more than ever," Mr. Berman said. "What sets my jam apart from all others is the caliber of the musicians who attend. Half are professionals who are among the most talented in the country. The other half are business people who also happen to be excellent players. Both halves agree that playing together helps keep them sane. The result is that some of the best jazz in the metro area is being played behind closed doors simply for the satisfaction of the musicians." 
 Mr. Berman is 49 and a former wine industry sales and marketing executive who gave up a six-figure salary to become a screenwriter. He is the author of "Fade In: The Screenwriting Process." He is also a dedicated guitar player.
"Music, especially jazz, has been a passion of mine since I started playing the guitar at Archbishop Stepinac High School in White Plains," he said. "I never do anything halfway. In the 60's I was so inspired by James Burton that I hitchhiked across the country to get to California just to meet him. I guess he was so surprised at my story that he agreed to meet me, and we became friends and remain friends. Through him, I met a lot of musicians."
 
Spontaneous Beginning
 Mr. Berman was also acquainted with musicians like himself, those he describes as good but not able to make a living from music.
"Even those at the top say it's a very tough way to earn a living," he said. "Our Thursday night jam sessions are purely for pleasure. Very therapeutic. For a couple of hours, everyone forgets their problems."
Mr. Berman, who has converted a family room into a studio by setting up amplifiers and a public address system, said the jazz sessions began spontaneously.
 
'I Always Get to Play'
 "When I became a screenwriter, I immediately found that writing is solitary work," he said. "I was home alone, 8, 10 hours a day, and I began to feel deprived. At a party one Labor Day, where there were a lot of other musicians among the guests, I suggested that we get together for an impromptu jam session. The following Thursday evening, seven of the musicians showed up. We had a ball, and the pattern was set."
The original group of 7 has grown to a group of 150 musicians; some work in recording studios, and others appear on Broadway, on television and in films.
"Everybody in the group has been auditioned, and there is a lot of talent there," Mr. Berman said. "We draw musicians from all over Westchester and Rockland Counties, but one fellow, Steve Rhian, a guitarist, drives three hours from Providence, R.I., to play. Every week, I rotate the talent, but I always get to play. That's my reward."
Mr. Berman said it takes him about two hours on the phone every week to set up the sessions.
"We start playing at 7:30 in the evening and sometimes go until 1 in the morning, although usually we quit earlier," he said. "Because a lot of the professionals travel so much, they are only around for a couple of months of the year. And it's true that some nights are definitely better than others because some people play better with each other, but since we started we have not missed a week, with the exception of Thanksgiving and Christmas."
The musicians, who range in age from 20 to 60, include veterinarians, craftsmen, middle managers, furniture restorers, doctors and business owners in addition to well-known names in the music world.
"We have Craig Purpura, who plays the tenor sax and the flute and has performed and recorded with Cecil Taylor, and Jeff Tillman, who is another full-time musician -- guitar, bass, vocalist," Mr. Berman said. "Jeff has performed frequently at the Rainbow Room and the Waldorf-Astoria. And there is Fred Smith, another full-time musician, who plays the trumpet and fluegelhorn and is the trumpeter and musical director for the Harlem Blues and Jazz Band. Fred recently recorded two albums with Bernard Purdy and played in the orchestra for the Broadway production of 'Ain't Misbehavin'."
 
Not an Easy Way to Make a Living
 Mr. Berman said the musicians are willing to play purely for recreation because it gives them the opportunity to play in an informal environment. "There's no attitude, no union, no politics or competition they have to contend with," he said. "It's just great music and great fun. And exposure to other musicians can lead to jobs. For instance, a drummer and guitarist who met at the house ended up working together to the advantage of both of them."
Mr. Smith, as music director for the Harlem Blues and Jazz Band, spends much of the spring, summer and fall touring Europe. But when he is home in Ossining, he says he plays with the group every chance he gets.
"The standards are very high," he said. "Those who aren't professional are very gifted amateurs and with them I get an opportunity to play material that I want to rehearse."
Mr. Smith, who emphasized that he never gets tired of playing, said: "I can relax with the group. And I've made some good friends, nice guys with artistic integrity who are committed to making beautiful music. The atmosphere is informal, like jazz clubs used to be. You could sit in and jam and just have a good time."
Another musician in the group, Arnold Evans Schnitzer, electric and upright bass, a former executive recruiter, is also a professional musician who has worked with top performers under the name Arnold Evans. Mr. Schnitzer is the owner of the A.E.S. Fine Instruments Shop in Yorktown, a store that sells and repairs musical instruments. Mr. Schnitzer, a regular Thursday night participant, said the musicians at the jazz sessions have an "unbelievable amount" of talent. "But it's a hard way to make a living as a full-time musician," he said. "Bob Berman provides an outlet for talent, an opportunity to 'keep your chops up.' It becomes very boring to practice alone. At Bob's, you find support and camaraderie."
And Nicholas Misch, a first bass guitarist who attends City College and is Mr. Schnitzer's assistant in the store, said that the jazz sessions have given him an opportunity to sit in with older musicians and learn from them.
"It's a terrific place to get experience and meet people," Mr. Misch said. "And I've gotten some gigs as a result. I performed in some local plays, a jazz gig, a wedding band. I'm definitely making money as a musician through the contacts I've made at Bob's."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Battery Park City;
A New Neighborhood Along the Hudson

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH still under development, Battery Park City, along the Hudson River in lower Manhattan, gives an impression of familiarity. The architecturally diverse residential buildings, set along wide streets and sidewalks edged in cobblestone, are reminiscent of the Riverside Drive area of the Upper West Side.
A third of the 92 acres of Battery Park City consists of parks and open space, including a broad, 1.2-mile-long Esplanade. With Victorian lights, hexagonal asphalt paving blocks and long green wooden benches, the Esplanade offers views of the Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island and the New Jersey shore. South of the esplanade is a wooden boardwalk, often crowded with fishermen and lighted at night by cobalt-blue lanterns. 
 The Esplanade also serves as an elegant backyard for the settlers of Battery Park City, who already fill 18 buildings with 4,800 apartments. And only half the building sites are developed. How many residents there will eventually be is uncertain, since it depends on what happens on the unbuilt sites.
Many residents walk to work -- either in the Wall Street area or in the offices and commercial space in Battery Park City itself, most of which is in the 6 million square feet of the World Financial Center, built by Olympia & York.
Launched as an urban-renewal redevelopment by the late Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller in 1966, the land was created by fill and rubble from the excavation for the nearby World Trade Center, dumped amid decrepit Hudson River piers. Following a master plan approved by New York City, the Battery Park City Authority leases out building sites by competitive bid to developers.
Matthew C. Monahan, chief spokesman for the authority, said the neighborhood was meant "to reflect the best of New York City." Its streets are continuations of the old grid, with Chambers, Vesey and other streets extending from the City Hall area into the complex. The idea was to prevent Battery Park City from becoming a separate enclave cut off from the rest of Manhattan by busy West Street on its eastern border.
But West Street is a barrier not easily crossed by foot, and pedestrians usually use the overpasses above it.
"I feel the isolation," said Maria S. Crouch, president of the Battery Park City Owners Association and a six-year resident. "The positive side is that you have a real feeling of community because you get to know your neighbors by spending more time in the neighborhood. The negative part is that you have to walk 10 minutes to some of the subways. So you don't take that much advantage of going to the theater or shopping in the rest of the city."
Mrs. Crouch, a public relations professional for the city, and her husband, Edward, an investment banker, moved from Staten Island six years ago because they felt Battery Park City was "one of the nicest neighborhoods in Manhattan." She still thinks so, but says that shopping options are limited.
Among the major shopping areas, South End Avenue has restaurants, coffee shops, beauty parlors, video stores, banks, two supermarkets and an Asian grocery.
"We need a bakery and some specialty shops and places where you can go for hamburgers and coffee at 2 in the morning," Mrs. Crouch said.
For upscale shopping and restaurants, there are the establishments in and off the 125-foot-high glass-vaulted Winter Garden of the World Financial Center, a performance and exhibition space with 16 soaring tropical palms and a splendid marble grand staircase. In warmer weather there is lunchtime and evening dining just outside on the plaza edging the North Cove Yacht Basin.
A survey by the authority found that 51 percent of the residents worked in the financial district and that a fifth of these were employed in the four-tower World Financial Center at the core of Battery Park City. The average age is 40 and nearly all adults have some college education.
The authority derives its income from World Financial Center rents and leasehold payments by rental-building and condominium apartment owners. The condominium leasehold payments, says Mrs. Crouch, are unfair because they are not deductible from Federal income taxes as is, for example, a share of the interest payments on a co-op's underlying mortgage.
"The authority must re-examine the property status and consider selling the land to the building associations," she says. "The present arrangement makes living here more expensive and makes potential buyers nervous." David Emil, president of the authority, said he sympathized with Mrs. Crouch. Lawyers have been retained to seek an Internal Revenue Service ruling, he said.
The apartments in Battery Park City, which was originally intended as a bedroom community for singles and working couples in the financial district, are mainly studios and one-bedrooms. Just 24 percent have two or more bedrooms. Most of the buildings went up as condominiums, but a substantial number of apartments are renter-occupied.
Prices are determined by square footage and the degree to which a unit faces the Hudson River. "The difference in price between apartments with no view and the same apartment with the best view is about 40 percent," said William Graizel, executive vice president of Regatta New York Realty at 300 Rector Place in Battery Park City.
He said the average two-bedroom apartment overlooking the Statue of Liberty and New York Harbor would sell for about $450,000. A similar apartment with no harbor views would be about $250,000.
One-bedrooms range from about $100,000 to $300,000, Mr. Graizel said, and three-bedrooms from $400,000 to $700,000. The most expensive sale in Battery Park City to date, says Mr. Graizel, was a rare four-bedroom, four-and-a-half-bath penthouse at 377 Rector Place, which went for $1,875,000 in October.
Rentals range from $1,300 for a one-bedroom with no harbor view to $4,500 for a three-bedroom unit with the best view.
CONTRARY to original expectations, demand for two-bedroom and larger units has been rising. A survey conducted by the Battery Park City Parents Association found that there were more than 580 children in the neighborhood.
Those children and their parents, as well as the public, can take advantage of 30 acres of parkland and large plazas that are maintained in part by a special "facilities fee" of $200 a year assessed to each unit owner.
"I think we have a better community than originally envisioned," said Mr. Monahan. "There is a true reflection of the spectrum of life -- from children to old people. But this is causing a space crunch, both in the apartments and in the schools."
Mr. Emil said his agency was considering plans for two- and-three-bedroom rentals in the northern, so-far-undeveloped section. Some, he said, would be rented at market rates while others might be moderately subsidized.
The Battery Park City Owners Association, however, has come out against building subsididized apartments, saying it would lower the value of existing units.
Among the private developers of Battery Park City is Andrew S. Goodstein, a partner in Goodstein Properties, which built four apartment houses and still retains many of the units as rentals.
"We are interested in more buildings at Battery Park City," Mr. Goodstein said. "The rental market there is extremely strong. There's not much traffic, it's safe and there are lots of parks."
The Parents Association is asking the authority to build a school in Battery Park City. Most of the children attend classes at the already overcrowded P.S. 234 in neighboring TriBeCa. Mr. Monahan says that although the authority would support the construction of a school, the primary responsibility belongs to the New York City school system.
"We think the authority should take more responsibility and fund the school," says Sharyn L. Lawall, who lives in a three-bedroom apartment with her husband, William Dratel, and their three children. "It was poor planning for them to put up this size neighborhood without proper infrastructure."
Ms. Lawall, who is studying for her doctorate in social work at New York University, moved to the neighborhood from Greenwich Village nine years ago. She says that although she loves Battery Park City because it is clean, safe and has a lot of parkland, she might feel compelled to leave if P.S. 234, now 90 pupils over its capacity of 550, becomes any more crowded. Lucy Mahon, staff developer at the school, said the projection for the 1994 school year was 700.
The only school in Battery Park City is the 10-story Stuyvesant High School, opened in September 1992 as the first new high school built in the city in a decade. Entrance to the school, which specializes in math and the sciences and is at the north end of the complex at Chambers and West Streets, is by competitive citywide examination.
Among the high-end restaurants in or near the Winter Garden are the Hudson River Club, Le Pactole and Sfuzzi. Less expensive ones on South End Avenue include Zen (Chinese) and Bankers & Brokers (Italian). Also well-known is Steamers Landing, a seafood and burger restaurant on the Esplanade.
The largest relaxation and recreation area is the 8-acre Hudson River Park, which has a playground, climbing areas and giant tic tac toe boards. Also in the park are a basketball court and handball courts.

HEADLINE: THE WILD WILD EAST

BYLINE: By Bill McKibben; Bill McKibben is the author of "The End of Nature." He
is at work on a collection of articles about environmental hope.

 BODY:
AS HE DROVE ACROSS THE LONGVIEW BRIDGE over the Black River one day in the winter of 1985, David W. Stahle, a researcher at the University of Arkansas, gave a long, low whistle. He had come to the Cape Fear region of North Carolina in search of old trees that he could core for his ongoing climatic research, hoping for specimens as old as the 600- and 700-year-old stands he already knew about on other lonely rivers. What he found along the Black, though, defied every stereotype of the East Coast -- an untouched stretch of river bordered by bald cypresses that dated back at least 1,700 years. "Since one of the characteristics of these old trees is hollowness in the cores, there's no question in my mind that many of those trees are 2,000 years old," Stahle says. And little question that they are the oldest living things in eastern North America, the most venerable organisms this side of the bristlecone pines of eastern California. This place exists as much in time as in place; it was protected by the Washington-based Nature Conservancy in the wake of Stahle's discovery and is now a living museum of natural history -- a kind of Pleistocene park. "These trees -- these very trees -- had Carolina parakeets and ivory-billed woodpeckers in them," said J. Merrill Lynch, a protection specialist at the North Carolina chapter of the conservancy, as we paddled the sleepy river in the spring of 1993. "Now those species are both extinct. We don't want these old-growth forests to go the same way."
 Most of the clamor about old-growth forests has come from the West, where environmentalist pressure to protect remaining large stands of ancient woods brought a halt to logging on many Federal lands and led to President Clinton's timber summit and recent compromise plan designed to protect habitats for endangered species. But biologists and conservationists in the East have recently begun to realize that there is more original forest here than was long believed to be the case, scattered remnants of the mighty forest that greeted the arriving Europeans. These woods seem to harbor no equivalent of the spotted owl, which is dependent on old growth, but scientists argue that their preservation is crucial. The first conference on the topic was convened in August at the University of North Carolina in Asheville, an event that also marked the publication of Mary Byrd Davis's landmark catalogue of the region's untouched woods. Though "old growth" is notoriously hard to define -- there are those who insist on absolute virgin forest, while others make concessions for human intrusion that hasn't altered the basic character of a grove --researchers are becoming more aware of undamaged tracts, and of what can be learned from them. "We have entries from every state in the East," Davis says, "and new discoveries being made all the time. People are just beginning to realize what's out there." 
The first rule when you're looking is to erase the postcard images of grandeur from your mind. Outside the Smokies and the Adirondacks, it's mostly 25 acres here or 50 acres there that by one fluke or another escaped the logger's ax. "We're dealing with little pockets of a landscape that's been totally disturbed, totally utilized," says Charles V. Cogbill, a Vermont ecologist, who has seen as many patches as anyone in the East. Usually, he says, the stands resemble the 20-acre patch of sugar maple, hemlock and yellow birch on Lord's Hill near his northern Vermont home. Though some of the trees are big and old, nothing is more characteristic, says Cogbill, than "old-growth dynamics," the replacement of dead trees by new ones. Wandering through the woods last spring, Cogbill spent as much time looking down as up -- "I'm a deadwood ecologist," he said. "I'm doing autopsies," checking rotting stumps for the progress of decay, looking at new seedlings pushing up through the ground.
 In some places the biology speaks louder than the written history. The historian Barbara McMartin, who next year will publish "The Great Forest of the Adirondacks," says as many as a half million of the park's six million acres may have escaped 19th-century loggers. "It was one man, one horse, one ax -- not really disruptive to the forest," she says. "You never see a stump in those tracts, there's a lot of dead and down trees. It feels old."
 Even in unprotected areas, say many researchers, there's more old growth than the traditional image of the cutover East would suggest. "It was an economically driven forest disturbance," says Stahle. "What that means is, they left a lot of low-end, uncommercial forest in its primeval condition. If you want to find some for yourself, look for harsh places. Look for rough ground."
 For some people even the scrappiest patches of original forest are filled with wonder. Robert Leverett and his son Rob Jr. are amateur old-growth sleuths who are credited with uncovering more ancient patches than anyone else in the East. Only an echoing series of exclamations allows one to track them as they bound down a steep slope above the Cold River in the Berkshire hills of western Massachusetts: "Dad -- over here. This ash is sooo good! This is ancient!" "Look at the bark on this yellow birch, will ya!" Careful researchers, always ready to pull out their tape measures and surveyor's inclines to record widths and heights, they also find their church in these forests. A former Air Force officer who currently teaches statistics and computer science to college students, Leverett is not your typical crystal-gazing New Ager, but he does have a theory: "In a very young wood, that forest is still sucking up energy as it grows, not giving it off. In the older stands, it's more in balance. I end up feeling a little higher. Not in any magnified way, but that balance seems to help the human organism."
EVEN AS SCIENTISTS BEGIN TO SENSE THE richness of eastern old growth, the stands are coming under new threats. Some seem inexorable -- gypsy moth and hemlock woolly adelgid infestations have already wasted some ancient forests. Ozone pollution and acid rain continue to devastate others, and development is always a threat, especially on smaller sites -- one 50-acre Delaware tract will be turned into luxury housing this year, the streets all named for eastern wildflowers.
But if the present is dark, the future could conceivably be brighter. A growing number of biologists are beginning to talk about "future old growth," about forests left to recover from the abusive logging of the past, until in time -- a matter of centuries -- they once again behave like natural forests. Much of the oldest woodland in the Southeast, for instance, is owned by the United States Forest Service, which contracts with private industry to cut timber. More than 60 percent of that national forest is scheduled to be cut at intervals of 60 to 120 years, says Dan Boone, an ecologist at the Wilderness Society -- a rotation much too short to sustain the diversity of the ecosystem. But, says William G. Martin, a Forest Service silviculturist -- silviculture is the science of growing trees -- "there's no question that in the East restoration of future old growth is going to be more important than protecting the little we've already got. It's going to be a major emphasis." Environmentalists have begun to call for a wholesale reappraisal of the role of Federal lands in the East, says Boone, protecting every meager patch of land that's left in order to preserve the region's biodiversity. Gary Miller, director of the environmental studies department at the University of North Carolina at Asheville, envisions the remaining pockets of eastern old growth as seeds for ecological corridors that might someday provide plants and animals with easy travel up and down the mountainous spine of the East. "We're talking about millions of acres, in order to stabilize the population declines that we're seeing," he says.
 In the meantime, small parties continue to scour the woods, weekend after weekend, trying to discover as yet unknown groves of old, old trees in overlooked parts of the East. One day last fall, Bob Leverett led a party out to hike an area near Lewey Lake in the south-central Adirondacks, land that old logging maps showed as devastated. But Leverett, driving down the road, had spotted some telltale craggy trees, and as he climbed higher up the slope he began to grow more excited. "Ooh, that's good," he said, measuring a yellow birch with a circumference of nearly 10 feet, pulling out his clinometer to declare a sugar maple 87 feet tall. Arizonan Dave Forman, a co-founder of Earth First and now a coordinator of the Wildlands Project, is along for the hike. "Even if I saw this back home, I'd say it was a big tree," he says as he pats a massive hemlock, its cinnamon-colored bark putting its age upward of two centuries.
 The day ends under a spruce, on a shaded and mossy hammock by a rushing stream. Leverett Sr. pulls out the surveyor's tools -- the spruce turns out to be exactly 100 feet, top to bottom. "That's a nice tree," says Leverett. "This is a very nice forest."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

THE VIEW FROM THE EAST
