HEADLINE: A Needless Gift to the Pentagon

 BODY:
The numbers are obvious: If President Clinton hopes to fulfill his promise to reshape spending priorities, he will have to cut existing domestic and defense programs by at least $50 billion over the next five years. Otherwise, he will not be able to hit Congress's deficit-reduction targets and pay for his economic strategy of investing in education, training, research and infrastructure.
Yet last week he made the budget hole $10 billion deeper by giving the Pentagon money to pay Congressionally mandated salary increases over the next five years. And the Pentagon wants even more to cover inflation during a five-year period in which it already plans to spend a whopping $1.2 trillion. That averages $240 billion a year -- about five times what Russia spends on defense and nearly as much as the rest of the world combined. 
 The President is surrendering too quickly. The Pentagon can find $10 billion for salaries and $20 billion for inflation in its own budget. If Mr. Clinton doesn't take on the military, he will jeopardize the core of his domestic agenda.
Unfortunately, Mr. Clinton's decision to fork over the $10 billion is only the latest in a series of retreats in the battle to cut the Pentagon budget. Mr. Clinton promised to trim military spending by $88 billion over five years, which seemed a plausible target given the collapse of the Soviet Union. But after a "bottom-up" review, Defense Secretary Les Aspin backed off.
Mr. Aspin's original idea was to base the military budget on a strategy under which the U.S. would be prepared to fight one Iraq-sized enemy on the ground while holding off another foe from the air. Instead he decided the U.S. must base its force levels on the assumption that someday it could be confronted with two regional wars simultaneously.
But if he has the will, Mr. Clinton can still find his $88 billion without even addressing the strategic question. He could, for example, cancel an unneeded new aircraft carrier -- which alone would save $5 billion next year -- and cut excessive force levels. He could also buy fewer F-22 stealth fighters, originally designed to counter future Russian fighters that in fact won't be built.
Without such trims, Mr. Clinton's domestic agenda will pay the price for Pentagon excess. The President originally proposed spending about $30 billion next year on his investment program -- mass transit, highways, early education, school-to-work assistance, job training, energy and scientific research. The total was later cut in half, to about $16 billion. And $2.5 billion will now be siphoned off to cover Pentagon pay hikes.
This year, Mr. Clinton funded only one-third of his important initiatives like worker training and early childhood education. If he is to turn the Federal budget as well as the economy around, he needs to grab every dollar he can find. The Pentagon is a perfect place to look.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Trouble in Foley Square

BYLINE: By Kenneth Conboy; Kenneth Conboy, a United States District Judge in the Southern District of New York since 1987, announced Dec. 6 that he is stepping down from the bench at the end of this year because of family considerations.

 BODY:
Many lament that litigation in America, particularly in the historic Federal court at Foley Square in Manhattan, is very different today from what it was in the 1950's.
What has brought about this change in the years since I was a boy, aspiring to practice here? 
 To begin with, the sheer numbers of lawyers now admitted to practice in the Manhattan Federal court have overwhelmed the powerful sense of collegiality and pride that obtained in the halcyon days of the 50's.
In 1958, there were about 600 new lawyers admitted to our rolls. Today, we admit 3,000 a year. At this annual rate, more than 50,000 lawyers will be authorized to practice before the court just after the turn of the century.
This crowding has caused a loss of focus and discipline among lawyers and has led to a regrettable reduction of quality in their legal papers, arguments and professional manners.
We have seen the creation of a vast and complex network of rules, regulations, statutes and entitlements that have provided a Dionysian feast of revenues for even the least gifted of our profession.
Litigants now routinely challenge the hiring, admission, suspension, firing, tenure, retirement, pension, discipline and promotion decisions -- or non-decisions -- of businesses, unions, corporations, universities, clubs, governmental agencies, cities, towns, the armed forces and myriad other organizations at every level of life in the nation, on the grounds of race, age, sex, gender preference, disability or national origin.
These cases, rarely settled, are characterized by high levels of acrimony and subjective claims of victimization; they are immensely time consuming and are controlled by legal standards that, lacking sufficient precision, are overgeneralized and of marginal use.
The crowds of lawyers and cases -- and the national obsession that any private disappointment is an affront of constitutional dimensions -- have altered the focus of trial work. Immense sums and years are spent in round after round of document production and counterproduction and endlessly multiplying depositions.
The economics of going to court chagrin and alarm the nation's business community, whose competitiveness in global markets is damaged by a degree of litigiousness in America that is simply unheard of in the rest of the world.
In recent years, the principal change in the institutional culture here at Foley Square has been our near-transformation into a national narcotics court -- a phrase used by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist in describing the metamorphosis of a number of Federal courts.
In the last fiscal year, this preoccupation with drug cases has been accompanied by an overall increase in criminal filings of all kinds by an astonishing 19.7 percent at Foley Square.
Today, drug cases dominate the docket. The complex sentencing guidelines have extended fivefold the time needed for sentencing proceedings. One result is that the great civil cases that defined the role and stature of the court at Foley Square for 203 years have greater and greater difficulty in being heard.
In the past, these matters -- touching upon patent, antitrust, telecommunications, banking, finance, commerce, labor relations, copyright, trade, taxation and securities regulation concerns -- gave the court national and often global influence.
To compound the problem, the Senate has now passed a most astonishing crime bill.
It contains more than 100 provisions that create new Federal crimes. It federalizes nearly all street crimes in which a gun is used, crimes related to youth gang activities and certain domestic violence cases.
A particularly significant provision would authorize Federal prosecutors to seek the death penalty in cases where a gun that crossed state lines under a broad new definition of interstate commerce was used in a homicide.
The response of the Congress and the Bar to these formidable alterations in the litigation culture of the Federal trial courts has been to call for the efficient management of the chambers of each Federal judge. But in deliberative matters it is misguided to think that faster is better.
Even more radical proposals are being heard. For example:
Double the number of Federal judges. Critics of this approach say that it would dilute the quality of the Federal bench.
Create more specialized courts -- for example, those that handle patent and tax matters. Constitutional scholars worry that highly technical benches focused exclusively on narrow legal areas will lose touch with broad legal values.
Abolish Federal jurisdiction in cases involving multistate litigants. A bad idea: reducing access to the United States courthouse is undesirable.
Eliminate jury trials in complex civil cases and substitute panels of experts. No, we should not tamper with the jury system.
Here are some changes I think should be made.
First, all lawyers who want to practice in Federal trial courts should be required to demonstrate a continuing special proficiency in litigation skills. Broad powers should be vested in district court judges to supervise, regulate and remove lawyers who do not or cannot meet requisite high standards of competence and civility. Vigilantly applied, such powers would be far more effective than the current practice of judges imposing "monetary sanctions" -- some call them fines -- on deficient lawyers.
Second, procedural constraints on the number of frivolous cases allowed to be filed by endlessly litigious plaintiffs must be devised. The United States Supreme Court has already said that such abusers can be denied indigent status. The Congress must take steps to bar such litigants entirely from the courthouse door or at least subject them to stiff and discouraging fees.
Finally, and most importantly, there must be a re-examination of Federal policy aimed at controlling violence and drug use that emphasizes exclusive enforcement in Federal trial courts.
Rather, state criminal courts should be given more money so that they can prosecute gun violence adequately. This would allow the Federal courts to pursue their central function of defining and defending constitutional values, interpreting and applying Federal statutes and conducting civil and criminal trials that fall under traditional Federal jurisdiction.
As for the immense problem of drug abuse, legalization of dangerous drugs is morally untenable.
Focusing Federal dollars on treating and re-educating drug addicts is the only long-term national approach that will rescue the nation from the misery inflicted on the addict, crime victim and society as a whole by the market economics of the heroin and cocaine industry. Such a policy would bring hope of more constructive results in the national effort to fight drugs.
These proposals, if enacted, would brighten the future of the great Federal trial court at Foley Square in a way that would be consistent with its illustrious history.

GRAPHIC: Drawing

HEADLINE: Blacks Join to Halt Deep South Waste Site

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A Dec. 13 news article reports that plans for a toxic dump site in Noxubee County, Mississippi, are pitting blacks against blacks. The facts do not support the view that the struggle is one of poor blacks for hazardous waste against middle-class blacks opposed to hazardous waste. I am the lawyer for African-American Noxubee County residents before the Environmental Protection Agency. 
 While you state that poor black people supported one of the hazardous waste projects, the only person you quote in support is Ike Brown, a paid consultant to Hughes/F.T.I., one of the hazardous waste companies seeking to locate in Noxubee. You do not mention that a 1993 survey by the Mississippi State University sociology department shows that hazardous waste opponents outnumbered proponents by 3 to 1 among black respondents in Noxubee County. This is hardly possible if only "middle-class blacks" oppose a facility.
You further report that the administrative complaint with the E.P.A. by African-Americans for Environmental Justice alleges that the decision to place two hazardous waste facilities in Noxubee County was racially motivated. The complaint makes no such claim. The complaint and additional documentation filed with the agency's Office of Civil Rights state that the claim is one of disparate impact, and not intentional discrimination.
Disparate impact analysis in this context looks not at racial motivations, but at whether or not one group of citizens will bear more of a risk than everyone else, and whether or not there is good reason to dump all the risk on that group. If Mississippi's only hazardous waste dump is in Noxubee County, African-Americans will bear the environmental, social and economic risk for the entire state.
The administrative civil rights complaint filed by African-Americans for Environmental Justice simply makes the point that Mississippi's hazardous waste facility siting system, largely supported by Federal taxpayer dollars, could ameliorate disparate impacts by adequately assessing the environmental, social and economic risks of placing huge hazardous waste facilities in poor areas.
You incorrectly state that Mississippi law allows the siting of only one hazardous waste facility to a county. There is no such limitation.
Your implicit assumption seems to be that disparate impacts of environmental risk on African-Americans should not be considered if there is disagreement in the black community -- even when it comes from paid consultants to the hazardous waste industry. If that standard were applied, a lot of discrimination would go unchallenged.
 
ROBERT B. WIYGUL
New Orleans, Dec. 16, 1993

HEADLINE: PULSE;
The Arts

 BODY:
The number of people directly employed by the arts in New York City and its environs has increased 16.6 percent since 1982, according to a study of the region's $9.8 billion-a-year arts industry by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The study credits the diversity and resourcefulness of the area's cultural institutions for the growth of the arts in tough economic times. The overall number of jobs generated directly or indirectly by the arts nevertheless fell 8.2 percent in the same period. Even though the arts have prospered, with the decline in manufacturing, the arts community tends to rely more on suppliers outside the region and its spending has less impact locally.

The Pulse chart in The Metro Section on Monday, showing the impact of the arts on the region's economy in 1992, misstated the amount of money represented by the dollar signs. Each sign represented $50 million, not $50 billion.

HEADLINE: Security Is Main Theme Of a Spate of New Laws

BYLINE: The Associated Press

 BODY:
"Safety first!" is the nervous theme of many state laws that will take effect in January, doing things like requiring helmets for bike-riding children in California and Tennessee, checking potential teachers for criminal records in Oregon, New Hampshire and Tennessee and making barbers train longer in Hawaii.
Whether seeking to protect children from bad apples or consumers from bad haircuts, state legislators strove this year to bolster security in an insecure world. 
 Florida, stunned by a spate of killings of tourists, banned guns from the hands of anyone under 18, except for hunting, marksmanship practice or competition under adult supervision. The threat of violence inspired a California law to let schools ban gang attire in class.
New Hampshire doctors who test positive for the virus that causes AIDS or for hepatitis B will need special permission to perform invasive surgery.
There is no special reason to enact laws in January, only the symbolism of a fresh start at the top of the calendar. Many states set laws to take effect 60 or 90 days after signing, or after the legislative session ends.
In sifting the tea leaves of these latest January laws, trends appeared. Last year saw a lot of taxes and tax breaks intended to squeeze revenue from an anemic economy.
A year later, money-making measures were conspicuously absent, though a few came close.
Oregon raised its minimum wage to $4.90. Mississippi exempted pensions from the state income tax. Florida employers will see worker-compensation premiums shrink. Michigan relieved property-tax payers of the burden of supporting public schools.
And Colorado's Legislature protected owners of baseball teams and stadiums from litigious spectators as part of the deal to get Denver a National League franchise, the Colorado Rockies. The law will limit the liability of a team and stadium if a fan is hit by a stray ball or slips on a hot dog.
Political scientists were at a loss to explain what, if anything, the lineup of new laws meant.
"We've had a change in the Administration, and maybe the states are waiting for new policy direction," suggested David King, assistant professor of public policy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.
Some observers forecast a slew of crime bills next year, but for now, safety seems the watchword.
Starting on Jan. 1, riding in the open back of a pickup truck will be illegal in California, where children age 6 and younger will also need life jackets in motorboats and in sailboats less than 26 feet long.
 
Enforcing Sobriety
 New Oklahoma regulations will allow tinted car windows to be only so dark.
Seeking safety against drunken drivers and following the lead of many other states, Florida, New Hampshire and New Mexico lowered the permissible level of alcohol in the blood to 0.08 percent from 0.10 percent. In California, drivers under 21 caught with a blood-alcohol level of just 0.01 will lose their licenses for one year.
Under a yearlong experiment, Illinois joined about 30 states that require repeat drunken drivers to use a device that keeps a car from starting if the driver has alcohol on his breath.
Addressing dangers in the marketplace, Rhode Island required credit agencies to send consumers their credit reports within four days of a request and to inform consumers when credit is denied.
Video stores in New York will be barred from selling their customers' names and rental histories to anyone.
Illinois outlawed unwanted sales pitches by telephone and banned such calls from 9 P.M. to 8 A.M.
Connecticut repealed its two-decade-old no-fault auto insurance law. Motorists should see premiums drop, but they will have to go to court to make accident claims against other drivers.
Car insurance in Illinois and buckling up in Vermont will be mandatory, as they already are in most states.
Some new laws will guard against the inept and the incompetent. Texas acted to regulate the operators of machines that keep blood and oxygen flowing during open heart surgery.
Notably, many of these measures will cost the states nothing, except for enforcement.
Greater expenses may be in the offing, of course, with changes in the national health care and welfare systems. Some states ventured ahead, not waiting for word from Washington.
Universal health care will come to Tennessee with a system called TennCare. And unmarried women in Georgia who are under 18 and pregnant, or are already mothers, must live with a parent or guardian to get welfare. Further, able-bodied recipients must accept job offers to remain eligible for welfare, and benefits will be frozen for two years for mothers on welfare who have another child.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 31, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday by The Associated Press about state laws that will take effect in January misidentified the state that has raised the minimum hourly wage to $4.90. It is Washington, not Oregon.

HEADLINE: 10-Degree Chill Brings Out Hardy, and Foolhardy

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE

 BODY:
Among the many acts of cold-induced dementia committed by frozen New Yorkers yesterday, Terry Mathurin's brief midtown escapade deserves a special place.
At 12:45 P.M., Mr. Mathurin, a limousine driver from Queens, grabbed a huge fistful of snow barehanded from the roof of an out-of-state car at the Plaza Hotel and handed it to his giddy passengers, children from a wealthy Houston family who had never seen it before. 
 "Thanks, Terry," said Seneer Paya, the 9-year-old sitting in the front seat, gazing at the pile dripping on the upholstery. "This is so cool."
The driver, though clearly bewildered by the unpredictable obligations of his trade, was hardly alone in reacting outlandishly to the cold spell, which seemed to startle New York after a lulling holiday weekend. Temperatures dropped to a low of 10 degrees in Central Park early yesterday and rose to only 20, immobilizing cars and penetrating both expensive parkas and makeshift cardboard shelters.
The sudden freeze was part of a cold wave that covered much of the Northeast and Middle West. [Page D19.]
But in New York, the streets of the city remained thick with activity and overt foolhardiness.
Scores of tourists and natives alike lined up outside mid-Manhattan attractions without hats or gloves, and were unable to provide satisfactory explanations for their bare skin.
"Well, it just didn't look that cold out," said Stephen Plaskow, a Greenwich Village man whose hands and head were brazenly exposed as he waited for 20 minutes to enter F.A.O. Schwarz. "I should have turned on the radio, right?"
Bob Lavner, a spokesman for the Automobile Club of New York, struggled to explain why the club received 5,000 dead-battery calls yesterday, about three times the number the club expects for a day of similar temperatures with no snow.
"It's the heaviest volume of calls for service that we've had in recent memory," said Mr. Lavner. "All I can figure is, it's the first cold work day of the season, on a Monday, after a holiday, and people were just caught short. Maybe in the last few years we've all grown a little soft."
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, was seen standing hatless and bemused in the middle of a Fifth Avenue sidewalk, next to Andrea Mitchell, the NBC News correspondent. If he were trying to gauge the state of the economy, he would have had to conclude that it was booming, with barely enough room to maneuver on the sidewalk. All of the Fifth Avenue theme parks -- F.A.O. Schwarz, the Coca-Cola Store, the Warner Brothers store, Rockefeller Center -- were surrounded by long lines or heavy crowds, their visitors undeterred by the cold.
 
Pockets of Good Sense
 There were scattered pockets of rationality, though. Peter Nichols, a magazine art director, boarded his Manhattan-bound bus in Hackensack, N.J., and barely recognized his fellow commuters for all the wool and Thinsulate.
"I looked around me and all I saw were bundles of clothes with hot breath steaming out and more than one passenger with a full-face ski mask on," said Mr. Nichols. "If you didn't know any better, you would have thought that it was the Terrorist Express."
The benches of Broadway along the Upper West Side of Manhattan were generally empty yesterday, after many homeless people decided the city's shelters were less unpleasant than the chill.
A bench in the Bronx, however, was the scene of an ordeal on Sunday night for Ivellise Otero and her four children, who suddenly found themselves homeless after an aunt with whom they had been living threw them out. A friend with whom Ms. Otero was hoping to stay had moved, the police said, and she had nowhere else to take her family but the park bench at Metropolitan Oval and Unionport Road in the Parkchester section.
Police found her and the children, ranging in age from 3 months to 7 years, at about 12:45 a.m. yesterday. The family had been in the cold for about two hours. All five were taken to Jacobi Hospital, where they were treated for exposure, and then were taken to emergency shelter.
 
Warmed by Con Ed
 Most homeless people who remained outside had more experience in survival, relying on the kindness of passersby and the warmth of Con Ed's steam pipes.
At 41st Street and First Avenue, across the street from the utility's steam-generating plant, about 15 men were laid out in sleeping bags and cardboard boxes along a sidewalk that the underground pipes had transformed into a blocklong radiator. Eduardo Gonzalez, the resident of Box 3, said the heat made his spot more comfortable than the shelter. He said neighborhood organizations dropped by every day to bring food.
Sure enough, a few minutes later James Lewis, an outreach worker with the Grand Central Partnership, walked by offering free hot meals nearby at St. Agnes Church.
"Maybe we'll get four or five guys who'll come in, and maybe two of them will stay inside for the night," said Mr. Lewis. "But maybe not. These guys are tough."
The police said an unidentified man in his 40's died of unknown causes in his home, an abandoned Cadillac, outside 159 East 126th Street at 3:50 p.m. yesterday. A fire was burning in the car, and Officer Andrew McInnis, a police spokesman, said the man may have started the fire to keep warm. The Medical Examiner's office plans to investigate to determine the cause of death, he said.
In Red Hook, Brooklyn, three men with canes and sticks stood at the center of a small, complicated shantytown along Columbia Street. A makeshift pot boiled on the top of an even more makeshift fireplace, cooking a curious collection of meats amid the acrid flames. With a good deal of defiance and irrationality, the men shrugged off the hardship.
 
'We Have Heaters'
 "Don't worry about us," one said. "We have heaters in our homes."
The city's shelters reported a below-capacity crowd of 6,233 homeless people, but many suburban shelters were full. In New Britain, Conn., the 36 beds of the Friendship Service Center had been taken when three more people came in at the last minute, said Ellen P. Simpson, the shelter's director. They stayed on couches in the shelter's lounges.
"Our policy in the cold weather is that nobody is to be denied entrance," Ms. Simpson said.
Roz Post, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, said the city received 1,656 complaints of no heat on Sunday and 1,850 through 4 P.M. yesterday, a long way from the record 6,107 calls received on Dec. 12, 1988, after several days of below-zero temperatures. She warned, however, that the number of calls was likely to increase as people returned home from work and found no heat.
At the new Riverbank State Park in Harlem, which had not yet experienced a truly cold day since its opening on May 27, officials were delighted to discover that the popular park had lost little of its allure in the chill. The indoor pool, at 86 degrees, was a natural attraction, and skaters at the outdoor ice rink found that skates glided more smoothly through the ice than they did on warmer days.
The weather even cooperated in disguising the most notorious trait of the park, built atop a sewage treatment plant.
"When I came in this morning there was no odor, and there's still no odor," said Mike Nixon, the park's deputy director, as a nose-numbing wind from the Hudson River swept over the hardy Astroturf of the park's track. "So maybe there's a silver lining in this weather, after all."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At 41st Street and First Avenue, near the United Nations, James Lewis of the Grand Central Partnership tried in vain to persuade a homeless man to go to a shelter at St. Agnes Church to escape the bitter cold. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUDGET GAP GROWS BEYOND $2 BILLION FOR NEW YORK CITY

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
The chief fiscal adviser to Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that New York City was facing a budget gap for next year even larger than the $2 billion projected a month ago by a special committee formed by Mayor David N. Dinkins.
The adviser, Abraham M. Lackman, said the gap in the budget for the fiscal year that begins in July -- the first Mr. Giuliani will have to prepare -- had grown by at least $250 million because of a significant decline in the assessed value of the city's real estate. 
 With Mr. Giuliani preparing to take office at the end of the week, the new projection underscored the difficulties he will face as he tries to balance the city's budget without the increases in taxes or painful cuts in services that he promised to avoid.
 
A First Step
 The new figures also marked the first step in the highly political budget process, in which City Hall typically seeks more money from Albany and Washington, tries to extract concessions from unions and prepares the public for the worst, just in case.
"Not to beat a dead horse, but this is the most severe budget gap any new administration has had to face in two decades," said Mr. Lackman, Mr. Giuliani's selection for budget director.
Officials in the Dinkins administration agreed that the assessments showed a decline, but said that other factors might work to mitigate the damage. Jon Lukomnik, the special assistant commissioner in Mr. Dinkins's Office of Management and Budget, said that while there might be a shortfall in the property tax revenues, there might also be an increase from other taxes, like the sales tax, as the economy shows signs of improving.
"It's very easy to pull out all the negative risks and come up with a big number," he said.
 
Special Advisory Role
 Mr. Lackman disclosed the new estimate as Mr. Giuliani announced that Marc V. Shaw, the finance director for the City Council, would serve as his Commissioner of Finance. The Finance Commissioner is responsible for collecting the city's taxes and other revenues and administering the city payroll, while the budget director drafts the administration's overall fiscal plan.
In making the appointment, Mr. Giuliani said he would expand Mr. Shaw's duties to include a special advisory role on fiscal policy, working with Mr. Lackman "to help us develop a broad strategy for economic development in dealing with the budget and for handling what are clearly very difficult problems."
Mr. Giuliani also made two appointments yesterday in the area of health care. Facing criticism about the relative inexperience of his appointees, Mr. Giuliani announced that he would keep on Dr. Margaret A. Hamburg, the current Commissioner of Health.
And he named Maria Mitchell, a health-policy adviser in the Koch administration, to serve as the director of the Office of Health Services. Hers is one of three newly created positions under Deputy Mayor Ninfa Segarra that will coordinate the administration's health, social service and education policies.
Mr. Lackman declined to specify how Mr. Giuliani would close the widening gap between revenues and spending in the city's nearly $32 billion budget. "I have a whole list of things that I plan to present to the Mayor," he said, "but I think it would be more appropriate to discuss those in January."
Last week, Mr. Lackman asked most of the city's agencies to prepare a scenario for cutting their budgets by 5 percent this year and another for cutting 10 percent. The request did not call for cuts in Medicaid, welfare or city debt service and exempted the Board of Education and City University of New York.
 
'Major Transformation'
 At the news conference announcing the appointments yesterday afternoon, Mr. Giuliani also avoided specific proposals on closing the budget gap, though he reiterated his campaign pledge to cut the city's portion of the hotel tax as soon as possible, which would increase the gap at least at first.
"New York City is going through a major transformation," Mr. Giuliani said, "in order to be more effective in the delivery of services and at the same time operate within a budget."
Mr. Lackman based his new budget projection on the annual assessment of property tax values, which is due next month, as the Mayor's office begins to put together its preliminary budget proposal. Those figures were unavailable to the mayoral commission that provided its estimate to Mr. Dinkins on Dec. 2.
Mr. Lackman said the reassessment showed a decline of $1.7 billion in the assessed value of property from the total of $78 billion this year -- a decline, he calculated, that would reflect a decline in tax revenues of $250 million to $300 million from the projections already written in the budget.
Joseph Dunn, a spokesman for the Department of Finance, confirmed Mr. Lackman's general estimate of a drop in revenue, but he declined to comment specifically, saying the final assessment would be released on Jan. 13.
Mr. Lackman and John S. Dyson, who will serve as Mr. Giuliani's Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, laid the blame for the gap on the economy as well as on the Dinkins administration, saying the city lost more than 300,000 jobs under Mr. Dinkins's stewardship.
"It's a legacy of an incredibly weak economy," Mr. Lackman said. "And it's a legacy of inaction."
In November, the Dinkins administration forecast a budget gap of $1.7 billion for the fiscal year that begins in July. That was an increase of $450 million from its projection in August.
Earlier this month, however, a special committee formed by Mr. Dinkins to study the city's perennial budget deficits estimated that the gap was actually nearly $2 billion.
The committee, whose report became known by the name of one of its members, Donald D. Kummerfeld, then outlined a series of harsh recommendations for closing the gap, including layoffs, fees for residential garbage collection and increases in the sales tax and property taxes for single-family homeowners.
Mr. Giuliani dismissed the committee's recommendations as examples of "the old thinking."
 
The Experience Factor
 Leland T. Jones, a spokesman for Mr. Dinkins, criticized the nascent administration for politicizing the budget projections while ignoring the well-intentioned proposals for solving the city's fiscal problems.
"They're just doing the old math," Mr. Jones said. "They're making the mountain as high as they can so they can blame somebody else when they back off their promises and take credit when they don't have to."
Mr. Giuliani's latest appointees -- who brought to 25 the total number of appointments -- have considerable experience in government.
Mr. Shaw, who is 39, joined the City Council as its chief budget analyst in 1989 after serving for eight years as an analyst for the Finance Committee in the State Senate, which is controlled by the Republicans. Mr. Shaw's experience in Albany and his familiarity with the City Council could prove helpful to Mr. Giuliani as he tries to push his proposals through the Democratic majority.
 
Health Over Politics
 "I think it will provide some level of institutional knowledge that will be good for the Council and good for the Mayor," Mr. Shaw said.
Dr. Hamburg, who is 38, is the second commissioner under Mr. Dinkins that the Mayor-elect has decided to keep on. Last week, he reappointed Dr. Luis R. Marcos as the Commissioner of Mental Health.
Dr. Hamburg, a graduate of Harvard Medical School, joined the Department of Health as a deputy commissioner in 1990, taking over as commissioner in May 1991. She was President Clinton's first choice to be the nation's coordinator of AIDS policy until she removed herself from consideration.
Dr. Hamburg has been a strong supporter of policies -- including exchanging needles to slow the spread of AIDS -- that Mr. Giuliani or his aides have criticized in the past. Yesterday, she praised the Mayor-elect for recognizing that the city's health issues require expertise. "Our mission really is one that rises above issues of political parties," she said.
As director of the Office of Health Services, Ms. Mitchell, who is 38, will oversee the city's health policies, particularly in the wake of the national health care reform now being worked out in Washington.
Mr. Giuliani said that Ms. Mitchell would be expected to consolidate a number of smaller offices under her new office. Those include the Office of Children's Health, the Office of AIDS Policy, the Office of Drug Abuse Policy and the Office of People with Disabilities and H.I.V. and Human Services Planning.

Companies
The insurance industry is changing the way it sells homeowner insurance after big losses from Hurricane Andrew. Companies say they are using new techniques to measure risk better and to price coverage more appropriately, raising prices for higher-risk customers while reducing costs for those at less risk. [Page A1.] 
 Metropolitan Life will offer refunds to customers who were misled in buying life insurance policies since 1990, and it dismissed or forced out seven executives, including its highest-paid salesman, in the wake of charges of improper sales activities. [D1.]
Prudential is accepting claims from estates of clients who died since buying partnerships that went sour. The administrator of a fund to settle fraud charges said he would require their acceptance; Prudential said statements barring them had been wrong. [D1.]
The dismissal by Campbell Soup of 62 employees at an Ohio plant, based on accusations of drug use from other workers and hired agents' testimony, raised questions on the company's tactics and whether it had evidence to justify the discharges. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Congressman Touted as a Candidate for Governor

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 27

 BODY:
In the latest attempt to unite New York State's Conservative and Republican parties, several prominent Republicans have begun a campaign to draft United States Representative Gerald B.H. Solomon, a Republican-Conservative from Glens Falls, as a candidate for governor.
Mr. Solomon, 63, had not figured prominently in the gubernatorial calculus before today, and his emergence as the latest compromise candidate underscores fault lines within the two parties that have stalled formation of a united front against the Democrats. 
 Significantly, United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a powerful leader of both parties, said today that he believed that Mr. Solomon, an eight-term Congressman, would be "the leading person, a very formidable opponent," if he runs.
Mr. D'Amato has been the leading supporter of State Senator George E. Pataki, a Republican from Peekskill, whose candidacy Mr. D'Amato encouraged. But Mr. Pataki has failed to win support from other key Republicans, and Mr. D'Amato indicated today that he might be willing to shift his support to Mr. Solomon.
 
Meeting on Draft
 The effort to draft Mr. Solomon, who said today that he had not decided whether to run, resulted from a meeting on Sunday between him and several Republican and Conservative leaders, including the State Senate Majority Leader, Ralph J. Marino of Oyster Bay, L.I.; Borough President Guy V. Molinari of Staten Island, and Michael Long, state chairman of the Conservative Party.
At that meeting, both Mr. Marino and Mr. Molinari expressed strong support for Mr. Solomon, spokesmen for both men said. Mr. Long said he liked the conservative stands Mr. Solomon has generally taken on social and economic issues, but wanted to see if he could win the support of members of the local Conservative Party state committee.
"It's early enough," Mr. Long said in an interview. "The best way to find the best candidate is to see who captures the imagination of the people and can develop support, not just among Conservatives but across party lines."
Mr. Molinari, who said today that he would not be a candidate for governor, said he helped arrange the meeting because he thought Mr. Solomon was one of only a handful of people who could win the support of both parties.
"For those of us that don't want to go through a repeat of what happened four years ago, we have to reach a consensus on the best candidate," Mr. Molinari said. "For a variety of reasons, Solomon is the alternative."
In 1990, the Republicans and Conservatives could not agree on a challenger to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the Democrat, who won in a landslide as the two parties split votes.
Mr. Cuomo has said he will say on or about the first of the year whether he will seek a fourth term.
Several weeks ago, Mr. Pataki was considered a strong contender for the backing of both parties, appearing to have the support of Mr. D'Amato and the Republican State Chairman, William D. Powers.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Bentsen, Beltway Insider, Now Fights The Notion That He's Out of the Loop

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
The last thing people would expect Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen to be is insecure, but nowadays the silver-haired Texan often comes across that way as he pursues a surprising mission: convincing the world that he is in the loop.
That was not a mission Mr. Bentsen expected last year when Bill Clinton, as President-elect, offered him the Treasury post to cap a distinguished 22-year Senate career, which included leadership of its Finance Committee and a much-praised stint as the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate in 1988. 
 But after a year that has proved far bumpier than he bargained for, Mr. Bentsen has felt compelled to begin a new campaign, one aimed at combating the rumors and murmurs about him: hints that he was cut out of the action on health care, that he was thinking of quitting, that he did not fit in with Mr. Clinton's 40-something crowd, that he could have done more to ease passage of the President's budget package last summer.
 
Listing His Credits
 Seated for an interview in a plush, off-white armchair facing an elegant portrait of Alexander Hamilton, the first Treasury Secretary, Mr. Bentsen is intent on explaining that he is no mere bit player.
It was Lloyd Bentsen from whom Mr. Clinton sought advice on Boris N. Yeltsin's showdown in Russia, the Secretary tells a visitor; it was Lloyd Bentsen who won Presidential applause when the budget was approved by Congress, and it was Lloyd Bentsen who persuaded Mexican leaders to make citrus and sugar concessions to win passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
"I'm enjoying this job more and more," Mr. Bentsen said. His voice is soft and low-pitched, and his message is unspoken: people who say the 72-year-old Treasury Secretary is out of the loop don't know what they're talking about.
In the view of Mr. Bentsen's aides, it is a sad commentary on Washington's backbiting political culture when a man with his credentials has to devote so much of his energy to debunking the rumor machine.
 
Questions on Health Care
 Although Mr. Bentsen irritated some of the Administration's more liberal members with his lack of enthusiasm for the President's $16 billion economic stimulus package, which the Republicans defeated last spring, many of the rumors about the Secretary's diminished role grew out of his role -- or lack of it -- in the Administration's effort to overhaul the nation's health care system.
And some of the rumors might have been fueled by Mr. Bentsen and his aides as they groused that Ira C. Magaziner, the President's senior adviser on policy development, who worked closely with Hillary Rodham Clinton on the health care plan, had largely left the Treasury out of the early preparations for the plan.
Mr. Bentsen put that problem behind him by going over Mr. Magaziner's head and telephoning Mrs. Clinton to say he would not testify before Congress on the plan until Treasury received enough information to assess its financing.
The day after he called, Mr. Bentsen said, the Treasury received the information he requested.
 
Skepticism About Costs
 The Secretary admits he was skeptical at first about cost estimates in the plan, but he now insists he is satisfied with it -- partly because of a change that bears his imprint.
"I pushed in a meeting with the President for caps on the entitlements and subsidies" in the health plan, Mr. Bentsen said. "And he very readily said: 'I'll agree to that. We don't want runaway entitlements.' "
Mr. Bentsen said he feared that plans to subsidize health insurance for small businesses and low-income households might someday spiral out of control. "In case we made some mistakes in our calculations, we put in a circuit breaker," he said. "That added to my confidence."
But other Administration officials say Leon E. Panetta, the White House budget director, and Robert E. Rubin, the chairman of the National Economic Council, share the credit for creating the caps.
 
Meeting With Moynihan
 The White House turned to Mr. Bentsen to help sell the health plan to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who succeeded him as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. Several days before, Mr. Moynihan had described the plan's financing as "fantasy."
After the Secretary explained the plan's financing in detail, Mr. Moynihan was reassured. As one participant recounted, Mr. Bentsen, using his powers of persuasion, told the Senator: "You have done more than anybody else to save Social Security. We know you care greatly about welfare reform and plan to do a lot about it. Here, with this health care plan, we are giving you the opportunity to deal with another of the biggest social problems facing the nation."
If there is one piece of evidence that convincingly demonstrates Mr. Bentsen's influence, it is the North American trade agreement, Administration officials say. At an Oval Office meeting in August, some aides proposed that the President allow the agreement to die a quiet death, but the Secretary, a longtime friend of Mexico, helped persuade Mr. Clinton to make an all-out effort to win approval of the agreement.
"He really persuaded the President that it was a fight to go to the mat for, regardless of the politics and chances of winning," said Gene Sperling, deputy director of the National Economic Council.
As evidence of Mr. Bentsen's role in the agreement, Treasury aides have prepared a fact sheet showing that he telephoned 64 members of Congress, met with 85 others, gave 45 speeches, took 9 trips and talked to 233 reporters.
 
Summer of Discontent
 The Lloyd Bentsen basking in the glow of the trade pact's passage appears to be a far cry from the Lloyd Bentsen of last summer.
"For a while it almost seemed that the Administration tried to keep him hidden," said Representative Dick Armey, a Texan who heads the House Republican Conference. In August it became known that three of Mr. Bentsen's longtime aides were leaving the Treasury, and rumors flew that he would not be far behind.
At the time, Mr. Bentsen did little to quell the rumors, something he could have easily done by acknowledging that two of the aides were being eased out in a management shake-up. The third took early retirement and moved back to Texas. Instead, Mr. Bentsen kept quiet, knowing that his silence would only fuel the speculation about his departure.
 
Questionable Criticism
 The insecurity that he occasionally projects stems less from any question about his abilities or performance than from a sense that he has been criticized unfairly as Treasury Secretary and that his place in history might be jeopardized.
There was, for example, an article in The National Journal, a Washington-based weekly magazine on politics and government, that gave him a "C" for teamwork in pushing the President's agenda. That irked him, and soon his aides were asking reporters: What senior official did as much in pushing for Nafta or the budget? Which department lined up international aid packages for Russia and the Palestinians?
Then there was the piece in The New Republic saying he was being outshone by Roger C. Altman, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, who ran the "war room" that helped push through the budget package, and by Lawrence H. Summers, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs.
 
Looking Ahead to 19861996
 "That's hogwash," Mr. Altman said. The reason Mr. Bentsen's top aides shine so bright, Treasury officials say with a bit of self-congratulation, is that he chose one of Washington's strongest staffs and, as he did when he was in the Senate, has given his staff a long leash.
Nowadays, his aides make sure he appears on the Sunday morning television circuit. And Mr. Bentsen sends out strong hints that he plans to stay as Secretary through 1996 -- although some officials would not be shocked if he stepped down in early 1995, shortly before his 74th birthday, saying he has achieved what he set out to do.
Although Mr. Bentsen frequently plays tennis and has breakfast with Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, the Secretary gives Mr. Clinton and his deficit-reduction plan, rather than the Fed chairman, most of the credit for the economy's recent upturn.
"Europe is flat, Japan is flat, and here we are the world's engine of growth, nothing spectacular but what we think is solid, sustainable growth, with low inflation," Mr. Bentsen said. "That is an achievement. Plus the lowest interest rates in 25 years. The financial markets have taken our deficit reduction seriously, and that's why we see interest rates so low. That's why the economy is doing so much better."
The unspoken submessage: if the President gets high marks for turning the economy around, so should his Treasury Secretary.
 
Lloyd Bentsen
 
Born: Feb. 11, 1921, Mission, Texas.
 
Hometown: Houston
 
Education: Sharyland High School, J.D., University of Texas.
 
Career Highlights: 1942-45, Army Air Corps; 1945-46, practicing attorney; 1946-48, Judge, Hildago County; 1948-55, member, U.S. House of Representatives; 1955-70, President, Lincoln Consolidated Inc.; 1971-93, member, United States Senate; 1993 - Secretary of the Treasury.
 
Family: Married to Beryl Ann Longino; two sons and one daughter.
 
Hobbies: Tennis, horseback riding, sailing, hunting quail

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Host Marriott Adds to Marquis Hotel Stake

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27

 BODY:
The Host Marriott Corporation, which was spun off from the Marriott Corporation in October, has seized a 28.6 percent interest in the Marriott Marquis Hotel in Times Square in New York after an Atlanta real estate developer and former partner in the hotel defaulted on a loan.
The Washington-based company, which took on $2.2 billion in debt in the spinoff, disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission last week that the foreclosure of the loan to the developer, John Portman, would have the effect of adding another $445 million in debt to its balance sheet. 
 By foreclosing on Mr. Portman's loan, Marriott, which had a 50 percent stake in the holding company that owns the hotel, gains a majority stake. As a result, current accounting rules require Host Marriott to consolidate the hotel's assets and $445 million in liabilities, the largest of which is a $375 million mortgage loan, on its own financial statements.
 
Hotel Worth About $400 Million
 Tom McConnell, a senior manager at Kenneth Leventhal & Co. in New York, said that based on recent hotel sales in Manhattan, he estimated the Marriott Marquis was worth about $400 million.
The increased balance sheet debt is important because skittish investors have already seen the value of their Marriott-related bond holdings go through one wild swing because of concerns about excessive debt. That was tied to the controversial restructuring that broke Marriott into two pieces: Host Marriott, an asset-rich company with a heavy debt load, and Marriott International Inc., a hotel management company.
But Host Marriott officials played down the effect of the New York hotel debt restructuring.
"Picking up a larger piece of equity doesn't increase our expenses," said Host Marriott's chief executive, Stephen Bollenbach. The company "just accounts for it differently."
A company spokesman pointed out that the holding company for the Marriott Marquis, rather than Host Marriott, would ultimately be responsible for repayment of the $375 million debt.
"The cash generated from the hotel will cover its carrying costs," said Robert Souers, the Host Marriott spokesman. "In the astronomically unlikely event that the hotel is unable to meet its debt service, the recourse would be to the hotel itself, not to the company."
He added: "We are comfortable having that debt on our books. This is a very strong piece of real estate."
The 48-story 1,874-room hotel, which opened in 1985, is one of New York City's largest.
Neal Kamin, general counsel for the privately held Portman Companies of Atlanta, declined to provide details of the transaction.
"There was a note with a high interest rate and the net result is that the property is going back" to Host Marriott, he said. "Basically, Marriott and Portman went through a technical glitch to transfer the asset as part of a restructuring of other assets."
In 1985, Marriott sold a 28.68 percent interest in the hotel to Mr. Portman for about $26.3 million. It loaned him the money at a 12 percent interest rate and took the stake as collateral, according to the S.E.C. filing.
 
Promissory Note Restructuring
 In 1992, it allowed Mr. Portman to restructure the promissory notes. But during the 1992 fourth quarter Mr. Portman "informed the company that he would not be making further payments on the promissory note," according to the registration statement. That led to the foreclosure, which Host Marriott said it hoped to conclude early in 1994.
For now, neither Standard & Poor's nor Moody's Investors Service plan to change their ratings on Host Marriott's debt, even though its balance-sheet debt is rising. "At this point, we don't have any plans for doing anything with the Marriott rating," said John Maxwell, an S.& P. analyst.
In trading on the New York Stock Exchange today, Host Marriott's stock ended up 12.5 cents, at $8.75, and Marriott International ended up 25 cents, at $28.375.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

COLD BRINGS OUT HARDY AND FOOLHARDY
The streets of New York City remained thick with activity and overt foolhardiness in the midst of a cold spell that seemed to have startled the metropolitan area after a lulling holiday weekend. Temperatures dropped to a low of 10 degrees in Central Park and rose to only 20, immobilizing cars and penetrating both expensive parkas and makeshift cardboard shelters. A1. 

NEW YORK CITY
 
BUDGET GAP IS SAID TO TOP PROJECTIONS
The chief fiscal adviser to Mayor-elect Giuliani said that New York City was facing a budget gap for next year even larger than the $2 billion projected a month ago by a special committee formed by Mayor Dinkins. A1.
 
TOYS-FOR-GUNS PROGRAM TO EXPAND

Despite the assertion of officials at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, a Chagall painting that disappeared nearly three decades ago was not stolen, a lawyer said as the trial began in a dispute over the ownership of the work. B4.

HEADLINE: New York's Puerto Ricans Split in Economic Success

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Financial differences among Puerto Ricans in New York City are growing, as some join the economic mainstream and others remain mired in poverty, an analysis by the City Planning Department has concluded. Over all, more Puerto Ricans left the city during the late 1980's than arrived, with many of the poorest returning to Puerto Rico and the middle class moving to the suburbs.
"The polarization is evident," said Angelo Falcon, president of the Institute for Puerto Rican Policy. 
 "The second generation is beginning to do better and once Puerto Ricans get up there they seem to do fairly well relative to other groups," Mr. Falcon said. "But that's the trick -- getting there."
Puerto Ricans have been disproportionately hurt by the dramatic decline in factory jobs and by the preponderance of female-headed households with a larger than average number of children, the analysis showed.
 
Highly Segregated Group
 "Although the overall picture of Puerto Ricans reveals economic progress in the 1980's, there are disturbing signs of deepening poverty in several Puerto Rican-dominated districts," the analysis said. Puerto Ricans are highly segregated, the planners found, supporting "the thesis that their poverty is sustained and in fact exacerbated by their geographic as well as economic isolation."
The analysis was supervised by Dr. Joseph Salvo of the Department of City Planning's Population Division, who said: "There are two Puerto Rican communities in New York and that rift is growing wider. There are those -- heavily born in the 50 states -- who are achieving growth in labor force participation, education and English proficiency. And there are those in bad straits and worse over time.
"The total city population doesn't have this serious bifurcation," Mr. Salvo said.
New York City's Puerto Rican population grew more slowly in the 1980's than during any other decade since the migration during World War II, the analysis said. For the first time, most of the city's Puerto Ricans were born on the United States mainland, not in Puerto Rico. Also, Puerto Rican New Yorkers no longer make up a majority of Puerto Ricans living on the mainland.
 
Difference Among Migrants
 Puerto Ricans migrating to the city from elsewhere in the United States were younger, better educated and had higher incomes than those who stayed put in New York. Those who came from Puerto Rico were similar to Puerto Rican New Yorkers, except that fewer women worked and household income was lower.
Drawn from census figures, the analysis presents a decidedly mixed picture of the city's dominant Hispanic group -- one that constituted 50.3 percent of the 1.8 million Hispanic New Yorkers counted in 1990, but which, presumably, no longer represents a majority because of a surge in immigration from the Dominican Republic, Colombia and other countries in Central and South America.
Puerto Ricans registered sharp gains in education, English proficiency and family income. Still, Puerto Ricans were among the poorest New Yorkers.
Nearly half the Puerto Rican children under age 18 are growing up in families headed by a woman and fully half the children live below the poverty level. One in three Puerto Rican households relied primarily on public assistance in 1989, reporting no earnings. All three of the city's 59 community districts in which real income declined during the 1980's, all of them in the South Bronx, have large Puerto Rican populations.
The analysis found that many children are growing up in what are termed subfamilies, in which neither parent heads the household. While that situation is not a Puerto Rican phenomenon, the report said, "its impact is felt more on the Puerto Rican population" because of the large number of children, the high proportion (though declining number) of female-headed families and the "poorer socioeconomic status of the population."
While twice as many Puerto Ricans reported income below the poverty level than New Yorkers over all, the analysis found a substantial rise in real income during the 1980's. Nonetheless, the Puerto Rican families still made only 56 cents for every dollar earned by all families in the city.
Predictably, married couples fared best. Their income increased by 41 percent during the last decade, raising it to about 75 percent of the average income for all New York families. Puerto Rican women who are college graduates earned 83 cents for every dollar earned by all women in professional specialty jobs.
But real income for all Puerto Rican families headed by a woman was outpaced by income gains for all female-headed families. Real income, adjusted for inflation, declined for Puerto Rican female-headed families with their own children.
 
Some Other Findings
 The Planning Department's analysis was presented at Manhattan Community College to representatives of civic groups and social service organizations by the department's director, Richard L. Schaffer. These are among the other findings:
*Puerto Ricans accounted for about 51,000 of the more than 800,000 people who moved into the city since 1985 and 138,000 of the more than one million New Yorkers who left town. Among the Puerto Ricans who moved from New York City, 4 in 10 went to Puerto Rico.
*The Puerto Rican population is maturing, but is still younger than the city's general population. A growing segment is made up of the 25-to-44-year-old sons and daughters of migrants from Puerto Rico.
*The proportion of Puerto Ricans age 25 and over who are high school graduates lagged behind the total population, but rose from 35 percent in 1980 to 46 percent in 1990.

HEADLINE: Thriving on Difference;
International High Students Speak Language of Learning

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON

 BODY:
Abdul Samad, a 20-year-old from Afghanistan, went to school for the first time three years ago. He said he did not know a word of English when he was admitted into the International High School in Queens. He felt blind and deaf and panicky.
"I was very crazy," said the high school student, dressed in a black leather jacket and jeans. "I wondered, 'How am I going to learn this language or study this? I've never been to school.' I didn't know how to write the alphabet." 
 Abdul is now a model student at International High, an alternative public school that is nationally recognized for the way immigrant students are taught and valued. He will graduate this spring as a senior, but came to school already a man.
Since age 10, Abdul had fought as a guerrilla rebel against the occupying Soviet forces in his homeland. He saw 10 friends die in combat and was hospitalized himself at age 14 with a bullet in his leg. He recalls precisely how he killed two Russian soldiers at point-blank range. He said they had fatally wounded his mother and seriously injured his father and three brothers in a bombing of his house.
He found his way to America through a network of Afghan contacts, and like thousands of other young immigrants each year, filtered into the New York City school system, where the foreign-born population has more than tripled in the last four years.
As issues such as violence, apathy and disenfranchisement dominate public discussion of the New York City school system, the International High School offers a glimmer of hope to immigrant youths on a first-come, first-served basis.
The school, on the sprawling campus of La Guardia Community College, admits only students who have been in the United States for less than four years and score low in English proficiency on a standardized language assessment test.
Enrollment reflects geopolitics. The 460 students, who are from 60 countries and speak 42 languages, come from places often in turmoil. When the school opened eight years ago as a joint effort of the Board of Education and the City University of New York, there were only a handful of students from Eastern Europe. Now Eastern Europeans are the third largest group, with 128 students. The biggest representation is from Spanish-speaking countries, followed by the Asian bloc, including China, Hong Kong, Bangladesh, India, Pakistan, Iran and Afghanistan.
When Abdul arrived, he was met with a swell of support from teachers and other students. He was thrown into classes -- the school does not separate students according to their varying abilities in English -- and his Afghan-speaking classmates helped him learn English, even as he went to classes in science, math, history and art. The teachers would speak slowly, write names and draw pictures to guide him along, and they started him off with easier assignments.
 
Impressive Academic Record
 At International High, teachers and staff break the mold in the way English is traditionally taught to students with limited English proficiency. Every teacher doubles as an English instructor to some extent, reinforcing language development as they teach instruction in the core subject areas.
The school has an impressive record of academic success. Ninety-three percent of the students go on to college and more than 90 percent graduate having taken at least one regular college-level course at LaGuardia Community College.
"It's an extraordinary place," said Jacqueline Ancess, a senior research associate at the National Center for Restructuring Education, Schools and Teaching at Teachers' College, Columbia University. "This school makes sure these students have a future and gives them the skills for the future. It lets them know that they are valued."
There is a calm, mature air about the business of education at International High. There are no school bells. Classrooms are dispersed throughout the campus, and students carry college IDs, enroll in college courses, eat in the college cafeteria and work out in the college gym. They participate in a career-oriented internship program outside the school for one third of each school year.
The population of the school, which was intended to accommodate between 400 and 500 students, is also small enough so that the staff gets to know students.
 
Learning to Get Along
 It was not long after Abdul arrived at the high school before teachers and counselors noticed his tenseness around Russian students. "He used to jump on anything a Russian said and make fun of it," said Ruthellyn Weiner, an assistant principal. "He would not get into physical stuff, but there would be verbal sparring."
But Abdul found that his enmity toward Russians had no place in the school. Every day, students have to work together in small groups to complete assignments. Some of his classmates were Russian.
"Just because of the constant working in groups, conflicts couldn't exist in that fashion," said the assistant principal. "He dealt with it. It was not even acceptable to him."
Abdul has now set his sights on life after high school. He aspires to be a pilot.
"I'm here to get an education and to get something for the future," he said during a class break. "In America, anything you want to do is possible."
 
Optimism Encouraged
 Abdul's optimism is echoed by many students in the school, as they stride the hallways and listen intently in class. The feeling does not come by accident, teachers and administrators say.
"The optimism is infectious," said the principal, Eric Nadelstern, whose own parents were Holocaust refugees from Poland and Romania. "To the extent that we are successful, students leave us as competent learners and competent individuals. The spirit that is shared by the entire faculty is that our students represent the future."
In a classroom humming with Polish, Spanish and Chinese accents on a recent morning, students expressed a litany of hopes and dreams in response to a math teacher's question about what kind of student they wanted to be.
"I want to be the best I can and I want to be an A-student and always improve," 15-year-old Maria Christian of Ecuador said in one happy breath.
"The more you want, the more we have," assured the teacher, Simon Cohen.
International High is constantly evolving to meet the needs of students. Over the years, the class periods have gone from 35 minutes to 70. This year, for the first time, the curriculum has gone entirely interdisciplinary, with instruction in core subjects linked by themes.
The school is now broken into six thematic clusters in what amounts to six mini-schools. Each trimester, a small team of teachers from each cluster is responsible for whta happens to about 70 students in the core subject areas during the day.
During their four years, the students cycle through 12 clusters to accumulate the credits needed to graduate. In one cluster called "Beginnings," incoming students like Rafael Dobrowolski explore their immigrant experience through lessons in English, math, science and art.
 
Remembering Homelands
 Rafael is a 15-year-old Polish boy. As far as he is concerned, the future shines bright. A year and a half ago, Rafael left Poland where there were soldiers on the street and the outlook was bleak. His father has found a job cutting grass in a Queens cemetery and his mother works as a secretary. Rafael, who was once ashamed to speak because of his hobbled English, is learning big new words like "sophisticated" this year.
"I say it quite a bit," Rafael boasted the other day.
Even as students labor over their English-speaking skills, International High makes a point of fostering the memories of homelands around the world. Teachers don't get upset if students speak in their first language in class. At a native language celebration at the school earlier this month, Martin Vu rose to read an essay he had written about his native country, Vietnam:
". . .Only deep, deep inside my heart actually knows how I miss those coconut trees running along the river side, those tenderly sweet taste of the mango, those intensely warm flavor of the durian. I don't want to recall any further because this makes me sad."
The voice rising with emotion came from a quiet 18-year-old who left Vietnam because he said he was not allowed to attend college. His father had served as a surgeon in the South Vietnamese Army and is still regarded as the enemy, he said. At age 13, Martin was imprisoned for 2 1/2 months as he tried to flee the country. When he finally did leave Vietnam in 1988, he spent two years in refugee camps in Malaysia and the Philippines.
Martin now lives in Queens with his mother and three sisters but his heart remains in Vietnam. His father, who is unemployed, and brother subsist there on financial support from relatives in America.
". . .I just want to say to all immigrants that America may be your home for the rest of your life, but don't forget where you came from," Martin told the assembly. "It's like you're in the present and heading to the future, but don't forget your past no matter how good or bad it was. You can't go forward unless you know what steps you have passed. Everyone has a country!"

HEADLINE: Seoul Journal;
A Korean Voice: Forceful, but Almost Inaudible

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Not long ago a military officer here, a hard-liner when it comes to North Korea's nuclear bomb project, expressed some grudging admiration for how the negotiations with the North had been handled by South Korea's very unmilitary Foreign Minister, Han Sung Joo.
Mr. Han, he said, is a brilliant man, the country's premier political scientist, probably a pretty crafty negotiator. But he suffers a character flaw, the officer said: he is so soft-spoken, so calm, that "he makes me wonder if he is really Korean." 
 In his Foreign Ministry office the other day, the man who has emerged as the precise, English-speaking voice of a new South Korea, one whose Government is no longer dominated by former military officials, conceded that he had often asked himself the same question.
"I'm more like a Thai than a Korean," the 53-year-old former professor said with a wan smile, in a voice so quiet that visitors sometimes have to lean over to hear him. "I think I'd like to do things in a more rational way, in a country that you could call, well, emotion-prone."
 
Chief Architect of Strategy
 Amid considerable struggles within South Korea's year-old Government, the first headed by a civilian in three decades, Mr. Han has emerged as the chief architect of Seoul's and sometimes Washington's strategy for dealing with the Communist Government of Kim Il Sung.
Along the way, he has brought a new tone to his country's diplomatic efforts, a self-assurance that has permitted the South to treat its traditional enemy less like a mortal threat, and more like a cranky, sometimes unpredictably violent old relative who must be humored and negotiated with in his last days.
In a diplomatic role reversal, it has often been Mr. Han, sitting within firing range of North Korea's forces along the demilitarized zone, who has urged the Clinton Administration, in distant Washington, to calm down, to keep cajoling and tempting North Korea's leaders rather than threatening them.
He is acknowledged as the architect of what has come to be known as the "package deal," the current offer to trade full inspection of the North's declared nuclear sites in return for an end to the annual Team Spirit military exercises and talks about trade, aid and diplomatic recognition.
But in Seoul, Mr. Han, who had never before served in a senior Government post, makes many uncomfortable -- especially in the military and the intelligence agencies. "The truth is that I have had an easier time dealing with the barbarians than my own domestic audience," he acknowledged, smiling at his use of a label once reserved for all foreigners.
 
The Center of Gravity
 "An overwhelming thought here is that we cannot trust the North Koreans, and therefore there is no use in talking to them. There is much truth in that. But they don't understand that on the basis of this possible deceit it is still useful to go on talking."
To Washington's frustration, South Korea's language has often seemed to veer from hawkish to accommodating in recent months, as different factions in Seoul captured the ear of President Kim Young Sam. But the center of gravity returns regularly to Mr. Han's let's-keep-negotiating view, one that a former official here says won the day because Mr. Han "nudged, pushed, cajoled, waited and let others take credit."
Mr. Han understands the price of failure: he still carries a small piece of shrapnel in his lower back, a stray bit of allied fire left over from September 1950, when Gen. Douglas MacArthur's troops retook Seoul. He may have been saved, he said, by a North Korean soldier who "took out a long cloth and tied up my wound," as he escaped to the mountain house of a family friend.
A few days later, caught again in the crossfire, he and his parents narrowly escaped execution by a less friendly band of North Koreans, who let them go after his father deceived them about the family's true loyalties.
Unlike those of many in his generation, though, Mr. Han's views seem shaped less by the trauma of the war than by the two decades he spent out of Korea starting in the early 1960's -- a sojourn of study and teaching that wound through the campuses of Berkeley, the City University of New York and Columbia University.
 
'Quietness Is Deceiving'
 He quickly became the best known Korean in the American foreign policy circuit, and grew close to many of the people who have since become the core of the Clinton Administration's foreign policy team. But by the time he returned to South Korea in the early 1980's as a professor, critic and columnist -- he often wrote for Newsweek's international editions -- his views were frequently unwelcome here.
"His quietness is deceiving, because he is quite firm," said Lee Hong Ku, the former Minister of Unification and a longtime friend of Mr. Han. "Clearly past Governments were not happy with his calls for democracy. But the way he presented his case, and his international status, seemed to protect him."
His selection as Foreign Minister this year was a surprise: as an academic, he had often taken the minority view here that relations with North Korea were not zero-sum, that the North could get some of the economic development it desperately seeks without harming the South's interests. It is a view he still holds.
But in his move from "a practical scholar to a scholarly practitioner," he said, he has decided that most of the international relations works he keeps on his shelves "are not really relevant" in dealing with a nuclear renegade.
 
An Evolving Viewpoint
 The exception, he said, is "The Strategy of Conflict," a classic written by Thomas C. Schelling, the Harvard professor. "Not a day passes without my thinking of some of Schelling's examples," he said, declining to tip his hand by citing a few. (Curiously, Mr. Han's critics cite the book as well, noting its warning that in a crisis the side that is too controlled, too disciplined and too sensitive to counterarguments can lose the respect of its opponents.)
Now, Mr. Han says, his own view of North Korea is evolving considerably. Though North Korea is autocratic, he said, "it may not have a very monolithic decision-making structure." And that opens it up to divisions, giving the South a chance to dangle incentives.
"It's worth a try," he said. "Nothing will persuade the hard-liners like success."

He shared his office last week with a portrait of President Kim Young Sam and two aides in conference. (Paul Barker for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.N. Chief Urges Patience on North Korean Crisis

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Dec. 27

 BODY:
The Secretary General of the United Nations, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, called today for patience in resolving the crisis over North Korea's nuclear weapons program and reported that he was convinced after meeting with the North Korean leader, Kim Il Sung, that the "political will" for a negotiated settlement still exists.
Speaking at a news conference here after arriving from North Korea on Sunday, Mr. Boutros-Ghali reported no progress toward winning North Korea's agreement to allow the resumption of international monitoring of its nuclear installations. His talks in North Korea coincided with a report that the United States Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that North Korea probably has built one or two nuclear weapons. 
 The North Koreans "are willing to continue negotiations and they believe they will be able to find a solution through more negotiations," he said. "There is a political will to solve peacefully this problem, the political will to avoid an escalation."
Mr. Boutros-Ghali would not say whether there was any deadline to the negotiations over North Korea's return to compliance with the monitoring provisions of the 1968 treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.
Negotiations between American and North Korean officials have been under way at the United Nations in New York and are said to be making some progress toward a resumption of nuclear inspections linked to specific security guarantees from Washington, cancellation of joint military exercises by the American and South Korean armed forces and possible economic aid incentives.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali said he had not asked China to use its influence to persuade North Korea to reopen its nuclear sites to inspection and monitoring. On Sunday, Prime Minister Li Peng told Mr. Boutros-Ghali that China still believes that putting pressure on North Korea through the imposition of sanctions will not produce results.

Seoul Sees Progress
 SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Significant progress has been made in talks between the United States and North Korea, South Korea's Foreign Minister said today. But the official, Han Sung Joo, said it was unclear whether enough progress had been made to resolve the dispute.
"I would say the chances of resolving the nuclear problem are 51 to 49," Mr. Han told reporters.
