HEADLINE: Giuliani May Shift Arts Financing To New York's Larger Institutions

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Describing the arts as an important element in New York's economic future, the incoming Giuliani administration plans to offer more support to the city's premier cultural institutions, possibly by cutting city aid to other less-established arts groups.
John S. Dyson, Rudolph W. Giuliani's deputy mayor for economic development and finance, said he would review the current roster of more than 431 arts groups that are getting $87.3 million this year in city assistance, to see how the administration might channel more aid to the more renowned institutions that attract tourist revenues. 
 "I think there's a lot of stuff going on because it's clubhouse-type political handouts," he said. "I don't know that but I want to find out."
"We have the best quality of art in the United States," Mr. Dyson added, "so the development question has to be quality, not a political standard."
 
Objects to Met Closings
 He said he did not yet know which institutions might lose under his proposal. But Mr. Dyson said he found it unacceptable that the Metropolitan Museum of Art has had to run taped telephone messages saying that "due to a reduction in city and state funding" some galleries are closed either mornings or afternoons midweek.
He compared the closings to the capricious hours of some European museums, saying, "It's like Italy -- sorry, we're closed except on leap years." He said, "When we get tourists here from Dubuque, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has to be open.
"What people come here to see are the finest things in the world and that's a source of hundreds of thousands of dollars in tourist revenue."
Mr. Dyson added that his emphasis on financing for top-quality institutions would not simply favor Manhattan, noting that the Brooklyn Museum, which has suffered from budget reductions, has an outstanding Egyptian collection. He also pointed to the New York Hall of Science in Queens, the Bronx Zoo, and the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. "It's not an outer-borough argument, it's a quality argument," he said.
But his suggestions were bound to further stoke the fires of what is already a heated annual debate over financing for the arts. Rochelle Slovin, the director of the American Museum of the Moving Image and chairwoman of the Cultural Institutions Group, representing 31 major arts institutions, said: "The issue is ultimately one of the total amount of resources available. It's a bit premature to be talking about taking away when in fact it's really a question of returning all of the cultural institutions and many of the programs to the levels we had a couple of years ago."
The city has long acknowledged that its concentration of cultural institutions is a boon to the local economy. In a study released in October, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey found that in 1992 the arts and other cultural activities in the metropolitan region generated almost $3.5 billion in wages, salaries and royalties, and were responsible for 107,000 jobs. It also found that the total economic impact on the region from the arts, counting spending by arts institutions, suppliers, wage earners, tourists and visitors, was $9.8 billion.
But in a signal that he wants to emphasize the economic development potential of arts and culture, Mr. Giuliani has shifted the city's Cultural Affairs Department into the portfolio of Mr. Dyson, instead of having it report to the deputy mayor for planning as it does now.
Mr. Giuliani said recently that culture and arts could be "a source of growth of the city if we do it right." Mr. Giuliani added that if city residents could come to view the cultural institutions as an area of growth and source of jobs, the perception could "create the political basis over a period of time to give more help to the arts."
 
More Money Called Unlikely
 Mr. Dyson acknowledged, however, that with the city facing a $2.2 billion budget gap in the next fiscal year, it is unlikely in the short term that more city money will be available for the arts.
He said he was hoping to put together a new program of corporate support for the arts that could be matched by city and state contributions to get major cultural institutions back to the financing levels of 1989, before recession-driven cuts in government support. "Rejiggering by itself will help, but will not help enough," he said. "We have to find some mechanism of restoring the budgets of these institutions and maintain them as an economic magnet that brings tourists to hotels, stores and restaurants."
Mr. Dyson spoke of his plans for the cultural affairs budget in an interview in which he set out his philosophy of how to bring economic growth and jobs to the city. "You start by keeping the people you have, not by bringing in new people," he said. "The second phase is making people here happy about us, and the third phase is we bring in more people who see that the people who are here are happy and the streets are safe."
 
Marketing City's Assets
 Like Mr. Giuliani, he said the city had to begin to reduce those taxes which make it uncompetitive, like the hotel occupancy tax, the unincorporated business tax and the commercial rent tax.
And Mr. Dyson, who as State Commerce Commissioner began the "I Love New York" campaign, said the city had to market its assets, like its huge labor pool, its concentration of leading research hospitals and its arts institutions.
His view of how to promote the city as a cultural mecca promised to be the most controversial effort.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art's president, William H. Luers, said the museum would need an additional $1.5 million to $2 million annually to insure that galleries would not have to be closed sporadically. But he expressed some discomfort at the idea that his museum might gain at the expense of others. "It's difficult," he said. "In fact, the biggest institutions are clearly the biggest draws in terms of tourists from outside the city, but the smaller institutions are part of a fabric that we all realize makes up the uniqueness of the city."
 
An Informal Formula
 Under an informal financing formula that has become a city tradition, the 31 major institutions that occupy city-owned real estate receive 85 percent of city financing and more than 400 other arts groups get 15 percent. Among the 31 institutions are the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Brooklyn Museum, El Museo del Barrio, the Bronx County Historical Society and the New York Shakespeare Festival. The 400 arts grant recipients vary from local street theater groups, to restorations like Flushing Town Hall, to the Yeshiva University museum, to the Museum of Modern Art. The extent of the reliance on city aid varies among the institutions, with the larger ones able to turn to private donors, admissions and endowments.
Earlier this year Mr. Dinkins's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, Luis R. Cancel, proposed increases for only 13 of the 31 major institutions, passing over the City Center and the American Museum of Natural History for smaller museums like the Bronx Museum and El Museo del Barrio in Manhattan. He said the money available was too limited to be spread across the board.
"One of the things I know Commissioner Cancel wanted to be remembered about is the importance of diversity," said his spokeswoman, Carole Sorell. "He just feels it's important besides European culture to begin to learn about other cultures and to value them. That's what he tried to do. Not that the Met isn't important -- it's very important."
In a bitter budget battle, the Council threatened to dissolve Mr. Cancel's department. Ultimately, after the Council restored money to the culture budget, the traditional financing formula was maintained and increases were more evenly apportioned.

HEADLINE: California Trails U.S. in Growth

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28

 BODY:
For the first time in two decades, California's population is growing slower than the nation's as a whole, the Census Bureau said today.
Last July 1 there were 257.9 million Americans, 2.8 million more than a year earlier. That translates into a population increase of 1.1 percent. Nearly a third of the growth, 894,000 people, was the result of migration from other countries, the bureau said. Births accounted for the rest. 
 But California's population lagged slightly behind the nation's as a whole, growing by 1 percent, to 31.2 million. Immigrants from abroad accounted for 95 percent of the state's growth.
In the 1980's, California grew twice as fast as the nation. But in recent years California's huge aerospace industry has shrunk as the military cut purchasing after the cold war ended. Heavy immigration has also contributed to a rapid growth in the number of people looking for jobs.
"There are no longer rumors floating around elsewhere in the United States that you can come to California and get a good job," said Peter Morrison, a demographer with the Rand Corporation, a research institute in Santa Monica, Calif.
Many Californians are migrating to states nearby like Washington, Oregon and Arizona, Mr. Morrison said, adding that newcomers to California are mainly younger people who provide a good work force for future growth. "They're more like unemployed college graduates than economic refugees," he said.
Nationwide, Nevada was the fastest growing state, at 3.9 percent, followed by Idaho, at 3.1 percent, and Colorado, 2.9 percent.
Two states, Connecticut and Rhode Island, lost population, by one-tenth of 1 percent each. The District of Columbia also lost population, by 1.2 percent.
The West was the nation's fastest growing region, at 1.7 percent, followed by the South, 1.4 percent, the Midwest, seven-tenths of 1 percent, and the Northeast, at one-half of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: An Immigrant Is Helped by the Neediest Cases Fund

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
When Ana Marin first set foot on American soil, she could barely see her new country. It was the middle of the night and she had just carried her infant daughter and young son for miles through the hills that descend into the small towns south of San Diego.
Along with dozens of other Mexicans and Central Americans that night in late 1981, she followed a "coyote," or immigrant smuggler, across the border. The members of the crossing party, called "pollos," or chickens, by the smugglers, were given no guarantee that the several hundred dollars they had each paid would guarantee their safe passage. 
 "But I had to come, because there was no work where I lived," said Ms. Marin, who hitchhiked to Tijuana after leaving her home in Guatemala. "You have nothing if you are from where I lived."
For Ms. Marin, like thousands of other illegal immigrants, the United States has not offered much more in the way of prosperity. In September 1982, she arrived in Brooklyn and worked at a factory for $3 an hour, packing shirt buttons into boxes.
At first, New York was an exciting and frightening place. "I thought it was very nice," Ms. Marin said, in halting English. "But I was scared too because of the tall buildings. In California, nothing was so tall."
Soon, the city's glittery image faded as Ms. Marin settled into a daily struggle to survive. Even with the legal status she received as a result of the 1986 Immigration Reform and Control Act, she found she could not make enough to feed her children and pay her rent.
For a time in 1990, after having to quit her job and flee her apartment because her boyfriend was beating her, she lived in a private shelter in Queens. Her unemployment checks were too small to pay a security deposit and first month's rent on an apartment, so she moved out of the shelter into one small room in a Bronx apartment building.
When she found out that she was pregnant again, however, the fragile hold she had on her life fell apart. Ms. Marin's daughter, Jasmine, was born nearly three months premature with underdeveloped lungs. Officials at the hospital told Ms. Marin they would not release the baby to her if she could not find better housing for her children.
In an effort to keep Jasmine out of foster care, hospital and city housing officials referred Ms. Marin to the Community Service Society, one of seven charities assisted by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
The fund is conducting its 82d annual appeal for donations to help the agencies help single mothers like Ms. Marin and countless other people who live in the city without housing, medical care or enough food. The donations sent in by thousands from New York and around the world are given directly to the charities because The Times pays all of the campaign's administrative costs.
As the result of aggressive advocacy by the Community Service Society to get Ms. Marin a housing subsidy from the city's Child Welfare Administration, she is now living in a three-bedroom clapboard house with a lawn in Far Rockaway, Queens.
Her struggle to pull herself out of poverty is far from over. She still lives on public assistance. She also suffers from epileptic seizures, and recently, burned her arm when she collapsed on the stove while cooking.
But despite everything -- despite even the fact that she could not afford a Christmas tree -- she still manages a broad smile when she speaks of keeping her family together.
"That is the thing that comes first," she said. "Everything else will come with time."

HEADLINE: Dow and S.& P. Edge Up to New Records

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Stocks inched higher yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index both touching new highs for a second day.
But in contrast to the situation on Monday, the records set yesterday were modest achievements. The Dow closed at 3,793.77, up 84-hundredths of a point, while the S.& P. 500 index closed at 470.94, up four-tenths of a point. 
 Meanwhile, the Nasdaq market showed a bit more vibrance, with its composite index advancing 3.50 points, to 764.56.
 
Advances Outnumber Declines
 Advances exceeded declines by 1,217 to 825 on a day when turnover continued at a low level during this holiday trading period. But yesterday's volume of 203.8 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange topped Monday's slow trading of 171.2 million shares. The Dow transportation average also rallied to a record of 1,775.61, up 5.14.
"I liked the tone of the thing," said John H. Shaughnessy, senior vice president of Advest Inc. "The breadth was definitely positive and it was a good, solid day."
Among the news developments affecting the stock market was a report that the Conference Board's consumer confidence index jumped more than 8 points this month to 80.2 -- its highest point in almost three years. In addition, the December survey of retail sales by the Johnson Redbook Service showed an increase at a seasonally adjusted rate of 8.1 percent over the year-earlier period.
Some retail stocks reacted positively to these developments. Wal-Mart Stores and May Department Stores were both on the Big Board's most active list, with the former gaining 3/8, to 26 1/8 and the later increasing 3/8, to 39 5/8.
Many economically sensitive cyclical stocks, closely tied to the rises and falls of the economy, moved to higher ground. Automobile shares particularly reflected investor optimism, as Chrysler -- which received a boost yesterday in a report from S. G. Warburg & Company -- rose 5/8, to 53 7/8, General Motors gained 1/2, to 56 3/4 and Ford advanced 1/4, to 64 3/4.
Airlines were strong during the day, apparently benefiting from weak oil prices and rising traffic. AMR, the parent of American Airlines, was up 1/4, to 67 7/8 and UAL, the parent of United Airlines, was up 5/8, to 148 1/8.
 
Food Stocks Turn Lower
 Also showing strength were the high-technology stocks, with analysts noting that shipments of computer chips are expected to be higher in 1994. Motorola rose 1/2, to 91 7/8, Texas Instruments increased 1/2, to 63 1/8, Advanced Mirco Devices gained 5/8, to 18 1/8 and Micron Technology climbed 1/4, to 46 3/8.
In contrast, some food stocks turned lower. H. J. Heinz declined 1/8, to 36 and Ralston-Purina slumped 1/2, to 39 1/8.
Foundation Health also wound up on the down side, dropping 5/8, to 29 3/4 after the Defense Department decided not to award the company a $3.5 billion contract for health-care to military dependents in California and Hawaii. And Oracle Systems, plagued by concern over its earnings outlook, declined for the fourth consecutive day by falling 7/8, to 29.
On the plus side, Cabletron Systems increased 1 3/8, to 112 1/8, following the signing of an agreement to sell computer newtwork products in Southeast Asia and Australia.
Closed-end country funds consisting of companies in emerging markets, which turned in a good performance on Monday, did so once more yesterday, including the Chile Fund, up 1 5/8, to 46 3/8 and the Thai Capital Fund, up 1 1/8, to 22 7/8.

HEADLINE: I.R.S. Raises Its Estimate of Tax Cheating

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28

 BODY:
Americans cheat the Government out of about $150 billion a year in taxes -- enough to cover three-fifths of the Federal budget deficit -- the Internal Revenue Service said today.
This is far more than it estimated as recently as last month.
In an appearance before Congress in November, Margaret Milner Richardson, the I.R.S. Commissioner appointed by President Clinton, put the "tax gap" at some $119 billion. But now that the agency has widened its net beyond income taxes -- mainly adding payroll levies and excise levies on items like gasoline, guns, luxury cars and fishing rods -- it has come up with the higher figure. 
 It expects to publish a formal report on these other aspects of evasion by mid-1994.
The scrutiny of the broader range of taxes is seen as part of increased enforcement efforts. This month the agency announced a plan under which it would consolidate customer-service and returns processing, transferring many people now in clerical jobs to front-line compliance jobs.
A major goal is to raise what the I.R.S. calls its voluntary compliance rate, now 82 percent, to 90 percent by the 21st century. Fewer than 1 percent of individual returns have been audited in recent years -- 91-hundredths of a percent of those filed in 1992.
The I.R.S. has also begun taking a more realistic view of its receivables -- the money that taxpayers acknowledge they owe, or the taxes that the Government levies on nonfilers or other recalcitrants but that remains unpaid. It is acknowledging that much of what is carried on its books can never be collected. For 1992, the only year so far estimated, it thinks it will eventually collect $22 billion of $70.9 billion now listed as owed.
The tax gap and receivables are not the same. The tax gap consists of how much extra revenue the I.R.S. should get if everybody reported all regular and moonlight income and nobody overstated deductions. It includes much of the so-called underground economy but not income from illegal activities like drug dealing.
The $150 billion gap figure was disclosed today by Commissioner Richardson at a briefing to begin the new tax-filing season. On Monday, postal employees are to start delivering more than 86 million packages of 1993 forms.
While the I.R.S. did not specifically contend today that tax cheating was on the rise, it has repeatedly expressed concern that the system is perceived as overly complex and unfair to the honest taxpayer, thereby undermining compliance.
In its latest annual report, it listed improved compliance as its "first major goal," saying it had to supplement traditional enforcement methods with new approaches. Among these are initiatives that for example, alert new businesses to tax responsibilities before they break the law.
"Experience has proved that our traditional enforcement approach alone cannot sustain appropriate compliance levels," the annual report declared.
 
Emphasizing the Positive
 At a time when many analysts are saying that tax increases enacted last summer are likely to slow economic growth again in early 1994, Commissioner Richardson sought today to emphasize the relatively small proportion of affected taxpayers.
"Despite the publicity about higher tax rates for 1993, the fact is that fewer than 2 percent of individual taxpayers will be in the new 36 or 39.6 percent tax brackets," she said. And those few, she said, may pay their additional 1993 levies in three annual interest-free installments.
The 36 percent rate begins at $115,000 for single taxpayers and $140,000 for a married couple filing jointly. A 10 percent surcharge kicks in at $250,000 for singles, heads of household and joint returns.
Among new developments this filing season are:
*About 2.5 million couples without dependents whose taxable incomes are under $50,000 will be able to use Form 1040EZ, the simplest form, previously limited to single people.
*The check-off for the Presidential election campaign fund rises to $3 from $1.
*Schedule D for capital gains and losses is 35 lines shorter, and five million self-employed people will no longer need to complete form 4562 on depreciation of business vehicles
*Filing returns by telephone, tried in a two-year experiment in Ohio, is being expanded to Florida, Indiana, Kentucky, Michigan, South Carolina and West Virginia. In southern Ohio, telephone filing will now involve a voice "signature" attesting to a return's correctness.
*Taxpayers in 23 states, including New York, will be able to file Federal and state returns electronically in one transmission to the I.R.S., up from 15 states last year.
The I.R.S. also said it had begun a pilot program to provide forms in other than English. In Southern California and South Florida it is testing a Form 1040A in Spanish.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Cheap Oil Fails to Energize Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Treasury securities were mixed yesterday in another day of subdued trading.
The market was supported to some degree by lower oil and other commodity prices, which lessened fears of any imminent resurgence of inflation. 
 An unexpected jump in the consumer-confidence data for December was largely shrugged off.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 2/32 , to 1008/32 , with its yield remaining at 6.23 percent, unchanged from Monday.
Prices of most Treasury securities sagged in early trading as market participants noted some selling in overseas accounts linked to a strong dollar and to profit-taking. With Monday's lackluster trading attitude spilling into yesterday's market, the bond market lacked significant trends.
"There are certainly more sellers than buyers," a trader said, "but that just means there are three people selling and two buying."
 
Consumer Confidence Rises
 Bond prices were temporarily weakened after the sharp surge in the Conference Board's December consumer-confidence index, to 80.2 from a revised 71.9 in November. While the report was beyond expectations, analysts said it was not devastating to the market because the trend had already been anticipated from earlier surveys by the University of Michigan and ABC/Money Magazine.
Economists also pointed out that the confidence index was only loosely tied to consumer spending habits, which are the prime movers of the economy.
Analysts at MMS International said prices of shorter-maturity issues continued to be stronger than those of longer maturities because most investors and traders had moved into a holding pattern of shorter-maturity obligations until mid-January.
Stephen Gallagher, money market economist at Kidder, Peabody & Company, said that yesterday's market was typical of holiday periods.
"The market experienced some down trading after the consumer confidence report, but received support from market participants entering to do some buying at the lower prices and by others covering short positions," he said. In covering short positions, investors buy securities to repay those previously borrowed and sold at prevailing prices in hope of future price declines. Rising prices generally set off such short-covering.
 
Oil Falls Further
 In addition to the short-covering, commodity and oil prices were down, Mr. Gallagher noted. "The fact oil fell below $14 a barrel late in the day encouraged Treasuries and helped them recover all their losses," he said.
The Johnson Redbook data of retail sales for December released yesterday afternoon was mixed but encouraging for retailers, Mr. Gallagher said. The report showed a decline of eight-tenths of a percent, but an 8.1 percent rise from a year earlier.
Mr. Gallagher noted that the numbers covered the period up to Christmas Day, with the days after Christmas still to be reported. That data, he said, had proved important over the last few years.
Also yesterday, the Treasury announced plans to sell $25.2 million of three-month and six-month bills on Monday at its regular weekly auction. The previous auction was for $26 billion.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed Despite Signs Of Economic Gains in U.S.

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against most leading currencies in light trading yesterday despite new signs of economic strength in the United States. The absence of the London foreign-exchange market, closed for the holidays, contributed to the quiet trading.
The Conference Board reported that consumer confidence jumped sharply in December, but the figures gave the dollar only a brief boost. 
 "There's no follow-through because there are no players around," said Tom Moore, senior director for American Express.
The dollar eased to 111.43 Japanese yen in late New York trading, from 111.45 late Monday. It also fell to 1.6980 German marks, from 1.7015.
Gold prices were also lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery, the most active futures contract, lost 60 cents to $388.50 an ounce.
The dollar has been trying this week to regain its footing against the yen after a selloff last week spurred by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, who said recent fluctuations in the dollar-yen rate were causing concern that Japan was not sticking to its commitment to trim the trade deficit.
Expectations that the Clinton Administration might adopt a "strong yen" policy to discourage American consumers from buying Japanese imports and to cut the country's huge trade deficit with Japan are keeping a lid on the dollar, dealers said.
Yesterday, Treasury Under Secretary Lawrence Summers pressed Japan to live up to an international commitment it had made on semiconductor trade, which calls for Japan to buy 20 percent of its semiconductors from foreign sources.
One dealer said that if trade relations with Japan soured further the dollar could fall as low as 90 to 110 yen. Conversely, many currency dealers are projecting it to hit 112 yen in early 1994 based on the fundamentals of a strong American economy compared with a weak Japanese economy.
The dollar closed in New York at 1.3310 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3275 on Monday. The British pound closed in New York at $1.5085, up from $1.5045 late Monday.
Other late dollar rates, compared with Monday's quotes, included: 1.4380 Swiss francs, down from 1.4430; 5.7880 French francs, up from 5.7945, and 1,679 Italian lire, up from 1,676.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Analysts say Kent Electronics can endure any economic phase.

BYLINE: By Robert Hurtado

 BODY:
SETTING recent buoyant economic news aside, many large investors recommend looking for stocks than can appreciate in almost any phase of the economy's cycle.
One that seems to fit the profile, some Wall Street professionals say, is the Kent Electronics Corporation, a Houston-based distributor of electronics components. "Economic phases wax and wane, but Kent keeps chugging along," Mark Plummer, an analyst with Stephens Inc., said. Indeed, the company has reported 30 consecutive quarters of increased sales and earnings since its initial public offering in June 1986. 
 Like the rest of the industry, Kent has benefited as component makers have increased their reliance on distributors, rather than selling direct, to build market share and control costs. For instance, AMP Inc., the world's largest producer of electronic connectors, named Kent in the fall of 1992 as one of its four nationally authorized distributors.
Kent has avoided the highly volatile semiconductor business and instead supplies components like resistors, capacitors and connectors -- a more stable but still growing market, analysts said. Last year, distributors sold more than $6.2 billion of these types of parts in the United States.
For the year that ended on March 31, Kent had revenues of $154.7 million, with two-thirds derived from component sales and the rest from the company's growing contract-manufacturing business. In those operations, Kent provides custom-built electronic units to original equipment manufacturers in industries like telecommunications, medical devices, energy, computers and data processing.
"Kent's expertise in contract manufacturing plays right into the rapidly growing outsourcing market, where equipment makers rely on outside vendors to supply assembled parts that meet specifications," Carlene Murphy, a portfolio manager for Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management, said. "Driving original equipment manufacturers to the outsourcing of engineered product systems and subsystems is the growing realization that American business must dedicate finite resources to strategic priorities, such as new product development, reduced inventory risk and improved operating efficiencies."
Analysts say Kent's contract-manufacturing business has grown at an annual rate of 33 percent during the last five years and they expect yearly growth to exceed 25 percent in 1994 and 1995. Earlier this year, Kent reported that gross margins for contract manufacturing dipped slightly because of some pricing pressure, but Wall Street believes margins have settled to a range of 26 to 27 percent, compared with historic levels of 27.5 percent.
Acquisitions are considered another important avenue for growth. Electronics distribution is a highly fragmented business, with about 1,500 small operators. Kent, which has a balance sheet free of debt and $27 million in cash, is considered by some market analysts to be well positioned as an acquirer. Indeed, the company has completed three acquisitions in the last six years. Each contributed immediately to earnings and increased the company's geographic reach. Since the last deal was made almost two years ago, some large investors think Kent is again on the prowl.
Investor interest helped to drive the stock to a new high of $28.75 a share on Dec. 8 in New York Stock Exchange trading. It closed yesterday at $27.125 a share, up 25 cents. Without including potential acquisitions, earnings, which were $1.20 a share in the fiscal year that ended on March 31, are expected to increase to $1.45 a share in 1994 and $1.75 a share in 1995, according to a Bear, Stearns & Company research report.

HEADLINE: Japan's Trade Surplus Ebbs

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 28

 BODY:
Japan's balance-of-payments surplus fell in November because of the strong yen, the first year-on-year decline in six months, the Finance Ministry said today.
The surplus in current accounts, a broader measure of trade and services, narrowed to $8.21 billion without adjustment for seasonal factors, from $10.34 billion a year earlier. 
 Economists said this could signal the end of a long rise in the surplus, adding that it was likely to continue shrinking because of the strong yen.
The trade surplus shrank to $9.05 billion last month from $9.57 billion a year earlier and $12.43 billion in October, the Finance Ministry said.
Economists said a dwindling surplus had not previously been apparent in dollar figures because the strong yen inflated the dollar value of Japanese exports. But now the yen's rise is putting enough pressure on Japan's export volume to cut the surplus in dollar terms.
A ministry official declined to say that the dollar-based current-account surplus was definitely on a downward trend. He said currency rates, crude oil prices and the broad domestic and foreign economic situations must still be watched.
Japanese products lost competitiveness in the world market as the yen traded at 108.82 to the dollar by the end of November, compared with 124.75 a year earlier. The yen's strength increased imports in November by making them cheaper.
The current-account surplus with the United States totaled $22.74 billion in the six months from January through June 1993, up from $19.65 billion a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said.

HEADLINE: Pickup Seen For Industry

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28

 BODY:
More than two years after the recession officially ended, the wheels of industry will start humming in 1994, the Government predicted today.
In its 35th annual forecast of winners and losers in American industry, the Commerce Department said prospects were bright for makers of automobiles, computers, factory machinery and home appliances. 
 Prospects were at least mildly positive for nearly every industry except military contractors. Of 136 manufacturing industries surveyed, 121 were expected to show increasing sales.
"We anticipate the fastest expansion in manufacturers' shipments since 1988," said Jeffrey E. Garten, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade.
Over all, the department's forecast, called the United States Industrial Outlook, projected an inflation-adjusted median growth rate in manufacturers' shipments of 2.8 percent, meaning half would see faster growth and half slower.
That compares with gains of 2 percent this year and 1.7 percent in 1992 and a decline of 3.7 percent in 1991, the year the recession ended. If realized, the predicted 1994 advance would be the third consecutive gain and the largest in six years.
Despite the prospect for higher shipments, 60 of the 121 manufacturing industries projecting growth are expected to cut employment.
They are achieving higher output by modernizing and computerizing their production. Payrolls in the fast-growing electronic component manufacturing business, for instance, are expected to shrink 2 percent.
The 1993 648-page outlook, prepared by more than 130 Government analysts, will be sold at Federal bookstores.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
Bye, bye Betsy: More than 300 of BETSY GOTBAUM'S friends and colleagues at New York City's Department of Parks and Recreation, who are known as "parkies," will gather tonight at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park to bid her farewell the department's Commissioner.
The party was originally planned to celebrate Ms. Gotbaum's four years on the job, said STEWART DESMOND, a Parks Department spokesman, "but there was some thought it might turn into a farewell." 
 Although Ms. Gotbaum said she expected the party to be a nostalgic occasion, organizers hope to keep the mood upbeat, planning what Mr. Desmond characterized as "a wild bash with Brazilian music."
Ms. Gotbaum said: "This is sort of bittersweet and very, very sad, but that's life. I love the agency and all the people, and, yes, I had hoped to stay on."
She will be succeeded by her immediate predecessor, Henry J. Stern, who served as Parks Commissioner for seven years under Mayor Edward I. Koch and who wanted to remain on the job when Mayor David N. Dinkins tapped Ms. Gotbaum four years ago. "I was interviewed, but they decided that was not what they wanted to do," she said, referring to the Giuliani administration.
"I have no idea what I will do next; not a clue," she added, noting that her husband, Victor Gotbaum, the former labor leader who resigned from the Board of Education last month, was out of a job as well. "You have the two unemployed Gotbaums," she said. "Any suggestions what we can do?"
Meanwhile, she had lunch yesterday with Mr. Stern at Fresco, the restaurant on East 52d Street. "I took him," she said. "It was the gracious thing to do."

HEADLINE: ...And Knowing What to Look For

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
"THERE are some real caviar connoisseurs in New York City," said Rod Mitchell, a seafood and caviar dealer in Portland, Me. His company, Browne Trading, sells mostly to restaurants, but he was talking about discerning private clients who order generous tins of caviar week in and week out.
They do not wait for New Year's Eve to splurge and eat a bit of caviar. 
 But for most people, even those who adore the glistening roe of the sturgeon (the only kind that can legally be called caviar without identifying the type of fish, as in lumpfish caviar), fine caviar is an infrequent treat. Maybe a canape or two at a wedding reception -- unless it's a Trump wedding with heaps of it on hand -- or some sybaritic spoonfuls at year's end. And for those who have not made caviar a habit, buying it always seems to be somewhat puzzling, a little like shopping for good jewelry.
Do you go to Tiffany's, knowing it will be expensive but reliable, or do you look for a bargain on Canal Street? For caviar there are also numerous top-of-the-line retailers like Petrossian and Caviarteria and mail-order companies like Browne Trading. But what about those dealers with rock-bottom prices, sevruga for a song?
These days there seems to be more bargain caviar than ever. Prices in general are lower than they were a few years ago, even at Petrossian. Some of the low prices at places like Macy's and Zabar's are loss-leaders in the usual year-end price wars. Others are offered by wholesalers who also sell retail.
How does all this caviar from different sources, some with prices half those of others, measure up? Which is the one to buy for New Year's? Samples of sevruga caviar, purchased from 11 retail, wholesale and mail-order sources, were tasted at The New York Times last week.
Not included in the tasting were the inexpensive little tins of caviar ($4 to $5 an ounce) that have to be opened with a can-opener and have labels entirely in Russian now being sold at delicatessens in the Brighton Beach area of Brooklyn, home to many Russian immigrants. This is black market caviar intended only for domestic consumption in Russia and smuggled out in someone's suitcase. A hundred years ago immigrants brought their diamonds. Now they bring fish eggs. But chances are it has not been kept refrigerated. Chances are it is not worthy of your Champagne.
Sevruga is the smallest, most abundant and, at $20 an ounce or less, the least expensive of the three major kinds of Caspian Sea sturgeon. Ossetra caviar is from a larger type of sturgeon with larger eggs that are often grayish or brownish and have an earthier, more nutty flavor. These days ossetra caviar costs about 20 percent more than sevruga.
Beluga, the most prized, is the rarest kind, with the largest, most delicate eggs. It comes from giant beluga sturgeon that can weigh as much as a ton. An ounce of beluga will set you back at least $50. Within each of these categories there are various grades.
The caviars that were tasted had typically small eggs, with some brands beautifully uniform and unbroken. Others were uneven, messy and downright soupy, evidence that they might have been badly handled, or were probably not as fresh as they should have been and certainly would not have provided that satisfying "pop," the sensation of a delicate bubble bursting when pressed gently against the roof of the mouth.
The way the caviar appears in a freshly opened tin is a good clue to texture, which is almost as critical as flavor. The eggs should be glossy and uniform in size, unbroken and not sitting in oily goo. Color is of secondary importance.
The flavor should be clean and balanced, with a light oceanic saltiness that may be more pronounced in sevruga than in the other kinds of Caspian Sea caviars but never overwhelming. A sweetness, nuttiness and earthiness are other desirable characteristics. Metallic, musty or acrid flavors and mushy, gritty or overly sticky textures are not.
Freshness is critical to the quality of fine caviar. In the Caspian Sea there are two annual sturgeon catches, spring and fall. The freshest caviar on the market today would ideally be from this fall's catch in October and November, which takes a month or so after being cleaned and lightly salted to reach the United States market. Aside from the celebratory aspect, that is why New Year's is a good time to buy caviar. And the turnover in shops during the holidays is the largest, another reason the caviar is likely to be fresher.
Pasteurized caviar, sold in glass jars that do not require refrigeration until they are opened, never has the oceanic delicacy or the elegant, barely resilient yet moist texture of the finest fresh kind.
Once purchased, a tin of fresh caviar (or a jar of it -- quantities of less than three ounces usually come in thick little jars) can be kept unopened in the coldest part of the refrigerator (but not the freezer) for up to a month without deteriorating. The best way to keep it is to place the tin directly on a frozen gel pack, changing the pack as it defrosts. An opened tin is best used in a single sitting. Any unused portion can be kept for another day or so if the surface is smoothed, a piece of plastic wrap is placed directly on it and it is kept in the coldest part of the refrigerator.
This year, Zabar's, a reliable store that sells about 5,000 pounds of caviar during the holiday season, has posted a sign advising customers to use their caviar within seven days of purchase. Murray Klein, one of the owners, said it was a precaution, because home refrigerators often do not keep the caviar cold enough, and had nothing to do with the freshness of the caviar they were selling.
All the players in the caviar pipeline insist their caviar is fresh, from the latest catch. But some say there are stocks of caviar from the 1991 and 1992 harvests in storage in Russia and Germany. "A great deal of the caviar that is supposedly fresh may be two, even three years old," said Bruce Sobol of Caviarteria in Manhattan. Kept under the proper commercial cold-storage conditions, some of it might still be acceptable but some will inevitably have become mushy or excessively salty.
Since the dissolution of the Soviet Union the caviar business has become increasingly byzantine, with slick entrepreneurs jumping on the bandwagon of an industry that was once under tight Soviet control. There are reports of Russian fishermen salting fresh caviar in their bathtubs and selling it to shady operators. "It's a mess over there right now," Mr. Mitchell, the caviar dealer, said.
Top importers like Petrossian and Caviarteria have agents in Russia selecting caviar. Others deal with reliable brokers in Hamburg, Germany, and, increasingly, in Poland.
Russia produces most of the Caspian Sea caviar, a harvest that this year is expected to amount to about 230 tons, less than 10 percent of what it was in the 1970's. Small amounts of caviar are being produced in Azerbaijan and Kazakhstan. Iranian production, which used to account for a sizable portion of the harvest, dropped precipitously after the revolution there in 1979 and remains small. Overfishing has also affected production tremendously, and the Russians are desperately trying to restock the Caspian Sea with sturgeon fingerlings.
"Even though production is low the prices have not gone up because there is so much in storage," Mr. Mitchell said. "But once that caviar is gone and dealers have to rely on the annual catch you'll probably see prices double."
This year, the market has been enhanced by sturgeon caviar from the Amur River in Siberia, from a huge sturgeon closely related to the beluga, but not the same. A few years back it was coming in from the other side of the same river in China.
The eggs look like top-of-the-line beluga, pewter gray, large, glossy and separate. Their texture is also first rate, but the flavor is somewhat saltier, less delicate and complex than true beluga. The caviar does have a nice sweetness in the aftertaste and, for a price comparable to that of sevruga, this caviar, often called keluga, is undeniably a very good buy, especially since it is likely to be reliably fresh.
Are some dealers selling this caviar as Caspian Sea beluga, as others suggest, and charging top dollar? Rumors hinting at unsavory practices are as much a part of the caviar business as year-end sales. Bal ducci's, among others, incorrectly advertises it as "beluga," even though it properly gives its source as either Russia or the Amur River and sells it for a quarter of the price of beluga.
For those who do not want to splurge on Caspian Sea or Amur River sturgeon caviar, there is fresh American sturgeon caviar of extremely variable quality and priced slightly lower than sevruga. Thick, jammy pressed caviar, the bottom of the Caspian Sea barrel, is cheaper still, but very intense; it is best eaten smeared on blini with creme fraiche or sour cream.
There are also roes processed from other fish like salmon, with its large, juicy orange eggs; whitefish, which is golden and fine-grained, and lumpfish, which is usually sold pasteurized and dyed black. Caviarteria is selling Carolina trout roe that is a reddish salmon color, fairly small grained, with a subtle flavor at once salty and fruity. And now in Brazil they are even starting to process the roe of some large Amazon fish.
"Good caviar can be awesome," Mr. Sobol said. "But the problem is that half the people who buy it think you should get some kind of a good deal and the other half think you should overpay. The important thing, especially for New Year's Eve, is that caviar should give real pleasure."

HEADLINE: Unfinished Bank Reform

 BODY:
Two years ago, in the aftermath of the $500 billion savings and loan bailout, Congress passed two-thirds of a bank reform. It poured money into a near-empty deposit insurance fund. And it vastly improved procedures by which regulators could close a bank before it tumbled into bankruptcy and required a costly infusion of taxpayer money to pay off insured depositors.
But what the 1991 bill didn't do is correct the cause of many bank failures: antiquated laws that prohibit banks from investing outside their own states and selling new products. 
 The Clinton Administration has now proposed three bank initiatives. One would simplify regulation, collapsing four overlapping agencies into one. That would be prudent, though multiple regulators aren't all bad: rivalry can stimulate innovation. The second initiative would simplify and toughen regulations that require banks to pump loans into low-income neighborhoods. Both proposals are reasonable and likely to do some good; neither is likely to make a big impact.
The third initiative calls for Congress to permit banks to set up branches anywhere in the country, thereby plugging the gap in the 1991 bill. Unfortunately, the Administration gives scant evidence that it's prepared to muscle this valuable and important idea past obstructionist forces in Congress.
Banks are generally restricted to investing primarily in one industry, real estate, and one state. That makes investment in banks risky. When the energy crisis hit in the 1980's, the economy of the Southwest collapsed, dragging the banks down also. One remedy is to permit banks to invest throughout the country -- relying on profits in South Dakota, for instance, to make up for losses in Texas. Another remedy is to allow banks to diversify out of real estate by selling financial products like insurance.
But frenzied lobbyists attacked these sensible ideas when they were proposed by the Bush Administration. Small bankers blocked interstate banking because they feared competition from big banks.
Of course small bankers wrap their opposition in high-minded rhetoric. They argue that small banks would provide more loans to local borrowers than interstate behemoths and that big banks would eventually overwhelm competitors and monopolize local banking. Neither is true. Where wide-scale branching is already permitted, like California, small banks prosper. Also large banks lend as much to local merchants as small local lenders do; small bankers have the same easy access to international outlets for their money. And competition from big banks drives up interest rates on savings accounts of local depositors.
The insurance industry blocked President Bush's proposals to give banks the right to sell insurance. Congress buckled under, even though banks would have served merely as sales agents for policies and would not have incurred risk.
Interstate banking won't get through Congress without a heave from the White House. President Clinton seems disinclined to tackle bank reform when more important measures -- health care, welfare and trade -- loom on the calendar. The political calculation might be faultless. But the nation's banks can thrive just so long on two-thirds of a reform.

HEADLINE: Still Out to Change Japan

 BODY:
After five bruising months in office, Japan's charismatic new Prime Minister, Morihiro Hosokawa, has lost some of his initial sparkle. But it is too soon to count him out.
Japanese hopes for more democratic, less corrupt and more consumer-oriented politics still ride on his shoulders. So do America's hopes for easier relations with its most important economic partner and chief Asian ally. 
 Mr. Hosokawa entered office with an ambitious reform agenda. In recent months he has had to come to terms with some formidable obstacles: his coalition Government's thin parliamentary majority, strains between the coalition parties and the strength of Japan's powerful bureaucracy. The new Government has also been constrained by the worst recession to afflict Japan in decades.
Mr. Hosokawa has resorted to some tactical compromises. He has stretched his timetable for key reforms. U.S. officials are already complaining about slow progress on trade issues.
Yet he has already racked up some notable achievements and is still drawing more than 60 percent support in opinion polls -- nearly 10 times the personal popularity enjoyed by some of his Liberal Democratic Party predecessors.
Largely at Washington's behest, he forced his reluctant coalition partners to accept an end to Japan's longstanding ban on rice imports. And, through an adept mix of leadership and compromise, he has come tantalizingly close to enacting his top priority, electoral reform.
Legislation to reapportion districts more fairly and restrict the influence of private campaign contributions has already passed Parliament's lower house. But it awaits an uncertain fate in the upper house. Mr. Hosokawa will try to exploit opposition fears that he will dissolve Parliament and call early elections to try to carry the measure through in the present legislative term. Should he succeed in passing the reforms, he may gain another year without elections, since parties will need time to organize themselves under new rules and in newly drawn districts. By the end of 1994, there may be no going back to the old one-party system.
Instead, various elements of the present governing coalition, which ranges improbably from Socialist left to nationalist right, and from good-government reformers to backroom godfathers, are likely to contend for power.
Mr. Hosokawa's own group represents a more modern political style than any of its main competitors. The Japan it envisions is more democratic, internationalist but not militarist, and ready to put the interest of urban consumers ahead of protectionist producer blocs. This Japan would be an ideal partner for the U.S.
The Hosokawa group is probably not strong enough to prevail on its own. But Mr. Hosokawa has shown in his brief tenure that he knows how to make pragmatic compromises while holding firm to principles. It is an encouraging record, well beyond what anyone, Japanese or American, would have dared predict as recently as a year ago.

HEADLINE: When Currencies Collapse

BYLINE: By Boyden Gray; Boyden Gray, a lawyer, was counsel to President George Bush.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The big trade agreements of the past few months have prompted rejoicing in the United States, Latin America, Western Europe and Asia. But they will be of little value to the former Soviet republics and Eastern Europe, where the growing economic disparity with the rest of the world will sow the seeds of enormous regional violence if it is not corrected soon.
The key to the economic plight of these nations is all too easy to overlook: the terrible instability of their currencies and the great difficulty of converting them to other currencies. Yet if the U.S. and the rest of world ignore the currency problems of the old Soviet bloc, we will be repeating the very mistakes that led to World War II -- and forgetting the lessons of the 1940's, which not only corrected these mistakes but also laid the basis for a world trading system and for the collapse of the Soviet empire. 
 What were these mistakes and lessons? Apart from the wrongheaded Smoot-Hawley tariff of 1930, the major mistake was to pull the financial plug on Germany in the 1920's, leaving it unable to establish sound money and trade with its neighbors. And it was the genius of the Marshall Plan to help re-establish all of Western Europe as an economic trading bloc after the war, so that everyone, winners and losers alike, could rebuild and prosper.
The key to the Marshall Plan's success was not foreign aid itself but the establishment of the European Payments Union, which guaranteed that currencies could be freely converted throughout Western Europe so that countries could attract outside private capital and grow through expanded trade with their neighbors.
But today there is no reliable or predictable currency convertibility and therefore no equivalent opportunity for investment, trade and growth in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, no matter how much foreign aid we pump in. This means economic decline and soaring inflation throughout the region -- conditions that closely resemble Germany's between the wars.
What can be done? As the Marshall Plan showed us, currency convertibility is essential to outside private investment and expanded trade. It requires special attention because there are so many pressures to look the other way. In the short term, the West lacks the incentive to correct the situation: private financial institutions find it too easy to make short-term currency profits out of the chaos. The countries themselves have no short-term incentives, either: clamping down on inflation means denying them the joys of a discretionary fiscal policy -- especially deficit financing (used now primarily to keep the old state-owned enterprises afloat).
Yet without stable currencies throughout Eastern Europe, privatization is certain to be a failure. We in the West take for granted the legal institutions that make privatization possible -- the rule of law, the enforceability of contracts and the independence of the judiciary. These are all legal developments that took a thousand years to mature and are essential to the preservation of property values that are in turn essential to a market economy, if not also to democracy itself. They are largely missing in the former Soviet bloc.
Even without them, Eastern Europe could obtain much of their benefit by looking to their currencies as the basis for a stable, transferable and convertible store of property values. The best way to do this -- and to emulate the best of the Marshall Plan -- is to establish currency boards in every Eastern European country.
A currency board is simply a monetary authority that links the money it issues to a reserve of hard currency, like the U.S. dollar, by means of a fixed exchange rate and 100 percent backing for the notes and coins it issues. (The reserve can be built up in any number of ways, including loans from the International Monetary Fund with natural resources as collateral.) The board earns a profit because its assets (reserves) earn interest and its liabilities (notes and coins) pay none. A currency board system is automatic, like a gold standard. It has no discretionary monetary or fiscal powers, and no power to act as a lender of last resort.
Since the establishment of the first currency board (in Mauritius, in 1849), there have been more than 70 around the world. All have delivered sound money even during civil wars.
The key to their success is their simplicity and foolproof nature. The Marshall Plan's payments union assumed a level of sophistication in currency operations in Western Europe that simply does not exist in the East. So a simpler, more error-proof mechanism is necessary.
John Maynard Keynes established a currency board in northern Russia in 1918, in the middle of World War I and the Russian Revolution. It functioned very well for two years until the Bolsheviks tore it down.
There are, of course, modern examples of currency boards. Hong Kong's is the most famous, and its dollar-backed currency is providing much of the stability behind South China's current economic miracle. Similar growth is happening in Argentina, for similar reasons.
A more pertinent case is Estonia. Like Argentina, it has the substantial equivalent of a currency board; both nations follow closely the advice given by Steve Hanke, the Johns Hopkins University economics professor whose "Monetary Reform in a Free Estonia" and "Central Bank or Currency Board?" were published in Estonian and Spanish, respectively. He has also provided advice on Lithuania, which is seeking I.M.F. and World Bank help to copy the Estonian experience.
What's most urgently needed is for a Western banking consortium to set up currency boards in Ukraine, whose 52 million people are saddled with inflation of almost 100 percent per month, and in other republics of the former Soviet Union. As the recent Russian elections made all too plain, economic instability can lead to political instability. Who would want to promote such a risk in countries that still have nuclear arsenals?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: $89 Million Awarded Family Who Sued H.M.O.

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
In a sign of surging conflict over medical cost containment, a California jury has awarded $89.3 million to the family of a woman whose health maintenance organization refused to pay for a costly, experimental procedure to treat the breast cancer that ultimately killed her.
The award, by far the largest in a case involving the denial of medical benefits, has sent nervous tremors through the health insurance industry, which is struggling to define limits on the coverage of therapies that are experimental or have only a slight chance of success. 
 How and where to draw such lines are central questions as the country seeks to contain soaring health spending amid a rush of technological advances and as more patients join cost-conscious, prepaid health plans like H.M.O.'s, a goal of President Clinton's proposals for revamping the nation's health care system.
Women's health advocates, who say, with support from some cancer specialists, that patients with otherwise dismal prognoses deserve access to a promising treatment, praised the jury award.
The woman, Nelene Fox of Temecula, Calif., who was 40 at her death, had sought coverage for a bone-marrow transplant to combat her advanced breast cancer. It was denied by her health maintenance organization, Health Net, based in Los Angeles.
The judgment was returned in Riverside County Superior Court by a jury that awarded the plaintiffs $77 million in punitive damages on Tuesday and $12.1 million in compensatory damages and $212,000 for medical expenses last week.
In an interview yesterday, the family's lawyer, Mark Hiepler, repeating arguments that had obviously touched a chord among jurors, said the defendant, Health Net, had violated a promise in its contracts to pay for bone-marrow transplants. He also contended that Health Net had financially rewarded its executives for denying coverage of costly procedures and he called this case a warning to any H.M.O. or other insurer that offers such incentives.
Dr. Sam Ho, the medical director of Health Net, which is the state's second-largest health maintenance organization, said the company covered bone-marrow transplants for certain conditions but also had a clear policy of excluding treatments that have not been proved safe and effective. He said that an outside advisory panel of medical experts had agreed that marrow transplants for advanced, metastatic breast cancer, as Mrs. Fox had, were of unproven value. The accusation that Health Net officials had a financial incentive to deny useful treatments was "preposterous," he said.
 
'An Unwarranted Award'
 In a written statement, Health Net said it had acted "in the best interests" of Mrs. Fox, who developed breast cancer in 1991 at the age of 38. The company contended that "the emotional aspects of the case caused the jury to render an unwarranted award" and said it would seek a retrial. Often, huge jury awards are later reduced by courts or in settlements.
James Fox, husband of the deceased patient, said, "I don't think they can hide behind the term 'experimental' and treat people the way they treated us." Mrs. Fox died last April, eight months after receiving the disputed transplant therapy with $212,000 in cash and donated drugs that were raised through public appeals.
"You don't know what the results will be until you try," said Mr. Fox, a junior high school teacher who is caring for their three daughters, ages 5, 10 and 12. "If there's an outside chance of a cure, you want to do it."
Cancer specialists said the costs of the procedure, as reported by Mr. Fox, were at the high end for bone marrow procedures, with charges at some hospitals now as low as $60,000 for some patients. Also, H.M.O.'s often negotiate lower rates than individual patients.
Disputes over payment for the marrow transplants in women with advanced breast cancer have raged for several years. Some insurers have refused to cover what they firmly maintained wa is an experimental method, while others quietly, or under threat of lawsuit, have agreed to pay. But legal experts said they knew of no related cases involving such a huge award. The highest previous jury award for denial of medical services was $18 million, according to records of Jury Verdict Research, a company in Philadelphia.
In interviews with The Los Angeles Times, jurors said Health Net had engaged in "reckless infliction of emotional distress," as one of them put it, and had sought to escape its contractual commitments. The jury foreman, Robley Bowen, said the $77 million in punitive damages had been set after the jury heard details of the company's finances, adding, "They've got their eyes open now."
The $12.1 million in compensatory damages were intended to pay the family for emotional distress and for the company's bad-faith action, said Mr. Hiepler, the lawyer, who is also Mrs. Fox's brother.
The grueling transplant therapy involves weeks of hospitalization and a 5 percent-to-10 percent risk of death from the procedure itself. Doctors remove and save some of a patient's own healthy bone marrow to protect it from huge, devastating doses of chemotherapy administered to the patient in hope of killing off all cancer cells in the body. The marrow is then re-injected to produce new, healthy blood cells.
The method has already proved helpful in certain blood cancers and is being tried in patients with breast and other cancers that have spread beyond the reach of conventional therapy. The Federal government is directing studies on the benefits and risks of marrow transplants in women with advanced breast cancer.
 
Donated Money
 First diagnosed in 1991, Mrs. Fox's breast cancer soon spread elswehere in her body, Mr. Fox said. A local physician and specialists at the University of Southern California said they believed she was a good candidate for a transplant, he said. In June 1992, after Health Net denied coverage, the Foxes launched a public campaign for funds, and she had the procedure in late August 1992. After doing well for several months, her husband said, she declined quickly and died last April.
Dr. David Eddy, a health economist with Duke University who has advised the White House and served as a consultant to insurance companies, said that in a case like this it was crucial to distinguish between issues of contractual obligations and scientific evidence on marrow transplants.
"If the message here is that health care organizations should be more precise in their definitions and procedures, and more consistent in applying them, then over the long run that's fine," he said, although he added that he deplored the size of this award and was not familiar with Health Net's specific actions.
"But if this is interpreted to mean that investigational procedures should be covered," he said, "that is a disaster, not just for the cost of health care but also for the quality of health care." Insurance coverage, he said, is a major barrier preventing wide use of unproved, possibly harmful treatments.
Medical researchers say that at best, a bone-marrow transplant gives a patient with advanced breast cancer, like Mrs. Fox, a small chance of a cure. Whether she would have survived as long as she did by instead relying on conventional therapies is impossible to determine.
Mr. Fox said he did not know if the delay in obtaining his wife's transplant or the strains of campaigning for funds had hastened her death. But he said that once she had the procedure she had a temporary remission and for five months she had "a very high quality of life."
"We had a wonderful Christmas last year," he said.

HEADLINE: Rites of Passage (With Plenty of Boxes)

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

 BODY:
In his dwindling days of power, as his office records and possessions were being packed up, David N. Dinkins set up a clothes rack in the executive wing of City Hall, stocked it with scores of the zippered warm-up jackets he had worn as his trademark costume as Mayor, and had a going-out-of-business souvenir offering for his neighboring loyalists.
Tenderly, he also saw to the wrapping of the kaleidoscopic array of photos of himself with the rich, the famous and the plebian that lined the hidden passageway leading down to the basement inner-sanctum from his office in the northwest corner. The Jimmy Walker-like society pleasures of incumbency for Mr. Dinkins were never clearer to outsiders than in that passageway.
 
Checking Out the Premises
 As if for contrasting symbolism, Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani arrived unannounced last Sunday morning with Peter J. Powers, his deputy mayor-designate and Richelieu-handyman. Lacking celebrity rotogravure, but with the City Hall building blueprint itself in hand, Mr. Giuliani meticulously took stock of the premises he finally won after a five-year, tooth-and-claw campaign. 
"The place was deserted and I was typing notes and letters of recommendation for City Hall people looking for new jobs, and suddenly I hear, 'Hey, Lee,' " said Leland T. Jones, Mr. Dinkins's press secretary. "There they were: the Rudester and the Powerster! Checking office space," said Mr. Jones, who admits to a spirit of bipartisan slap-happiness in the face of all the packing crates and passing power.
This week, the jewel-box setting of City Hall seemed a stage being cleared for a freshly proclaimed hit. A big blue trash bin stood on wheels in the lobby rotunda, filled to the brim with discarded notions and tumbled reports -- notably a full 1993 set, through November, of paperback tomes titled "Reform and Renaissance of the New York City Government." Ominously or not, the bin's contents were marked "recyclable."
"This is a democracy, warts and all," Mr. Jones exulted, confessing to a few tears, as his emotional threshold remains as frayed and narrow as the margin of defeat, but to sudden giggles of liberation, too. His wife, Victoria, is weaning him from all-news, all-adrenaline radio station cycles by finding wispy Kenny G reed music that became popular sometime in the last 10 years and three months of Mr. Jones's spin-doctoring ministrations around City Hall.
"In his first year, Giuliani will have the same problem that Koch and Dinkins had: finding the right character to play," predicted Mr. Jones, who worked for the two previous mayors.
A likely standout among the new City Hall faces may be that of Lincoln, a mongrel dog adopted by Cristyne Lategano, Mr. Giuliani's press secretary. "He was going to be put to sleep," she said, guessing City Hall is a preferable fate. She hopes to bring the black-and-white, mixed breed, "decidedly Fusion" mutt to work with her in the Rudester's press office, as a kind of wet-nosed relief from the press corps, packed together kennel-like down the hall.
Long gone from the building is City Council President Andrew J. Stein, a drop-out early in the mayoral sweepstakes who left politics. "I'm calling from Malibu, from my friend Shirley MacLaine's house," Mr. Stein announced brightly in responding to a query left at his northeast corner office, the most splendid in the building. It is being redone by carpenters for use as a reception room to resonate with the countless "nice-to-see-you's" to come. His old job title is being eliminated under a charter change, but Mr. Stein hardly sounded in a California sulk.
"So much of politics is defensive, worrying about all those groups you have to please," said Mr. Stein, exhausted from 24 years of trying to please more of those groups than his rivals did. "So far I'm not missing any of it."
Still, a visitor to his old office had to note a packing box topped off with a supply of white yarmulkes, de rigueur campaigner's raiment in this city. But Mr. Stein said he was done, evermore, except for some state study commission hearings on juvenile crime. "A favor for the Governor," he said. "We open in New York on the 11th."
In the dying administration, the more dedicated have been treasuring their incumbency the way Walt Whitman once savored his pristine ferry ride to the City Hall shore: "I stood, yet was hurried."
 
'I'm Unemployed'
 Going through her office stuff, Finance Commissioner Carol O'Cleire acain paused even at a long-lost lipstick. "I'm unemployed. I'm going home," she said almost bereftly, "to the Upper West Side."
Deputy Mayor Barbara Fife, an indispensable aide to Mr. Dinkins for a decade, a workaholic to the end, worried about an unfinished agenda stretching from the new city watershed plan upstate to the protection of the African burial ground just outside, by the Tweed Courthouse.
"Issues you put so much into," she said. "It could take six months for the new guys to get back to speed."
Ms. Fife was packing up her office things, including a collection of coffee mugs, and driving some uptown each night while sampling the early nostalgia. "A lot of sadness at first, because it's like breaking up a family," she said. "I will miss the excitement of addressing a problem and working it through, and the collegiality of the talented people here."
What's not to miss at City Hall? "All that take-out food," she said. "And the memos reminding me I failed to answer the previous memo."
The victors are getting their ducks in a row, none more so than former-former Commissioner Henry J. Stern, who is returning to run the Parks Department and was busy retrieving from city storage the dozens of duck decoys and models that previously adorned his office.
"Out-again, in-again is the best political cycle," attested Mr. Stern, who is as effusive as Machiavelli on the intricacies of power. In his out years, he counted four distinct ways that friends were loyal or not, from those who treated him as the once and future commissioner -- "like a Romanoff" -- to those who "tried to chase me out of city organizations."
"I've been imagining going back for some time now," Mr. Stern said not so cryptically.
With City Hall's inaugural bunting up and blowing in the icy East River winds all week, the mood in the downtown municipal warrens includes considerable anxiety. Thousands of patronage appointees have no idea whether they might be retained in or near their specialties, as often happens with transitions through serendipity, patron connivance or merit.
"The holiday is murder," explained one veteran hoping to survive. "The hiring will go on into the spring," he added, speaking of doubt as much as hope.
The Mayor-elect's powers to affect individual morale extends to the 215,000 workers on the city payroll, not to mention the 17,254 inmates and criminal detainees tucked about the city prisons. There is heavy holiday labor but no complaint from Martin Preston, a "facilities management" executive from the General Services Department. He has been seeing to the inauguration stage constructed on the steps of City Hall, as well as to the moves of the two mayors among Gracie Mansion and City Hall and their private offices and residences.
"The movers are part of a contract service, kind of like privatization," explained Mr. Preston, no slouch at picking up on the Mayor-elect's favorite motif.
In the cold and snowy blur just outside City Hall, Mr. Dinkins's voice could still be heard yesterday firmly in control, his image playing endlessly on a kiosk TV screen of visitors' information options as he prepared his own exit through the looking glass. "Just touch the choice that interests you," he boomed, making city governance sound no trickier than virtual reality.
