HEADLINE: New Debate on Regional Economics

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
In an era of academic downsizing, small departments are prime targets for university cost cutters. And to administrators at the University of Pennsylvania, the three-decade-old regional science department seems a likely candidate for closing. Only six faculty members and three dozen graduate students are part of the tiny band that studies the economies of cities, states and groups of countries.
The change, said Barbara Beck, a spokeswoman for the university, would be "part of an overall effort to streamline and re-engineer the college." 
 The proposed closing is attracting an unusual flurry of attention within the economics profession, where academics since the birth of modern economics have pretty much ignored anything smaller or larger than a single nation. But as traditional macroeconomic approaches to policy are again found wanting, the study of individual regions -- long a backwater of a profession that worships at the altar of elegant theory -- is attracting more notice.
Regional differences seem more intriguing after a decade in which the Massachusetts miracle was followed by the California catastrophe, and the continents of Africa and South America stagnated while Asia surged.
The paradox is that the Penn department, the flagship in its field, may be closed precisely at a time when regional economics has become a hot topic among mainstream economists.
"All the action in the profession is focused on the regional level," said David Friedman, a consultant in Los Angeles who is analyzing the Southern California economy. "Those with a national perspective really don't have anything new to say."
The interest is not limited to the classroom. Policy makers, including Clinton Administration economists who are fretting over the threat from California's lingering recession to the President's re-election prospects, are suggesting that solving the problems of particular regions may call for more than the simple application of broad-brush macroeconomic policies.
Among the most immediately relevant projects is work by Lawrence H. Katz, an expert on labor markets and chief economist at the Labor Department, and Olivier Blanchard, a macroeconomist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. They have been focusing on how long it takes regions that suffer economic shocks to recover, and how they do it.
The classic view has been that a suffering state's economic health ultimately improves because its wages have fallen relative to those in other areas, stimulating demand for workers and capital and attracting jobs back to the state. But Mr. Katz and Professor Blanchard, who looked at the experience of 50 states over the last 45 years, discovered that depressed states recovered mainly because many of their residents piled their belongings on top of the family car and headed for greener pastures.
One implication is that government could speed the healing process by making it easier for workers to move. That might be accomplished by making pension, health and other benefits more portable.
 
A Treasury of Knowledge
 Indeed, despite the flurry of new interest from mainstream economists, there is no danger that the study of how the economy works in a city or a cluster of countries has displaced the search for elegant theorems on general economic behavior. Rather, policy makers and even some professors are finding that the mundane focus on the dynamics of an area and its interplay with other regions can yield a trove of insights.
One result is that many younger economists, who had thought purely in terms of "the economy" and never cared whether growth was happening in Portland, Ore., or Portland, Me., now agree that the key to understanding everything from economic development to international trade is location, location and location.
Mainstream economists have traditionally ignored regional analysis because it is a messy discipline that borrows from a half-dozen other disciplines. Paul Krugman at M.I.T., who talks about international trade as a subfield of "economic geography," points out that the rise of a region's economy typically involves specific business decisions to put down roots as well as other phenomena, "all of which are hard to model formally even now, in the buttoned-down fashion most economists like."
Despite the difficulties, regional economics is attracting some of the brightest young economists.
Besides Mr. Katz and Professor Blanchard, a group led by Professor Krugman is applying trade theory to patterns of industry location.
 
A Study of Western Europe
 Professor Krugman and Anthony Venables at the London School of Economics recently analyzed the potential impact of economic unification on Western European industries. While the French and Germans have feared that heavy industry would migrate to lower-wage countries like Spain and Portugal, the economists found that different countries would likely specialize more than they do now, with each seeing some industries expand and others shrink.
Closer to home, Gordon Hanson at the University of Texas, writing with Professor Krugman, predicted that freer trade in Mexico under the North American Free Trade Agreement would cause Mexico City, one of the world's most overcrowded cities, to shrink as a manufacturing center. He said factories would start moving toward Mexico's coasts and northern border -- a result that everyone from poverty specialists to environmentalists would welcome.
The recent breakthroughs in regional economics may or may not impress decision makers at the University of Pennsylvania in coming weeks as they weigh the fate of the regional science department, as well as the religious studies and American civilization departments.
While Penn's regional science department has not been setting off many fireworks, its scholars are seen as the keepers of a body of knowledge about specific regions as well as a kit of analytical tools. The department pioneered, among other things, now-classic techniques for analyzing the effects of expanding or cutting military spending.
 
Unique Role
 "The point is there's been no other department like this throughout the world," said Walter Isard, who founded it in the late 1950's when he saw that demand for rigorous regional analysis was mushrooming. He concluded that mainstream departments were getting too theoretical to meet that demand.
Economists outside Penn also argue that a separate department has a unique role to play. Professor Krugman of M.I.T., for example, said the Penn department is a repository of techniques, case studies and data with which most mainstream economists are simply not familiar. Further, he said, mainstream economics departments cannot yet be trusted to hire regional specialists and to train graduate students in the field.
But many others say that whatever its success, regional science should not be a department of its own. Professor Hanson at the University of Texas, who has pursued his research on Mexico within the economics department, argued that academics in regional science could gain from integration into traditional departments.
"The regional science people didn't take advantage of the incredible advances in economic theory in the last 20 years," he said. "The way you get respectability is to become a major field within mainstream economics."

HEADLINE: Dow Creeps Up a Fraction to a New High

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
A late push in the stock market helped the Dow Jones industrial average to edge up to a new closing high yesterday.
The Dow closed at 3,794.33, up 56-hundredths of a point. The gain was even smaller than the fractional gain recorded on Tuesday, yet it brought the index a step closer to 3,800, a psychologically significant level. And while the close marked the third consecutive gain this week, it was off the day's high. At one point, the Dow traded at 3,799.64. 
 Advancing issues outnumbered those that declined, 1,170 to 859, and volume on the New York Stock Exchange, at 269.6 million shares, was greater than the average daily volume for the year. On Tuesday, 203.8 million shares were traded on the Big Board.
 "The market held at this very high level, despite lots of profit-taking by professionals and a rising crescendo of cautionary advisories from the major brokerage firms," Robert H. Stovall, the president of Stovall/ Twenty-First Advisers, said. "The broader market was firm."
The Nasdaq composite index rose 3.92 points, to 768.48, but the Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 0.36 point, to 470.58, its first decline in five sessions. The Dow transportation index, which reached a record on Tuesday, dropped 4.29 points, to 1771.32.
Stocks also advanced in Europe, where the London and Paris markets set new closing highs. But the Frankfurt market continued to fall from a high reached on Monday.
Many American investors reacted positively yesterday to a report from the Commerce Department that showed its index of leading indicators rose five-tenths of a percent in November, the fourth consecutive gain. In another report, the National Association of Realtors said sales of existing homes increased 2.9 percent in November, which was better than expected.
With analysts seeing a reviving real estate market and fresh signs of economic growth, hotel stocks were particularly strong. Hilton Hotels rose 1 3/4, to 59 3/8, and Hospitality Franchise Systems gained 2 1/4, to 52 1/2.
Other stocks benefited from recommendations by brokerage firms, including Kennametal, which increased 2 1/4, to 44, and Maxus Energy, which gained 5/8, to 5 5/8.
Sears, Roebuck announced that it planned to open a group of specialty furniture stores, and its shares rose 1 3/4, to 53 5/8.
American depository receipts of Telefonos de Mexico, whose earnings are expected to be sharply higher in 1994, jumped 1 7/8, to 67.
Two big airline stocks slumped as a result of lowered ratings from brokerage firms, hurting the Dow transportation index. UAL, which owns United Airlines, slid 2 1/8, to 146, and Delta Air Lines fell 1, to 54 5/8. Kmart fell 3/8, to 21 3/8, after it received a lower rating.
General Motors closed at 56, down 3/4, but it also achieved an all-time high in intra-day trading, when adjusted for stock splits, of 57 1/8. The previous high was set in October 1965.
Some closed-end country funds, especially those investing in emerging markets, retreated from recent advances. The Chile Fund was down 2 1/2, to 43 7/8, the Korea Fund was down 3 1/4, to 22 5/8, and the India Growth Fund was down 1 3/4, to 28 1/8.
Advanced Marketing Services, a book distributor, declined 1 1/4, to 4 3/4, after it announced that it expected lower third-quarter earnings. And Emulex, a computer hardware company, fell 3/8, to 5 7/8, after it said that it expected a loss for the second quarter.
The most active stock on the Big Board was the SCE Corporation, the holding company of the Southern California Edison utility, which fell 1/2, to 21. A huge amount of shares, 28.9 million, changed hands as a result of dividend activity.

HEADLINE: Poland Becomes a Major Conduit for Drug Traffic

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, Dec. 29

 BODY:
When four containers of fish from Nigeria arrived at the airport recently, customs officers were suspicious about the unusual cargo. Fish from Nigeria? So they searched, and they discovered, packed with the 120 pounds of carp, half a ton of marijuana worth about $2 million on the street.
A few weeks before, Polish officials on the border with Belarus seized 4.5 tons of hashish that had been secreted in a shipment of fermented raisins from Afghanistan. And earlier this year, the Costa Rican Ambassador to Poland was arrested at the Warsaw airport with nearly 25 pounds of pure heroin in his luggage, with a street value of $900,000, while another drug bust netted 220 pounds of cocaine from South America, with a value of about $7.5 million. 
 These drug seizures reflect a sharp increase in narcotics entering Poland. Some of it is for a growing domestic market, but most of the drugs are en route to Western Europe and even the United States, where Federal law enforcement officials have expressed alarm about heroin being smuggled into the country from Poland. The volume is expected to increase.
 
Trafficking Throughout Region
 And while law enforcement officials in Eastern Europe say Poland has become the biggest transshipment point, drug trafficking has also increased sharply throughout the region, in the Czech Republic, Hungary, Bulgaria and Romania, as well as in Russia.
In February, a staggering 1.2 tons of cocaine was seized in St. Petersburg, in a container of canned meat that had been sent by ship from Colombia. Russian officials believe that the cocaine was to be divided into smaller parcels and then smuggled into various Western Europe cities, where the street value would have been in excess of $75 million.
Increasingly, organized criminal elements from Russia and other former Soviet republics, where law and order has almost completely broken down, are operating in Eastern Europe. This new mafia is not only moving into other traditional organized crime fields, like prostitution, but into arms smuggling as well, often financing the purchase of weapons with their enormous drug profits, law enforcement officials say.
"It is an explosion," said Maciej Lubik, a senior Polish customs official and director of the Eastern European office of the Customs Cooperation Council, an international organization, about the growth of the drug traffic in the region.
 
Americans 'Alarmed'
 "The Americans are very, very alarmed," he said, adding that he had been working closely with officials from the United States Customs Service and the Drug Enforcement Administration.
No one knows for sure the total volume of drugs now moving through Eastern Europe -- the countries have only recently begun keeping records of seizures, and they are spotty at best -- but Mr. Lubik said that at most only 5 percent of the drugs moving through Eastern Europe were being seized.
He estimated that at least 25 percent of the heroin being consumed in Western Europe was now passing through Eastern Europe, and he said that of the 30 tons of hashish seized in all of Europe this year, half had been found in Poland and Bulgaria.
At the moment, most of the drugs passing through Eastern Europe appear to be destined for users in Western Europe, but the United States is alert to the possibility that the drug traffickers will "exploit opportunities in the United States," Stephen Greene, acting administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration, said in a telephone interview from Washington.
Washington is particularly concerned by the activity of the Nigerians in Eastern Europe, he said. "They are some of the most experienced heroin traffickers in the world," he said.
Mr. Green added that his agency had gathered intelligence that organized criminal groups from the former Soviet Union were using confederates in New York and Atlanta to smuggle drugs into the United States.
 
Collapse of Controls
 Drug syndicates are turning to Eastern Europe in the aftermath of the collapse of the Soviet Union, which has brought an end to rigid border controls, and in the wake of the war in Yugoslavia, which has led to a disruption of traditional drug routes. And the former Communist countries, confronted by a problem they did not face until recently, are woefully unprepared, handicapped by inadequate laws, a lack of experience and paltry resources.
For the drug dealer, once he has contraband in an Eastern Europe country, he finds it easier to move it West. This is because a person landing in New York or Amsterdam or London from Prague or Warsaw is not as likely to arouse suspicion as a person arriving from Bogota, Istanbul or Lagos.
This month, the German authorities seized 638 pounds of heroin entering the country from the Czech Republic in a shipment of Turkish nuts. Worth an estimated $18 million on the street, it was the largest heroin seizure ever in Germany, officials said. It was 200 pounds more than was seized in the record heroin seizure in New York in December.
In October, at the Black Sea port of Constantin, Romanian customs officials seized 9,196 pounds of hashish, worth just over $20 million on the street in Western Europe, packed in tea shipped from Kenya on a Uganda-registered ship. Three days later, they found 13,838 pounds of hashish, worth about $31 million, on another Ugandan freighter, this time secreted among textiles.
 
A Number of Routes
 The illegal narcotics are entering along a number of routes.
From Afghanistan, Pakistan, Thailand and Burma comes heroin, following through Romania, Bulgaria, Hungary and the Czech Republic and into Western Europe. Previously, the major heroin route was through Yugoslavia.
Also from the fields of Central Asia come hashish and marijuana, which move by truck through Russia, the Caucusus and Ukraine and into Poland before reaching the ultimate markets. A third route is from Africa, primarily Nigeria, by air and sea.
Even cocaine from Latin America is showing up in Eastern Europe. "The Colombian cartels are beginning to forge links with local traffickers," said Rensselaer W. Lee 3d, an American who has been studying the drug trade for a decade and has turned his attention in recent years to Eastern Europe.
In April the Polish authorities seized 220 pounds of cocaine, with a street value of $7.5 million, in the port city of Szczecin. The ship had come from Latin America, and one of the men arrested with the cocaine had links to the Medellin cartel and had previously smuggled drugs from the Netherlands to England, Polish officials said in recent interviews.
 
Back to United States
 Officials here are beginning to investigate whether some of the cocaine entering Poland from Latin America is being routed to the United States. They also say they believe that the heroin they seized from the Costa Rican Ambassador, Carlos Vargas Solis, was destined for the United States. Mr. Vargas, who is no longer ambassador and has maintained that he is innocent, could not be reached for comment; the Polish police and the Costa Rican Embassy declined to say where he was.
But until now most of the drugs coming into Eastern Europe have been destined for Western Europe.
"There is no immediate threat to the U.S. yet, but I would underscore 'yet,' " Mr. Lee said. "It is only a matter of time."
Eastern European laws make it difficult to keep drugs from entering and leaving the countries. In Poland, for instance, possession of drugs for personal use is not a crime. "It is a progressive law, one of the most humanitarian in the world," said Andrzej Koweszko, a senior officer in the Interpol office in Warsaw. But he added, "It was written by doctors, by sociologists, by everyone but police officers."
 
Little Risk of Capture
 Although smuggling and sale of narcotics are illegal, unless someone is extremely careless, there is little risk of being caught. This is because undercover and sting operations are prohibited by law in Poland, as they are in the Czech Republic and Bulgaria. Nor in these countries is it possible to have a "controlled delivery" -- that is to follow the drug courier to find the person to whom he is delivering the drugs.
These laws are left over from the Communist era, but in that time the police had whatever power they wanted, and drug users and traders were often charged with "crimes against the state" and were severely punished.
In Poland and the Czech Republic, efforts are under way to change these laws, but police officials in these countries said they did not expect their Parliaments to act swiftly.
 
More Resources Needed
 Even with new laws, without vastly more resources, Eastern European governments will have little chance against the drug trade, which is in the hands of organized criminal syndicates. An increasing number of criminal syndicates are run by Russians or others from the former Soviet Union; these groups have long tentacles and ruthless methods of operation.
In many of the countries of Eastern Europe there is a lack of resources and training. Trying to help remedy this problem, the Germans and the United States Drug Enforcement Administration have started conducting classes for law enforcement officials in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union in how to detect drugs and arrest smugglers.
"We are complete newcomers, greenhorns," Mr. Lubik, the senior Polish customs officer, said. "It's very easy to cross the border with the knowledge that the customs officer is overworked, that his knowledge about drugs is almost nonexistent, that he has no means of communications. Try to call right now to the border -- sometimes it takes two days."
Drug traders are almost arrogant in their attitude toward the Polish authorities, he said. What else could explain that someone would try to bring a half ton of marijuana into the country packed in fish, he asked.

HEADLINE: J. Wayne Reitz, 84; Headed U. of Florida

BYLINE: New York Times Regional Newspapers

DATELINE: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Dec. 29

 BODY:
J. Wayne Reitz, a former president of the University of Florida, died on Friday at Shands Hospital here. He was 84 and lived in Gainesville.
The cause was respiratory failure after a gall bladder infection, his family said. 
 Dr. Reitz was the fifth president of the university, and the student union building bears his name. For the past 20 years, he worked at the University of Florida Foundation to raise money for the university.
He was born in Olathe, Kan., in 1908 and earned degrees from Colorado State University, the University of Illinois and the University of Wisconsin.
Trained as an agricultural economist, he taught at Colorado State, Illinois and Florida before being named president at Florida in 1955. He resigned in 1967.
He paved the way with the Board of Control, the predecessor of the current Board of Regents, for doctorate programs that formed the nucleus for several research programs, one of which was the precursor of the university's medical school.
He also guided the peaceful racial integration of the university in 1958 after a Federal court order.
Dr. Reitz is survived by his wife, the former Frances Huston Millikan; two daughters, Marjorie Turnbull of Tallahassee, Fla., and Margo Cooke of Huntingdon, Tenn.; two sisters, Nadine Beals of San Diego and Flossie Donovan of Gardner, Kan., and three grandsons.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up Solidly in Europe, Breaking Resistance Levels

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose solidly against the German mark and other European currencies yesterday after a burst of dollar-buying in Europe drove the American currency through key levels.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.7274 German marks, up from 1.6990 marks on Tuesday. The British pound, meanwhile, dropped to $1.4775, from $1.5080. 
 The dollar also rose a little against the Japanese yen. In New York, it finished the day at 111.80 yen, up from 111.43 yen on Tuesday.
Gold prices rose in New York after falling overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery, the most active futures contract, gained $3.30, to $391.80 an ounce.
Dealers said the dollar was helped by Government reports showing continued strength in the United States economy. The index of leading economic indicators, the Government's chief forecasting gauge, rose five-tenths of a percent last month, in line with expectations.
Moreover, the National Association of Realtors reported a strong 2.9 percent jump in the sales of previously owned homes.
"There's a lot of reason to be bullish on the dollar," said Dave Glowacki, a senior trader at the National Bank of Detroit. "We are at least moving in the right direction as far as our economy goes."
Another trader, John Duffy of Bank Austria, said traders in London returning from a four-day weekend bought dollars because of strong consumer-confidence figures released on Tuesday.
"The Europeans paid a lot more attention to that number than the Americans did," he said.
There were also rumors of a large speculative buyer in Europe, whose dollar purchases may have been enough to spur the dollar gains in light trading before the New Year.
The buying drove the dollar through significant technical levels, which prompted traders to purchase still more dollars.
"I think today showed a fundamental demand for dollars" in the early part of 1994, said Margaret Kudarauskas, senior foreign exchange analyst at Technical Data, a Boston analysis firm.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
In an age of retailing overkill, new products are fewer and more focused on finding customers.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
OUT with the old, in with the new! That cry will be heard often in the next couple of days. Consumer product marketers, though, have been shouting it at shoppers and retailers almost since the moment World War II ended.
New products have helped to fuel the growth of the mighty American consumer economy since 1946, when Tide detergent, "the washday miracle," revolutionized clothing care by supplanting soap flakes. And as recently as this week, Alpo Petfoods announced that it would introduce -- no kidding -- Alpo Beef Chip Cookies, a crunchy dog treat that is baked, shaped and bagged to resemble chocolate chip cookies. (Anthropomorphism has its limits, however; there's no chocolate.) 
 Yet in recent years, shoppers and store managers have cooled considerably to any product bearing the word "New!" inside a starburst. There is no such word as overchoiced, but perhaps there ought to be, for there is a widespread belief among consumers pressed for money and time, as well as among retailers overwhelmed by overcrowded shelves, that products are proliferated beyond necessity, practicality and, perhaps, rationality.
New Product News, in its January issue to be distributed beginning next week, will report that the number of new products in 1993 climbed only modestly for the second consecutive year. Marketers have introduced 17,571 products this year, the publication found, up 4.6 percent from the 16,790 introduced in 1992; that year's increase was just 4 percent from 1991. By contrast, the average annual growth rate in the last decade, according to New Product News, was 14.4 percent.
"Retailers are starting to eliminate what they see as wasteful duplication," said David Olson, vice president and group research director at the Leo Burnett Company who heads the agency's New Products Planning Group. For instance, he noted a decision by Cub Foods Stores, a Midwestern supermarket chain, to "limit the number of products in the cereal aisle."
As a result of such reactions, he added in an interview from Chicago, marketers and their agencies must focus on new products that "have the potential to fundamentally contribute to grow net incremental sales."
"There'll still be a very important role for new products," he continued, "but companies should take a hard look at their new-product activity and redefine what the purpose of that activity is."
Burnett's new products group, which has been involved in 120 new-product test markets in the last 10 years, recommends that marketers concentrate on introductions offering what Mr. Olson called "customer-creating potential."
"The issue of new products that don't create customers for the manufacturer or the retailer is probably the No. 1 area of friction between them," Mr. Olson, a Burnett employee for 21 years, said. "So the concept of creating customers will really resonate with retailers."
The group recommends that retailers "work more with manufacturers to evaluate the potential of new products," he added, "by using individual stores as testing labs and using scanner data to measure the incremental sales of the new products."
In a 30-page report on new products, the group gives examples of those that have successfully demonstrated their customer-creating potential. One is Quaker Chewy Granola Dipps, a chewy, chocolate-covered granola bar that has "expanded the category" and simultaneously enabled Quaker to garner "a large share" of it, the report said. Another is Stainmaster, Du Pont's stain-fighting carpet fiber, which, the report said, consumers "have begun to ask for as if it were a particular brand of carpet."
The report also provides 15 "principles of successful new product marketing," which mix common-sense observations with some unconventional thinking.
"Capitalize on core corporate competencies" is one important principle, urging marketers to base new products on qualities they have already proved they can deliver. Hypothetically, then, the maker of Crunchy Nuggets cereal, beloved by America because it doesn't get soggy in milk, would have the credibility to introduce a similarly sog-fighting brand called Crunchy Flakes.
If the new-product process has become so vexacious, why, then, continue to introduce new brands?
"Over the long haul, new products are incredibly important to us as an agency," Mr. Olson explained. "Fifty-five percent of our current billings are from products we've helped clients launch in the marketplace."
So, happy new products!

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Rebounds as Investors Cover Their Short Positions

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Oil prices surged yesterday in a short-covering rally ahead of an anticipated weekly report on domestic inventories and the expiration of some energy contracts at the New York Mercantile Exchange.
 Crude oil for February delivery jumped 33 cents to $14.44 a barrel after dipping below $14 on Tuesday. Yesterday's move erased most of Monday's 35-cent drop. 
 January heating oil also rose sharply amid forecasts for continued cold weather this week in the Northeast. The January contract gained 1.21 cents to 44.82 cents a gallon. January unleaded gasoline rose 1.04 cents to 39.18 cents a gallon.
 The natural gas for January eased 2.1 cents to $2.054 per 1,000 cubic feet. Traders said there was too much competition from cheap heating oil to let gas prices rise too far.
 Many traders scrambled to rid themselves of short positions ahead of a possible market-moving report from the American Petroleum Institute and today's expiration of January energy contracts.
 After the close, the A.P.I. reported that crude stocks rose 1.6 million barrels, distillate fuel supplies swelled by 813,000 barrels and gasoline stocks fell 592,000 barrels.
 "I think what we're seeing is a short covering rally spurred by the product expiration," said Gerald Samuels of ARB Oil in Los Angeles.
The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities also soared to a three-year high, spurred by higher oil prices and slightly stronger precious metal prices.
 The index, a closely watched inflation barometer, gained 1.18 points to 226.56 points.
 "The C.R.B. index is on a definitive bull run," said Mark Chandgie of Lafayette Commodities. "After years of depressed prices, several commodity markets appear to have made the necessary supply adjustments to drive higher."
 On other commodity markets, wheat prices rose on talk of fresh export demand.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Russia's political turmoil follows half steps, not shock therapy.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
STARTLING events have a way of focusing the attention of an otherwise distracted body politic. And few events in recent months have been as startling as the rise of Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, Russia's 1930's-style bully boy with a 1990's flair for television.
Mr. Zhirinovsky's success at the polls, Vice President Al Gore says, shows that economic reformers have asked excessive sacrifice from the already-humbled Russian masses. Or, as Strobe Talbott, Ambassador at Large to the former Soviet republics and the nominee for Deputy Secretary of State, put it, reform has consisted of "too much shock and too little therapy." 
 That idea plays well in both Washington and Moscow. No wonder: It places the blame on the shoulders of ivory-tower theorists and callous technocrats rather than the people nominally in charge. The trouble is, says Stanley Fischer of M.I.T., who served as chief economist of the World Bank, it doesn't square with the facts. "There just hasn't been much shock," he said.
Jeffrey D. Sachs, the Harvard University economist who advises the radical reformers in President Boris N. Yeltsin's Cabinet, is less diplomatic. The notion that shock therapy has been tried and failed "is preposterous and false," he insists.
 Economic shock therapy has become the treatment of choice for those who believe that rapid change is often less wasteful, less vulnerable to sabotage, and therefore more likely to succeed, than gradual change. The evidence amassed in the shock therapists' favor ranges from the overnight end to hyperinflation in post-World War I Germany to the mass privatization of industry in the Czech Republic over the last year.
Shock therapy came into intellectual vogue in the last days of the Soviet Union, when Mikhail Gorbachev's economists proposed a great lunge toward capitalism, ballasted by weighty sums of Western aid. But a true "grand bargain" -- Western gigabucks in return for a commitment to free up prices, discipline the budget, contain credit and encourage private enterprise -- came only with the rise of Mr. Yeltsin.
The Yeltsin Government eliminated most price regulation and then made a run at bringing down inflation in early 1992 by trimming the subsidies and central bank loans that allowed big industries (particularly those related to the military) to stay in business. But the Communist-dominated Parliament balked, and friends in the Cabinet of the entrenched state enterprises, notably Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin and Viktor V. Gerashchenko, the head of the central bank, undercut the reformers' ambitious plans.
The only changes of enduring consequence, Mr. Fischer notes, were the initial price liberalization and the ambitious start to privatization. But by the same token, very little of the ballyhooed Western aid arrived: Mr. Sachs estimates that less than 20 cents on the dollar of the package promised at this year's economic summit meeting in Tokyo has made it through the bureaucratic sieve.
The fact that neither side delivered does not, in itself, answer the question of the hour: did even a little shock therapy prove too much?
Allowing the prices of staples to rise to free-market levels led to a one-time cut in living standards, Mr. Fischer acknowledges. But the continuing pain for ordinary people, he says, the destruction of private savings and the bewildering scramble for personal security in the teeth of "one of the great income redistributions in history," have largely been results of the failure to stop inflation.
Even those who favor a gradual approach agree that the Clinton Administration has muddled the story: "Shock therapy was only applied for four months," says Padma Desai, an economist at the Harriman Institute of Columbia University.
Most frustrating to the shock therapists is what they see as the nonstrategy behind the White House's response to the Zhirinovsky "wake-up call." Settling for less shock doesn't translate into a policy, Mr. Sachs argues. "You just can't fine-tune hyperinflation," he said.
If some good is to come from the Clinton Administration's belated discovery that a failed Russia may still prove a malevolent force, Mr. Sachs suggests, time is of the essence. At the top of his to-do list is a recommitment to past agreements, with the Yeltsin Government hunkering down on inflation in return for sufficient help from the outside to finance a social safety net for pensioners and the unemployed, convert salvageable military industries and provide the start-up capital for thousands of new businesses.
Mr. Fischer adds that such a deal must be hammered out and overseen at the very top, rather than handed over to the international lending agencies and Kremlin subministries. "Going through the midlevel bureaucrats at International Monetary Fund just won't work," he says.
White House spin control is an understandable, maybe necessary, first response to the elevation of a demagogue who seems to have drawn all the wrong conclusions from the Soviet empire's collapse. But some way, somehow, the West is going to have to lengthen its attention span. To get the job done, the civilizing of the former Soviet Union must remain Priority 1 for the next decade, not just the next month.

HEADLINE: Woman Is Charged With Killing Her Lover After Bailing Him Out

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 29

 BODY:
A Medford, N.J., woman has been charged in her lover's slaying shortly after she paid the money for his bail, the police said.
The slain man, William Kelly, 31, of Philadelphia, had been in jail since Dec. 19 on aggravated assault charges, accused of dragging the woman, Margaret Kosmin, 32, by the hair and beating her with a club at a train station in Cherry Hill, N.J. 
 Ms. Kosmin had no choice, said the couple's 15-year-old daughter, Michelle. Her father abused her mother when he became drunk, and had been doing it since the couple were teen-agers, their daughter said.
"My Mom was totally right to do this," Michelle Kosmin was quoted as saying in The Philadelphia Daily News. "If my father hadn't been killed, he would have killed her."
 
Prosecutor Relates Scheme
 Mr. Kelly stayed in jail in Camden until Ms. Kosmin raised enough cash to post his bail, the Camden County Prosecutor, Edward F. Borden Jr., said today. Early Monday a friend of Ms. Kosmin, Tammy Ann Molewicz, 25, also of Medford, posted the $1,000 cash and picked Mr. Kelly up in her red Corvette, Mr. Borden said.
The three drove to Medford, where they stopped at a convenience store to buy food for Mr. Kelly, Mr. Borden said. When Mr. Kelly and Ms. Kosmin returned, the prosecutor said, Ms. Kosmin walked up to the open car window and shot him.
"It was a premeditated, planned and carefully executed murder," Mr. Borden said. "She wanted to get back at him for his beatings and then see that he didn't do it again. She had had enough."
Ms. Kosmin and Ms. Molewicz were arrested on Tuesday and charged with first-degree murder. They are being held on $200,000 cash bail each.
 
Unfair, Women's Group Says
 The body, with two bullet wounds in the head, was found by hunters later on Monday in Wharton State Forest in Waterford Township, face down in a cranberry bog; his head was covered with a pillowcase, the prosecutor said. The body was wrapped in a sheet and twine was tied around the neck, legs and hands. Authorities also found a .32-caliber revolver at the scene, he said.
The murder charge was assailed as inappropriate by Sandy Clark, assistant director of the New Jersey Coalition for Battered Women. Ms. Kosmin may have feared an imminent threat even though Mr. Kelly was in jail, she said.
Michelle Kosmin, their daughter, said her mother had tried to avoid Mr. Kelly for 15 years, fearing violence from her childhood sweetheart.
"We'd move and move, every year practically," the couple's only child recalled. But two months ago they tried to reunite, and Mr. Kelly, who was unemployed, moved into their two-bedroom home in Medford.
 
Police Often at House
 The violence began almost immediately. Neighbors said police cars were frequently sent to the house.
Authorities said Mr. Kelly beat Ms. Kosmin on Nov. 24, breaking her nose. The police arrested Mr. Kelly and Ms. Kosmin immediately obtained a restraining order.
"Her nose was all taped; she was bruised," said a neighbor, Donna Woodhull. "She definitely had been beaten up."
That time Mr. Kelly was released from jail; he returned the same night and was rearrested, authorities said. He was released on bail and less than a week later Ms. Kosmin dropped the domestic violence complaint.
But the couple argued again on Dec. 19 at the train station. Mr. Kelly was arrested and jailed after failing to post $1,000 bail.
 
'Obviously Wasn't Herself'
 When Ms. Kosmin returned to her job as a hairdresser after the attack, "she obviously wasn't herself," said the salon owner, Marco Bonelli. No one knew about the abuse she suffered, he said.
"Her personal life was her personal life," Mr. Bonelli said. "We really didn't know much about her situation."
Ms. Clark of the Coalition for Battered Women said today: "We have dead battered woman after dead battered woman. Sometimes it doesn't matter what she does."
But Mr. Borden said Mr. Kelly had not posed a danger to Ms. Kosmin.
"The bail set was adequate to keep him in jail for a period of time and keep him away from her," Mr. Borden said. "She was being protected by the system."

HEADLINE: Talk of Shifting Arts Money Is Met With Anger

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN

 BODY:
Plans by the Giuliani administration to increase financial support for New York City's premier arts institutions, possibly at the expense of less renowned ones, was met with anger and trepidation yesterday by members of the arts community and politicians who have wrestled with apportioning ever-shrinking arts dollars.
Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan called such plans "misguided and unfortunate." Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and the chairman of the Council Finance Committee, Herbert E. Berman, Democrat of Brooklyn, said they would protect money for cultural institutions against any "ill-informed and insensitive actions by the new administration." 
 Mr. Vallone said Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani's new cabinet members "have a lot to learn" about making public their policy proposals before they have been fully developed.
Arts groups throughout the city said some of them might not survive if their subsidy from the city's Department of Cultural Affairs is cut.
"If you cut D.C.A. funding for Thalia Spanish Theater and other program groups like us, you will kill us, plain and simple," said Kathryn Giaimo, administrative director for the dance group in Queens.
The reactions followed comments Tuesday by John S. Dyson, Mr. Giuliani's deputy mayor for economic development and finance, that some arts institutions in the city might be receiving municipal money because of "clubhouse-type politics." He said the new administration would review support levels for the 431 groups now sharing $87.3 million in municipal assistance, to see how the city could funnel more of the money to the highest-quality institutions, like the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which he said contributed more to the city's economic development by attracting tourists to the city.
He said no decisions had been made about the level of financing for any group, especially as Mr. Giuliani has yet to name a new Cultural Affairs Commissioner.
But his comments were interpreted as elitist by the directors of some small arts groups, who said it was strange, coming from an administration that had campaigned on improving the quality of neighborhood life.
Concerned about the tone of outrage at his statements, Mr. Dyson called Mr. Vallone himself to discuss the administration's policies on money for the arts. He said that in the end they agreed to work together to increase financing for the arts, and to discuss cuts to any particular program before they are made.
The size or the fame of each institution, he said, would not be the main guideline in determining its merit.
"For them to only honor the elitist institutions, it just doesn't make sense," said Sylvia Herskowitz, director of the Yeshiva University Museum in Washington Heights. "Everyone is going to give money to the big museums. It's the small ones that need this money. There isn't a big museum in Washington Heights. Does that mean that Washington Heights will just be left to wither away?"
 
Value of Diversity
 The statements also prompted Ms. Messinger to call a news conference with several smaller arts groups to condemn any plans to favor the pre-eminent institutions at the expense of more obscure ones.
"The arts industry in the City of New York is strong precisely because it is diverse," she said. "Just as it is smart economic development policy to pay attention to small businesses as well as large ones, precisely the same thing is true of the arts. You have to pay attention to poetry reading groups and small dance performance studios in Brooklyn."
Others said that despite Mr. Dyson's assurances that he would not favor Manhattan, his emphasis on institutions that are a tourist draw would end up penalizing the other boroughs.
"I want to point out in my 17 or 18 years as Borough President the problems we had," Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn said. "One incoming commissioner who paid a visit to my office had the audacity to ask, 'Why do we need the Brooklyn Museum? We have museums in Manhattan.' I found that to be so aggravating, I can't describe it. I tried to explain and will to Dyson also, there is no such thing as the best cultural institution. They are all great. They are all necessary."
 
A Divisive Move
 Mr. Vallone and Mr. Berman said Mr. Dyson was trying to pit arts groups against one another.
"The Council has worked very hard over the last four years to encourage all the city's cultural groups to lobby as one voice," they said.
Mr. Dyson said yesterday: "The No. 1 focus is economic: how do we get New Yorkers employed? The focus is what do each of these institutions that are getting money do. We will look at each institution through the lens of economic development and ask ourselves what does this particular program do to increase the number of jobs in the city of New York."
Mr. Vallone said later that Mr. Giuliani could have avoided the uproar in the arts community if the new policy had been better thought out.
"I just think they have a lot to learn," Mr. Vallone said. "I'm trying not to be too critical, but we've gone through these mistakes before."
"You've got to be very careful with what you say," he said. "The last thing we need now is for the cultural institutions to think we're going to abandon them."

HEADLINE: The Carpet Man Fulfills a Promise;
With Guns-for-Toys Program, Fernando Mateo Succeeds at Last

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
The toys-for-gun man, so deluged by claims on his time, was hardly able to ponder wall-to-walls or cut-piles, though it was his success in floor coverings that made his goodness possible.
"I'm going crazy, but it's a good kind of crazy," he said, settled behind his carpet store desk, which was strewn with phone messages. The phone and his beeper trilled simultaneously. He scooped up the phone. 
 "Hi, yeah, it's Fernando," he said to a toy executive. "I'm tired. This is for a good cause and I'm going to continue. But, I tell you, I better start selling some carpet or the banks are going to call my mortgages."
Fernando Mateo, the 35-year-old carpet man, said he had no idea that his notion last week to trade toy store certificates for guns in perilous Washington Heights would achieve such wondrous success that people throughout the world would start dialing him up. "I haven't eaten in three days," he said the other afternoon, insisting on breaking for some Chinese food. "I get home at night and have stomach cramps. I've even gotten calls from London, Australia, France. They want to know how to start programs."
He gulped some rice. The Larry King show called. Some shrimp. The mother of a slain police officer. Broccoli. The Chase Manhattan Bank.
"I need help for the program," he implored the bank. "If you guys can give me $10,000, $20,000, $30,000, I'll get you all the media you want."
Mr. Mateo is short, lithe, kinetic. He has an obdurate belief in himself and a ravening appetite for work. His carpet business, though, has endured plenty of tumult. The rush of publicity, he said, has made many people think he is some millionaire carpet king. He only wishes. In fact, the $5,000 he contributed to inaugurate the toys-for-gun program was charged, he said, on his MasterCard. "And I was already pretty close to my limit," he said.
 
Wall-to-Wall Trouble
 His own life, he said, has been mostly devoid of guns and violence -- he was fairly straight arrow as a teen-ager, though he bought a gun himself when he turned 21 -- but it was always a teasing struggle.
Like many of the residents of Washington Heights, he is Dominican. He was born in Santo Domingo. His father, a struggling owner of taxi cabs, had some 25 children out of wedlock and another 10 with Mr. Mateo's mother, he said. When Mr. Mateo was two-and-a-half, the family gravitated to New York and established a home on the Lower East Side. His father dabbled at this and that -- he owned a bodega, had a linoleum business, imported fruits and vegetables -- and money was tight.
After attending parochial schools, Mr. Mateo entered Seward Park High School. "I was scared," he said. "I was a hick. I dressed wrong. I wasn't hip, and I was laughed at." To gain acceptance with classmates, he experimented with drugs. To break free of this cycle, he dropped out. His father didn't speak to him for three months. "I was supposed to be the doctor or lawyer in the family," he said. "I was the one who was supposed to make the family the proudest."
He was 15 and he wanted to lay floors. He trained with two brothers who had their own linoleum businesses, then switched to a more seasoned carpet company. "One day we were cutting white carpet and I stepped on the carpet and the owner went berserk and chewed me out in front of everyone," he said. "I quit. I got a job at another carpet company and got married, and when I returned from my honeymoon the owner said he couldn't afford me. I decided then that I would never work for anyone else again."
With a $2,000 loan from his father, he rented a storefront on Avenue A, and Carpet Fashions was born. It was 1976, the Bicentennial year, and he decorated the window with a big American flag made out of carpet.
 
Pleading for Solvency
 Business was tepid at first, he said. He transported carpet roped to the roof of a crumpled 1969 Chevrolet, and one accident resulted in the car's trunk being shoved into the back seat.
His first big job was at a six-story tenement -- to carpet all the stairways -- a $2,000 order. The customer wouldn't pay him, and Carpet Fashions almost folded, he said. Mr. Mateo called on a carpet distributor and sank to his knees. "I begged him for a credit line," he said. "He told me to get off the floor. He said, 'Kid, you're going to make it. I'm going to give you a $1,000 credit line.' "
He learned, and business came. He opened a showroom on Fourth Avenue and 12th Street. He was basically breaking even, but he envisioned becoming the largest carpet retailer in New York and then a chain with outlets in every major city.
That was when he got sidetracked. There is a Dominican tradition known as "la promesa," in which, in return for an answered prayer, a person makes a sacrifice: not wear shoes for a week, skip lipstick for a year. In 1977, Mr. Mateo had prayed for health and success, and if it came he promised to give back to the community.
 
Trouble in Midtown
 In 1989, he felt it was time to deliver. He and his second wife, Stella, had moved to a nice house in Westchester. It was virtually bare, but he told Stella that furniture must wait, he said. It was "la promesa" time.
He contributed $2,000 and countless hours to start a program on Rikers Island to teach nonviolent first offenders to become carpet layers, plumbers, electricians. This became the Mateo Institute of Training.
"I was spending two, three days a week at Rikers and I neglected the business," he said. The recession blew in. Another unanticipated blow struck: the publicity about the Rikers program soured clients, he said, with some telling him they wouldn't buy carpet from him and have convicts come to their homes to put it down.
In 1990, by which time Mr. Mateo had opened a glassy showroom on East 54th Street across from Citicorp Center, Carpet Fashions had lost $17,000 and sank more than $500,000 into debt, he said. Even his accountant thought he was going bust.
To help out, his wife returned to work running a real-estate office in the Bronx. And Mr. Mateo shifted his emphasis from residential customers to big commercial work. He courted construction contractors and jobs came. Mr. Mateo said that Carpet Fashions hung on in 1991 and 1992, and has turned a decent profit this year on sales of about $6 million. He said he laid all the carpet at Madison Square Garden for the Democratic Convention and installed 60,000 yards of carpet for the new headquarters of Price Waterhouse.
"Freddy's always had that dream to make it," said Sgt. Richard Pacheco, an officer in the 19th Precinct who grew up on the Lower East Side with Mr. Mateo. "When he dropped out of school, I thought he was going to be sucked up like everyone else, but he always had this determination and this positive outlook. And he's always been one of these give-the-shirt-off-my-back type of guys."
Of late, Mr. Mateo said that he makes a solid middle-class income, but has no savings account and two mortgages on his home.
He says it annoys him that few have stepped forward to create jobs for the graduates of his Rikers program. After four years, only 18 have emerged from the program. If support doesn't come, he said he may have to abandon it.
 
An Idea Becomes Reality
 The gun idea originated while Mr. Mateo was watching the Giants-Saints game with his son, 14-year-old Fernando Jr. (he also has two young daughters). At half time, they switched to the news and heard about four people being shot in Washington Heights. His son, repulsed by violence, said he would forgo Christmas presents if he could get just one gun off the streets. That, he said, planted a seed, which became the offer of a $100 gift certificate at Toys 'R Us for any gun that came into the 34th Precinct.
Mr. Mateo makes it clear that he does not wish to disarm all of America. He said the gun he bought when he was 21 was only to protect himself, though he said he never fired it. He would not say whether he has a gun now, yet he thinks it is fine for businessmen and politicians to own guns. But he wants assault weapons and Uzis off the streets and guns out of the hands of the irresponsible.
By now, more than 400 guns have been turned in at the 34th Precinct, with contributions from other companies paying for additional certificates. Mr. Mateo believes at least 60 percent of those who relinquished guns are gang members or drug dealers. A 12-year-old brought in a gun, and so did an elderly man in a wheelchair. People showed up from New Jersey and from Connecticut with their arsenals.
Now the program has been extended at least until Jan. 6, when many Dominicans observe Christmas. Moreover, Mr. Mateo intends to organize a national committee to help other cities start programs. He plans to survey people in Washington Heights to see what they want for their guns. He has gleaned that they prefer starter jackets, expensive sneakers, and airplane tickets.
Ideas spin out of his head. "I would like Mercedes-Benz to give me a vehicle a month so we can raffle it off," he said. "Anyone who turns in a gun will not only get a certificate but a raffle number. We'll talk to G.M., Toyota, all the car companies. I think they'll respond. A weapon off the street is good for everyone. Because you're a chief executive doesn't mean you're bulletproof or your child is bulletproof."
So far, he said, no one has come into Carpet Fashions, inspected the 10,000 samples and said that they so admire his idea that they are going to buy his carpets. "I could use the business," he said. "If I got it, I could do more. But I hope people just view me as being grateful to all New Yorkers who gave me a business opportunity."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I'm going crazy, but it's a good kind of crazy," Fernando Mateo, a 35-year-old carpet merchant, said of the response to his idea last week to offer toy store certificates for guns in Washington Heights. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Haiti: Ready to Explode?

 BODY:
There is no justifying the vicious mob attack that killed two civilian supporters of Haiti's military regime Monday and provoked a retaliatory rampage against slum dwellers presumed to support the exiled President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
But it is not hard to understand why frustrated Aristide supporters may now be turning to violence. Since the September 1991 military coup, most have put their faith in international diplomacy or sought to flee Haiti altogether. 
 But with diplomacy consistently thwarted by military obstructionists, anti-Aristide gangs swaggering triumphantly and a U.S. Coast Guard flotilla blocking all refugee ships, the patience of the poor and desperate may be about to run out.
Let the Clinton Administration heed the warning. Washington, in its efforts to win the Haitian military's consent to a workable compromise, has leaned hard on President Aristide to accept repeated concessions and delays. That is understandable. Short of sending in the marines -- a very bad idea -- give-and-take negotiations are necessary.
But all give by the Aristide side and all take by the military has not produced a solution. What it may produce instead is disastrous social combustion. To lessen that risk, Washington needs to tighten the pressure of sanctions and loosen the safety valve of refugee flight.
That means following through on a French proposal to broaden the U.N. oil embargo to other items if there is no diplomatic breakthrough before the Jan. 15 deadline. And it means listening to the conscientious misgivings of Administration officials and modifying the present policy of turning back all boats carrying fleeing Haitians without listening to claims to legitimate political asylum.
One reason the Pentagon has always been reluctant to send U.S. troops to Haiti is that it fears Americans could get caught in the middle of mob violence. Specifically, it worries that Aristide supporters, emboldened by an international presence, would seek revenge on paramilitary death squads and that the paramilitaries would fight back. Monday's bloodbath demonstrates how realistic those anxieties are.
Washington cannot produce magical solutions to Haiti's crisis. What it can usefully do is crank up the embargo against the generals and crank down the blockade against fleeing refugees. Desperate Haitians need to know they are not forgotten.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Office Pool 1994

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

 BODY:
Welcome to the 20th annual Office Pool. Because this participatory prognostication has answered the unfelt need of millions, this tradition has been imitated in all media.
I have always tried to score lower than my readers, and last year went especially deep into the tank: all but one wrong. (That one, however, forewarned that Clinton would jack up the highest effective tax bracket over 40 percent. Richies could have saved millions acting on this tip.) 
 As experienced pool-players know, the point is in the range of intriguing options offered. My advice: Never play percentage pool; always play your hunch.
1. The highest pitch of tension within the Clinton Administration will be between (a) guru James Carville and the Florida gubernatorial hopeful Janet Reno; (b) Hillary Clinton and Al Gore, laying the basis for Democratic primaries in the year 2000; (c) Strobe Talbott and Bobby Ray Inman over Russia policy; (d) the Clinton adviser Bruce Lindsey and the Criminal Division's chief, Jo Ann Harris.
2. Centerpiece of the health care bill that passes will be (a) mandated employer coverage; (b) universal care; (c) state monopolies as outlined in Hillary's plan; (d) not any one of the foregoing.
3. Senator Bob Packwood will (a) lose in court and oblige the Byrd-Kassebaum juggernaut by resigning; (b) be the first Senator since the Civil War to be expelled; (c) win in court on Fourth and Fifth Amendment grounds, accept Senate censure and publish best-selling diaries.
4. Political upset of the year will be (a) the seven-seat capture of the Senate by the Republicans; (b) low-rated Gov. Pete Wilson of California routs Kathleen Brown; (c) sure-thing Gov. Mario Cuomo edged by unknown Roy Goodman; (d) Chuck Robb survives Doug Wilder primary challenge and beats Oliver North.
5. Talk of the magazine world will be (a) the success of youthful cyberspace-salesmen in selling "Wired"; (b) the stigmatization of young singlehood in Rupert Murdoch's "Married Woman"; (c) editor Angela Harrington's successful launch of Time's youth-oriented "Mouth 2 Mouth."
6. Of nonfiction best sellers, the one stirring the greatest outrage will be (a) "The Betrayed Profession," by Sol Linowitz and Martin Mayer; (b) "The Deep Divide," by Sherrye Henry; (c) "The Man in the Water," by Roger Rosenblatt; (d) "Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Happiness," by Peggy Noonan; (e) "Taking Charge," by Irene Pollin; (f) "Leaving Home," by Art Buchwald.
7. Yeltsin's nemesis will be (a) club-in-the-closet Vladimir Zhirinovsky; (b) rejected confidant Gennadi Burbulis; (c) yes-but reformer Grigory Yavlinsky; (d) slow-to-act Marshal Grachev.
8. In the Middle East (a) the autocrat in Arafat will split the P.L.O.; (b) disillusion with Rabin's concessions will topple Labor; (c) Syria's Assad will make a Golan deal under U.S. pressure and lead to a Palestinian state.
9. Big issue in 1994 Congressional elections will be (a) conservatives' repressive "law 'n' order," renamed by liberals "personal security"; (b) unexpected second-half economic slump revives calls for tax cut; (c) who lost health reform? (d) intervention vs. isolation.
10. Clinton's biggest mistake in '94 will be (a) abdication of defense leadership to Sam Nunn; (b) embrace of Yeltsin to the exclusion of rivals; (c) appeasement of North Korea.
11. First special prosecutor under the new Independent Counsel Act will be assigned to (a) Whitewatergate, the charge of conflict of interest between investor Clintons and the regulatory Clinton; (b) Iraqgate, the Bush abuse of the commodity credit corporation to arm Saddam Hussein, and subsequent obstruction of justice within Justice; (c) Commerce Secretary Ron Brown.
12. Stunning changes will include (a) Mickey Kantor to Secretary of State, Christopher to chief of staff, McLarty to Budget; (b) Mario Cuomo to replace William Rehnquist as Chief Justice; (c) C.I.A. chief James Woolsey to rescue Pentagon from big-spender, don't-call-me-Bobby Inman; (d) Zhou Rongji slips past favorite Jiang Zemin to run China after Deng's death; (e) CBS's Larry Tisch, stripped of N.F.L. ball, tackles Disney.
My own daring dozen: 1-c, 2-d, 3-c, 4-d, 5-c, 6-a, 7-c, 8-a, 9-a, 10-c, 11-b, 12-d. Ya gotta play to crow.

HEADLINE: Why Blame California For Rice Subsidies?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Contrary to "Look at What Rice for Japan Will Cost Us" (letter, Dec. 19) by Prof. Thomas Koelble, California rice grows principally in northern California with a small amount in central California, and none in southern California. No water from the Colorado River is diverted to central or northern California. Furthermore, diversion of Colorado River water, while not used for rice growing, is neither an economic disaster nor environmentally destructive. 
 Yes, there are subsidies to rice growers in California (as well as Louisiana, Texas, Mississippi, Japan, Korea and Thailand, to name a few), but the California growers are not "among the most heavily subsidized agricultural producer groups ever."
The original goal of the United States in the Uruguay Round was to eliminate all agricultural subsidies, at least among Organization for Economic Cooperation Development countries. That failed because major trading partners, including the European Community, would not agree.
While the Uruguay Round did not bring about as much trade liberalization as the United States (and others) originally desired, it is a great step forward.
 
ROGER J. BACCIGALUPPI
Sacramento, Calif., Dec. 21, 1993
 
The writer is vice chairman, California Chamber of Commerce.

HEADLINE: SALES IN NOVEMBER OF EXISTING HOMES HIT A RECORD PACE

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29

 BODY:
Spurred by growing confidence in the economy and a fear that low interest rates may not last, Americans snapped up single-family homes in November at the fastest pace ever recorded, the National Association of Realtors announced today.
Sales of existing homes in November ran at an annual rate of 4.21 million homes. That rate, which is statistically adjusted for seasonal variations, was 2.9 percent higher than in October and 9.1 percent ahead of the November 1992 pace. 
 The previous record, set in November 1978, was an annualized rate of 4.15 million home sales.
This higher-than-expected activity reinforced optimism that the economy would continue to expand at a brisk pace in the new year, a prospect also reflected in a separate set of figures issued today showing a five-tenths of 1 percent rise in the Government's main forecasting index.
 
 
'Interesting Numbers'
 The composite index of leading indicators has now climbed four straight months after managing only one gain in the first seven months of the year. Composed of items that tend to move ahead of the economy at large, like orders for manufactured goods, the Commerce Department index is designed to peer six months or more into the future.
"These are interesting numbers, especially the home sales," Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist for the PNC Bank in Pittsburgh, said. Forget about a possible early 1994 slump from tax increases, weak exports and military cutbacks, he advised, adding, "All's clear on the recession watch."
The strength of the broad, current economy was confirmed by the Commerce Department's index of coincident indicators, which also posted a gain of five-tenths of 1 percent last month -- its fourth consecutive advance.
But since most of the index's components had been previously published, the bulk of the attention today went to the housing report. While sales of existing homes do not have the economic impact of building new ones, they do mean strong sales of items like drapes, paint and appliances, as well as business for lenders, lawyers, real estate agents, appraisers, moving companies and various kinds of insurers. The Government will issue its report Thursday on November sales of new homes.
November marked the seventh sales advance in the latest eight months and the highest since the real estate group began keeping records in 1968.
All regions of the country except the West contributed to the new sales record, which was a result not only of 20-year lows in interest rates but of an improved job market, rising consumer confidence, gains in income and relative stability in the price of houses.
"Month by month, I think the public has gotten more confident," said P. Wesley Foster Jr., president and owner of Long & Foster Realtors, which is based in Fairfax, Va., and is the nation's third-largest real estate concern. "When interest rates bottomed out and started kicking up, people really got busy," Mr. Foster said.
The national average commitment rate for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages was 7.16 percent in November, down from 8.31 percent a year earlier but somewhat above late-summer lows.
Mr. Foster said that after the first quarter, when his company's sales were 10 to 12 percent below those a year earlier, the company had posted quarterly gains of 18 to 25 percent for the rest of the year. He said he expected strong sales to continue.
 
 
Median Price of Homes
 The median price of homes sold last month was $106,800, up $200 from the October level but below the $109,300 in June that was the highest so far this year.
Month to month fluctuations, however, are heavily affected by what kinds of buyers are active and do not necessarily indicate the overall direction of prices. Still, the recent price data tend to confirm a belief that the sales surge is concentrated among first-time buyers moving from apartments.
For his company, Mr. Foster said, first-time home buyers accounted for about 48 percent of recent sales compared with the traditional proportion of about one-third.
By region, the Midwest posted a November sales gain of 7.3 percent, to an annual rate of 1.17 million. It was followed by the Northeast, up 4.9 percent to 640,000, and the South, up 4.1 percent to 1.53 million. The decline in the West was 4.3 percent, to a rate of 880,000, the report showed.
 These numbers include a factor for typical seasonal variations, such as higher sales volume during the summer that reflect favorable weather and a desire by many families to minimize their children's school disruption. But analysts caution that these adjustments can sometimes distort results, particularly those that are then annualized by assuming that a monthly pace continues for a full year.
Nevertheless, the association's criterion that it takes several months to establish a trend has now clearly been met.
Actual sales last month, with no adjustment, were 140,000 in the South, 75,000 in the Midwest, 65,000 in the West and 43,000 in the Northeast.
The Commerce Department's forecasting index was impressive not only in its string of four straight increases but in its sustained breadth. Eight of the 11 components contributed to the November advance, paced by lower first-time claims for unemployment benefits, higher orders for new plants and equipment and a rise in the price of materials especially sensitive to the business cycle.
 
 
Other Gains
 Other elements helping to push up the index were a rise in building permits, higher backlogs for manufactured durable goods, an expanded work week, a higher money supply and manufacturers' new orders for consumer goods and materials.
Negative forces were lower consumer expectations, which were reversed in December; faster deliveries to companies by their suppliers, and stock prices as gauged by the Standard & Poor's 500 index.
The department's companion index of lagging indicators that move only after a turn in the economy eased two-tenths of 1 percent last month, the fourth consecutive month without a rise.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 1, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page chart on Thursday, with an article about a surge in housing sales, mislabeled the 1993 figure for sales of existing single-family homes. It represented the annualized rate of home sales for the month of November, not for the year through November.

HEADLINE: U.S. Sees Progress On Nuclear Talks With North Korea

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30

 BODY:
North Korean diplomats have told the United States that international monitors can have access to their seven officially disclosed nuclear sites, Clinton Administration officials said today.
But the North Koreans have not approached the International Atomic Energy Agency to work out the procedures for the inspections, nor have they offered to allow inspectors to visit two undeclared nuclear waste sites that have been off limits to the agency. As a result, Administration officials say it is too soon to determine if the two sides have achieved a breakthrough in the talks, as the official North Korean news agency asserted today. 
 Still, Washington and Pyongyang have made progress toward opening up the seven sites to inspection, senior Administration officials said today.
"As a result of the most recent talks," the State Department said, the United States has "moved closer" to meeting its objectives.
The issue of North Korea's nuclear program has become the Administration's most perplexing foreign policy problem and has raised fears of renewed conflict on the Korean Peninsula.
The issue has divided specialists. Some State Department officials say they believe that North Korea is prepared to give up its nuclear program in return for economic and political concessions. Analysts from the Central Intelligence Agency tend to view North Korea as a defiant regime that is intent on proceeding with its nuclear program and is just playing for time.
The Administration is working for a diplomatic settlement, but has held out the threat of economic sanctions in case the diplomacy fails. South Korea and Japan strongly support the diplomatic approach, reflecting anxiety about a political, and possible military, confrontation on the Korean Peninsula.
To defuse the North Korean threat, the Administration has adopted a phased approach.
During the first phase, the United States wants the North Koreans to agree to inspections of their seven sites and agree to exchange envoys with South Korea. In return, Washington would suspend the military exercise the United States carries out every spring to practice the reinforcement of South Korea's defenses.
While the North Koreans have indicated that international monitors can have access to the seven sites, Administration officials say the test of Pyongyang's intentions will come if it works out satisfactory arrangements with the International Atomic Energy Agency.
The North Koreans have previously allowed inspectors to visit some of the sites, but have sometimes made it difficult for them to conduct their work.
"Right now, interpreting the North Korean statements is sort of like trying to decide how many angels can dance on the head of a pin," said a State Department official. "The test will be what they do with the I.A.E.A."
Even if the inspections are resumed, they will not resolve some critical questions. The inspections would constrain North Korea from producing more plutonium for nuclear bombs, but they would not resolve the issue of whether North Korea has produced enough plutonium for a nuclear bomb or has already made a nuclear bomb.
The Central Intelligence Agency and most other American intelligence agencies have told the White House that there is a better-than-even chance that North Korea has already developed one or more bombs. But State Department intelligence experts dispute that assessment, as do Chinese diplomats.
The question of whether North Korea has already diverted enough plutonium for a bomb is to be taken up during a second phase of talks, in which the United States would try to persuade the North Koreans to give international monitors access to two nuclear waste sites in return for expanded economic and political ties. The two sites have been off limits to the International Atomic Energy Agency and are not among the seven sites officially disclosed. The waste sites could provide evidence of how much weapons-grade nuclear material the North Koreans have produced.
Talk of a breakthrough was stimulated today by a dispatch from North Korea's official press agency, which quoted a North Korean Foreign Ministry spokesman.
"Through the latest contact, the sides removed a series of stumbling blocks," the spokesman said. He added that the two sides have achieved "a breakthrough for the progress of the talks by displaying the spirit of mutual understanding and cooperation."
Senior Administration officials said the statement might be a sign that North Korea intends to contact the International Atomic Energy Agency in the near future.
A State Department spokesman said he expected further meetings between the two sides aimed at hammering out an agreement. Because the Clinton Administration is maintaining the posture that it is not conducting high-level talks with North Korea, the American delegation in New York is headed by Tom Hubbard, a mid-level State Department official.

HEADLINE: Rita Klimova, 62, Czech Dissident Who Became Ambassador to U.S.

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS

 BODY:
Rita Klimova, a former dissident who served as Czechoslovakia's first Ambassador to the United States after the ouster of the Communist Government, died yesterday in a hospital in Prague. She was 62.
Her death was reported by The Associated Press, which quoted C.T.K., the official news agency of the Czech Republic. She had recently undergone treatment for leukemia. 
 Mrs. Klimova was diagnosed as having the disease shortly after she was named Ambassador to Washington in February 1990. She stepped down from the post in August 1992, less than four months before her country split into two nations, the Czech Republic and Slovakia.
After her retirement from the Czech diplomatic service last year, she lectured on Czech affairs at several universities, including the New School in Manhattan.
 
Schooling in New York
 Mrs. Klimova was born in Europe but spent part of her youth in Manhattan, where her family fled in 1939 after the German invasion of Czechoslovakia. Her father, Batya Bat, was a journalist and writer who used the pen name Stanislav Budin.
She attended grade school and junior high school in New York. In 1946, her family returned to Czechoslovakia, where she attended high school and college.
Mrs. Klimova became a member of the Communist Party in 1948. She worked as a translator and taught political economics at Charles University in Prague.
She was dismissed from her university post after Soviet-led troops of the Warsaw Pact invaded Czechoslovakia in 1968 to crush the liberal reforms of Alexander Dubcek.
She devoted her efforts to defending human rights and the political opposition, and she was expelled from the party in 1970. In 1989 Mrs. Klimova became the spokeswoman for the peaceful revolution that toppled the Communist Government and elevated her fellow dissident, the playwright Vaclav Havel, to the presidency.
 
Voice of the Revolution
 When the Communist regime began to disintegrate in November of 1989, she nearly missed the big moment.
She had been in Hungary meeting with two Czechoslovak exiles, and she drove home on the night of Nov. 19. There she found a message from Mr. Havel saying he wanted to meet with her the next morning.
Arriving at his apartment, she found him facing television cameras and photographers. Mr. Havel had called a news conference to mobilize the anti-Communist opposition, and he wanted to be sure Mrs. Klimova would be there to convey his message in American English.
She sat down next to him and began interpreting. For the next several weeks, as the old order crumbled, hers was the English-language voice of the "Velvet Revolution," an expression that she coined.
She is survived by a son, Vladimir Mlynar, and a daughter, Michaela Barlova, both of Prague.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rita Klimova (The New York Times, 1990)
