HEADLINE: Florida Seeks U.S. Aid For Illegal Immigrants

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 30

 BODY:
Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida has ordered his state to sue the Federal Government to try to reduce the flow of illegal immigrants and recoup the money Florida is forced to spend on social services for them.
"The people of Florida should not be compelled to subsidize the entry of illegal aliens into the United States, nor should they tolerate continued failure of the United States Government to carry out its duty under the law," Mr. Chiles wrote in a letter to the State Attorney General, Bob Butterworth, this week. 
 Mr. Chiles' office estimated that Florida spent at least $739 million in 1992 to provide health care, education, housing and other social services to immigrants and political refugees. In his letter, the Governor said Florida should get full reimbursement for the services and care it gives illegal aliens.
"If the United States Government chooses to selectively enforce the law, it has a corresponding obligation to incur the costs," the Governor wrote.
Mr. Chiles' action is the latest in a heated discussion about the nation's ability to absorb new arrivals from abroad. In August, Gov. Pete Wilson of California, the state that received more immigrants than any other during the 1980's, urged Congress to require identity cards for legal immigrants. He also called for a constitutional amendment to deny citizenship to the children of illegal immigrants.
 
Other States Complain, Too
 Officials in Texas and Illinois have also complained that Washington has not helped them bear the rising cost of social services for immigrants. And both New York and California have in recent years sued the Federal Government as they sought relief from part of that burden. In both instances courts dismissed the complaints.
But Florida's Deputy Attorney General, Pete Antonacci, said today that he thought the new suit stood a better chance of success partly because the factual issues were slightly different and partly because more judges were becoming sympathetic to the difficult position of states. "As the situation worsens, the courts are going to take a realistic approach in dealing with this problem," he said.
As an example, Mr. Antonacci cited the Supreme Court's decision in a challenge to the 1990 Census. He said he found the case comforting because "the underlying theory is that the judiciary should give the executive a wide berth except when entitlement programs are involved or there are consequences to cities and states that are financial and not political."
He noted that the challenge was ultimately rejected but that "there are four votes that are still there" in favor of Florida's position.
Asked if Mr. Chiles intended to pursue the suit all the way to the Supreme Court, Mr. Antonacci replied, "We'll go wherever we need to go to get people to hear us."
Immigration is now at its highest point since the early years of this century. Experts have estimated that more than 1.2 million people a year, mostly Latin Americans and Asians, have entered the United States legally or illegally in recent years.
More than three-quarters of all legal immigrants are concentrated in six states: California, Florida, Illinois, New Jersey, New York and Texas. When illegal immigrants are added in, that proportion rises to about 90 percent, demographers say.
 
Politics in Florida
 Mr. Chiles, a Democrat who was elected in 1990 on a populist platform and said he would run for a second term next year, has in the past been sympathetic to the aspirations of newly arrived immigrants. He is likely to face a stiff Republican challenge in 1994, and the position he has taken in ordering the lawsuit is one that has already proved popular in Florida.
At the same time, Mr. Chiles is trying not to alienate the state's powerful Cuban constituency or other voters of Latin American or Caribbean descent. He sought to draw a distinction in his letter between political refugees who are fleeing oppression and illegal immigrants who are looking for economic opportunities. "There is no intent to cast any aspersion on people seeking freedom in this country," the Governor's communications director, Ron Sachs, said today.
Nevertheless, in his letter, Mr. Chiles complained of the way in which Washington handles political-asylum claims. He was especially critical of the common practice of allowing refugees to stay while their cases are being heard.
Mr. Chiles was not available today to comment about his action. But Mr. Sachs said the Governor had acted after years of frustration with Federal immigration policies. Mr. Chiles was a United States Senator at the time of the Mariel influx from Cuba in 1980.
Mr. Chiles "has exhausted the appropriate diplomatic channels of letters, visits and phone calls" in trying to persuade the Federal Government to reimburse the state for the costs of immigration, Mr. Sachs said.
 
Diplomacy Fails
 Among those efforts was a letter Mr. Chiles and the Governors of New York, Texas, California and Illinois sent to President Clinton in January, calling for the new President to "restore a partnership with the states" in paying for the costs of immigration.
"If the Federal Government wishes to sustain a humanitarian foreign policy which fosters immigration and refugee admissions, then it must allocate the financial resources required to support this population once it has arrived," the five Governors wrote.
Since 1980, Florida absorbed three large, unexpected waves of immigrants that were direct results of American foreign policy, and Mr. Chiles has repeatedly complained that the Federal Government has provided virtually no help. The 125,000 Cubans who came to the state in the Mariel boat lift were followed later in the decade by an estimated 100,000 Nicaraguans in the late 1980's and an equal number of Haitians in recent surges. The Haitians, unlike the Cubans and Nicaraguans, are not classified as political refugees.
People from all three countries are still coming and have tended to cluster around Miami, giving the local economy a burst of energy and investment but adding to demands for social services. One-quarter of the pupils in the Dade County school system were born outside the United States, and the county's largest hospital estimates the cost of treating undocumented immigrants at $300 million over the last three years.
"When do we reach the saturation point?" Florida's coordinator of immigrant and refugee affairs, Nancy Wittenberg, asked in a telephone interview today. "It gets more and more difficult to respond, and transportation and jobs and everything else become a problem. You have to stop somewhere and examine the whole scenario, and that's what we are trying to do."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Joint Venture To Merge Plastics Units

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: MILAN, Italy, Dec. 30

 BODY:
The Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Italy's Montedison S.p.A. said today that they would merge large parts of their plastics businesses, creating a company with annual sales of nearly $3 billion.
The new company, to be equally owned by the parents and based in the Netherlands, will be the world's largest producer of polypropylene, a plastic widely used for car parts, and will have 18 percent of the world market. 
 Montedison, the debt-laden chemicals group controlled by Ferruzzi Finanziaria S.p.A., will contribute about two-thirds of the assets, including Himont Inc. of Wilmington, Del., with sales of about $2 billion. Shell is bringing assets with sales of more than $1 billion.
Montedison will receive no cash from the transaction, but will transfer about $2 billion of its $10 billion debt, thus reducing its financing charges once the agreement is final early next year.
Lorenzo Colucci, an analyst at Natwest Securities Ltd. in London, called the deal a plus for Montedison and a great one for Shell. "They are creating the world's largest polypropylene group, merging with a U.S.-based unit they can easily run and supervise, and are buying a well-known name just when the recession appears to be ending," he said.
Montedison's Himont is the world's largest producer of polypropylene, with 12 percent of the market, while Shell is No. 2 with 6 percent. Polypropylene is a rapidly growing market but is suffering from overcapacity.
 
Merging Polyethylene Units
 The two companies will also merge their polyethylene activities, putting the new venture among the top 10 producers of the plastic. Polyethylene is the most widely used plastic, found in most packaging and toys.
Montedison's sale of Himont to the venture may be the first of several the chemical holding company undertakes as part of a plan to cut its debt, analysts said. Himont was Montedison's largest operating unit and potentially its most profitable, they added.
Analysts also said similar mergers could be made elsewhere in Europe. The British Petroleum Company P.L.C. and Italy's Enichem S.p.A. are seen as possible partners.
Montedison, which is also selling another polypropylene maker, Moplefan S.p.A., to the venture, still controls the energy group Edison S.p.A. and the chemicals group Montecatini.
Montedison reported a 1993 first-half operating profit of $460 million on a 26 percent increase in sales, but because of financing costs it had a $420 million net loss. Shell's chemicals division lost $249 million in the third quarter.
Ferruzzi's total debt at the end of June was about $17 billion, run up in the 1980's during an acquisition spree just before the worldwide recession made debt financing prohibitive.
Shell said the new enterprise would include all of Montedison's and most of Shell's polyethylene and polypropylene activities. Not included are Shell's joint ventures in Japan, Germany and Singapore and the Shell Oil Company's polyolefins activities in the United States. Polyolefins include polypropylene and polyethylene.

HEADLINE: Conservative Thinkers Are Insiders;
It's Now Their City Hall, and Manhattan Institute Is Uneasy

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN

 BODY:
With Rudolph W. Giuliani about to become Mayor, the conservative Manhattan Institute should be riding high. The iconoclastic research group has seen some of its favorite ideas -- selling city hospitals to private groups, cutting local business taxes, curbing the excesses of multicultural education -- adopted as pillars of Mr. Giuliani's campaign.
The group's stalwarts are on first-name terms with the new City Hall team. One trustee, Peter M. Flanigan, managing director at Dillon, Read & Company, had lunch this week with Donna Hanover Giuliani, the Mayor-elect's wife. Ninfa Segarra, the new Deputy Mayor for health, social services and education, has praised its work on giving parents more choice of the public schools their children attend. And Richard J. Schwartz, senior adviser to Mr. Giuliani, calls the institute an "integral part of the movement for a new urban agenda for the 1990's." 
 Yet for all its ties, the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research, as it is formally known, is finding it hard to switch from outside critic to inside participant. No one thinks it is harder than William Hammett, the institute's president since 1980.
"For most New Yorkers, politics is about little more than jobs; what we care about are ideas," Mr. Hammett said in the earnest manner that friends consider his most endearing trait. Surrounded by books and papers by authors he has sponsored, Mr. Hammett was in his office at the institute's headquarters at 52 Vanderbilt Avenue, near Grand Central Station.
"The commitment of New Yorkers to ideas does not, to say the least, run very deep," he said. "What New York is about is amassing money, acquiring influence and power. Whose law firm is up and whose is down. Which developer is in, which is out. That's how this city runs. But when the new people come in, without fresh ideas they'll be dead."
 
Idea Merchants vs. Power Politics
 The clash between idea merchants and power politics is already evident.
Stephen Kagann, an outspoken advocate of lower taxes and a prominent contributor to City Journal, the institute's quarterly magazine, was the Giuliani campaign's research director. Pushed out after the election, Mr. Kagann gave an angry parting blast in a Newsday interview last week. The Mayor-elect's top advisers, he charged, were "all political operatives and former prosecutors" with "no managerial talent."
"I'm not meant to be an insider," Mr. Kagann says. "You'd have to say I've burned my bridges in a most spectacular blaze. I guess I'm just more comfortable playing the role of critic."
Others at the institute already express disappointment with several Giuliani appointments. They complain that the new Mayor is much too sanguine about the pain required to tame the fiscal crisis. And like Mr. Kagann, they doubt Mr. Giuliani's team has the skill or fortitude to carry out a far-reaching overhaul of city government.
The nonprofit Manhattan Institute, with a budget of $5 million and a staff of about 30 people, would seem wildly out of place in liberal New York. Its attacks on what it calls the welfare state, which New York City embodies in so many ways, branded the institute as an outpost of the anti-urban Reaganism that swept Washington in the 1980's. The institute's founding in 1978 by William Casey, Mr. Reagan's C.I.A. director, didn't help.
Indeed, the institute emerged from obscurity by sponsoring two books that helped define the conservative counter-revolution: George Gilder's "Wealth and Poverty," a 1980 paean to tax cuts and freewheeling capitalism, and Charles Murray's "Losing Ground," a tough-minded 1984 attack on social welfare programs (both published by Basic Books).
In recent years, however, the Manhattan Institute has turned its attention closer to home. Its three-year-old City Journal, now edited by Peter Salins, has built a following in government, academia, the media and business with its detailed analyses of the failures of local government.
 
Ringmaster and Fund-Raiser
 Mr. Hammett, once an investment banker, serves as the institute's ringmaster and fund-raiser. Among its luminaries are Dr. Salins, an urban affairs professor at Hunter College who advocates an end to rent control; Seymour Fliegel, once a deputy school superintendent in Manhattan's District Four and author of "Miracle in East Harlem: The Fight for Choice in Public Education" (Times Books, 1993), and Linda Chavez, who headed the United States Civil Rights Commission and now runs the institute's Center for the New American Community, based in Washington.
Driving the institute's thinking is the conviction that New York's government can no longer ignore the economic changes that have transformed the globe. "In this world economy, you can't hide anymore," Mr. Hammett said. "Even socialist governments are changing -- but New York is still trying to be the last centrally planned political system."
That belief is common among conservatives. What distinguishes the Manhattan Institute is its work to translate its ideology into concrete proposals that appeal to a wide spectrum of political beliefs.
"They've become a kind of Alcoholics Anonymous for many liberals," said Sol Stern, executive director of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's Commission on Juvenile Justice Reform. "We can go there and confess that we, too, think something is fundamentally wrong with the way the city works."
Institute ideas once considered heretical, like cracking down on homeless drug addicts who gather in public places, are now urged even by such liberals as Pete Hamill, the writer.
 
Less Theory, More Garbage
 "I respect them as responsible conservatives," said Andrew Hacker, a professor at Queens College who wrote a scathing indictment of racism in American society, "Two Nations: Black & White, Separate, Hostile, Unequal" (Scribner's, 1992). "I'd rate them well above the American Enterprise Institute, the Heritage Foundation and others of that ilk in Washington. They are not concerned so much with grand theory as with the best way of collecting garbage."
To be sure, the Manhattan Institute is not lacking in critics.
Peter Marcuse, a professor of urban planning at Columbia University, said he "welcomes their focus on urban issues, but most of their remedies are wrongheaded."
"The consensus among professionals in the field is that the prosperity of the city cannot be left simply to private initiative," Dr. Marcuse said.
They have also been accused of extraordinary narrowness. Last year the institute co-sponsored a forum on "Rethinking New York" at which all 12 speakers were white men. "Never even thought of it, to tell you the truth," Mr. Hammett said.
 
Not the Most Sensitive Soul
 Ms. Chavez, an advocate of assimilation for Hispanic people and other minorities, strongly defends Mr. Hammett, though she says he may not be the most sensitive soul. "All institutions have their own networks, but it's not just white males," she said. "I'm not interested in being a token anything, and at the Manhattan Institute, I don't think I am."
The move from a libertarian emphasis on individual freedom to a focus on the nuts and bolts of local issues has cost the institute some early supporters, like the Adolph Coors Foundation. "We don't have far-right funding," Mr. Hammett said. "They hate New York and would be just as happy to see it go to hell."
Still, it has such conservative backers as the Sarah Scaife, Smith Richardson and John M. Olin Foundations. It is also aided by the more liberal J. M. Kaplan Fund and the Commonwealth Fund. Corporate sponsors include Chase Manhattan Bank, State Farm Insurance and Citicorp.
In the late 1980's, nearly all the local seers expected New York to weather the nation's economic slump better than most places. Manhattan Institute experts were among the few who rightly predicted the worst.
"We were almost the only people who took the decline of the city seriously," said Fred Siegel, a Cooper Union professor who recently stepped down as editor of City Journal. "That gave added force to our argument that there was something profoundly dysfunctional about the political culture of New York."
Mitchell Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University and an unpaid adviser to Mayor David N. Dinkins, praises the institute for taking on such neglected issues as fostering small business, overhauling urban transport and having city services done privately.
"The Manhattan Institute has superseded the traditional foundations based in New York -- the 20th Century Fund, the Ford Foundation, Rockefeller, Carnegie -- as a source of new ideas for the city," he said. "The others have gone off into another world."
But Dr. Moss also sees a hard road ahead: How does the institute, which "thrived as a critic of the liberal welfare state," stay vital "now that it has friends in high office?"
 
The Leverage of Ideas
 Mr. Hammett replies that the institute will stick to what it does best. "The real leverage is on the side of ideas," he said. "The best way to insure that the 'outs' keep them in mind once they're 'in' is to keep the ideas flowing."
Ms. Chavez said the group's thinkers probably should avoid political office. "Success for us doesn't necessarily mean you take the people who generate the ideas and put them in public positions," she said.
Despite its focus on New York, the Manhattan Institute has had its greatest influence in other cities. Mayors in Philadelphia, Indianapolis, Jersey City and Phoenix have praised it and adopted some of its advice.
If the institute is no longer the intellectual bomb thrower it once was, it hopes at least to throw off enough new sparks to catch the practical politicians' attention. The obstacles remain immense.
"There is not going to be any quantum leap under Giuliani because everybody realizes how hard it is to get anything done in New York," said an institute senior fellow, Edward N. Costikyan, a seasoned Democrat and a senior partner at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, who served on the Giuliani transition council. "It is very easy to write an article saying what should be done. But nobody has written the article on how you do it."

HEADLINE: New Home Sales Jump By 11.3%

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Sales of newly built single-family homes shot up 11.3 percent in November to their highest level since 1986, the Commerce Department reported yesterday -- providing new evidence that families are hurrying to move out of rented apartments and into their own homes before they are priced out of the housing market again.
"People are starting to believe that the declines in home prices that had plagued the market for months have stopped and prices might move up again, along with mortgage rates, so they are taking advantage of this window of opportunity," said Richard T. Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's Consumer Research Center. 
 At an annual rate, buyers signed contracts to purchase 807,000 single-family dwellings -- some of them already completed and some still being built or not yet even started. That represented a rise of 11.3 percent from the October level of 725,000 dwellings. The report was the second in two days to underscore a boom in home sales that first surfaced in late summer.
 
 
Most Gains in the West
 Most of the November increase in new-home sales came in the West, including California, where the economy has been especially weak. The strong Western showing might reflect a reviving California housing market, or might be a fluke, economists said. Sales in the Northeast fell in November from October's level.
President Clinton hailed the boom in home sales as evidence that "the American people are taking control of their economic destiny," according to a spokesman, Jeff Elder. Mr. Elder quoted the president as having said, "This shows the result of low interest rates, low inflation, bringing the deficit down and increasing investment. People are getting more optimistic about the future."
With Government spending cut way back to reduce the budget deficit, the Clinton Administration has relied on low interest rates to stimulate the economy. The policy has paid off in rising car sales, the booming market in single-family homes and rising appliance sales -- all items usually purchased on credit. Largely as a result, the American economy has grown much more strongly in the fourth quarter than in the first nine month's of 1993.
Reflecting this strength, initial weekly unemployment claims fell by 39,000, to 291,000 last week, the lowest level since February 1989, the Labor Department reported yesterday.
The housing boom has also pushed up sales of previously owned homes. They reached a record annual rate of 4.2 million units in November, the National Association of Realtors reported on Wednesday. As for new-home sales, they were higher in November than at any time since March 1986, when sales reached 880,000 at an annual rate.
The Commerce Department yesterday also revised upward the October figure in yesterday's announcement, increasing that month's sales to 725,000 from a previously reported 679,000, at a seasonally-adjusted annual rate.
 
'They Rushed In'
 Such figures in recent months have convinced many economists that the boom is a result of an unusual, and perhaps fleeting, set of circumstances, one that cannot be explained only by low mortgage rates. Many families had postponed home purchases, waiting not only for mortgage rates to fall below 7.5 or even 7 percent, but for home prices to stop the fall that began in 1987, after the stock market crash. This summer both goals were reached, and the boom developed in both sales and construction of single-family homes.
 "My hypothesis is that people held off in the spring and summer, waiting for mortgage rates and home prices to hit bottom, and once they saw the bottom, they rushed in to buy," said Lyle Gramley, chief economist of the Mortgage Bankers Association, offering a widely held view. "I would caution that while we may be able to hold the current sales levels, we may not see substantial additional increases in 1994."
The median price of new homes sold in November rose to $130,000 from $129,400 in October and $126,000 in August. Mortgage rates, in turn, have risen to 7.2 percent for 30-year, fixed rate mortgages, from 6.6 percent in the summer.
The sharp rise in new-home sales last month reflects a Commerce Department calculation that home sales are normally strong in the spring and summer and weak in the fall, particularly November. To allow for this weakness in determining the annual rate, the actual number of home sales is adjusted upward. The actual sales figure in November was 56,000 units, roughly equal to the 57,000 units sold in October and also in September, the Commerce Department said.

HEADLINE: Stocks Slip in Thin Trading; Dow Off 18.45

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Pressured by a weak bond market and profit taking after setting new records in previous sessions, the stock market declined yesterday on light trading volume.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 3,775.88, down 18.45 points, and the Standard & Poor's 500 index closed at 468.64, down 1.94. But the Nasdaq composite index of secondary stocks rose 2.60 points, to 771.08. 
 "The stock market did well," considering the moves in interest rates, said Hugh A. Johnson, senior vice president of the First Albany Corporation. "A little bit closer look at the market indicates that it wasn't as bad as the decline in the Dow suggests."
 
Bond Yields Up
 Long-term interest rates rose sharply on thin trading in bonds, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond increasing to 6.34 percent from 6.24 percent Wednesday.
Bond prices fell after two Government reports suggested that the economy might be stronger than expected. One report showed the number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits last week fell to nearly a five-year low. Another report showed new single-family home sales rising 11.3 percent in November, to the highest level since April 1986.
The number of declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange narrowly exceeded advances, 1,093 to 991. Volume was 193.7 million shares, well below the 269.6 million traded on Wednesday.
"The one message that comes out of the market this week is that it is clearly struggling," Mr. Johnson said. "It's been two steps forward and 1.9 steps backward."
With gold prices higher, many gold stocks advanced yesterday. Battle Mountain was up 1/8, to 10 3/8; Homestake Mining was up 1/8, to 22, and Newmont Gold was up 1/8, to 46 3/4.
Some closed-end country funds moved higher, as investors continued to give attention to companies in emerging countries. The Chile Fund gained 5/8, to 44 1/2, and the Korea Fund increased 7/8, to 23 1/2.
 
A Gain for MCI
 MCI Communications rose 1 1/2, to 27, after reports that it would announce plans to reduce the amount it pays local telephone companies to complete long-distance calls. Arrow International, a medical supplies company, was up 1 1/2, to 22 1/2; it said its fiscal first-quarter profit topped analysts' forecasts.
Among other gainers, Sci-Med Life Systems jumped 2, to 39 1/2, after its rating was raised by Dain Bosworth. And USF&G climbed 1 1/4, to 15 1/8, apparently in reaction to being named one of the top stock selections by Kidder Peabody.
Utility stocks fell, reflecting concern over higher interest rates. The Dow Jones utilities average eased 0.72 point, to 230.36.
In addition, IMC Fertilizer, whose rating was lowered by J. P. Morgan, dropped 1 5/8, to 44 5/8. Supermac Technology, which will take a fourth-quarter write-off for job reductions and a plant closing, declined 1 3/4, to 10 1/4.
And Lady Luck Gaming, which was served a complaint on Wednesday by Mississippi gaming officials accusing it of moving and operating casino equipment without authorization, fell 1 1/4, to 9 1/2.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Drop Sharply

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Reports of more strong economic trends on a day of very slow trading combined to push prices of Treasury securities down sharply yesterday, sending interest rates higher.
The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond dropped 19/32 , to 9826/32 , or about $12.81 for each $1,000 of face value, while the yield jumped to 6.34 percent, from 6.24 percent Wednesday. 
 Charles E. Roden, managing director and head of fixed income at Josepthal, Lyon & Ross, said the market appeared to be awakening to the fact that business is getting better.
"Interest rates do not just go up because of inflation fears," he said. "They also go up as the demand for money increases. As business continues to get better banks will start lending money."
With the economy getting stronger, investors who had been buying longer maturities to get higher yields are now repositioning, buying shorter maturities and selling some long-term issues. But the slowness of the market yesterday, with many traders preparing for the New Year holiday, meant that a sizable sell order could move the market.
Initially, it was the unexpected plunge in weekly jobless claims that helped to weaken Treasuries. The number of people filing for jobless benefits declined by 39,000, to 291,000, last week. But analysts attributed the decline to the holiday-shortned week, leaving one less day for applications.
 
Surge in November Home Sales
 A short time later, the Commerce Department reported that new home sales surged in November, which brought a further slump in Treasury prices. As a result, sellers took control of yesterday's thinly traded market.
The 11.3 percent gain in November new home sales was much stronger than expected. But MMS analysts said the breakdown of the data suggested that the gains were uneven. Much of the increase was in the West, where sales are 34 percent higher. Gains in the South and Midwest were slight, while the Northeast had a decline. Some traders also said that the strong housing sector had already been discounted in credit market prices.
Also released yesterday was the Chicago Purchasing Managers' index, which was close to expectations, backing off slightly to 62.6 percent in December after November's strong 65.3 percent.
With no data for release today, and with half-day sessions scheduled for both the futures and cash markets, the market is expected to close 1993 on a quiet note.
With most of the November economic numbers known, the main worry will be whether the strength of the fourth quarter will spill over into the first quarter of next year, some analysts said.
The December employment report is scheduled for release on Tuesday, with inflation data due out later in the month, which should begin to provide indications of the economy's end-of-the-year direction.
The Treasury announced yesterday that it plans to sell $16 billion in 52-week bills next Thursday, unchanged from its previous auction requirement.
Short-term Treasury securities were mixed, with the three-month bill rate off 1 basis point to 2.98 percent and a six-month rate up 2 basis points to 3.20 percent. The outstanding one-year bill was up 1 basis point to 3.44 percent. A basis point is one hundredth of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: Gratitude for Deliverance With Gifts to the Neediest

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
In late 1939, Ernest and Auguste Mohr received the most important letter of their lives.
In the envelope sent to their home in Bavaria was an affidavit of support signed by Julius Ochs Adler, a vice president and general manager of The New York Times and a friend of the Mohrs' distant relatives in the United States. 
 The piece of paper literally saved the couple's lives, helping them get a coveted visa to flee Hitler's Germany even as Mr. Mohr was being held in a concentration camp.
"At that time, people could leave only if they had someone here to testify that they had family in the United States," Mrs. Mohr, who lives in Kew Gardens, Queens, said recently. "Mr. Adler said that if need be, he would take care of us. Without him, we would have never gotten out."
 
Continuing a Tradition
 Now, 54 years later, Mrs. Mohr is continuing a tradition that her late husband began several years ago, to honor Mr. Adler and to commemorate his act of kindness by contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which is conducting its 82d annual appeal for donations.
Mrs. Mohr's gift of $50 is one of many that have been sent this year in memory of loved ones who died in the Holocaust or as a small token of gratitude from people who escaped or survived its atrocities.
As in the past, The Times pays the administrative costs of the campaign so that all contributions are sent directly to seven social-service agencies to help the city's homeless, hungry and disabled.
The agencies face growing responsibilities. In addition to people with illness, addiction or family problems, the charities also have to help scores of people who are facing unemployment and homelessness for the first time because of the weak economy.
 
For Each Year in U.S.
 Eric W. Zielenziger of Great Neck, L.I., and his wife, Ruth, recently sent in a check for $47. "I am a Holocaust survivor," Mr. Zielenziger wrote. "I have been in the U.S. for 47 years and they have all been good years! One dollar for each year!"
Other donors, like Hannah Herz and her brother Werner, sent in a contribution to carry on a tradition their parents, Alfred and Hedwig, began decades ago to celebrate their family's escape from the Nazis.
The Herz family arrived in the United States on Dec. 20, 1937. "As soon as they could afford it," Mr. and Miss Herz wrote, "our parents celebrated the anniversary of this date with a donation to the fund, in gratitude for the safety and good life we found here."
With the opening of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington this year and the release of "Schindler's List," a film by Steven Spielberg about the Holocaust, many people with no direct connection to the events during World War II have been moved to action.
Marcia Robinson of Manhattan contributed $50 to the fund, as she has done for the last two years. But her reason this time was different.
"This year, because of the recent release of the movie "Schindler's List," I have decided to make my contribution in memory of the Simon family (although I cannot tell you the correct Polish name and spelling of it) who perished in the Holocaust," Ms. Robinson wrote.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on Good News For the American Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar moved higher on world currency markets yesterday, bolstered by better-than-expected data on the American economy.
Gold prices, meanwhile, rose sharply in Europe on speculative buying but ended only marginally higher in the United States. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery settled at $391.90 an ounce, up 10 cents. 
 Two favorable Government reports supported the dollar in light, holiday-week trading. The Commerce Department said sales of new homes shot up 11.3 percent in November to the highest rate in more than seven years, while the Labor Department reported that the number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits plunged 39,000 last week to the lowest level in nearly five years.
 
 
Office Closings Cited
 Analysts cautioned that some of the drop might be attributed to the closing of Government offices the day before Christmas, which left fewer days to file claims.
Still, the reports were enough to send the dollar through resistance levels against the German mark and the Japanese yen in active dealings. Though the dollar settled below these highs, it was still up on the day.
In New York, the dollar stood at 1.7353 marks, up from 1.7274 marks on Wednesday. It also ended at 111.81 yen, up from 111.80 yen.
The economic reports "just convinced people that maybe they shouldn't be so worried about the U.S. economy slumping over in the first quarter" of the new year, Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group, said.
Even though investors want to see more data for December, "good numbers keep rolling in better than expected," Mr. Donney said, and that's convincing people that the recovery is sustainable.
A strengthening economy would give the Federal Reserve greater latitude to raise interest rates. Higher interest rates help to bolster the dollar because they increase the yield on dollar-denominated securities.
A certain bullishness about the dollar is building. "A lot of funds are trying to position themselves for an anticipated rally in the dollar in the first quarter," said Michael Malpede, an analyst with Refco Group Ltd. in Chicago, and that means buying dollars.

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Bruce Weber

 BODY:

Noble Efforts
Everyone knows it has been a tough few months in the commercial theater, particularly on Broadway. "Wonderful Tennessee," "The Kentucky Cycle" and "The Red Shoes," among too many others, closed prematurely, and the specter of a nearly unmitigated flood of musical revivals looms. The Broadway Alliance, the consortium of producers, craft unions and theater owners dedicated to bringing in low-cost dramas, teetered on the brink of extinction after two productions -- "Mixed Emotions" and "Any Given Day" -- foundered, and a third, Sam Shepard's "Simpatico," was abandoned. 
 But there are plaudits to be awarded as well, and not just to Tony Kushner's "Angels in America: Perestroika," which has already gathered plenty, or "My Fair Lady," which, by box office standards at least, is the surprise hit of the season.
Before the year is history and their efforts with it, let's acknowledge these people:
*David G. Richenthal, the novice producer of "The Kentucky Cycle," who, in a mammoth effort against all odds and much advice, did the deed; he brought in a worthy show that New Yorkers had never had a chance to see, and kept it running probably longer than was good for him.
*Margaret Illmann, the Canadian ballerina who starred in "The Red Shoes"; Lar Lubovitch, the show's choreographer, and Heidi Landesman, the designer, whose set is now sitting in a dump in Torrington, Conn. All their work would surely have been remembered with Tony nominations had the show run long enough to qualify for them.
*Roger Berlind, the producer of "Paper Moon," whose decision to postpone the $4.5 million show indefinitely after its out-of-town tryout was a prodigious act of bullet-biting. He returned all the money to his investors, and in the process avoided a public disaster on Broadway.
*Jonathan Tolins, the 27-year-old playwright whose play "Twilight of the Golds," about a young couple who learn their unborn child will be homosexual, never found an audience in New York. Mr. Tolins is a promising young writer with a provocative subject; even those who didn't like the play, and there were many, would agree that in better days, there would be a place for it on Broadway. Indeed, if contemporary audiences have such a short memory that they turned their back on the proven playwrights Brian Friel and Frank Gilroy this fall, it's an equally sorry signal that they didn't give the kid a break.
 
<SC0>Sweet Successes
 Things were generally better elsewhere. The commercial Off Broadway houses have just about finished a cycle, as two successful holdovers from last season, "Jeffrey" and "Oleanna," are about to close: so is "Later Life," which transferred from a nonprofit venue, Playwrights Horizons, where it opened last spring; and so, more sadly, is "Forbidden Broadway," which, after threatening to close earlier in the month, will now do so for sure on Sunday, ending an 11-year tradition.
Here are some other end-of-the-year nods:
*Claudia Shear, whose one-woman show, "Blown Sideways Through Life," an acerbic tour of the author's unemployment history, had enough of an impact that in October Ms. Shear was chosen by ABC News -- national! -- as "Person of the Week." Having begun life at the New York Theater Workshop, the show now gets a commercial run, opening at the Cherry Lane Theater on Jan. 7.
*Andre Bishop and Bernard Gersten, respectively the artistic director and executive producer of Lincoln Center Theater, whose productions this fall illustrate a coherent and well-realized game plan. "The Lights," Howard Korder's nightmare vision of New York, initiated a Festival of New American Plays; the revival of Robert Sherwood's "Abe Lincoln in Illinois" began a series of resurrections of works from a forgotten period of American playwriting. With Spalding Gray's monologue, "Gray's Anatomy," and the upcoming revival of "Carousel," they describe a satisfying panorama of American theater works.
*Lynn Meadow and Barry Grove, respectively the artistic director and managing director of the Manhattan Theater Club. Their offbeat productions, John Patrick Shanley's "Four Dogs and a Bone" and "The Loman Family Picnic" by Donald Margulies, shared a funny, acid spirit. And they were both successful at the box office, too.
 
A Legal Matter
 After failing to resolve among themselves issues involving pay-per-view television, the producers of the upcoming revival of "Damn Yankees" and Actors Equity, the performers union, took the dispute to arbitration. The main question was about participation in the pay-per-view performance as a condition of an actor's employment.
On Wednesday, the arbitrator, Walter Gellhorn, a Columbia University law professor, ruled in favor of the producers, Workin' Man Films and Polygram Diversified Entertainment, meaning that in order to appear in the Broadway production of the show, which opens at the Marquis Theater on March 3, an actor must agree to appear in a pay-per-view performance as well, should the producers decide to have one.
 
Happy New Year, She Said
 The year's last word comes from Lynn Redgrave, whose one-woman show, "Shakespeare for My Father," a personal tribute to both men in the title, was one of the year's surprises. Produced by her husband, John Clark, it opened at the Helen Hayes Theater in April with plans for a modest six-week engagement; when it closes on Sunday it will have played 272 performances.
"It's been an extraordinary year," Ms. Redgrave said, about her own experiences and those of her theatrical neighbors. "We've seen how hard it's been for everybody, if we needed any more reminding of how lucky we've been with this one."
Given that the show is such a Redgrave family event, it's surprising that neither Ms. Redgrave's mother nor her sister saw it until November.
"There was some reticence early on," she said. "I wondered how they would find it. They saw things in it they didn't know, and as it turned out, hadn't thought of." Knowing they were in the audience, Ms. Redgrave said, "was very nerve-wracking for the first five minutes; then I heard my sister laugh, and I settled down."
Asked if she had any parting words, Ms. Redgrave was gracious and grateful.
"I thank the gods of theater," she said. "There is something about Broadway. As actors we like to be noble and say it doesn't matter where you play, audiences everywhere need entertaining. But Broadway is the pinnacle. We all know it. English actors know it. Why do you think we come here?
"It is so tough and so exciting, and you can fail miserably or fail nobly. Or you can sometimes have your wildest dreams come true."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Magnuson's New Role: Ann Magnuson, probably best known as the self-involved magazine editor on television's "Anything but Love," is to take over the role of Collette, the self-involved aging ingenue in John Patrick Shanley's play "Four Dogs and a Bone," now at the Lucille Lortel Theater. She replaces Polly Draper (best known as the self-involved single woman on "Thirtysomething") beginning Jan. 25.

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
Sacred Pieces From Sardinia

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER

 BODY:
AS of February, the I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art will present shows from its permanent collection, and will no longer offer the loan exhibitions that have made it a vital presence in New York City during the last decade. With such scholarly shows as "Corot to Monet: The Rise of Landscape Painting in France," the splendid Tibetan showcase "Wisdom and Compassion" and highlights from several of America's treasurable smaller museums to its credit, the gallery's track record has been honorable, and sometimes a good deal more than that.
It ends, happily, in a literal blaze of glory with the filigreed, gilded altarpieces that constitute "Sardinia: Sacred Art of the 15th and 16th Centuries," organized by the Italian Ministry of Cultural and Environmental Assets and the State Archives of Cagliari, among others. No doubt the light, reflective gold paint that covers these objects lends them a mysterious, numinous glow in dark churches and monastic interiors. But at least as mysterious for the visitor is the distinctive but hard-to-define collective flavor they project, a flavor that has much to do with the rocky Mediterranean island from which they came and where they still reside today. 
 It is especially difficult to define since the art seems at a glance to be so little of a piece. The first 15th-century painting one sees in the show is a triptych of three saints who have the smooth, imperturbable demeanors associated with the early Florentine Renaissance. The second is an altarpiece or retable by the Catalan-born artist Joan Barcelo in which the crisp folds of the Virgin's robes bring Flemish painting instantly to mind. And the third, a rosy panel with the stiff figure of St. Martin dressed in red and gold damask-patterned trousers, points unmistakably to the art of northern Spain.
One of the show's most impressive works, the huge "Retable of St. Peter" (1500) by the so-called Castelsardo Master, brings stylistic and other influences together in a single work. This offers a uniquely Spanish iconography, Flemish-style landscapes and adaptations of the signature motifs of such diverse Italian painters as Perugino and Piero della Francesca. The result, spread over two dozen panels large and small, exemplifies the nervous, pungent, festive, slightly-beyond-the-fringe style that characterizes so much of Sardinia's art of these centuries.
It is a style that has everything to do with being created on an island. Sardinia was at the center of things geographically, without being central culturally. Lying in the Mediterranean between the great powers of Italy and Spain, it remained, as it does today, a marginal outpost with a subsistence economy based on farming and herding. It was aligned with Italy until 1323, then annexed by Spain, which kept it for 200 years as a maritime trading port, one that attracted not only Spanish and Italian visitors, but others from France and Germany, the Middle East, Africa and Asia.
No doubt all of these countries left their cultural traces, though Sardinia was unlikely to have been visited by any of the front-rank artists who kept the major European urban centers supplied with religious and political icons. Rather it was their students or students of students who came and took on pupils of their own in Cagliari, the Sardinian capital. The big-name art that arrived on the island often took the form of engravings (in the case of, say, Albrecht Durer) or drawings (in the case of Raphael) much in the way that contemporary Western art may be known to non-Western audiences through magazine reproductions.
The Italianate strain reached a high point in the work of the Sardinian-born Pietro Cavaro, whose plush figures are among the most imposing in the show. But even his Classical late-Renaissance mode takes unexpected, quirky twists. The expressive face of the single Raphaelesque figure in his "Madonna of the Seven Sorrows" is lifted from Durer. The sky behind the Madonna's head is finicky gold punchwork, not a realistic blue. And the seven long orange lines that converge on her breast are examples of just the sort of dogmatic literalism that mainstream Renaissance painting had worked so hard to eliminate.
What one finds here, in fact, is a lesson in the way art travels outward from a culture's center to its edges and is transformed into something different, surprising, often daring. Like much Sardinian work, Cavaro's painting is a stylistic hybrid, shaped by local patronage, skills and devotional practices. Often regional legends are folded into imported formulas and images of princely magnificence are leavened with hints of everyday life. The image of the kneeling donor about to be knifed by an assassin in "The Retable of Milis" (1503) probably records a hot local news story now long forgotten, and a small panel from the St. Eligius altarpiece showing a chapel hung with flesh-colored wooden body parts refers to a type of popular worship as close to paganism as to Roman Catholicism.
Yet none of these factors fully accounts for the fantastical, slightly hallucinatory quality that makes the work in "Sardinia: Sacred Art of the 15th and 16th Centuries" so compelling. The explanation may well come back once more to the fact of its island origins, with its insularity less a sociopolitical fact than a state of mind. Like the species on Darwin's remote Galapagos, a culture like that of Sardinia -- or Ireland or Malta or Sri Lanka -- resembles those elsewhere but is different. It develops a kind of psychological isolation, in a community whose physical border is absolute and which has, no matter how often intruded upon, its own legends and myths, enthusiasms and prejudices, all of which shape its art. The resulting pervasive tang of exoticism and intensity eludes scientific description, but it has everything to do with the character of this beautiful, atmospheric show.
"Sardinia: Sacred Art of the 15th and 16th Centuries" remains at the I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art, 590 Madison Avenue, at 56th Street, through Jan. 29.

HEADLINE: Fund the Arts Broadly

 BODY:
John Dyson, Rudolph Giuliani's deputy mayor for economic development, said this week that the new administration wanted to give more support to New York's prominent cultural institutions, perhaps by cutting the budgets of less established arts groups. The more popular institutions draw tourists and therefore help the city's economy, he explained, while lesser-known groups do not, and some may be getting political handouts to boot. Though he was not sure of that.
Mr. Dyson's acknowledgment of the economic importance of the arts is most welcome. But his view is narrow. Since when does a government interested in all its citizens play reverse Robin Hood, robbing from the poor to give to the rich (or, given the weak economy, the less poor)? 
 The larger cultural institutions are indeed crucial to the city's economy. As a recent study by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey confirmed, they draw tourists, create jobs and add to the tax revenues. Last year, the study found, the arts and other cultural activities in the metropolitan area generated $9.8 billion, and nearly a quarter of that money came from tourists who said they had come to New York -- or lengthened their stays in the city -- for the museums, galleries, theaters and concerts.
Economic considerations are crucial, especially now. But New York City's cultural life represents a great deal more than money. It is part of the city's fabric, part of what sets it apart from other cities.
The smaller institutions, from the Studio Museum of Harlem to Snug Harbor on Staten Island, are important to their neighborhoods, to the people who visit them or work in them or just regard them as a vital part of their communities.
Moreover, even from a strictly economic standpoint, those less prominent institutions play a positive role. They may not lure visitors from Europe or elsewhere. But New York is not just a mecca for tourism. It also attracts young artists who come to study, learn and practice, and their presence contributes to the city's economy as well as to its vibrancy.
By looking at cultural institutions strictly through a fiscal prism, Mr. Dyson risks hurting the very city he wants to help. No doubt some arts institutions get political pork. If he is as serious as he sounds about de-politicizing arts funding, Mr. Dyson should authorize a review of the city's policy, and root out the political abuse.
He is likely to find, however, that most small groups are legitimate institutions that promote the arts and boost their neighborhoods. Those less prominent groups -- 400 of them -- shared 15 percent ($13.1 million) of the $87.3 million in city funding that went to the arts this year, while 85 percent went to the 31 major institutions on city property.
The city devotes less of its budget to the arts now than in recent years. Maybe Mr. Dyson will find a way to reverse that, without adding to an anticipated budget gap of $2.2 billion. If he does, New Yorkers can only hope that he treats all arts institutions fairly, and does not help the established ones at the expense of the less prominent.

HEADLINE: Events in Russia Send Shivers East and West;
Not I.M.F.'s Fault

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Vice President Al Gore chose the wrong target in blaming the International Monetary Fund for difficulties in Russia. The I.M.F. has no power to direct its financing to provide the social safety net Russia needs. 
 The risk now is that time will be lost by putting I.M.F. stabilization on the back burner, while a doomed attempt is made to revive the economy sector by sector. President Boris N. Yeltsin, like any other politician, may want to grasp at that straw. But the election returns suggest that Russia needs more, not less, progress against inflation -- as the I.M.F. has insisted. All the I.M.F.'s experience shows that progress toward a free market requires a more stable economy, which will attract foreign capital while building the confidence of Russians in their own future.
The Clinton Administration should not blame, but encourage the I.M.F. and support its role by supplying American leadership for adequate direct aid to alleviate suffering. There may still be time for reform with democracy to succeed. But time is running out.
 
CHARLES S. GARDNER
Eagles Mere, Pa., Dec. 22, 1993
 
The writer is a retired International
Monetary Fund staff member.
